The bill also provides $71 million to replace air traffic control facilities at Chicago's O'Hare and Midway airports and at Helena, Mont., Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Montgomery, Ala.; Newark, N.J.; San Diego, Calif., and St. Louis. The radar funds are for Columbus, Ohio; Chicago's Midway; Indianapolis; Milwaukee; San Juan, Puerto Rico; Oklahoma City and Wichita, Kan. The rail money, $736.5 million, is $667 million higher than what the administration requested and $30 million over this year's level. It includes $482 million in subsidies for Amtrak and $12 million to study the prospects of developing a magnetic levitation system, which would use magnets to lift and propel trains. The $3.2 billion set for mass transit is more than $900 million above the administration's request and $156 million over this year's level. Among the projects are $440 million in new rail systems, including $150 million for construction in Los Angeles, $66 million for St. Louis, $45 million for San Francisco, $30 million for metro transit in Houston, $20 million for light-rail development in Dallas, $22 million for a skyway project in Jacksonville, Fla., and $10 million for engineering and design of a light-rail system in Honolulu. An existing project, the Washington, D.C., subway system, would get $108 million.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Received AIDS-Tainted Blood Dies
DOC.TEXT: A man who mistakenly received the AIDS-tainted blood of a patient with the same last name has died, apparently of non-AIDS-related causes. The patient, whose name and age weren't disclosed, died Thursday, the Veterans Administration Medical Center said. The man was elderly and was already seriously ill before receiving the erroneous injection June 26, the hospital said. The man died long before the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome normally would disable a body's immune system. That can take years. ``It is the opinion of the patient's physicians that his death was not AIDS-related,'' hospital spokesman Ron Lopez said. An autopsy was planned. Dr. Darwin Palmer, chief of infectious diseases at the hospital, has said the patient inadvertently received the AIDS-infected blood when he and an AIDS patient underwent the same blood scan within 24 hours of each other. Both men had the same last name and were in the same ward.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Prepare to Trade Tax Boost Plans
DOC.NOTE: EDS: GOP, Democratic negotiators meet separately in morning EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Budget negotiators from the White House and Congress expect to begin trading offers by early next week on about $25 billion in tax boosts for next year. Bargainers from both political parties, asking to remain anonymous, said Republicans could send Democrats the first package of levies by Monday. It would be the first serious effort in the 2-month-old talks to tackle the most politically delicate issue negotiators face: whose taxes will be raised, and by how much. ``We expect to have it in hand by early next week,'' a Democrat said. ``The group will then evaluate it.'' Republicans said no final decisions have been made on what taxes the plan will include. But one GOP bargainer said it will probably contain boosts in excise taxes, perhaps on alcohol and tobacco products, as well as a cut in the capital gains tax rate. It is unlikely to contain a boost in income tax rates, which many Republicans have adamantly opposed, the official said. In recent days, participants in the talks and lobbyists have said that broad energy taxes also stand a good chance of emerging from the negotiations. Budget summit sessions today and Thursday were canceled so bargainers from the two parties could meet separately to formulate strategies. Negotiators are searching for at least $50 billion in spending cuts and tax boosts for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, in an effort to shrink a budget shortfall that will otherwise hit at least $160 billion. On Thursday, Republicans discussed a list of 70 to 80 possible tax increases but made no decisions on which should be included in any package, said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., one of the negotiators. Packwood said the Republicans talked about taxes on sales of stocks and on tobacco, alcohol, energy and luxury items. Also Thursday, House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia said it was ``arrogant and outrageous'' for Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell to demand higher income tax rates for wealthy Americans in exchange for a GOP-sought cut in the capital gains levy. Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican leader, said Mitchell's stance threatens the budget talks. Mitchell, D-Maine, said Wednesday that if President Bush refused to accept a boost in the income tax rates paid by the nation's richest wage-earners, there would be no deal to cut the capital gains tax rate. Bush has sought a reduction in the capital gains tax since his presidential campaign. The tax is paid on the profits from the sales of property such as real estate and stocks. Republicans say reducing the tax will encourage property sales and thus allow the government to collect additional money. Democrats say the idea would increase tax collections immediately but be a long-range money-loser. On the House floor and at a later news conference, Gingrich said budget bargainers had agreed that everything would be negotiable. ``I think it was a stupid mistake,'' he said of Mitchell's demand. ``I think it is arrogant and outrageous. I think he should withdraw it.'' Gingrich, who is one of the budget negotiators, added, ``If that's his non-negotiable position, I don't see any reason to walk into a room with him.'' Asked if he would boycott the talks, Gingrich said, ``I don't know. We'll have to wait and see how irrationally obstructive George Mitchell wants to be.'' Mitchell declined to respond to Gingrich. A spokesman said: ``The senator will continue to discuss the substance of issues but will not engage in a name-calling contest with someone like Rep. Gingrich.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Friend Says Cocaine Possession No Crime
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Court resumes 10 a.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.TEXT: A prosecution witness at Marion Barry's trial says he doesn't think cocaine possession is a crime, while another told the jury the mayor was a victim of entrapment. The statements came Thursday from two longtime friends of the mayor who were testifying reluctantly for the government. Both men said they had possessed cocaine and distributed it to Barry. They aren't being charged because of their assistance to the government. ``I thought use of cocaine was a personal matter,'' said Jeffrey Mitchell, an advertising executive who worked on Barry's mayoral campaigns. Mitchell testified that he and the mayor snorted cocaine on at least 10 occasions from 1985 to 1987. In most instances, Mitchell said he was the one who supplied the cocaine. ``You don't feel you committed a crime?'' Mitchell was asked. ``Under the circumstances that went down, no,'' Mitchell replied. Mitchell said he thought distribution of cocaine was a crime, but didn't think his own actions necessarily constituted distribution. But Barry's chief lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, pointed out that Mitchell gave cocaine to his friends, and that is a crime. ``I guess technically, yeah,'' Mitchell conceded. Mitchell testified that Barry was taking drugs and drinking heavily before he was rushed to a hospital by ambulance during a Super Bowl party in Los Angeles in 1987. Mitchell said he found Barry collapsed on a living room chair complaining that he was having trouble breathing. The mayor was making sniffing noises, as he had done in the past after using cocaine, said Mitchell. He and the mayor had smoked a marijuana cigarette the day of the party and Barry drank four bottles of champagne, a fifth of cognac and some wine, said Mitchell. After an ambulance rushed Barry to the hospital and oxygen was administered, Barry felt better and said ``he didn't want any tests,'' Mitchell testified. he said the mayor then left the emergency room. Mitchell said he refused to give cocaine to the mayor when he had city duties to perform. ``I love Marion Barry,'' he said. Darrell Sabbs testified that he and Barry snorted cocaine four times. Sabbs said he worked for Barry on different city assignments over the years and had developed ``almost a father-son relationship'' with the mayor. Sabbs came to Washington on Jan. 19 to be on hand for Barry's planned announcement that he would seek re-election. The announcement was never made because Barry was arrested in an FBI sting operation the previous night 18 and charged with cocaine possession. By the time Sabbs got to Washington, ``There had been this entrap, sting or whatever,'' he told the jury. The spectators in the courtroom chuckled over Sabbs' reference to entrapment, the defense Barry is using in seeking acquittal on the FBI sting. The mayor was videotaped smoking crack cocaine. He is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury. Meanwhile Thursday, another U.S. District Court jury acquitted David Rivers, former head of the city's Human Services Department, on bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with the awarding of $2 million in city contracts. Rivers had been charged with steering contracts to the firms of friends or companies headed by his co-defendant and Barry associate, developer John B. Clyburn. The jury reported it was still deliberating charges against Clyburn. In the Barry trial, a witness alleged that Rivers and the mayor used cocaine together.

DOC.HEAD: Two Million Aging Australian Sheep to Be Killed
DOC.TEXT: Two million older sheep will be killed in controlled shootings around the country to thin out the country's sheep population estimated at a record 175 million head, officials said today. Farmers said they will begin the mass shootings as early as next week because many old ewes, held over when wool prices were higher, are now being sold for as little as 10 cents each. ``It's sad, but some of the sheep aren't worth as much as a bullet,'' said one farmer who was not identified. Earth movers will likely be used to dig trenches to bury the sheep, other farmers said. More than a million of the sheep will be killed in Western Australia state, while several hundred thousand are expected to be shot in New South Wales state and the remainder in other areas of the country. Rob Sewell, spokesman for the New South Wales Farmers Association, says most of the sheep to be killed are over the age of 7. ``They've outlived their breeding purposes and are too old for commercial production either for their wool or mutton,'' Sewell said. ``This really is the only humane way out of the problem now,'' said Dr. Hugh Wirth, president of Australia's Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, who said he will urge tight government controls over the shootings. He said the sheep population crisis, which had been forecast several years ago, had intensified recently when the floor price of Australian wool was lowered and when live sheep trade to the Middle East was disrupted due to diseased shipments. There were a record 175 million head of sheep in Australia as of March of this year, a spokesman for Australian Bureau of Statistics said today. ``There are a lot of old sheep around, many of them that cannot be shorn anymore,'' said bureau spokesperson Elisabeth Davis. She said the last reported mass killings of sheep, for which no figures are available, occurred in 1972-73 when stocks were again too large. Wirth, who said recent bids at sales had only received from 10 to 20 cents a head, said Australia's rural community had not paid enough attention to the sheep problem. ``We've been warning them for years,'' he said. ``It seems there really isn't any other alternative but the bullet, although we believe the industry must urgently explore alternatives.'' Kevin Sheil, executive-director of the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, said the industry had been looking at ways of avoiding the problem by promoting mutton sales overseas. But those sales are also down, including a $1.2 million (U.S.) shipment due to be sent to the Soviet Union in two weeks that was canceled by Moscow. ``We understand that the public may be distressed to hear that sheep may have to be destroyed,'' said Sheil. ``But the public must understand that the farmers are also disturbed at the possibility of shooting their own sheep.''

DOC.HEAD: Fidel Castro Changes Name to Mike
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro has changed his name to Mike and is living in Bradenton working for a capitalist bank. No, not that Fidel. With the stroke of a pen Wednesday, Circuit Judge Stephen Dakan changed the legal name of Bradenton's Fidel Castro _ named after the Cuban president _ to Michael Anthony Castro. ``If you had a name like Fidel Castro, wouldn't you want to change it?'' Castro said. ``I have heard every joke _ `Where's the beard?' `Where's the cigar?''' Castro said he could handle the ribbing, but worried his career might be hurt. ``I think from a business point of view, a lot of doors might shut in my face because of the name,'' said Castro, a lending representative for a bank. ``Should a position present itself, I wouldn't be too keen on moving to Miami with the name Fidel Castro, knowing the intense sentiment against him there,'' he said. Miami has a large Cuban exile community. Antonio and Amparo Castro of Miami named their newborn son on Jan. 22, 1961, after the man then considered a hero for overthrowing dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959. But Castro later changed Cuba into a Communist state. One person still will be calling Michael Castro by his former name. ``My wife said whatever I wanted to do was fine, but I'll still be Fidel to her,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Workers Killed in Manhole Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An explosion in a manhole killed three utility workers. The men were trying to change electrical cables when the explosion occurred Thursday night, fire dispatcher Lori Fitch said. ``We don't know the cause of death at this time,'' Ms. Fitch said. She said there was a report of fire in the manhole. The victims worked for the Pasadena Public Service Department. Their identities were not immediately released.

DOC.HEAD: Voters, Not Courts, to Decide Impeached Governor's Political Fate
DOC.TEXT: Evan Mecham can run for governor again this fall despite being impeached and removed from the office in 1988, Arizona's Supreme Court ruled. Voters, not the courts, should decide whether the former governor is worthy of holding public office again, the state's highest court ruled Thursday in unanimously rejecting a challenge to Mecham's comeback bid. ``Impeachment, essentially a political process, is not subject to judicial review,'' the justices said. ``Any appeal from the impeachment conviction lies in the electoral process.'' Mecham was convicted by the state Senate of misusing about $80,000 given him by supporters and trying to thwart an investigation of an alleged death threat against an aide. He is one of five candidates seeking the Republican nomination in the Sept. 11 primary. Mecham has a small but extremely loyal following and could win the primary if the turnout is low and the other Republicans splinter the vote, a pollster said. ``I don't think he's a leader in the race right now, but he's still a contender,'' said Earl De Berge of the Behavior Research Center in Phoenix. ``His hard core is hard core, and everything depends on turnout.'' But De Barge said Mecham almost certainly would lose the general election. A retired Arizona highway patrol officer, Dennis Ingram, had challenged Mecham's right to hold office again, saying the state constitution automatically barred him from doing so because of his impeachment and ouster. Mecham, 66, contended the ban was not automatic. He noted that the Senate specifically failed to prohibit him from running again. The justices said the constitution was not clear on that point and ``election, the ultimate weapon of democracy, is favored where any doubt exists.'' Mecham, campaigning in Yuma Thursday evening, was jubilant. ``The court made the only decision that we could see that they could make,'' he said. ``We appreciate that, and now let's get on with the election and let the people do the choosing of who their next governor's going to be and get on with solving the critical problems of the state.'' Ingram said through his lawyer, Michael Meehan, that he was disappointed in the 5-0 decision. Mecham has said he believes a political opponent was behind Ingram's challange. Meehan denied it. Ingram has declined to discuss his motivation for filing the challenge. Mecham won the governorship on his fifth try in 1986. While in office, the former auto dealer offended blacks, Hispanics, Jews and women with inflammatory remarks, but he remained popular with many conservatives. Gov. Rose Mofford, a Democrat who as secretary of state automatically succeeded Mecham upon his removal, is stepping down. Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard is the only major Democratic candidate. The Senate convicted Mecham by a two-thirds vote but came up three votes short of a two-thirds majority when it considered a ``Dracula clause'' that would have banned him from holding public office. Vice Chief Justice Stanley Feldman, writing for the court, said the constitution left it unclear whether the separate vote on the ``Dracula clause'' was even needed or whether the conviction vote automatically meant Mecham could never hold office again. Given the uncertainty, he wrote, it is best to leave it ``to the will of the people.''

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Soldier's Medal Of Honor Given To Congress
DOC.TEXT: America's original Medal of Honor, hidden away for generations in an Ohio family's safety deposit box, is for the first time going on display in the U.S. Capitol. The descendants of Jacob Parrott, the first medal recipient, returned their heirloom to Congress on Thursday. Parrott, of Kenton, Ohio, was a 19-year-old Union Army volunteer when his regiment sneaked into Georgia and captured a locomotive 200 miles behind the Confederate line. With the opposing Army in pursuit, the raiders ran the train for 90 miles, until it ran out of fuel. All 22 were captured and eight were hanged. Secretary of War Edwin Stanton chose the raiders to be the first to get the medal. Pvt. Parrott got the prototype medal because he was the youngest in the group. Marilyn Frackelton of Westlake, Ohio, tearfully turned over to House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., the medal presented to her great-grandfather in 1863. During a formal ceremony attended by Foley, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and 33 Medal of Honor recipients, Mrs. Frackelton said she turned over the original medal ``with a great sense of relief, of mission accomplished.'' Through the generations, the Parrott medal was kept in the family's bank safety deposit box. Its new home will be a climate-controlled display case in the House Crypt beneathStatuary Hall in the Capitol.
DOC.HEAD: Toy Cymbals, Dolls Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The cymbals on about 9,200 Sesame Street Rhythm Band sets will be replaced because a New York toy company says the parts pose a choking hazard for small children. LEWCO Corp. said this week it would offer to replace the Oscar the Grouch cymbals for its model 3553 band sets because ``the heads detached from the cymbals'' and fail the Consumer Product Safety Commission's small-parts test. The sets consist of a drum, drum sticks, maracas, slide whistle, tambourines and the cymbals. Only the cymbals are subject to the replacement program, the company said. There have been no injuries reported involving the sets but consumers should discard the original cymbals and contact LEWCO Corp., 1107 Broadway-Suite 905, New York, N.Y., 10010 for replacements. In a similar action, another toy manufacturer recalled 2,364 dolls because various body parts detach easily and present a choking hazard to young children. Allen-Lewis Manufacturing Co. of Denver, Colo., said its ``Cutie Kid'' dolls were sold or distributed as free premiums since 1989 to tourists in small towns throughout the nation. The 6-inch dolls came with pacifiers and are dressed in a pink or blue two-piece pajama outfit. The cardboard headers on the clear plastic bags packaging are labeled ``Cutie Kid Made in China.'' Consumers should take the dolls away from young children and contact Frank Garlett at 1-800-525-6658.
DOC.HEAD: Hamilton Beach Recalls Coffee Makers
DOC.TEXT: Hamilton Beach Inc. is recalling 42,500 drip coffee makers because of a potential fire hazard. Hamilton Beach Inc. said this week that it was recalling the under-the-cabinet coffee makers because ``a defect in the analog clock may cause the appliance to catch fire during use,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. The North Carolina-based company has received 25 reports of the coffee makers catching fire, with consumers being burned in two instances. The recall is limited to models 816-2 and 816-3 manufactured between November 1987 and November 1988 and sold nationwide. Consumers may contact Hamilton Beach at 1-800-334-2785. North Carolina residents should call 1-800-672-5872.
DOC.HEAD: Papp, Actors Lobby Against Art Endowment Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Theatrical producer Joseph Papp and a delegation of performers are lobbying Congress against restrictions on funding for the National Endowment for the Arts. Legislators on both sides of the issue have predicted Congress will almost certainly impose restrictions when it votes on whether to extend the federal arts agency's life for another five years. Critics of the agency want to restrict the content of works that receive tax-paid grants from the endowment. Papp was accompanied by actors Kathleen Turner, Morgan Freeman and Kevin Kline. He said they had lunch with the Congressional Arts Caucus and Black Arts Caucus and encountered ``a mixed bag of opinion.'' ``Everyone was for the NEA, but they weren't solid on restrictions,'' he said. He said they had ``a very lively discussion'' at a meeting attended by Speaker of the House Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and lawmakers from both parties.. Then, he said, they went to the office of Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., where they ``met a number of senators who think differently than we do,'' including Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. He said the group included Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., and ``I think we had some impact on her.'' Asked whether they met with Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., one of the endowment's sternest critics, Papp said, ``Unfortunately, he didn't show up. He was invited, though. It would have been fun to talk with him.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Broadcast Operations to Combine Under VOA
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Information Agency wants the government's radio, televison and film service operations to be consolidated under the Voice of America as a unified broadcasting group. The reorganization, proposed Thursday, would combine the government's Satellite Television and Film Service, Radio Marti, TV Marti under the direction of VOA chief Richard W. Carlson. The move would ``better position the agency'' to be more effective in a rapidly changing world, USIA Director Bruce Gelb said in a statement. ``Hopefully, we will be also be able to bring about operating efficiencies that will allow us to make better use of our resources,'' Gelb added. The four divisions involved in the consolidation have a combined budget of $222 million and employ 3,500 people. Gelb told The Washigton Post in an interview published in Friday's editions that no current employees would lose their jobs in the reorganization. Two other broadcasting networks _ Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty _ operate under the Board for International Broadcasting, an organization separate from the USIA. Gelb said the new broadcast group would begin operation Oct. 1, the start of the 1991 fiscal year, pending congressional approval.

DOC.HEAD: Four Opposition Lamwakers Quit, Radicals Hurl Firebombs, Broadcast Strike
DOC.TEXT: Angry over government plans to revamp the nation's broadcast system, four opposition lawmakers quit, hundreds of broadcast workers walked out and radical students clashed with police. The lawmakers' resignations capped a week of controversy over government-sponsored bills which restructure the nation's broadcast industry and the military's operational command. Opposition groups claim the government of President Roh Tae-woo is railroading the bills through the legislature. Broadcast union leaders claim the bills are timed to strengthen the government's grip on broadcasting prior to next year's national elections. They say the bills will effectively allow the government to control ownership and censor programming of broadcast networks. The government claims the bills are aimed at rejuvenating South Korea's broadcast industry, introducing new programming and allowing the formation of new privately owned stations and cable television. In the provincial capital of Kwangju, about 200 radical students hurling firebombs at a government building today were dispersed by riot police firing tear gas, said the Joong-ang Daily News. ``Evil laws!,'' students shouted, according to the reprot. Hundreds of broadcast workers shouting anti-government slogans walked off the job today at Munwha Broadcast Corp. television. Also, a strike vote was being taken among 5,000 union workers at the state-run Korean Broadcasting System Co., the largest of the country's three networks. Most of MBC's news programs were shortened or canceled and senior management officials took over programming jobs, the network said. A statement released by the four lawmakers charged that the assembly has become a ``rubber-stamping body to pass undemocratic administration-sponsored law bills.'' They said it was the result of a merger of President Roh's governing party with two conservative opposition parties in February. The merger gave the new party control of 218 of the total 299 votes. Opposition lawmakers, dissidents and radical students have called the merger a political coup. Under the law, lawmakers' resignations are subject to consent through plenary session voting when the assembly is in session. The assembly was not expected to vote before its current session ends Monday. When the broadcasting bills were passed by committee on Wednesday, governing party members ignored procedural norms and used a quick standing vote. A scuffle broke out and one lawmaker was injured. Many Koreans eager for more choice in programs watch Japanese satellite television and the American military television. The government views both as cultural erosion. South Korean media came under strict government control in 1980, after disgraced former president Chun Doo-hwan seized power. Chun closed private networks and placed virtually all radio and television stations under state management. Roh succeeded Chun in 1988 and has introduced press freedom and other reforms. Networks have aired news reports critical of the government. In April, about 5,000 KBS workers staged a strike to challenge the head of the network, who had been appointed by Roh. They demanded a more reform-minded figure run the network. Riot police were used to squelch the 19-day strike.

DOC.HEAD: Unlike Other Cancers, Oral Cancer Survival Rates Not Improving
DOC.TEXT: Many cancer patients in the United States are increasingly likely to survive, but for about 30,000 hit by throat and mouth cancer every year the chances are roughly 50-50 _ and not getting any better. Oral and pharynx cancers killed 9,742 Americans in 1987, the latest year for which statistics are available, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. That fatality rate _ 3.6 deaths per 100,000 people _ is unchanged from 1973, said CDC dental health specialist Linda Crossett. But the survival rate hasn't changed much since then either, the Atlanta-based disease center said. Only 52 percent of oral cancer patients survive five years or more. That's in contrast to the survival rates for breast, prostate and colorectal cancers, which are improving, officials said. Survival rates are lowest for blacks, and getting worse. Statistics for 1981 through 1986 showed that just 31 percent of black patients survived oral cancer, compared with 35 percent in 1974-76. For white patients, the survival rates have remained more constant: 53 percent from 1981 through 1986, down from 55 percent during 1974-76. ``We're not making a lot of progress,'' Crossett said, adding that about 30,000 new cases a year are diagnosed in the United States. Major risk factors for oral cancer include use of tobacco, either smoked or smokeless, and drinking. ``The combined risks from tobacco and alcohol use appear to be substantially greater than those from tobacco or alcohol alone,'' the CDC said in its weekly report. ``The increased use of tobacco among women, adolescents and children'' _ as compared to a decline in smoking overall _ ``is likely to elevate death rates for these cancers in the next several decades,'' the report said. Another major reason for oral cancer deaths ``is the fact that there has not been any improvement in early detection,'' Crossett said. ``Most are only detected ... after they've grown pretty large, so advanced that it's obvious.'' Dentists traditionally have been most likely to perform extensive oral exams, but the CDC documented in 1986 that people at highest risk for oral cancer seek the services of a physician four times more often than a dentist. ``And many people going to their physician may not get a thorough oral, head and neck exam,'' Crossett said.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Expect Early Demise Of Communism In Albania
With AM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Albanian refugees who escaped Europe's last stronghold of Communism hope that even in their tiny country the days of one-party rule are numbered. A group of 51 Albanians who had sought refuge in the Czechoslovak Embassy in the Albanian capital Tirana were transported to Prague early Monday on Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel's plane. They were the first of about 4,500 asylum-seekers sheltering in foreign embassies allowed to leave their country. They speculate that the exodus could be the harbinger of the demise of Communism in their abandoned country. Hundreds more refugees arrived in Italy by ship today. ``I give Communism in my country one or two years,'' said Kola, a 36-year-old construction worker who is housed together with the other refugees in a workers' barracks on the outskirts of Prague. Like others, he declined to give his full name out of fear of possible reprisals against his family at home. ``It was intolerable. We all dreaded the isolation,'' Kola said in fairly fluent Italian. He was one of the few who spoke anything but Albanian. Kola claimed he spent five years in jail for publicly criticizing the late Albanian leader Enver Hoxha. ``Some people spent up to 40 years in jail for similar offenses,'' he added. During his 40 years of leadership, Hoxha steered his country into increasing isolation internationally and suppressed dissent to maintain absolute rule of the Communists. The country's current leader, Ramiz Alia, who took over after Hoxha's death in 1985, has opened his country considerably to the outside world and initiated some modest reforms, mostly in the economy. But he has rejected any far-reaching political changes. Other refugees confirmed that the leadership continues to exercise a tight grip on its people's freedoms. Residents of Tirana are not permitted to travel further than 25 miles out of town without a special permit, they said, and the omnipresent secret police, known as Sigurimi, kept a close watch over their private lives. ``The Romanian Securitate was like The Salvation Army compared to them,'' Kola said. He was referring to the hated secret police of Romania's ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu who was executed after his overthrow by a bloody revolution. The reference to the Romanian Securitate indicated that Kola and other Albanians were able to keep themselves informed of what was happening in the world, despite the tight reigns on the Communist-run press in Albania. Kola said his knowledge of Havel, garnered from foreign broadcasts that can be received in Tirana, was one reason for his choosing the Czechoslovak Embassy to seek refuge. ``Everybody listens to Italian and Yugoslav radio in Tirana and we knew very well what happened in Czechoslovakia,'' he said. But he admitted his reasons were not merely political: ``Quite frankly, the fence around the Czechoslovak Embassy was one of the lowest, too,'' he laughed. When the Albanian refugees arrived at the Ruzyne airport in Prague Monday, many of them carried pictures of Havel and chants of ``Long live Havel'' were still heard from the jubilant arrivals as a bus was taking them off to their quarters. Czechoslovak authorities provided each of them with about $1,700 worth of basic clothing, medical help and a little pocket money. All of the refugees were said to be in good health. ``It is just too bad we do not have such intellectuals and dissidents in our country,'' Kola said of Havel, a former dissident playwright turned statesmen in the wake of Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last year that ousted Communists from power. ``Most of them are corrupted,'' Kola said of intellectuals in his country. Kola said he had not yet decided where he wanted to settle, but indicated that he did not plan to stay in Czechoslovakia. ``I`d like to go to the U.S.,'' he said. But Kola made clear that ideally he would like to consider his homeland an option as well. ``Certainly I hope the Communist rule ends soon and we can all be free like you,'' he concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Potential Victims of Radiation Releases Seek Compensation
LaserGraphic NY9
DOC.TEXT: Legally barred from suing the government, people whose health may have suffered because of huge radiation releases from Hanford nuclear reservation began considering other ways to get compensation. Scientists today were to start trying to determine just how much radiation people who lived downwind from Hanford were exposed to by releases into the air in the 1940s and into the Columbia River in the 1960s. The federal government disclosed the magnitude of radiation releases Thursday, revealing for the first time that people and farmland were exposed to significant levels of potentially cancer-causing nuclear contamination. ``We really believe we're getting the truth now,'' said Tom Bailie, a farmer and spokesman for people living east of the southern Washington reservation. Residents are legally barred from suing the government for damages suffered by radiation exposure, but could win compensation through congressional action, Bailie said. Pending legislation in Congress would pay uranium miners for radiation-related illnesses, though they also are blocked from suing the government by the so-called doctrine of sovereign immunity, he said. ``The federal government owes something if folks have been harmed by these early releases of radiation,'' Rep. Sid Morrison, a Republican whose district includes the reservation, said in Washington, D.C. ``While these estimates are preliminary and they will change, the potential for harmful side effects is with us to stay,'' he said. An independent panel of scientists was scheduled to meet here today to begin the second phase of a five-year study. They will try to determine individual radiation exposure and health risks for those who lived downwind from the 560-square-mile site. The first phase studied airborne radioactive iodine emissions from 1944 to 1947 and radioactive cooling water poured into the Columbia River from 1964-67. The five-year, $15 million study is being paid for, but not directed, by the U.S. Department of Energy, which operates the reservation. Hanford was established late in World War II as part of the Manhattan Project to build atomic bombs. Fuel rods irradiated in as many as nine nuclear reactors at the site were taken to several top-secret plants where plutonium and uranimum were extracted to fuel nuclear bombs. The iodine and other radioactive materials was released into the air through unfiltered stacks, officials said. A few infants were hit hardest, with doses as high as 2,900 rad over three years. One rad is the amount of radiation a body organ would absorb from about a dozen chest X-rays. The panel concluded that most people living near the Hanford site from 1944 to 1947 were exposed to low doses of radiation. The study covered 270,000 people living in 10 Washington and Oregon counties. In releasing the first phase report, John Till, a South Carolina scientist and nuclear consultant, cautioned that the results should not be used to make health risk estimates. But as many as 13,500 people, or 5 percent of the population, may have received doses of more than 33 rad in milk after cows grazed in contaminated pastures, he said. About 1,400 infants and children living in the area received 15 to 650 rad, with only a small number suffering the 2,900-rad doses, Till said. When it concentrates in the thyroid gland, radioactive iodine-131 can cause cancer and other diseases. Scientists hope that within a year they will be able to tell people who lived in the area what their highest potential radiation doses likely were. Such information would greatly help doctors treat affected residents, Dr. George Laramore, professor of radiological oncology at the University of Washington School of Medicine in Seattle. Bailie led an impromptu press conference of downwind residents angered by the report that came decades after radiation was routinely released in the rural agricultural area. ``I feel like they used us for guinea pigs, and I don't feel like they cared one iota what happened to us either, or our families,'' said Betty Perkes, a farmer in Pasco.

DOC.HEAD: Doubter Fights Friday the 13th Superstitions By Tempting Fate
DOC.TEXT: Those who dread today _ Friday the 13th _ don't have to cringe under the covers until Saturday, thanks to superstition-smasher Jerry Karol. The prop store owner's 13-step, tongue-in-cheek remedy for triskaidekaphobia may seem to tempt fate, though. In Karol's ``Theme Factory,'' a showroom where he creates props for unusual parties, museum exhibits and other events, he has set up what he describes as a ``disease-killing display leading to a 13 cure.'' People who want to break the fearful habit are invited to stop by and: _Break a mirror. _Walk under a ladder. _Let a black cat cross your path. _Whistle indoors. _Toss three coins in a fountain. _Spill salt. _Walk a plank. _Stir a caldron of witch's brew. _Step on a crack in a block of cement. _Circle a tombstone. _Open an umbrella indoors. _Kiss a moose. _Hop on one foot while counting backwards from 13. Karol admits he doesn't really believe in the allegedly unlucky day, so the truly superstitious might not want to try his cure. Then again, Karol says, ``Why not?'' ``Anything is worth a try, and if you can do it, especially on Friday the 13th, it should cure triskaidekaphobia, which is only in the mind, anyway.'' ``It's long been held that the best way to get rid of anxieties and frustration is through laughter and fun,'' he said. ``It's important to look at our fears and put them in perspective. Then one realizes that most superstitious fears are figments of our imagination.'' Those who try the remedy will be asked to make a contribution to Mothers Against Drunk Drivers, or their favorite charity, Karol said.

DOC.HEAD: Hunt for Zodiac Killer Fruitless, But Dartman Suspect Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A police dragnet based on astrological research failed to turn up the Zodiac killer and cost the city as much as $30,000 in overtime for undercover officers sent out as decoy prey. ``Maybe he read in the papers that we were beefing up,'' Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said Thursday after the all-night hunt. ``I'm happy he didn't shoot anyone. I'm not happy we haven't caught him yet,'' Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said. Investigators activated ``Operation Watchdog'' because they feared the gunman would strike according to a 21-day, Thursday pattern he has followed over four months in attacks on four people. In another prominent New York crime spree, police arrested a 33-year-old man with a history of psychiatric problems as a suspect in the ``Dartman'' dart-blowing attacks. In the past few weeks, 55 well-dressed women have reported being jabbed by homemade darts in the buttocks, legs and arms as they walked down streets, mostly in midtown Manhattan. Of the ``Night of the Zodiac,'' Borrelli refused to say how many officers scoured the city in search of the gunman, who said in letters to police and news organizations that he chooses his victims by their astrological signs. All four of the Zodiac's victims, including one who died, were shot on Thursday nights between midnight and dawn. The 21-day cycle of shootings started March 8, with other shootings on March 29, May 31 and June 21. The time between the second and third shootings was 63 days, a multiple of 21. The gunman vowed in letters to police and news media to shoot 12 people _ one for each sign of the Zodiac. At least two men who resembled a sketch of Zodiac were picked up by detectives, questioned and released during the dragnet. Borrelli estimated the operation cost the city as much as $30,000 in overtime for officers. Borrelli said the absence of a Zodiac shooting early Thursday ``is not inconsistent with him because there was that period'' of 63 days between the second and third shootings. In the Dartman case, authorities said Jerome Wright, 33, of the Bronx, a messenger with a criminal record and admitted psychiatric problems, was charged Thursday in the firing of darts made from straight pins, sewing needles and paper. Wright was identified in a lineup by three women Wednesday night and was charged with three counts each of reckless endangerment, criminal possession of a weapon and harassment. ``We believe he is our darter,'' said Manhattan Chief of Detectives Joseph DeMartino.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Intensifies in Tamil-Government War
DOC.TEXT: The army and navy have launched a major offensive against the rebel Tamil Tigers, killing more than 70 insurgents, capturing two camps and blowing up six boats, military officials said today. The government operation began Thursday in the Trincomalee district, about 140 miles northeast of Colombo, according to the military officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. A total of 130 Tigers and government troops have been killed since Wednesday night, according to government tallies. There was no independent confirmation of the reports. Contact with the Tigers has been tapering off because of the fighting and also due to poor communications. The Tigers have been fighting seven years for a separate homeland for their ethnic minority in northeastern Sri Lanka, claiming they need to protect Tamils from discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. The government claimed the Tigers lost 40 men when the government attacked two guerrilla camps near the deep-water port city. At least 33 more Tigers were killed when navy gunboats destroyed six rebel boats in a lagoon, the officials said. They said 45 soldiers were killed when the Tigers overran a camp at Kokkavil, about 180 miles northeast of Colombo. A survivor was quoted as saying the rebels used armor-plated bulldozers to mount the assault. Government troops fanned out to look for more survivors. Officials said a search party early today killed eight rebels at Mankulam, 12 miles south of Kokkavil. In the far north, a Tiger sniper killed one soldier at the 200-year-old Dutch colonial fort, the only government-held post in Jaffna town. The town has been a rebel stronghold since the Tigers launched their offensive in 1983. Three other soldiers were killed in the northwestern town of Mannar and in the northeast, the government said. No breakdown was given. About 2,400 combatants have been reported killed since July 11 when the Tigers overran a chain of police stations, shattering a 13-month-old cease-fire. Many civilians also have died, but no figures were available. The mainly Hindu Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and say they have been denied equality in jobs and education. The predominantly Buddhist Sinhalese account for 75 percent of the population and have run the Indian Ocean island since it became independent from Britain in 1948. More than 17,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Envoy In Beirut Seeking Word Of Hostage
DOC.TEXT: An Irish envoy was in Moslem west Beirut today seeking further information on whether kidnapped Irish teacher Brian Keenan will soon be freed after four years' captivity. The envoy, Adrian McDaid, arrived in Beirut Thursday, five days after Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said in a brief dispatch from Beirut that pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups might release one of 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. ``I'm here to collect information about the possible release of Brian Keenan,'' said McDaid, the first secretary at the Irish Embassy in Baghdad, which is also responsible for Lebanon. IRNA did not say which hostage could be freed but said he would probably be one of 10 missing Europeans. Sources close to the Syrian Army headquarters in Beirut have speculated that Keenan would be the one freed. ``We don't have official confirmation that it will be him, but we're hopeful that it will be him,'' McDaid said. Apart from Keenan, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and an Italian are missing in Lebanon, along with six Americans. The longest held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. Keenan, a 39-year-old English language teacher from Belfast, was kidnapped in west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked to work at the American University of Beirut. No group has claimed to hold him or made any demands for his release. Former hostage Frank Reed, an American educator freed April 30, said he saw Keenan two days before his release, which was announced by a group calling itself Islamic Dawn. McDaid, interviewed at the Irish consulate in west Beirut, said the duration of his stay in Lebanon ``depends on the developments.'' Declan Connolly, the Irish Ambassador to Syria, said he was in constant touch with the Syrian Foreign Ministry in Damascus. Syria, Iran's main Arab ally, has played a role in previous hostage releases. The Syrians have 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate to quell a civil war between Christians and Moslems that broke out in 1975. Officials and diplomats in Damascus said Thursday a release was not likely before next week because President Hafez Assad, Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and other senior government officials were scheduled to be in Cairo Saturday and Sunday. In another development, Beirut's al-Liwa daily said the Belgian government and the Palestinian faction of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal have struck a deal for the release of four Belgians held by the group for more than 2{ years. The front-page report, attributed to unidentified Western diplomatic sources, said the four would be freed July 21 after Belgian King Baudouin issues a ``special pardon'' for Palestinian Nasser Sa'eed, who is serving a life sentence for a grenade attack on young Jews June 27, 1980. Al-liwa does not have a record of accurate reporting on the hostage issue.

DOC.HEAD: Suspects Charged in Activist's Death; Police Suspect Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The killing of a militant Wesleyan University student was related to drugs, not his civil rights activism, police said after charging two suspects. Police said Nicholas B. Haddad's death was plotted by cohorts who feared reprisal after they lost or misspent a large sum of the money he invested in a drug-dealing operation. Haddad's body was found in his car July 6. Carl Lightner, 20, and Kumar Viswanathan, 21, were charged Thursday with murder and conspiracy in Haddad's death, officials said. Neither suspect is a Wesleyan student. Lightner has been in custody since July 7 on an unrelated drug charge and was scheduled for arraignment today, with bail set at $550,000. Viswanathan remained at large. His bail was set at $750,000. Haddad, 21, a Lebanese-American, had organized several rallies and taken part in a hunger strike at the university to protest racism on campus, prompting initial speculation that his activism was tied to his death. Hartford State's Attorney John M. Bailey ruled out that theory Thursday. ``We found no motive concerning the deceased's activities at Wesleyan University and there was absolutely no racial motive in this case,'' Bailey said. Found in Haddad's car was a cache of weapons, including an Uzi semiautomatic, police said. Police Lt. Frederick Lewis theorized that Lightner and Viswanathan were to buy and sell drugs purchased with money supplied by Haddad, who was to receive a percentage of the profits. The two men plotted Haddad's slaying because they lost or misspent an undisclosed large sum of his money, Lewis said. Haddad, a Lebanese-American from Red Hook, N.Y., was co-editor of a the student publication ``The Afrikan Nation.'' He and nine other students went on a nine-day hunger strike in May following the discovery of racist graffiti on a black student dormitory. Activists said the graffiti was the product of a climate of racial intolerance at the elite private school with an enrollment of 2,700. In another episode, black students complained that police had unfairly singled out Haddad and several other minority-group members as suspects in two April firebombings on campus.

DOC.HEAD: Military to Victorious Opposition: Don't Try To Declare Government
DOC.TEXT: The military junta today told the opposition that scored a landslide election win six weeks ago not to try to declare a government. Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the head of military intelligence, said the junta would not yield to international demands that it transfer power to the National League for Democracy and release the opposition group's general secretary, Aung San Suu Kyi. Ms. Suu Kyi, the daughter of Burma's foremost independence hero, has been under house arrest for nearly a year, since last July 20. ``The (junta) is a military government ruling the country under martial law. No attempt for a unilateral declaration of government will be tolerated,'' Khin Nyunt told the weekly government news briefing in Rangoon. He acknowledged international pressure to transfer power and free Ms. Suu Kyi, ``but we do not care at all about such threats.'' The pressure amounted to ``undue interference in the internal affairs of our country,'' Khin Nyunt said. The junta took power in 1988, brutally crushing a national uprising for democracy. It allowed the nation's first free election in 30 years to be held May 27. The National League trounced the miltiary, winning 396 of 485 parliamentary seats. The military government says the newly elected parliament must approve a constitution before it can govern. In the past, it had said the parliament could choose between two previous constitutions or draw up a new one. The National League has said it wishes to adapt the constitution of 1947, used after Burma gained independence from Britain the following year. But Khin Nyunt said ``both the 1947 and 1974 constitutions are no longer adaptable to the country's present situation,'' adding: ``Hence an entirely new constitution which would not entail legal problems arising out of its shortcomings must be drawn.'' The military would be willing to hold talks with political leaders only when all election expenses and objections had been cleared by the Elections Commission, Khin Nyunt said. He said Ms. Suu Kyi was being detained ``according to the law,'' and that she had been treated with lenience. ``Though she is restricted to her home, all facilities are being provided for,'' he said. Khin Nyunt said she was able to receive gift parcels from her British husband through the British Embassy. He said Ms. Suu Kyi would be allowed to hold a religious ceremony on July 19 to commemorate the anniversary of the assassination of her father Aung San 43 years ago. The junta detained Ms. Suu Kyi after she vowed to lead a mass anti-government rally to commemorate the last anniversary of her father's death.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet-Japanese-North Korean Fishing Flap Apparently Settled
DOC.TEXT: Soviet authorities today permitted a dozen North Korean-flagged fishing vessels and their mainly Japanese crews to leave a Soviet port where they had been held for alleged poaching, Japanese officials said. But the ships were bound for North Korea, and it was uncertain when the Japanese crewmen would be brought home. Shigeo Takenaka, acting Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, told foreign journalists the North Koreans said they would return the fishermen to Japan ``without delay'' after arrival at the port of Hungnam in North Korea. The ministry said earlier the crewmen were wary of going to North Korea. Japan's consul general in the Soviet Far East port of Nakhodka strongly protested that the crewmen were not being brought directly to Japan, and Japanese coast guard vessels were dispatched to try to monitor the voyage. The incident, which started in mid-May, was a three-way dispute between the Soviet Union, North Korea and Japan over fishing in salmon-rich waters off the Soviet coast. The seized vessels flew North Korean flags and had North Korean officers, but they had been leased from Japanese companies and about three-quarters of the crew was Japanese. Soviet authorities directed their complaints about the alleged poaching to their ally North Korea, while Japanese authorities scrambled to try to get the crew released. Japan and Communist North Korea have no diplomatic relations. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said North Korea would pay compensation to the Soviets for the illegal fishing. But no amount was announced. North Korea has no fishing agreement with the Soviet Union, and North Korean boats had been permitted to fish for salmon, experts said. It was speculated that such informal arrangements enticed Japanese operators to put their vessels under North Korean flag and take more salmon than what was permitted in the Japanese-Soviet agreement. But Japanese authorities said it was illegal to lease fishing vessels to North Korea without permission, which had not been given. The Japanese crew's fears were proably raised by the fact that two Japanese fishermen were imprisoned in North Korea after they allowed a North Korean to stow away on their boat and defect to Japan. The two went back to North Korea to fish after the incident and were arrested, tried for espionage and sentenced to 15 years in prison. North Korea has suggested they would be released in exchange for the defector, but Japan has refused.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Refugees Volunteer to Return Home from Thailand, Malaysia
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Vietnamese are expected to return to their homeland in the first voluntary repatriation of Vietnamese refugees from Thailand since 1975, a U.N. official said today. Sixty other boat people will return home Sunday from Malaysia, the United Nations said. That would bring to 167 the number of boat people who have returned from Malaysian camps voluntarily since the beginning of 1989. Southeast Asian countries burdened by thousands of Vietnamese who fled their Communist homeland have threatened to forcibly repatriate refugees unless the United States and other countries help resettle them. Fifty-nine refugees are awaiting authorization from Vietnam to return while another 130 have indicated they want to go back, the U.N. statement said. In the departures from Thailand, an official of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said 113 refugees from the Phanat Nikhom refugee camp had volunteered to return to Vietnam and would be interviewed by Vietnamese immigration officials in Thailand early next week. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he expected the refugees would return to Vietnam within one or two months. There are now some 14,000 Vietnamese refugees in Thailand. Less than 2,000 are currently eligible for third-country resettlement. All Vietnamese who arrived in Thailand after March 14, 1989 must be screened to determine their eligibility for resettlement. Most of the Vietnamese refugees now in Thailand arrived after that cutoff date. The group of 113 had not yet been screened, the official said. It appeared they were returning due to the lengthy screening process and because they were pessimistic about the prospect for eventual resettlement, another relief official said. The U.N. official said the number of Vietnamese arriving in Thailand had increased in the first five months of this year to an average of about 1,000. He said it appeared the Vietnamese now perceived Thailand to be more receptive to them than countries Malaysia and Hong Kong. There are about 17,500 Vietnamese refugees in Malaysian camps. Of these, 14,000 arrived after the March 1989 cutoff date. Vietnamese began fleeing their homeland after the Communist victory over U.S.-backed forces in South Vietnam in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama Man Executed for Woman's Murder
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: A murderer called the death penalty racist before he was strapped into the electric chair and executed early today. Wallace Norrell Thomas, 35, quoted from the Bible and read a 1{-page statement as relatives and other witnesses looked on. ``Let my death serve as an instigator that will awaken a nation to fight and adopt the philosophy of the late, great Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who said, `Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere,''' Thomas said. Thomas, who was black, called capital punishment a ``racist, violent penalty.'' He wore a purple ribbon and a sticker saying, ``Execute justice, not people.'' Alabama death row inmates clanged the bars of their cells and yelled as the execution time drew near. Thomas was condemned for the Dec. 20, 1976, abduction and gunshot slaying of Quenette Shehane, 21, who had graduated from Birmingham-Southern College just a few days before. She was kidnapped at a convenience store near the campus. One of two other men charged in the case implicated Thomas in the shooting. Thomas' co-defendants are serving life sentences. The U.S. Supreme Court, which rejected an appeal in the case in April, on Thursday rejected Thomas' plea for a delay. Later, Gov. Guy Hunt restated his intention to let the execution proceed, and the state Supreme Court denied an emergency stay motion. In the appeal, Thomas' lawyer, Bryan Stevenson, argued that the electric chair is inhumane, based on two instances in which inmates were not killed with the first flip of the switch. He also challenged a judge's instructions to jurors for Thomas' trial. Thomas was the 133rd person executed since the Supreme Court in 1976 allowed states to resume use of the death penalty, the eighth in Alabama. While on death row at Holman Prison near Atmore, Thomas helped found Project Hope, an anti-death penalty group for inmates and their families. The organization seeks to educate the public about capital punishment and tries to bring condemned inmates and their relatives together. Miss Shehane's mother, Miriam Shehane, has become Alabama's leading advocate for victims' rights. Mrs. Shehane helped found the group Victims of Crime and Leniency.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Rocket Ignites California Blaze, Lightning Fires Rage Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager's toy rocket touched off a roaring fire that blackened 7,000 acres of brush in Southern California, and lightning-sparked blazes rampaged through the Okefenokee Swamp in Georgia today. Five people, including the 15-year-old boy accused of starting the fire with the model rocket, were injured in the fire that broke out Thursday in Chino Hills State Park, about 40 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. The boy, whose name was withheld because of his age, was arrested for investigation of unlawful use of a model rocket and was released to his parents. ``He did admit to starting the fire,'' Orange County fire spokeswoman Maria Sabol said. ``He tried to put the fire out and sustained minor burns to his right leg.'' Seven hundred firefighters were expected to surround the blaze today, said fire dispatcher Lori Malavenda. Three prison inmates fighting the fire were overcome by smoke and were treated at the scene. Another inmate firefighter fractured an elbow in a fall. The fire was near the Carbon Canyon area, where 6,000 acres were consumed in the last three days of June by an arson fire. Charred land there acted as a fire stop, keeping the new fire from spreading in that direction, fire officials said. A wildfire triggered by lightning last weekend in the Okefenokee Swamp burned out of control today, adding to 3,900 acres of charred brush. The Georgia fire on Mitchell Island, about six miles from the Florida state line, spread from 1,700 acres on Wednesday to 3,900 acres by Thursday afternoon, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Don Corban. A new lightning-sparked blaze erupted in Yellowstone National Park on Thursday and had blackened at least 15 acres of forest by today, officials said. Air tankers were dispatched to drop fire retardant on flames about eight miles north of Yellowstone Lake, park spokesman Joan Anzelmo said. The latest fire was the park's 12th of the year, but only the second to surpass two acres. As many as 300 lightning-caused fires dotted the Cascades Mountains in Washington and Oregon on Thursday, but most were small and did not threaten any buildings, U.S. Forest Service spokesman Ralph Satterberg said. The largest fire was a 100-acre blaze in the William O. Douglas Wilderness Area of the Gifford Pinchot National Forest in southwestern Washington state, he said. Another blaze charred about 50 acres of forest near the Henry M. Jackson Wilderness Area of the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, about 40 miles east of Everett, Wash., said Ron DeHart, another forest service spokesman. In Oregon, the largest fire was a 55-acre blaze burning in Douglas County south of Roseburg, said Doug Decker of the Oregon State Forestry Department. In Alaska, wildfires continued to burn, many unattended. There have been 615 wildfires in Alaska this season, scorching a combined 545,706 acres, according to Bureau of Land Managment figures.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across East, South and Parts of Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `At midnight...', to CORRECT to Thursday sted Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Rain sprinkled the eastern third of the nation early today and temperatures cooled in the Pacific Northwest after a scorching day of temperatures shooting well past the century mark. The northern Plains, Rockies and desert Southwest were mostly dry, but severe thunderstorms, with a chance of tornadoes, were expected in eastern Louisiana, Alabama and Mississippi. Heavy showers also could develop in the Virginias. At midnight Thursday, temperatures had dipped to 83 degrees in Pendleton, Ore., and to 79 at Boise, Idaho. Earlier in Washington state, Pasco hit 116, Hanford reached 110 and it was 108 in Walla Walla. Torrid temperatures were expected to cool in the Northwest today, and thunderstorms over eastern Washington state were moving toward Montana. In the Southwest, temperatures were likely to soar past 100. Death Valley, Calif., had a high of 125 degrees on Thursday, and in Arizona, Bullhead City and Lake Havasu City hit 116. Rain fell across much of the Northeast early today, and was scattered across the South and Ohio Valley. Rain also fell in parts of the Midwest. A cold front extending from the Great Lakes was likely to push cool air across the Plains to northern Texas, bringing unseasonably cool temperatures. Moist air from the South will collide with a stationary front stretching across the Appalachias from western Tennessee to northern Virginia. Heavy rains were expected just north of the front. DOC.HEAD: Polish Lawmakers OK Bill to Sell Off Most State Industries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to clarify that bill would sell off all state industry, which is 80 percent of total in Poland. Pickup 2nd, `The Sejm...'
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers voted today to sell off Poland's state-owned industries, a major step in the Solidarity-led government's 7-month-old radical reform program. More than 80 percent of the country's industry is government-owned, including steel mills, coal mines and factories. Government officials said no sectors of the economy would be off-limits to privatization. The Sejm, or the lower house of parliament, passed the legislation 328-2, with 39 abstentions. The vote came one day after the long-delayed measure reached the floor. The privatization measure still needs Senate approval, but with 99 of 100 senators elected from the non-Communist Solidarity movement, it was not expected to have any difficulty. Companies in the best financial shape would be put on the auction block first. ``I think this is the most fundamental bill ever passed by the Polish parliament, said Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz. ``This is a foundation of the new economic system in Poland.'' Introducing the bills a day earlier, Balcerowicz told lawmakers that the ownership changes must come quickly. ``Without a decisive change in the ownership of the economy, further progress of the reforms is not possible,'' he said. Poland, whose Communist regime was replaced by the Solidarity government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in August, embarked in January on a radical economic reform program. The first goal was to stabilize runaway inflation. The program whittled inflation down to 3.4 percent in June, compared to 600 percent to 1,000 percent inflation in 1989. But the social cost has been high _ real incomes have dropped by 30 percent. The privatization measure bogged down for some time because of disputes over how to proceed. Many people feared foreign investors or the former Communist elite would be the only ones with the capital to buy state property. But the government promised that ``privatization coupons,'' which can be used toward purchase of state-owned property, would be issued to all citizens. ``In this way, the idea of citizen's stock ownership will be put into practice,'' said Balcerowicz. He also promised that Polish citizens would be allowed to buy shares on an installment basis and, in some cases, on favorable credit terms. Employees of enterprises would be allowed to buy up to 20 percent of the shares of their companies on preferential terms. Foreign investment will be at the discretion of the government agency overseeing the transactions. Although the government wants to sell off state companies as quickly as possible, it will take time. Krzysztof Lis, who heads the privatization office, estimates that even after three years, less than 50 percent of Poland's 7,600 enterprises will be in private hands.

DOC.HEAD: South Florida Water Restrictions Eased
DOC.TEXT: Officials are easing water-use retrictions for most of south Florida because recent rains have raised underground water levels. Under the South Florida Water Management District's relaxed rules that begin Monday, car and boat washing is permitted any time, and lawn sprinkling is permitted every day before 9 a.m. and after 5 p.m. The restrictions adopted Thursday end most water-use restrictions in coastal areas from Palm Beach Gardens to Key West and west to Lee County. Stricter rules remain for rain-deficient Jupiter and Tequesta areas. Although the south Florida drought is now in its 23rd month, even below-average summer rains have topped off the Biscayne Aquifer and ended the threat of its contamination by sea water. Still, Lake Okeechobee, the region's backup water supply, stands at almost 2{ feet below normal.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Makes Fall Schedule Changes Early
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. said it will start its fall season early with two programming moves designed to snatch viewers from the Big Three. ``Babes,'' a half-hour comedy about three overweight sisters, will premiere at 8:30 p.m. on Aug. 23. That show will be preceded on Thursday nights by repeats of ``The Simpsons,'' as the latter moves early into its new time slot against NBC's top-rated ``The Cosby Show.'' Original episodes featuring the animated Simpsons family will begin in late October. Fox's highly publicized decision to do battle with Bill Cosby is the most daring aspect of the alternative network's fall schedule. Thursday's announcement that ``Babes'' will debut in six weeks came just two days after Fox executives said the pilot was being redone because some of the program's jokes were considered too raunchy. Breaking with tradition has been one of the reasons cited for the success of the 4-year-old Fox network. For example, it has launched its fall shows early while ABC, CBS and NBC are still broadcasting summer repeats.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Proposes Joint Searches for MIAs
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese experts told U.S. officials that joint searches for U.S. servicemen who were listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War should be held soon, the Voice of Vietnam reported today. U.S. and Vietnamese officials met in Hanoi from July 10-12, the radio said, in a report monitored in Bangkok. ``The two sides frankly exchanged ideas on the issue.'' it said. It gave no additional information on the Vietnamese proposal for joint searches. Vietnam has said that since April the United States has twice suspended meetings between MIA specialists from the two countries. At the beginning of this month, Richard Solomon, U.S. assistant secretary of state for east Asian affairs, complained of ``a relative lack of serious cooperation over the past several months'' on the MIA issue. Washington lists about 2,300 Americans missing from the Indochina war; about 1,700 of them in Vietnam, and the rest in Laos, Cambodia and Chinese coastal waters. The U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency last month said it had confirmed a decade-old report that Vietnam had the remains of 400 or more U.S. servicemen stored in a warehouse. The radio report said that during the Hanoi meeting the Vietnamese side rejected as ``ill-intentioned fabrications'' both this report and another which said U.S. servicemen were still being held in Vietnam. Cooperation on the MIA issue is hampered by a lack of diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam. Hanoi has eagerly sought diplomatic relations, but Washington has first demanded a peace settlement in Cambodia, where U.S.-backed guerrillas are fighting the government Vietnam installed after a 1978 invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Staten Island Ferry Fare Going Up
DOC.TEXT: The round-trip cost of chugging across New York Harbor in a bright yellow Staten Island ferry is going up from a quarter to 50 cents. Mayor David Dinkins signed bills Thursday making the fare hike _ along with $564 million in new taxes _ official. The fare goes up in three weeks. The ferry takes riders on a seven-mile trip across the harbor, past the Statue of Liberty, between Manhattan and the city's least populous borough. The fare is paid in Manhattan by outgoing passengers. Besides commuters, the ferry is popular with tourists. The last time the price went up was in 1975. Until then, the traditional fare was a nickel, each way.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
NAACP Seeks To Distance Itself From Charges Of `Jewish Racism'
DOC.TEXT: NAACP leaders agreed to meet with Jewish groups angered by a statement that claimed ``Jewish racism'' had kept blacks from being treated fairly in the entertainment industry. While distancing themselves from the remarks, made during a panel session at the NAACP convention here, leaders reasserted their view that blacks are victims of racism in Hollywood. ``We do not agree with the statement, but we do not exercise thought control. I would not invite a panelist here and then say you cannot say this or that,'' said NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks. ``We do have a position that there has been racism in Hollywood. That's proven,'' Hooks told reporters Thursday. ``We don't want to separate it into Italian Americans, or Jewish Americans or Greek Americans. They're all white folk as far as we're concerned, and we've got to sit down and reason together as brothers and sisters,'' Hooks said. The time and place for a meeting will be determined by an NAACP committee assigned to work out the details, Hooks said. The organization also issued a call on Thursday, the concluding day of its convention, to the movie and recording industry for an agreement to bring more blacks, women and other minorities into the entertainment field. Hollywood studios have been reluctant to talk about any aspect of the issue. A telephone poll on Wednesday produced refusals to comment from the major studios, with one executive calling it a ``no-win'' situation. Jewish organizations contacted Thursday said they were satisfied with the move by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Leaders said they agreed with the NAACP stance about racism in the entertainment industry, but said it was ``negative and misguided'' to point at Jews as its source. An official for the Anti-Defamation League of B'Nai B'Rith said any meeting with his group on the issue would only concern the remarks of an NAACP delegate regarding Jews. ``We're not the right address for dealing with Hollywood,'' said B'Nai B'Rith regional director David Lehrer. ``If they wish to discuss the motion picture industry, they should meet with them. We don't represent that diverse industry.'' Marla Gibbs, a producer and star of the NBC sitcom ``227,'' said during a Tuesday workshop session at the convention: ``I think we're all talking about film distribution and marketing based on how the Jewish people and the other people set it up. It was not set up for us. So we have a problem.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Denies Holding, Torturing Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: South Korea today denied allegations in an Amnesty International report that said the country holds hundreds of political prisoners and has tortured some of them. The Justice Ministry said in a statement that since President Roh Tae-woo took office in 1988 no individual has been punished simply for harboring certain political views. ``It is regrettable that without giving any evidence or criteria, (Amnesty International) defined some of those in prison as prisoners of conscience and demanded their release,'' the statement said. In its annual report released Wednesday, Amnesty International charged that South Korea holds about 900 political prisoners and some have been tortured. ``In South Korea, there are no prisoners of conscience as referred to by the International Amnesty report. Those who remain in prison have either violated laws or endangered the very safety of our nation,'' the statement said. It said that many of those defined as ``prisoners of conscience'' by the London-based human rights monitoring group are spies sent by North Korea. It said the Communist nation poses a serious threat to South Korea's security. The two Koreas have been bitter rivals since the division of the Korean peninsula in 1945. Addressing the issue of torture, the statement said two suspects died last year in police custody but that they were isolated cases. Two policemen involved in torturing the prisoners were arrested and put on trial, it said. In its annual world survey of human rights, Amnesty also said thousands of people were imprisoned, tortured and killed last year by governments seeking to suppress conflicts arising from ethnic tensions or nationalist yearnings.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Official Says His Group Approved Meeting With Defense Minister
DOC.TEXT: A PLO official said in an interview published today that his organization approved in advance the first major meeting between local Palestinians and a Cabinet minister in the new Israeli government. The meeting between Defense Minister Moshe Arens and three West Bank Palestinian mayors came after the new right-wing government said it hoped to reach a Middle East peace settlement by talking only to Palestinians not linked to the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel's refusal to give the PLO even an indirect role in peace talks was one reason U.S. efforts to mediate a peace settlement have stalled. Abdullah Hourani, a member of the PLO's executive committee, said in an interview with the Jerusalem Arabic weekly Al-Nadwa that the PLO knew of the meeting ahead of time and received reports on it afterward. ``The PLO endorsed a meeting as a chance for Palestinian national figures to notify the Israeli official that the PLO is the legitimate representative ... for the Palestinian people,'' Hourani was quoted as saying. Mayor Farah Araj of Beit Jala, one of those who met with Arens on June 27, verified the account given by Hourani. ``The content of our talks (with Arens) that the PLO is the only representative is also correct,'' he told The Associated Press today. Mayor Elias Freij of Bethlehem, who also attended the meeting, said Hourani ``has the right to say this'' when asked about the PLO official's comments. Freij, who is regarded as among the most moderate Palestinians, had said after the June meeting that the officials told Arens that only the PLO could negotiate with Israel. The third mayor who attended, Hanna Atrash of Beit Sahour, was not available for comment. After Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir formed the new right-wing government on June 11, officials immediately reiterated the stand that the government would not negotiate with the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. Officials said later that the government's peace effort would focus on trying to open talks with Palestinians who are not part of the PLO, a tactic that has repeatedly failed in the past. ``We are going to make a determined effort to convince our Palestinians here that the PLO option is not available,'' said Yossi Ben-Aharon, a top policy adviser to Shamir. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said last month that any peace talks with Israel need the acquiescence of the PLO. Without PLO consent, Baker said, ``there won't be any dialogue for Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Civil Rights Bill for Handicapped
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with White House reaction; picks up 4th graf pvs, Bush earlier...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate gave final congressional approval today to legislation guaranteeing a full range of civil rights for disabled Americans. The measure now goes to President Bush, who is expected to sign it next week. The Senate passed the bill 91-6 a day after the House approved it 377-28, culminating two years of legislative efforts. The measure guarantees the nation's estimated 43 million disabled people access to jobs, transportation, telephone service and stores, restaurants, shopping malls and other public accommodations. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration welcomed the final congressional passage of the measure. ``We congratulate the Congress for joining us in this landmark legislation,'' Fitzwater said. He said there would likely be a White House signing ceremony next week. ``When the president proposed this legislation, he said disabled Americans must become full partners in America's opportunity society. We consider passage of this important civil righrts legislation to be among the most important accomplishments of the administration,'' Fitzwater said.
