Bush earlier this year urged Congress to speed passage of the bill, which has been called the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1964 act that guaranteed rights for blacks and other racial minorities. Voting against the legislation were Sens. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo.; Sens. Jake Garn, R-Utah, Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., Steve Symms, R-Idaho, and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., Not voting were Sens. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va.; James A. McClure, R-Idaho, and Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo. The vote followed a brief debate that included a speech in sign language by Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, the chief Senate sponsor of the bill. Harkin paid he silent tribute to his deaf brother. Harkin later explained, ``I wanted to say to my brother Frank that today was my proudest day in 16 years in Congress.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said the bill ``ensures that millions of men and women and children can look forward to the day when they will be judged by the strength of their abilities, not misconceptions about their disabilities.'' ``It is a comprehensive piece of legislation that will have a dramatic impact not only on the disabled but on the consciousness of America as well,'' said Rep. Steny H. Hoyer, D-Md., the lead House sponsor of the bill said after the House vote. Hoyer added that Bush ``will be ecstatic to sign this bill with the largest possible crowd he can invite.'' Bush has vetoed other major domestic legislation _ minimum wage and family medical leave. A special commission under former President Reagan had urged a disabilities bill, however. A key supporter has been James S. Brady, the former White House press secretary who suffered a disabling head injury when shot in the 1981 assassination attempt on Reagan. Business, transportation systems and local governments will bear most of the costs of the bill. Supporters say businesses will ultimately benefit by the increased participation of disabled people in the economy, and the federal government will pay less for welfare and special support. The House on Thursday accepted a compromise provision that helps protect the jobs of AIDS-infected workers in food industries, including restaurants. Under the legislation, the Health and Human Services Department must determine which diseases are transmitted by food handling. HHS Secretary Louis W. Sullivan, a physician, has told lawmakers that AIDS cannot be transmitted by handling food. The bill phases in its requirements and exempts businesses with fewer than 15 employees from its hiring requirements. Small businesses would have more time than larger ones to make their premises accessible to disabled customers, but no change would be required that would cause a financial hardship to companies. Transportation requirements, including making all new buses accessible to people with wheelchairs, would occur over years. Amtrak and commuter rail lines will be covered. The cost to supply relay services for hearing- and speech-impaired telephone users would be spread out among all telephone users, adding little to average phone bills, supporters said. The bill does not list disabilities that are covered, saying rather that anyone is disabled who has a mental or physical impairment that limits a person ``in some major life function.'' It also includes anyone perceived as being disabled, such as someone with a disfiguring scar. The bill specifically excludes, however, active drug users and people with mental disorders such as pyromania or kleptomania that could lead to criminal behavior. Although the bill protects people who suffer from AIDS _ large numbers of them homosexuals _ it does not protect homosexuals per se. Still, critics of the bill say the language is so vague that only lawyers can understand it. The bill will create ``a firestorm of litigation,'' said Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., who voted against it. Businesses that repeatedly violate the public accommodations provisions could be fined $50,000 for the first finding of violation and $100,000 for the second. The Justice Department could also seek compensation, but not punitive damages, for victims of discrimination. Sanctions for violating the employment provision are tied to the 1964 Civil Rights Act, meaning a person who is discriminated against may seek a court order, back pay and lawyer's fees.

DOC.HEAD: North Testifies Before Iran-Contra Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Former White House aide Oliver L. North testified for the sixth time today before the special federal grand jury that is continuing to investigate the Iran-Contra affair. The retired Marine lieutenant colonel, who is appealing his three Iran-Contra convictions, has been questioned before the panel by prosecutors working for independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. North coordinated a secret operation to ship arms to the Nicaraguan Contras after Congress banned U.S. military aid when he served as a National Security Council aide in the Reagan administration. The panel has also heard testimony from North's old boss, former national security adviser John M. Poindexter, who was convicted of lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter, who received a six-month prison term but is free pending appeal of the convictions, is expected to give additional grand jury testimony. The grand jury is trying to determine if other Reagan administration officials participated in efforts to deceive Congress about the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and the diversion of weapons-deal profits to the Contras, sources say. It also is trying to perform a final assessment of the roles of then-President Reagan and then-Vice President Bush in the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out in Subway Utility Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters today battled a blaze in a subway utility tunnel under construction that forced authorities to close downtown streets and a heavily-used freeway through the morning rush hour. About 140 city firefighters were battling flames in the 700-foot utility tunnel, said city fire spokesman Pat Marek. The cause of the fire, reported at 1:50 a.m., was not immediately known. Intense heat, smoke and toxic fumes from burning plastic prevented firefighters from entering the tunnel, Fire Chief Lon Pursell said. Fire crews decided to let the blaze burn itself out, he said. The fumes posed no immediate threat to the public, Pursell said. The fire struck a utility tunnel for the Metro Rail rapid transit line that is under construction. Two firefighters suffered minor injuries, Marek said. The fire was contained to the tunnel and no other structures were threatened, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Boatloads of Albanians Reach Italian Soil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th, `Albanians lining....' to CORRECT translation of chant to `We shall win' and inserts 3 grafs after 24th, `The Albanian...' to ADD that West German Embassy closed for renovations. Pick up 25th pvs, `Alia introduced...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BRI1,3
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of exhausted, grimy Albanians reached this Adriatic port today on board a flotilla of ferries that evacuated about 4,500 asylum-seekers from embassies in the hard-line Communist state. The first ship, the Espresso Grecia, arrived this morning after a journey of about seven hours. As it docked, a Red Cross nun in a starched white uniform dashed off clutching a newborn baby in an orange blanket. ``I feel so many emotions, so much liberty,'' said a beaming young woman as she disembarked. Police whisked her away before she could give her name. Albanians lining the decks of three more ships broke into chants of ``Italia! Italia!'' and ``We shall win!'' as they arrived this afternoon. Five ships chartered by West Germany, Italy and France cruised to Albania on Thursday to pick up thousands of refugees who have packed Western embassies in the capital, Tirana, in the last two weeks. The ship chartered by the French, the Orient Star, was cruising directly to Marseille, French officials said. The evacuation was expected to defuse one of the worst crises facing Albania's hard-line Communist government in decades. Many of the Albanians leaving the ships in Brindisi looked stunned. One man crossed himself as he got off the Appia. On the Espresso Grecia, a man swung a baby in a white sweater up and down in glee. Many of the Albanians boarded trains for West Germany after a quick breakfast of hot milk and croissants provided by the local government. ``Everyone off to freedom!'' a refugee cried to his cheering countrymen waving from the windows of a departing train. The arrivals, many of them single men or young families, were sweaty and their clothes were grimy after crowding together for two weeks or more in the small embassies. ``We are all feeling glad,'' said a mining engineer named Muharrem, clutching a foil-wrapped packet of Italian army-issue crackers. ``We are going in the West toward freedom. All the world is going West,'' he said, grinning. ``We want freedom,'' said Arjan Xhaferi, 32, carrying his 5-year-old daughter, Arrisa, on his shoulders. ``I have sacrificed everything _ even my life.'' He said he and his family entered the West German Embassy in Tirana by scaling the wall in the middle of the night. A few people were carried off the ferry on stretchers with foot injuries apparently suffered when they entered the embassies. Albanian police fired at some of the asylum-seekers. The five ships were bringing out about 3,200 people who had crowded into the West German Embassy, more than 800 from the Italian Embassy and about 540 from the French Embassy. The Albanians were transported by bus from the embassies 20 miles west to the port of Durres, where they boarded the ferries, they said. Police ringed the dock to prevent anyone else from jumping aboard, crew members said. Durres is about 85 miles from Brindisi. The Albanians from the Italian Embassy will be transferred to a temporary shelter outside the town. West Germany sent three trains to the dock to pick up the Albanians. Authorities would not disclose their destination. Until today, only 51 of the 5,000 or more asylum-seekers had left Albania. The small group was permitted to leave the Czechoslovak Embassy and take a plane to Prague on Tuesday. Hungary's official news agency reported that 40 Albanians who sought refuge in the Hungarian mission in Tirana would be put aboard a special flight tonight for Budapest. The assault on the embassies and several accompanying demonstrations presented the biggest challenge in decades to the Albanian government. The situation was reminiscent of a rush on foreign embassies in East Germany last year, which contributed to the collapse of that country's Communist system. The Albanian government of Communist leader Ramiz Alia agreed to let the refugees leave the embassy compounds after supplies of food and medicine ran low and hygienic conditions deteriorated. The West German Foreign Ministry in Bonn said its embassy in Tirana had been closed for renovations. ``The embassy is in an inconceivable state,'' said spokesman Juergen Chrobog. He said renovations would ``last a long time,'' and he did not know when the embassy would officially reopen. Foreign Ministry officials have said the resolution worked out for the Albanians who left today included an agreement that seeking refuge in embassies could not become an accepted route for emigration. Alia introduced limited reforms this year, including some religious freedom and travel abroad, which Albanians have not been able to do for 45 years. The crisis in Albania has caused a shake-up in the leadership, but the government has vowed to maintain its Communist line.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Health Advocates: Cost of New Wonder Drug Too High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to CLARIFY that National Alliance for the Mentally Ill not participating in conference but has adopted same position. Picks up 3rd graf, `We're hearing....'.
DOC.TEXT: Mental health advocates are hailing a new drug for acute schizophrenia but criticizing its pricetag _ $750 per month per patient. Groups attending a weeklong convention on psychiatric treatment want Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. to provide more information on clozapine's cost. They also urged state hospitals to buy more. The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill has adopted the same position. ``We're hearing what sound like testimonials at church revivals on the effects of the drug,'' said J. Benedict Centifanti, deputy director of Pennsylvania Protection and Advocacy Inc., a support group for psychiatric patients. Clozapine reduces emotional disturbances and thought disorders in schizophrenics who haven't responded to conventional treatment, said Sandoz, which introduced it in February. ``In some cases recovery is quite dramatic,'' said Barbara Gordon, research director for the state Office of Mental Health. ``In others it's not so dramatic, but even they are showing improvement.'' Unlike other drugs prescribed for schizophrenia, such as thorazine and prolixin, clozapine doesn't cause involuntary facial tremors known as tardive dyskinesia, an irreversible condition in some cases. ``When you take one of those drugs you are rolling the dice,'' said Dr. Janice Guidotti, who held a workshop Thursday at Duquesne University. The workshop was part of a five-day convention attended by 1,000 current and former mental patients and their advocates, whose goals include getting rid of a perceived stigma associated with psychiatric treatment and advancing a nationwide civil rights movement for mental patients. Sandoz Pharmaceuticals of East Hanover, N.J., said part of the reason for clozapine's high cost is the need for patients to undergo weekly blood tests to check for a potentially deadly side effect _ a reduction in white blood cell count. The company estimates 5,000 patients in public and private hospitals in the United States take clozapine. Sandoz Pharmaceuticals estimated up to 2 percent of patients taking the drug could develop the side effect. The price of the drug should drop when more psychiatrists prescribe it, said Dr. Gilbert Honigfeld, a Sandoz spokesman. At a workshop Thursday, Centifanti cited the case of James Angliss, a patient at Western State Hospital in Steilacoom, Wash., who sued for the right to take clozapine. Administrators withheld it because of cost and potential liability. The case is believed to be the first in the United States involving clozapine, Centifanti said. A jury awarded Angliss $600,000 and his mother $60,000 after he was forced to take another drug and developed tardive dyskinesia. The hospital has appealed the case. Pennsylvania will spend $2 million this fiscal year to treat schizophrenics with clozapine in state hospitals, enough for about 220 patients. Gordon said there are 4,500 schizophrenics among 7,000 state hospital patients.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets with President-Elect of Colombia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met today with President-elect Cesar Gaviria of Colombia and praised his ``forthright commitment'' to cooperate with the United States in fighting drug traffic and on other issues. Welcoming Gaviria to the Oval Office, Bush said that in their talks, ``respect is the word here today and friendship.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the two leaders would discuss the war on drugs and the administration's $80.5 million aid request this year to assist Colombia's drug interdiction efforts. Trade issues, including Colombia's complaints about U.S. trade restrictions on some Colombian exports, were also likely to come up, he said. Appearing earlier on the NBC ``Today'' show, Gaviria said the United States ``has not found many ways to help Colombia in this time.'' He said he is looking for help in the areas of trade and commercial assistance. ``Right now we are losing so much in lives and we are incurring so much cost economically and politically,'' Gaviria said. He added that ``if we do not curb the demand for drugs, we are going to have a lot of violence in Colombia and I think that's the engine of the problem.'' Gaviria was elected May 27 when millions of Colombians went to the polls in defiance of terrorist threats following the bloodiest campaign in the South American nation's history. Gaviria became the Liberal Party candidate after Luis Carlos Galan's assassination by drug traffickers on Aug. 18. Gaviria succeeds outgoing President Virgilio Barco, who could not by law succeed himself. Gaviria at 43 will be the youngest man ever to lead Colombia. Gaviria has vowed to continue Barco's fight against drug traffickers. He also called on developed countries to cut cocaine consumption. The major campaign issue was whether to continue the government's tough crackdown on drug traffickers and its policy of extraditing top dealers to the United States for prosecution. Gaviria, an economist, took the toughest position on the drug traffickers and pledged to continue the U.S.-backed crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Criticizes Western Pressure For Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela suggested today that Western nations have no right to pressure African countries to accept democratic reforms. The 71-year-old African National Congress deputy president was speaking in Kenya, where four days of violent clashes between stone-throwing mobs and heavily armed riot police left at least 20 people dead. The rioting began Saturday when the government tried to stop a pro-democracy rally. Mandela made no mention of the riots in his address to 20,000 people at a sports stadium in the outskirts of Nairobi. But he did praised Kenyans who fought for independence from Britain in the 1950s and said: ``What right has the West, what right have the whites anywhere, to teach us about democracy when they executed those who asked for democracy during the time of the colonial era?'' Kenya has accused the United States of fueling the pro-democracy movement and interfering in Kenyan internal affairs. Also today, a Kenyan human rights lawyer who fled his country this week said in London that he fears the government of President Daniel arap Moi will resort to massive violence to quash the pro-democracy movement. Gibson Kamau Kuria flew into London on Thursday morning after taking refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi for four days. Also today, The Standard newspaper reported that police detained six more people in continuing arrests following the riots. The newspaper's acting editor-in-chief, Mitch Odero, went into hiding Thursday to avoid seizure. The reported arrests would bring to 17 the number of people picked up since July 4, when the leading advocates for multiparty democracy were seized. Mandela also made no mention of an open letter to him Thursday by the wives of seven prominent Kenyans who are in detention or went into hiding to avoid arrest for their criticism of Kenya's one-party government. They had asked Mandela to intervene on their behalf in securing their husband's freedom. Mandela's wife, Winnie, however, said in her brief remarks that: ``I speak on behalf of those (women) who waited.'' Nelson Mandela was freed in February after spending 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-minority South African government. Mandela noted Kenya's assistance to the ANC, and he singled out Kenya's 1978 public collection of about $181,000, which Moi later handed over to ANC President Oliver Tambo. Mandela said the ANC still needed ``material and political assistance'' from the international community and Africa in particular. ``We go home determined to fight harder than ever before because we smell victory,'' Mandela said, who is concluding a worldwide tour in which he called on the West to maintain economic sanctions on South Africa. The ANC is the largest group seeking the abolition of South Africa's policy of racial discrimination. Mandela is scheduled to leave Kenya on Saturday for Mozambique before heading back to South Africa in time for his 72nd birthday on July 18.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Calls for More Cooperation from Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 7-8, Quayle ended, with remark on National Guard service. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Lt. Gen. Editing throughout to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will ``do everything a government can do'' to learn the fate of American servicemen missing in action, Vice President Dan Quayle said today. But he said more cooperation is needed from Vietnam. Quayle spoke to the 3,650-member National League of Familes of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia, which is holding its 21st annual meeting in Washington this weekend. ``The fullest possible accounting will continue to be a matter of highest national priority until we achieve success,'' Quayle told the group. ``We will do everything a government can do to recover your loved ones. And, if we discover proof of captivitiy, action will be taken to bring our men home.'' However, he said, increased activities on the POW@MIA issue ``can be fully productive only if Vietnam makes the political decision truly to cooperate with us.'' ``Vietnam can provide the information, historical records and cooperation necessary to resolve the contradictions and unanswered questions which still exist,'' the vice president said. ``Why they don't recognize that doing so is in their own best interest remains a mystery. I again appeal to the government of Vietnam to make the fundamental decisions necessary to resolve this issue.'' Quayle ended his speech on what he called ``a personal note'' referring to a controversy that arose during the 1988 presidential campaign. Critics said he avoided campaign duty during the Vietnam War by joining the Indiana National Guard. ``I did not serve in Vietnam,'' he said. ``And while I have not apologized, and never will, for my National Guard service, I recognize that the members of my generation who served in Vietnam made a sacrifice for their country that was far, far greater than mine.'' Another group, the newly formed National Alliance of Families for the Return of American Servicemen, was holding a forum later in the day on its believe that as many as 5,000 prisoners of war from the Korean war may have remained behind in Chinese and Soviet labor camps and some could still be alive. On the group's agenda was a report on the case of Bill Sowles of Edmonds, Wash., who believes one of the men shown in a film recovered from North Korea 37 years ago may be his father, who vanished on a Korean battlefield in 1951. Their claims are rejected by the Defense Department, the State Department and the National League of Families. ``To the best of our knowledge there is no verifiable evidence that has surfaced to support these claims,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher says. ``We don't believe that there are U.S. POWs in the Soviet Union.'' Lt. Cmdr. Ned Lundquist, a Defense Department spokesman, said the department has documents in its files about such allegations but ``there is no evidence today that leads us to conclude that any of those reports were true.'' The league's public relations director, Betsy Cox, said, ``There is absolutely no intelligence to back up such assertions.'' Sowles, 47, was attending an American Legion meeting in Bellingham, Wash., when he saw a film recovered from the North Koreans by U.S. intelligence agents in 1953, and unearthed more recently by a Seattle television station. It purportedly showed a group of prisoners with their communist captors. One frowning figure caught Sowles' eye. ``My first thought was, `Gee, that fellow looks like my son.' And then it just hit me that that was my dad,'' Sowles said. He said his son, Lewis William Sowles IV, 24, ``is the spitting image of his grandfather.'' Sowles said Dr. Michael Charney of Colorado State University, an expert on identifying Vietnam area remains, studied the film and told him the man in the picture is his father. Willy Sowles, then 32, a medic who had also served in World War II, disappeared when Communist Chinese Army forces overwhelmed the U.S. 2nd Infantry Division in 1951 at the Battle of Kunu-Ri in what is now North Korea. He was never seen again and became one of the 8,000 Americans listed as missing in action as a result of the 1950-1953 conflict. The reporter who unearthed the film, Mark Sauter of KIRO-TV in Seattle, has said that declassified U.S. military intelligence reports show that U.S. officials were told by French intelligence in 1951 that 3,000 American prisoners had been shipped to the Manchurian border with Korea. He said CIA reports in 1951 established the location of secret POW camps in China. Col. Delk Simpson, a retired Air Force officer who lives in Palm Beach, Fla., said that when he was U.S. military attache in Hong Kong in 1954, a refugee gave him a detailed account of American prisoners being transferred from a Chinese to a Soviet train at the Chinese-Siberian border town of Manchouli. Facing skepticism about their stories, alliance members are seeking public disclosure of information in government files concerning POW-MIA personnel from World War II, the Korean War or Vietnam. The bill they support would exempt information that would compromise national security by disclosing sources and methods of intelligence. The League of Families opposes this legislation, saying it could jeopardize Americans who might still be held. Noel Woolsley, legislative director of AMVETS, said that organization also is expected to oppose the bill at its convention next month.

DOC.HEAD: Immigrants Charge Ethiopian Government Holding Jews Ransom
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian leader Mengistu Mariam Haile is denying 10,000 Jews permission to emigrate to Israel as a way to get military supplies from the Jewish state, a leader of the Ethiopian community here said today. The accusation comes amid reports that Mengistu's hard-line Marxist government is teetering as secessionist rebels gain ground in their battle to topple him. An Israeli government spokesman said the claim was untrue. Rahamim Elazar, chairman of the Public Council for Ethiopian Affairs in Israel, said Mengistu was demanding arms from Israel in exchange for allowing more Jews to leave his country for Israel. ``Mengistu is trying to use them for military aid,'' he said. Israel has sought to bring out all of Ethiopia's Jews since immigration was cut off in 1984 when a secret airlift campaign known as Operation Moses was halted after the Ethiopian government learned of it. About 8,000 Ethiopian Jews were brought to Israel in the U.S.-supported, three-month operation. About 15,000 Jews are believed to remain in the North African country. Elazar told The Associated Press that 10,000 Ethiopian Jews were encamped in Addis Ababa after leaving villages in the province of Gondar in hope of eventually emigrating to Israel. The Jews went to the Ethiopian capital after Israel and Mengistu's government resumed diplomatic relations in October, Elazar said. He said his information came from Jews who managed to leave Ethiopia. On Wednesday, the chairman of the U.S. House Subcommittee on African Affairs charged that Mengistu was trying to pressure Israel into supplying Ethiopia with 1,000 cluster bombs. Rep. Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat, was quoted by the newspaper Washington Jewish Week as warning Mengistu not to use Ethiopian Jews to pressure Israel. Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, denied that Mengistu asked Israel to supply him with weapons. He also denied that Ethiopia was placing obstacles in the way of Jews wanting to leave. ``The situation there is so complicated, there is a war there, confusion, famine,'' said Pazner. ``This is the reason they are being held up.'' An Italian newspaper reported Saturday that Mengistu made a secret visit to Israel on July 3 to meet Israeli leaders. Israeli officials denied the report. In January, The New York Times quoted unidentified U.S. officials as saying they strongly suspected Israel had supplied Ethiopia with cluster bombs for it war against the rebels. Other reports said Israel also supplied Mengistu with military advisers, ammunition and spare parts. Israel has denied it supplied cluster bombs to Ethiopia. It has refused to confirm or deny reports of other supposed arms sales under its standing policy of not discussing any weapons deals. A recent article in the independent Hebrew daily Haaretz written by Zeev Schiff, a respected military analyst, said U.S. officials were trying to damage Israel's image by fabricating the reports of cluster bomb sales. The United States has criticized Israeli support for Ethiopia. The U.S. government objects to sale of cluster bombs without Washington's permission since the weapons were developed with U.S. technology.

DOC.HEAD: `Cheers' Star Held for Trial on Cocaine Charge
DOC.TEXT: ``Cheers'' co-star Kelsey Grammer was ordered to stand trial on a cocaine possession charge after failing to enter a drug treatment program. Grammer, 35, made no comment Thursday as Van Nuys Superior Court Judge James Coleman rejected a defense request to give the actor another chance to complete the drug program, said Deputy District Attorney Teri Hutchison. The drug charge could have been dropped after the program. Grammer plays the egocentric, patrician Dr. Frasier Crane in the hit NBC comedy series. He is accused of possessing about a quarter-gram of cocaine which police said they found in the back seat of a patrol car after bringing the actor in on a warrant for an outstanding speeding ticket. Grammer was pulled over April 14, 1988, because his license plate registration tags were expired. The cocaine charge carries a maximum sentence of three years. Grammer, who lives in Van Nuys, has a previous misdemeanor conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol, Ms. Hutchison said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Officials Said Hubble Flaw Clearly Avoidable By Simple Tests
DOC.TEXT: NASA officials said today the flaw that gives the Hubble Space Telescope a fuzzy view of the universe could have been detected in simple, low-cost tests that were not performed before launch. Lennard Fisk, the chief scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the perscription error in the two main mirrors of the $1.5 billion Hubble is so precise that it had to have happened during manufacturing. It is an error, he said, that could have been detected and corrected while the mirrors were being made or after they were assembled into a telescope. ``The error is very large, therefore some simple, low-cost, no-risk test that could have been done could have detected the flaw,'' Fisk said in testimony before the House committee on science, space and technology. Asked why the test was not performed if it was so low-cost and simple, Fisk said, ``We're asking those same questions.'' NASA officials had said in earlier statements that tests to detect the focusing flaw that has disabled Hubble would have required up to $300 million and the construction of a special facility. But Fisk said today that may not have been the case. He said such a facility would have been required for a test of the fully assembled telescope, but that there could have been other, cheaper tests performed that were not done. ``You could have performed tests on the mirrors individually that could have detected this flaw,'' he said. Failure to conduct such tests, said Fisk, ``was a technical decision and not a financial decision.'' Hubble was built in the early 1980s and was launched on April 25 of this year. It was only after it had been in orbit for more than two months that engineers discovered there was a flaw in either the 94-inch primary mirror or the 12-inch secondary mirror that collect and concentrate starlight. The lack of focus has cut the possible research by the telescope by about half, according to most estimates. Fisk said the focus problem will be corrected for the main Hubble camera in 1993 when a replacement camera is flown up to the telescope by the space shuttle and spacewalking astronauts switch out instruments. But that mission will correct the focus for only one of the five instruments on board Hubble. Other corrections will have to wait until 1996 and later. Hubble is designed to operate for 15 years, and Fisk said that with the replacement instruments the telescope will recoup work lost by the focusing error. ``Hubble is not a dud,'' he said. ``Hubble will be capable over its 15-year lifetime to accomplish all the science'' that is expected. Richard Truly, administrator of NASA, said that an investigation committee is now studying records on Hubble and eventually will determine where the mistake was made that allowed a flawed telescope to be launched.

DOC.HEAD: Concert Promoters Threaten To Cancel Convention if Labeling Becomes Law
DOC.TEXT: A group that promotes concerts threatened today to cancel its New Orleans convention this fall if the governor approves a bill that requires labels for explicit records. It was the latest complaint about the bill, passed by the Legislature and sent to the Gov. Buddy Roemer for either his signature or his veto. Under the bill, which would be the first state law of its type, records with lyrics some consider obscene would be labeled and kept from minors. Carl Freed, director of the North American Concert Promoters Association, said in a statement from New York: ``If this bill becomes law, concert promoters, recording artists and community retailers will be driven out of business. They are being made scapegoats by soap box politicians.'' Freed said the association would cancel its convention, scheduled for Oct. 5, if record labeling becomes a law. On Thursday, members of the music industry in Louisiana suggested a program of voluntary labeling to head off the governor's signature of the mandatory labeling bill. ``Our plan is to have every record dealer in the state voluntarily sign a pledge that they will not sell records with explicit lyrics to minors,'' said Shea Dixon, backer of a proposed Grammy Hall Of Fame for New Orleans. ``That's pretty much what's being done now. This just formalizes it.'' The Record Industry Association of America labeling system, which took effect July 1, effectively singles out explicit records, said Freddie Szilagi, manager of Tower Records in New Orleans. According to the pledge to be sent to the governor, record dealers agree not to sell any recording to any minor that either bears the RIAA warning or any other manufacturer-imposed warning, or one that they find should be so labeled. Roemer has until July 29 to decide the fate of the record labeling bill. If he does not sign it or veto it, the bill automatically becomes law.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed After Climbing in Zoo Enclosure
DOC.TEXT: A woman was attacked and killed Friday after climbing into a zoo enclosure with a female rhinoceros and its calf. The woman approached the 8-year-old rhinoceros and stroked it for several minutes, city authorities said. When the young beast neared, the mother's protective instincts were apparently aroused and she went for the woman. The unidentified 29-year-old Swiss woman tried to escape with the help of a zoo attendant but was attacked a second time and fatally injured, authorities said. Police were investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Starts Talks with Mohawks in Land Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that police decline comment on report of officer's death, insert 1 graf after 17th, `Initial reports....' Pickup 18th, `Jocelyn Turcotte...'
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk Indians have opened talks with the Quebec government after a police officer died in a gunfight over plans for a golf course addition on land the tribe claims. But the Mohawks in this town near Montreal swore to keep their barricades up until police leave and they get immunity from prosecution. Quebec's native affairs minister, John Ciaccia, said the two sides held talks late Thursday and agreed to more talks today. ``We've had a very positive meeting,'' Ciacca said. He said Thursday's talks were halted to ``respect the Mohawk tradition of not continuing this type of a meeting after sunset.'' The dispute centers on plans by the Oka town government to build a golf course addition the Indians say encroaches on their ancestral land. Police brought in reinforcements Thursday, bringing to about 1,000 the number of officers in the area. The Mohawks dug trenches and strengthened their concrete-block and barbed-wire barriers with crushed police cars as they prepared for a possible showdown. Dozens of police wearing flak jackets and carrying shotguns were seen patrolling their new sandbagged positions reinforced with concrete blocks. All day Thursday, the two sides faced each other across their barricades, about 200 Mohawks at the top of a hill on the highway that goes through this picturesque town, 18 miles west of Montreal, and the police at the bottom of the hill. ``The police have to retreat completely from the area before we can ever work out a deal with Ciaccia,'' Mohawk spokeswoman Ellen Gabriel said. A Ciaccia aide said earlier the minister was negotiating with members of the Mohawk band council and their Warriors Society, trying to resolve the dispute. Mohawks, wearing camouflage and carrying revolvers, hunting rifles and assault rifles, raised the yellow and red Warrior Society flag over the golf course's immaculate lawns. They commandeered a fleet of golf carts to ferry leaders and messages between encampments. The Mohawks claim title to a small pine forest Oka wants to cut down so the golf course can add nine holes. Police intervened at the request of Oka's mayor after Mohawks refused to tear down a small barricade they built four months ago. Early Wednesday, a raiding force of about 100 Quebec police attacked the barricade. They retreated after Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31, was shot. Police said they were not certain whether he was shot by Mohawks or fellow police. According to a newspaper report today, ballistics tests indicated the bullet was not from Lemay's weapon or from the weapon used by his colleagues. Le Journal de Montreal also said the bullet that killed him pierced his lungs and heart and was found under his right shoulder blade. It said Lemay was wearing a bullet proof vest but the bullet slipped through a small opening under his right arm. Initial reports said he was shot in the face. Montreal police declined to comment on the report. Angele Joyal, a police spokesman, said there would be no comment until the investigation was completed. He also declined to say when the autopsy report would be ready. Jocelyn Turcotte, president of the Quebec provincial police association, came to the lines to talk to his union members. ``We don't want to send our members back in to assault this barricade again, because the Mohawks are heavily armed and it would not be a safe action at this time,'' he said. ``One policeman has already been killed and we don't want another death.''

DOC.HEAD: Bart Simpson's Face Shows up on LSD Stamps
DOC.TEXT: Bart Simpson, the television cartoon character whose image can be found on everything from coffee mugs to T-shirts, is now turning up on stamps of the psychedelic drug LSD. Bart's smirking face has appeared on blotter acid, LSD-laced stamps that are sold in sheets, police said. Michael Borcsok, 21, of Albany, was charged Tuesday with possession of 261 ``hits'' of hallucinogenic Bart Simpson stamps, police said. Another batch of the stamps surfaced last week in Pittsfield, Mass., about 40 miles east of Albany, police there said. ``These stamps are very obviously aimed at young children. Kids love Bart Simpson,'' said Steve Dnistrian, a spokesman for Phoenix House, a New York drug rehabilitation center. Cartoon characters such as Mickey Mouse and Goofy have been placed on blotter acid sheets since the 1960s, when the illegal drug became widely sold.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Names New Washington Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: United Press International has named Berl Schwartz, a former executive editor of the York, (Pa.) Daily Record, as its new Washington bureau chief. UPI spokesman Milt Capps said today no new assignment had been determined for outgoing bureau chief David Wiessler. The news agency also announced the appointment of Edgar Miller, a former managing editor of the Chattanooga, (Tenn.) Times as assistant managing editor for national news.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Undergoes Second Tanking Test
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with test completed, data being analyzed. Picks up 6th graf, ```We're going ...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA partly filled Atlantis' external tank with liquid hydrogen today in an attempt to locate a leak that has grounded the spacecraft and has all shuttle missions on hold. A leak reoccurred during the testing around a valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the external tank to the main engines. Engineers planned to spend the rest of the day analyzing the data and try to pinpoint the source of the leak. ``There's no speculation on exactly how much was leaking or exactly where the leak was coming from, whether it was the orbiter side or the tank side,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. During the testing, super-cold volatile fuel was pumped into the tank. A small amount of hydrogen escaped into a bag around a 17-inch-diameter valve. When the flow was increase, more hydrogen leaked in the valve area. Extra sensors had been placed next to valves, pipes and seals suspected of leaking, with plastic bags covering the components. The contents of the bags will be analyzed in an attempt to pinpoint the leak. ``We're going to a lot of trouble to add numerous points of data collection,'' said David Winterhalter, director of systems engineering and analysis for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A less vigorous test was conducted June 29, during which hydrogen escaped from Atlantis' extensive plumbing system. The shuttle's classified Defense Department flight in mid-July consequently was put on hold. In late May, a hydrogen leak was detected in Columbia while the shuttle was being fueled for an astronomy mission. Columbia was returned to the hangar for repairs. Atlantis remains at the launch pad. The leaks have prompted NASA to ground the three-shuttle fleet. It was the first time the fleet has been grounded since shuttle Challenger exploded in January 1986, killing seven crew members. No shuttle flew for two-and-a-half years after that. Rockwell International, the shuttle builder, has identified Columbia's leak in laboratory tests in California but has not yet found the source in the group of pipes and valves linking the orbiter with the external tank. The space agency encountered more trouble with leaks Wednesday when hydrogen escaped from an unmanned Atas-Centaur rocket during a simulated countdown. The problem quickly was fixed and was considered so minor it would not have delayed Tuesday's launch with a NASA scientific satellite, said agency spokesman Bruce Buckingham. That launch was postponed one to two weeks, however, after problems were discovered Thursday with one of the satellite's two ``black boxes.'' The so-called command decoder units receive ground commands and plug them into the spacecraft's system. ``All they know at this point is it's not returning any information or indicating it's even receiving any information,'' Buckingham said. ``It's just kind of staring back at us.'' The Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite, or CRRES, will study the invisible magnetic and electric fields in space and measure space radiation and its effects on microelectronics. It is a joint program of NASA and the Defense Department.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Agrees on Trimmed Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Armed Services Committee early today approved a $289 billion defense bill that cuts troop strength in Europe by 50,000 and reduces the budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative by nearly $1 billion. In a session that began early Thursday and ended shortly after 1 a.m. today, the panel agreed to an overall budget that is $18 billion less than President Bush proposed in January. The committee, as expected, agreed to the total its chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., had called for in military spending. ``This is a responsible and manageable glide-path toward a major restructuring of the military establishment and the way it does business,'' Nunn told reporters at a news conference announcing completion of the bill. The full Senate is expected to take up the bill just prior to the August recess, and Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on panel, predicted fights over the level of spending for SDI and an Air Force satellite. ``We've postponed the battle to the floor,'' Warner said of the SDI issue. In a surprise move, the panel adopted a measure that reduces armed forces in Europe, an issue left unresolved by U.S. and Soviet negotiators after stalled talks on cutting conventional forces. The panel agreed to a total 100,000-person reduction in military personnel. Nunn has told the committee to draw up legislation around two numbers _ his preferred budget level of $289 billion and the Budget Committee-approved level of $286 billion. Bush proposed $307 billion in defense spending for fiscal 1991, but it has been assumed that Congress would cut the budget. As expected, the committee agreed to limit money for the two land-based nuclear missiles _ the MX and Midgetman _ to only research and development funds. The administration requested more than $2.2 billion for the two missiles but the committee earmarked $548 million for the MX and $202 million for the Midgetman, said the sources, who requested anonymity. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney also proposed canceling the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter and flies like a plane. But the Armed Services panel agreed to more than $200 million in research and development funds for the aircraft. In a politically divisive issue, the panel agreed to eliminate about $1 billion for the Milstar program, an Air Force navigation and communications satellite. The vote in the full committee was 11-9 along party lines, the sources said. The committee significantly reduced funds for the C-17 transport plane and the Navy's A-12 attack plane, an aircraft that has been at the center of controversy ever since the service said it was a year behind schedule. The decision to cut the C-17 program came despite Cheney's revised proposal for the aircraft that called for cutting the purchase from 210 to 120. The defense secretary made that announcement in April. The reduction in SDI to about $3.7 billion cuts the program's budget to about the level Congress approved last year for the anti-missile shield. The 1990 reduction marked the first time since former President Reagan presented the plan seven years ago that the requested funding had been cut. The Armed Services panel also approved a plan that eliminates advanced procurement money for the Trident submarine, a decision that largely limits the program to 18 submarines. Cheney, faced with a diminishing Soviet threat and budget constraints, revised his request for the B-2 bomber to two planes in fiscal 1991 and 75 planes in total. The panel agreed to the secretary's proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Jump 0.5 Percent in First Increase Since January
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A big burst in department store sales last month helped push retail sales up 0.5 percent, the first increase since January, the government said Friday. ``It's a welcome sign for a beleaguered sector of the economy. ... It offers a good deal of hope that the economy will keep on expanding,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Other analysts, however, cautioned against reading too much into the turnaround. They noted that the June increase followed three months of declines in retail sales _ a period of weakness unseen since 1981. ``The question is whether it's a one-time reversal of a string of weakness or the start of something new,'' Sinai said. Retail sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $147.82 billion last month, up $784 million from the May sales level, the Commerce Department said. Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, prolonged weakness in this area raises fears that the economy could be headed for a downturn. June's upturn in retail sales was probably due, in part, to consumers making up for lost ground in April and May, analysts said. Cooler temperatures in May probably resulted in Americans holding off on buying summer clothing, air conditioning and other seasonal items, analysts said. They probably made those purchases in June when the weather warmed up, analysts said. David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill called the June increase ``just a rebound from the softness we saw in May.'' ``We're up only 2.4 percent from a year ago. That's not even keeping up with inflation,'' Wyss said. Americans continue to demonstrate signs of cautious spending, said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``The consumer did not turn tail in the spring, but nonetheless is behaving in a rather restrained way,'' Dederick said. The 0.5 percent increase in June was the first rise since a big 2.8 percent jump in January. After that gain, retail sales showed no change in February and then fell 0.4 percent in March, 1 percent in April and 0.6 percent in May. Last month's increase was led by a 2.8 percent rise in spending at department stores, reflecting a rebound after a big 2.2 percent drop in May. Analysts attributed part of the dramatic increase in department store sales, which had fallen for three months, to price cuts intended to encourage purchases of slow-moving summer clothes. Auto sales edged up a tiny 0.1 percent in June after being down 0.2 percent in May. Weakness in auto sales has been a major factor contributing to the overall sluggishness of consumer spending this year. Sales at building material and hardware stores rose 1.3 percent after falling 0.2 percent in April. Bucking the upward trend in June, sales at furniture and home furnishings stores plunged 1.9 percent. They had been up a slight 0.4 percent in May. Sales at grocery stores were up 0.3 percent while sales at gasoline stations climbed 0.5 percent. Sales at drug stores were up 1.2 percent but spending at bars and restaurants fell 0.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Extremists Claim U.S. Chemical Factory Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grfs after 17th pvs, `We have...' to ADD more company comment; Pickup 18th, `Plant manager...'
DOC.TEXT: An extremist Islamic group today claimed reponsibility for an explosion at a Texas chemical plant July 5 that killed 17 people. Arco Chemical Co. of North America said from its headquarters in Newtown Square, Pa., that it had not heard of the claim and did not know whether it was valid. The cause of the blast is under investigation, and no signs of sabotage at the plant have been reported. A spokesman for the Islamic Liberation Front told The Associated Press the Arco plant in Channelview, Texas, was attacked because the United States supports Israel despite ``its killings and terrorism against our Palestinian families'' in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Washington ``ignores the human rights of our Palestinian people,'' said the official, who met with an AP reporter and spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We want Washington to taste the pain of the deaths of its people the same way we feel the pain of the killings of our Palestinian families at the hands of the Zionist criminals,'' he said. There was no way independently to verify the claim of responsibility. The Islamic Liberation Front threatened two weeks ago to attack U.S. and Israeli interests worldwide to avenge the May 20 massacre of seven Palestinian laborers in a Tel Aviv suburb by an ex-Israeli soldier. The Front is a relatively large group based in the West Bank and Gaza. It has followers in Jordan and several other Arab countries. It advocates armed struggle against neighboring Israel and calls for the elimination of the Jewish state. The Front has opposed Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat since 1983 over his moves toward reaching a settlement with Israel, and hundreds of guerrillas broke away from the PLO. The Front was responsible for an attack on an Israeli army patrol May 17 near the West Bank city of Hebron in which an Israeli soldier was wounded. ``This factory was providing the U.S. Army with chemical equipment, although it was publicly operating as a factory manufacturing supplies for civilians,'' the Front's spokesman claimed. ``One of our unit commanders, operating in the United States of America, informed our headquarters in the occupied territories last Friday that our commrades had set ablaze a Texas chemical factory and that the mission was successfully accomplished,'' he said. He refused to give any further details for ``security reasons.'' The Arco plant, 15 miles east of Houston, was wrecked by the explosions and fire, which leveled an area the size of a city block. Arco spokeswoman Sallie Anderson said from the company's headquarters today that the cause of the explosion had not been determined. She also said she was unaware of any recent threats against the company. ``We have no knowledge of any warnings,'' she said. ``There were no warnings from that group that they were planning to blow up the plant.'' Asked if the company knew why it would be singled out as a target by the group, Anderson said: ``we have no idea.'' She said the company had no dealings with Israel and she disputed the Front's claim that the plant was providing the U.S. Army with chemical equipment. ``I think their statement from what I understand says that we make chemical weapons for the Army and we do not,'' Ms. Anderson said. Plant Manager Earl McCaleb said last week it was believed that ``some kind of work'' was being done on a device that compresses gases before they enter tanks containing flammable hydrocarbons. He did not elaborate. The plant produced propylene oxide, used to make foam for seat cushions and bedding. The substance also is used in cleaning compounds. It also produced styrene monomer, used for insulation, foam drinking cups, packaging materials and automotive parts. Another product was methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high octane blending component used as a replacement for lead in gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: Protester Ordered to Leave King Motel
DOC.TEXT: A woman who has camped for two years in front of the motel where Martin Luther King Jr. died was ordered today to get out of the way of workmen building a museum. Chancery Court Judge George Lewis said he would send in sheriff's deputies at noon Saturday to move protester Jacqueline Smith if she defied his order. Ms. Smith promised to stay. ``Right now, I don't have no intention of moving no place,'' she said as she left Lewis' courtroom. Lewis denied her request to delay the hearing days while she tried to find a lawyer to represent her. He said she has had ample time to find a lawyer. Ms. Smith has been camped on a sidewalk in front of the Lorraine Motel, where she was a former employee and resident, since March 1988. She contends the motel should be used as housing for the homeless, not as a museum. King was assassinated at the Lorraine in 1968. The $9 million museum, called The National Civil Rights Center, is being built by the state, county and city governments. It is to open July 4, 1991. Lewis said Ms. Smith must carry on her protest somewhere other than the museum site. She has refused requests to move to a sidewalk across the street. ``The court has no alternative except to order her out of the way of the construction,'' Lewis said. His order came on a petition from Jameson-Vaccaro Construction Co. Inc., the primary contractor for the museum. Anthony Vaccaro, project manager, said Ms. Smith is camped in a spot that must be torn up for utility lines.

DOC.HEAD: Former Congressman Says He's Advised Neil Bush on S&L Controversy
DOC.TEXT: Former Rep. Thomas Ashley, a longtime friend of President Bush, confirmed today that he's been giving advice to Neil Bush since last winter on the controversy surrounding the president son's role in the collapse of a Denver savings and loan. But Ashley, a banking lobbyist, denied that Bush had asked him to contact his son. ``That is absolutely inaccurate,'' Ashley said in an interview. ``I'm to smart to do that.'' The Denver Post reported in today's editions that Ashley, a college classmate of George Bush's from Yale, had talked to the younger Bush at the president's behest before Neil Bush was questioned by federal banking regulators. The newspaper attributed the report to comments by Neil Bush himself, contained in a deposition taken by the Office of Thrift Supervision. ``If Neil thinks his father called me, he's mistaken,'' Ashley said. Ashley, 67, a Democrat, is a former congressman from Ohio. He is currently president of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, a banking lobbying organization based in Washington. Neil Bush faces a public disciplinary hearing before federal regulators in September on his role as a director of the bankrupt Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan. Ashley said that he contacted Neil Bush on his own last winter after reading about his troubles in the paper. Since then, ``I've seen Neil a half dozen times. We talk about it,'' Ashley said. He said that, although President Bush didn't ask him to contact Neil Bush, the president is aware that he has been counselling the son. Bush has pledged not to get personally involved in the investigation of his son. Ashley said ``I don't think the president has any problem'' with the fact that he has involved himself in the matter. ``What he feels is I'm a longtime friend of Neil's.'' ``Is everyone who is close to the president supposed to stay away from Neil?'' Ashley asked. President Bush ``doesn't go along with that. He rejects that,'' Ashley said. ``I've talked to the president (about the situation) on a couple of social occasions, when we're alone,'' including once at Camp David, Ashley said. ``I talk about the kids. Neil's one of the kids.'' Ashley said that Neil has made his own decisions in the matter. ``What we do is talk about the consequences of one course or another,'' Ashley said. Ashley said that his own experience in politics and in bank regulation make him a good source for advice for Neil Bush. ``The situation is such that he can't go to his father and talk to him,'' Ashley said. ``It's not a partisan matter or he wouldn't be coming to a Democrat,'' Ashley added. ``It's just a situation where somebody he's known for a long time is available and has experience in matters involving regulatory matters.'' ``I'm a good sounding board,'' Ashley added. Ashley said that Neil Bush decided on his own ``not to take the easy way out'' and that he's been the victim of ``a little selective treatment'' from federal regulators. But, Ashley said, ``He hasn't whined or complained about that.'' He said that Neil Bush was concerned that when the Office of Thrift Supervision ``decided to go public'' about the case, ``it only presented its side of the matter. A thousand pages. It didn't include Neil's defense.'' Ashley and Bush have remained close friends since they were both members of the secret society Skull and Bones while they were undergraduates at Yale University in the late 1940s.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO RESTORE GRAPH MARKER AFTER LEDE
Robbers Hold Up Train At Midnight
DOC.TEXT: A gang of thieves forced a train to stop in the middle of the night in southern France, then made off with several sacks from two mail cars, police said. There was no immediate word about the nature or value of the stolen goods. No one was hurt in the robbery, which occurred Thursday night shortly before midnight. A railroad official said at least one robber hid aboard the engine in Marseille when the train was being assembled. About 60 miles out of the Mediterranean port city, the engineer was accosted and ordered to stop the train in the countryside. At least three accomplices were waiting to board. The engineer was ordered to signal on his radio that the train had broken down, and the robbers then took several sacks of mail and drove off in cars. Passengers aboard the train apparently were unaware at the time that a theft was taking place.

DOC.HEAD: East German Factories Agree to Preserve Jobs, Raise Wages
DOC.TEXT: Scores of East German factories agreed Friday to raise wages and preserve jobs for 350,000 metalworkers but said the labor contract may actually speed the collapse of some plants. The one-year pact was reached after a series of strikes by hundreds of thousands of metalworkers around Berlin. It is the biggest labor agreement since East Germany became a free market on July 1. The contract at least temporarily ends one of many confrontations between former government enterprises facing new Western competition and workers demanding better pay to cope with suddenly higher food prices. But while one labor dispute was settled, another arose almost immediately. About 60,000 retail industry workers held demonstrations in a half-dozen cities Friday to protest plans to dissolve the government-run retail chains. East Germany, meanwhile, said it is facing a huge drop in income because of declining production and would need more money from West Germany. Finance Minister Walter Romberg told Parliament that East Germany would have nearly $38.7 billion in expenditures through the second half of this year but only $17.5 billion in income. East Germany merged its economy with West Germany's on July 1 in a prelude to the full unification expected later this year. It is now in the early stages of converting its moribund, centrally planned economy to a market economy. Prices have risen dramatically, and East German companies already are feeling the effects of Western competition. Many East German factories are expected to fail, causing wide unemployment in the coming months. Workers in several industries have staged ``warning strikes'' to press their demands for job protection and better wages. The metalworkers contract ends a bitter confrontation. The contract was negotiated by the powerful West German labor union IG Metall and its East German affiliate and covers 350,000 workers at 164 factories in an area around Berlin. Management said the pact may hasten the closing of enterprises already struggling to meet their payrolls. ``This extensive compromise package is not economically justifiable,'' Lothar Heinzmann, head of the employers group, said in a statement carried by the East German news agency ADN. He called it ``an advance payment for an uncertain future.'' In a statement, the union said the agreement keeps the burden of moving to a free market from being placed ``fully on the workers.'' The contract is expected to set a pattern for other labor agreements currently being negotiated. ``It must be feared that factories will close because of this contract,'' said Christoph Borchelt, spokesman for the employer association, the Association of Metal and Electronics Industries of Berlin and Brandenburg. The agreement raises the annual monthly salary of $666 to $850 through October, then to $880 through April 1, when the wage portion of the contract expires. The job-guarantee section runs through June 1991, after which workers can be laid off. The contract also increases the factories' participation in a government program aimed at heading off layoffs. Under the program financed largely by West Germany, workers targeted for layoffs receive 63 percent of their salaries while remaining in the plants, where they receive training for other jobs. The contract will increase factory participation in the program, raising the salaries of workers targeted by layoffs to 85 percent of their former wages. About 220,000 East German workers nationwide are in such programs and another 240,000 are expected to be added shortly, the government said. About 162,000 workers are unemployed. Negotiations are continuing in other parts of metalworking and electronics industries, a sector that employs 1.6 million of the nation's 8 million workers.

DOC.HEAD: Job Protection Seen as Sticking Point in Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs with conference session; picks up 5th graf pvs, Many members ...; edits pvs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: The House and Senate opened talks on clean air legislation today as a White House aide reiterated President Bush's opposition to giving financial aid to workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The congressional talks lasted only an hour today and are expected to drag on for weeks. Separate clean air bills passed by the House and Senate last spring call for tougher pollution controls on factories, automobiles and electric power plants, breezed through both the House and Senate last spring. Their aim is to curb urban smog, cut toxic industrial releases and acid rain pollution by the end of the decade. But scores of differences will have to be resolved in the coming weeks. A major issue will involved job protection for workers who become unemployed by the tougher pollution controls. The House bill contains a three-year, $250 million assistance program for such workers and the Senate version does not. After today's House-Senate session, Roger Porter, President Bush's chief domestic policy adviser, who will sit in on the talks, said the administration remains ``fundamentally opposed'' to any jobs protection provision and that he would recommend the president veto legislation containing such a program. ``It sets a precedence that we're uncomfortable with,'' said Porter in an interview. Even though no substantive agreements were reached in the first session, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he remained ``hopeful and certain'' that a compromise bill can be worked out with the House before Congress is scheduled to adjourn in early October. Many members of Congress would like to wrap up action on clean air before the November election in view of polls that indicate the environment and clean air are important voter concerns. Environmentalists on Thursday expressed concern that the tight congressional schedule may jeopardize a strong clean air bill, especially if it is held over for final action in a possible lame-duck session after the November election. ``The time for (approving) a good bill is running out,'' Richard Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, said. He noted that in 1976 a clean air bill won approval by both the House and Senate and cleared a conference committee, only to die in the final days of a session because of a Senate filibuster. The issue of job protection has dogged both the Senate and House bills. In the Senate, an aid package for coal miners lost by only a single vote after an emotional appeal by veteran Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. The House approved a less ambitious assistance measure, which calls for spending $250 million over three years in extended unemployment compensation for workers in all industries who lose their jobs to pollution controls. Lobbying by industry as well as environmental groups also is expected to intensify during the talks, as both sides see the conference as a last chance to influence the final law. Neither side completely likes either the House or Senate version. The auto industry is expected to fight the alternative-fuel provision in the House bill. Under it, the industry this decade would have to build 300,000 vehicles that use a fuel other than gasoline as part of a pilot program in California. But a House provision on automobile tailpipe emission controls is preferred by automakers over a similar version in the Senate bill. Requirements in both bills for cleaner fuels in cities with the worst smog problems is strongly opposed by the oil companies as well as the White House because it allegedly favors an ethanol blend over other fuels. Environmentalists will push to retain tougher toxic industrial emission controls enacted by the House because they cover a broader range of small polluters than the Senate bill. Industry argues the House version will drive many small companies out of business. The administration, meanwhile, is expected to seek changes in the House bill that call for new pollution controls for national parks and for specific phaseout requirements for various chemicals that harm the ozone layer.

DOC.HEAD: New Washington Bureau Chief Named at UPI
DOC.TEXT: Berl Schwartz, a former executive editor of the York (Pa.) Daily Record, has been named Washington bureau chief for United Press International. No new assignment had been determined for outgoing bureau chief David Wiessler, UPI spokesman Milt Capps said Friday. In another management change, Edgar Miller, a former managing editor of the Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times, was appointed UPI's assistant managing editor for national news.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. School District Superintendent Says He'll Resign
DOC.TEXT: The superintendent of the nation's second-largest school district says he will resign at the end of the next school year. ``I have served as an urban school superintendent for almost 11 years both here and in another major districts and now feel I would like to consider other major professional opportunities,'' Leonard Britton, 59, said in a letter to the Los Angeles Unified School District's board of trustees. Britton joined the district three years ago. He also served eight years as superintendent for Florida's Dade County Unified School District, the nation's fourth largest. He presided over the Los Angeles district during last year's rancorous teachers strike, the first in nearly 20 years. He also has moved to implement year-round school sessions in a district jammed with classrooms that must accommodate more than 500,000 students. Britton said there are several prospects he would like to pursue once he leaves his $164,555-a-year job.

DOC.HEAD: Speaker Accuses GOP Official of `Raw Partisanship' in S&L Scandals
With PM-Republicans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New material on letter to Thornburgh, editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley accused a Republican Party leader today of trying to politicize the growing savings and loan scandals with ``unrestrained and totally raw partisanship.'' Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, meanwhile, signed a letter seeking a special prosecutor's investigation of a failed Colorado savings and loan where President Bush's son Neil was a director. Foley, D-Wash., responded sharply to comments a day earlier by Ed Rollins, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, who urged party leaders to get on the offensive and blame Democrats for the S&L scandals. In his speech, Rollins said, ``For a few million dollars in campaign contributions, the Democrats sold out the taxpayers.'' Foley said Rollins ``sounded like he was in a panic'' and has demonstrated he is an ``out of control person.'' ``The fact is, he's a political operative, a hired gun,'' Foley said. ``He's there to spread whatever mischief he can. ... Certainly he's not the most composed, rational and fair minded man in town in either party.'' He called Rollins's remarks ``a wild statement'' and ``unrestrained and totally raw partisanship.'' Foley's broadside came as 12 House Judiciary Committee Democrats signed a letter asking Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the $1 billion failure of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Republican House Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia charged the move was politically motivated. ``I am sick of the stench of corruption and hypocrisy which permeates the Democratic Party on Capitol Hill,'' he said Thursday. But Thornburgh said he would consider the request and respond within 30 days as the law requires. In another development Thursday involving Silverado, Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., suggested that a $10,000 donation to the Republicans by developer Ken Good could have been ``hush money'' to block an investigation of the Denver thrift. Annunzio, who has accused the Bush administration of not prosecuting savings and loan fraud vigorously, didn't provide specific evidence to back up his allegation concerning the Nov. 2, 1988, donation. Good, a business partner of Neil Bush and a former shareholder in Silverado, accused Annunzio of ``spreading vicious, false accusations in the public arena without any basis.'' ``No government agency at any level has accused me of any wrongdoing,'' Good said in a statement issued by his attorney. He said the donation was made two yars after he ended his relationship with Silverado. Neil Bush has denied any wrongdoing, and the president has defended the ``honor and integrity'' of his son at news conferences. Neil Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said his client would have no comment Thursday. The Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee said the involvement of the president's son, Good and other political contributors poses a conflict of interest in a Justice Department investigation of Silverado. ``It's a clear-cut case for a special prosecutor,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas, a member of the Judiciary committee who signed the letter. But Gingrich said the Democrats were being hypocrites ``who pretend they care about ethics and then exploit the president's son for their own narrow partisan reasons.'' If the Democrats move forward with their request, Gingrich said he would press for special prosecutors to explore the role of seven current and former Democratic lawmakers in the thrift crisis. Annunzio said officials of the Office of Thrift Supervision made five criminal referrals concerning Silverado to the Justice Department, but the thrift office has refused to give him the names or dates of those referrals. He speculated that one of the referrals could have involved Good. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said the names of any people who might be involved wouldn't be made public since they would be part of a pending investigation. He wouldn't confirm whether Silverado referrals had been made to the department. Good donated more than $90,000 to Republican candidates in the 1987-88 period, including $5,750 for George Bush's presidential bid, the Federal Election Commission said. About $85,000 was given to candidates other than Bush in November 1988 just before the elections. Records show Good contributed $750 in August 1986 and $5,000 in October 1987 to the Bush presidential campaign, said FEC spokesman Scott Moxley. During Neil Bush's tenure on its board, Silverado loaned Good around $30 million that was never repaid. Federal regulators have ordered the president's son to answer allegations of conflict of interest in his role as a director of the thrift. Among others, the regulators allege that he failed to adequately disclose his ties to Good.

DOC.HEAD: State Agrees to $1 Million Settlement in Cadet's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with widow's lawyer saying settlement reached but refusing to say how much. Picks up 4th graf, `Other defendants ...'
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for the family of a police cadet who died after collapsing during the first day of training said today a settlement has been reached in their lawsuit against the state. But lawyer Michael Hashim said he could not disclose the terms of the settlement under an agreement reached with the state's attorneys. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said Thursday he wants the Legislature to include $1 million for Timothy Shepard's family in a deficiency budget to cover costs during the fiscal year that ended June 30. But it was unclear whether the request would also include funds to cover the medical bills of Shepard and the other injured cadets. Shepard's widow, Holly, sued the state and 14 others last December, claiming that ``brutal, inhumane and life-threatening training practices'' killed her 25-year-old husband. Other defendants in the suit included the Criminal Justice Training Council, training academy officials and State Police training officers. Shepard and 15 other recruits in the 50-member class became ill during the first day of training, a hot day in September 1988, at the Agawam training academy. Shepard died two months later. The incident led to changes in the way the state trains police officers.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Exodus From Communist Party Begins After Yeltsin Quits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with delegates approving Central Committee members, Gorbachev's comments as congress ends. Pickup 4th, `Yeltsin...'
DOC.TEXT: The mayors of Moscow and Leningrad today joined populist Boris N. Yeltsin and leaders of the reform bloc of the Communist Party by quitting the party in the first split since the time of Lenin. The dramatic events came as Mikhail S. Gorbachev was wrapping up a personally victorious 28th party congress with adoption of new party rules and the election of new members of the Central Committee. In a secret battot, the delegates approved 412 members of the policy-making Central Committee. ``All those who stand for democracy and socialism, we extend a hand and call for their cooperation,'' President Gorbachev said in a six-minute closing address that drew a standing ovation. The delegates then sang the Communist anthem, ``The Internationale,'' to close the congress. Yeltsin, elected president of the Russian republic in May, announced to a hushed congress Thursday that he was leaving the Communist Party because his new post meant that he could no longer obey only party policies. ``I have to obey the will of the people and their all-powerful representatives,'' he said. ``Therefore in connection with my obligations, I declare my exit from the party.'' By quitting the party, Yeltsin became the first non-Communist leader of Russia in 72 years of Soviet power. As the silver-haired reformer strode forcefully up the center aisle in the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses, delegates shouted ``Shame!'' and whistled derisively. A very few, however, applauded. Gorbachev had no reaction, except to say that Yeltsin's decision would not be discussed at the congress. Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak issued a statement today saying they were quitting the party because of its inability to offer a realistic program for transition to a new society. ``Recognizing all the responsibility before the people and history, we have taken a decision in the situation that arose to leave the Communist Party in order to help create a multiparty system,'' said their statement, released at the Moscow City Council. On Thursday, progressive delegates Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, a leader of the Democratic Reform bloc, told the congress that he and other progressive delegates, including Yuri Boldyrev of Leningrad and Vladimir Lysenko of Moscow, were leaving the party and would form their own independent organization. ``I am empowered to declare a division in the Communist Party, and our intention to form an independent, democratic, parliamentary party,'' Shostakovsky said, announcing the first split in the Communist Party since 1921. Another delegate, Vladimir Polokholo, today announced the formation of another new bloc, called Democratic Unity in the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, designed to chip away at the party's traditionalist bastion. ``The threat of a mass exodus from the party has not been removed,'' he told the congress. It was not clear how many members the bloc might attract, although within 30 minutes of his speech, Polokholo had collected the signatures of 96 sympathetic delegates.
