For Gorbachev, the departure of the enormously popular Yeltsin and members of the Democratic Platform represents a break in the unity among reformers that he has been telling the congress was essential ever since it convened on July 2. ``If perestroika fails, it will be because someone succeeds in splitting the pro-perestroika forces,'' he said, referring to the Russian word for his policy of restructuring the government and economy. Yeltsin's resignation led the Soviet evening television news program ``Vremya,'' whose announcer declared it a ``sensation.'' Hard-liner Yegor K. Ligachev, who earlier in the day had been defeated for the No. 2 party post by Gorbachev protege Vladimir A. Ivashko, hinted that the party was better off without Yeltsin. ``There are people who, in leaving the party, could strengthen it,'' said Ligachev. Gorbachev survived an onslaught by hard-line critics in the congress earlier in the week and was re-elected party general secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Envoy Waits For Word On Possible Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: An Irish envoy waited in vain Friday for word whether kidnapped Irish teacher Brian Keenan would be the European hostage Iran's official news agency says will likely be freed. Hopes of a weekend release diminished as Syrian President Hafez Assad and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, a key figure in arranging previous hostage releases, prepared to fly to Cairo Saturday for a two-day visit. The summit with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak will be the final chapter in a reconciliation between Syria and Egypt that ended a 12-year rift caused by Egypt's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Adrian McDaid, first secretary of the Irish Embassy in Baghdad, which also oversees Irish affairs in Lebanon, flew to Beirut Thursday ``to verify that Mr. Keenan will be the European hostage released.'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported last Sunday that pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremists might release a hostage. It did not say who would be freed, but said it probably would be one of the 10 European hostages. McDaid visited IRNA's Beirut office on Friday and met with the agency's resident correspondent, Mussayeb Naimih. ``We stressed that our sources are reliable and we explained to Mr. McDaid that the hostage to be released will probably be a European national,'' Naimih told The Associated Press. ``He asked us about the reports that said Keenan will be released and we explained to him that our report did not name the hostage,'' Naimih said. Before visiting IRNA, McDaid had spent the day at the Irish consulate in Moslem west Beirut, waiting for the kidnappers or other Moslem leaders to contact him. But consulate sources said no one did. ``I'm here to collect information about the possible release of Mr. Brian Keenan. We don't have official confirmation that it will be him but we are hopeful that it will be him,'' McDaid said. Sources close to the headquarters of the Syrian Army in Lebanon said there were no indications that the release of any of the 16 Western captives was imminent. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, commander of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon, was in Syria, which ``indicates that nothing major is cooking'' for the time being. Kenaan has always been in Beirut for previous releases, when hostages are usually handed over to Syrian Intelligence and driven to Damascus to be repatriated. Sources close to Syrian army command in Beirut have speculated that Keenan will be freed. Keenan, a 39-year-old English language teacher from Belfast, was kidnapped in west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked to the American University of Beirut where he worked. The other Western captives are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Officials and diplomats in Damascus noted Thursday that a hostage release was not likely before Assad and Sharaa return. McDaid said the duration of his stay in Lebanon ``depends on developments.'' No group has claimed to hold Keenan or made any demands for his release. But former hostage Frank Reed, an American educator who was freed April 30, said he saw Keenan two days before his release. He said he had spent almost three years in the same house or room with him and kidnapped British journalist John McCarthy. A group called Islamic Dawn announced Reed's release.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze at Plant Destroys Rocket Fuel Oxidizer
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through a storage area at a Kerr-McGee Corp. plant, destroying 100 tons of a fuel oxidizer used in the space shuttle and military rockets. Authorities credited a new storage system mandated after a disastrous blast at a neighboring plant two years ago with averting a more serious fire or explosion. Fire and company officials say 106.5 tons of ammonium perchorlate was destroyed in the blaze late Thursday. Damage was estimated at $200,000, according to Rick Stater, operations manager at the plant. Kerr-McGee produces about 1,500 tons of ammonium perchlorate per month, according to Stater. Stater and fire officials credited new fire safety regulations with averting a disaster similar to one on May 4, 1988, when an explosion of ammonium perchlorate destroyed the Pacific Engineering Co. (Pepcon) plant a mile from the Kerr-McGee facility. Kerr-McGee and Pepcon were the only companies in the United States producing the critical fuel oxidizer, and the loss of the Pepcon plant left U.S. officials faced with a possible shortage of the critical fuel element. Pepcon has since rebuilt a new plant in Cedar City, Utah. The Pepcon blast killed two people and injured more than 300. The blast rocked the Las Vegas Valley and cause more than $74 million in property damage, primarily in this community of 55,000, some 25 miles southeast of Las Vegas. Following the Pepcon blast, Clark County fire officials imposed strict new fire safety codes at the Kerr-McGee plant. Included was a provision that ammonium perchlorate be stored on separate pads, with concrete walls separating the pads.

DOC.HEAD: No Progress In Talks, But Rebels Willing To Continue
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations to end Liberia's civil war were at an impasse Friday, but the head of the rebel delegation said he was prepared for more talks next week. Thomas Woewiyu, the chief rebel delegate, said he had conferred with the mediation committee of the Economic Community of West African States for two days and was returning to Liberia to report to rebel leader Charles Taylor. ``There has been absolutely no cease-fire and no agreement for an occupation of Liberia by ECOWAS forces,'' Woewiyu said, referring to the organization. But, he said, the rebels were willing to sit down with members of the economic group ``to find a way to peace without any preconditions.'' In the Liberian capital of Monrovia, power had been restored to a small area of the city for the first time in two weeks. The government also said it was sending technicians to power plants to try to resume regular power supplies. Water remained cut off. The road out of Monrovia to neighboring Sierra Leone also was reported open, although numerous government checkpoints made travel slow. The Liberian government's delegation to the talks was led by Senate President Tambakai Jangaba. But Woewiyu and Jangaba did not meet during the current round and did not jointly attend any meeting of the mediation committee. There was no immediate comment from the Liberian government on the talks, which began Thursday. ``It's a waste of time talking to the delegation of the Liberian government,'' Woewiyu said. ``There is no Liberian government.'' However, he said he would return to Freetown for more talks on Monday. Abbas Bundu, secretary-general of the mediation committee, said the talks would resume Tuesday. The rebel delegation commandeered a fishing boat from the rebel-held port of Buchanan to travel to Freetown on Wednesday night. Rebel forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 and since have taken control of more than two-thirds of Liberian territory. They have been advancing on the capital and now are fighting government troops in the suburbs of Monrovia. The guerrillas accuse President Samuel K. Doe's government of corruption, tribalism and suppressing the opposition. They have said they will lay down their arms only after Doe leaves office. Doe took power in a 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. Taylor supports capitalism, but Washington and other governments have questioned his commitment to democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Military Group Claims Responsibility for Bombings
DOC.TEXT: Six bombs exploded Friday, causing damage but no casualties, and an anonymous caller claimed the explosives were planted by military dissidents opposed to President Corazon Aquino. Troops and police went on full alert in the capital following the pre-dawn blasts, which occurred in the tourist and financial districts. Unexploded bombs were also found in cars at the Silahis Hotel and Philippine Plaza Hotel and on two trucks in the Paco district. Three rifle grenades were also found in a plastic bag near the headquarters of an American-sponsored foundation. An anonymous caller told the private television station ABS-CBN the bombs were the work of the underground Reform the Armed Forces Movement. The station said the caller, who claimed to be a military officer, said the bombings were part of a ``test mission'' for new recruits to the organization. The dissident military group led the February 1986 revolt against the late President Ferdinand Marcos, which triggered the uprising that propelled Mrs. Aquino into office. Later, the group turned against Mrs. Aquino and played a major role in at least three of the six coup attempts against her. The most recent was a December coup that left 113 people dead. Earlier, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus said the chief suspects in the attacks were right-wing military dissidents seeking to topple Aquino. Brig. Gen. Marino Filart, chief of the police Capital Command, ordered round-the-clock checkpoints established throughout metropolitan Manila, which has a population of almost 8 million. The military chief of staff, Gen. Renato De Villa, appealed to the public to ``remain calm and go about their usual activities.'' He called the bombings the work of ``a handful of extremists.'' Small-scale bombings have often preceeded coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino, but De Villa said there was no indication of a coup attempt. ``Coup plotters do not have a capability to launch a major attack at the moment,'' he said. Mayor Gemiliano Lopez said the explosions were aimed at discrediting the government and scaring off foreign investors. He said he was calling an emergency meeting of hotel managers, business leaders and private security firms to discuss ways to prevent bombings. Guards were stationed at the entrances of several luxury hotels to check belongings of those entering.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles to Long Beach is a Different Ride Than in 1902
With AM-Blue Line Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The last time a trolley lumbered from Los Angeles to Long Beach was in 1961, when the Pacific Electric Red Car line died of neglect by car-crazed Southern Californians. The Red Cars first rolled on July 4, 1902, when thousands jammed the trolleys for an inaugural ride through scenic countryside and farming communities like Compton. Clean beaches with lively waves, an enormous heated saltwater bathhouse and a growing amusement zone known as the Pike awaited them in Long Beach. Accommodations ranged from fancy hotels to tent camps. In the decades since, nothing at the start, the middle, or the end of the 22 miles of track has remained the same. Only the route of the new Blue Line trains beginning service this weekend is identical. Barely a city a century ago, Los Angeles has become the country's second largest metropolis. Traffic is terrible and the air can be dirty. Police battle street gangs. Its infrastructure is aging and nearing the breaking point. Despite its problems, Los Angeles continues to attract new waves of immigrants. Long Beach has turned from tourism to become a top-ranked seaport, oil producer and business center. But the city also had the state's largest crime increase last year, much of includes ``Kojak,'' ``The Rockford Files,'' ``Baretta'' and CBS' old late-night ``Night Heat.'' With the one-hour ``Top Cops,'' he's entering what is known as ``reality'' TV. In each show, three real police officers recount the most memorable experiences of their careers as each of their stories is recreated, with actors playing the cops. The premiere includes the tale of Paul Ragonese of the New York Police Department's bomb squad, and how he felt when helping disarm a particularly complex bomb containing 15 sticks of dynamite. The bomb was found in mid-December 1986 in an empty abortion clinic in Manhattan. It had been put there by a madman whose target was the bomb squad. The man later surrendered, got a three-year prison term and was out in two, Grosso says. ``I'm really trying to let people understand what it's like'' to be a cop, he says. ``And that those streets out there are telling us every day, `Something ain't working, pal.' '' Despite 14 years in the entertainment business, Grosso's heart, as you might expect, remains with cops. ``One thing you have going in the police department is that any cop, no matter who he is, can get a call, `man with a gun' or `family dispute,' and be right in the middle, his life on the line,'' he says. ``Whereas so many people in this business never take a chance, never go out on a limb, and never understand the camaraderie, never understand what it means to get along with people you work with because you're dependent upon them for your safety.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, July 27-29

DOC.HEAD: Flawed Mspi Gun Permit Law Raises Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to reaise reference to flawed law; SUBS 5th graf, `The law ...' to CORRECT `exemptions' to `exceptions' ^By MYRA HUMPHRIES
DOC.TEXT: The gunslinger of the Old West may be poised for a comeback _ in Mississippi, because of a loophole in a new gun law. On July 1, the state's new gun permit law went into effect. And to the chagrin of the governor, lawmakers and law enforcement officials, it allows most Mississippians to tote concealed handguns almost anywhere _ including sports events, bars and even the state Capitol. An 11th-hour attempt to fix the flawed legislation failed in a special legislative session last month, and law enforcement officials fear its looseness will allow the wrong people to be armed _ and in the wrong places. ``It's the law, and we've got to live with it,'' said Sharkey County Sheriff Joe Ford, president of the Mississippi Sheriff's Association. The law allows Mississippians over age 21 willing to pay $100 for a three-year permit to carry a concealed weapon. The only exceptions are convicted felons, fugitives, drug and alcohol abusers, the mentally incompetent, illegal aliens, those dishonorably discharged from the military, those who renounce their citizenship or those who falsify permit applications. Applicants must undergo background checks, be fingerprinted and photographed. But the background check requirement is indicative of what critics say is the sloppiness of the law. It says that applications are to be issued within 30 days, but the state Department of Public Safety says such checks with the FBI take about six weeks. It's also not clear when the 30-day period is intended to start. And law enforcement officials complain there's no provision for revoking the permits, which are automatically renewable. The law began as a state Senate bill to allow judges to carry handguns. But it evolved in the House into a bill to loosen up an old law that defined a weapon as concealed if any part of it was not open to view. Lawmakers have since admitted they made a mistake. But they failed to pass a cleanup bill at last month's special session. Unless Gov. Ray Mabus calls a special session _ for which there are no plans _ the law stays on the books until the Legislature can act when it meets in regular session in early January. The Mississippi Rifle and Pistol Association, an affliate of the National Rifle Association, lobbied for the passage of the law, but with the understanding that the glitches would be ironed out, said group president David Hawkins. Hawkins said he was disappointed that the cleanup bill was not passed. ``It was a very good compromise .. a bill we all liked and something we could live with. That's what we wanted passed,'' he said. State and law enforcement officials in Mississippi are still assessing what has happened and what can be done, said Cliff Treyens, a spokesman for Mabus. Officials hope to have a solution by the end of the month, possibly before the first of the permits are issued. Applications are accepted only on Wednesday, beginning with this week. On the first day, 426 people sought permits. In 1987, Florida also had to fix a flaw in a new concealed weapons law after lawmakers inadvertently repealed a provision that prohibited people from carrying firearms openly in public. Once the glitch was discovered, lawmakers came back into session to repeal it and are now satisified with the amended law, said Robin Hassler, staff director of the Florida House of Representatives's committee on criminal justice. Lawmakers say Mississippi's law, once it is amended, will be similar to Florida's.

DOC.HEAD: Some Smokers Face Jail Sentences in Nigeria
DOC.TEXT: Nigerians who smoke in public places could be jailed for up to two years under a decree published Friday by the military government. The law, published in Lagos newspapers, prohibits smoking in cinemas, elevators, schools, offices and on public transportation. The new law also limits broadcast and newspaper advertisements for cigarettes, requiring them to include warnings that smoking could cause cancer. Companies that violate the law can be fined and their directors jailed. The health minister, Dr. Olikoye Ransome Kuti, had been campaigning vigorously for such a law for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Organization of Church Publications Protest Baptist Suppression
DOC.TEXT: An organization of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox publications has strongly protested restrictive moves on the Southern Baptist news agency and ouster orders against its top editors. ``We are alarmed that responsible and respected journalists have been penalized and dismissed for their proper reporting of the news,'' officers of The Associated Church Press said in a letter sent to officials of the Southern Baptist Convention. The organization represents 195 periodicals of various denominations and independent religious publications. The letter, dated Tuesday, was sent to the Rev. Morris H. Chapman, new president of the Southern Baptists, who are now controlled by a fundamentalist wing, and to its executive committee. That committee has scheduled a special meeting in Nashville, Tenn., next Tuesday to deal with the chief editors of Baptist Press, Al Shackleford and Dan Martin, who have been put under an ultimatum to resign or be fired. The agency, which serves 38 weeklies of the 14.9-million-member denomination and also about 400 other news outlets, has been prohibited in the meantime from carrying news of the affair. Declaring the steps ``adversely affects the credibility of religious journalism in North America,'' Donald F. Hetzler, executive director of the transdenominational press group, and its president, Mary Lou Redding, wrote: ``What makes this situation especially regrettable is that Southern Baptist Press has earned a high degree of credibility and trust among secular press agencies for its open, balanced reporting of controversial matters.'' Chapman has declined comment on actions against the news agency editors, but said ``the feeling has surfaced ... that there seemed to be a bias that leaned toward the moderate perspective in the convention.'' The letter came as various others, including editors of Baptist weeklies across the country, decried the crackdown on the news agency that was launched by officers of the denomination's now ruling fundamentalist officers. Television journalist Bill Moyers, defending the journalistic integrity of Shackleford and Martin, said a key fundamentalist strategist, Houston Judge Paul Pressler, had ``shamelessly engineered'' the action against them. In a letter to editors of Baptist newspapers, Moyers urged them ``to rise to challenge this vindictive act and the bully who is responsibile. ... He rules the Southern Baptist Convention like a swaggerring Caesar, breaking good men when it pleases him.'' Pressler, reported out of the country and unavailable for comment, is vice chairman of the denomination's executive committee, and has frequently criticized Baptist Press. Moyers, a lifelong Southern Baptist, said the two longtime editors were being ``dumped on the street'' because they ``refused to dishonor their calling ... and refused to be lackeys for Paul Pressler.'' Meanwhile, Nashville attorney Frank Ingraham, a Southern Baptist opponent of fundamentalist tactics, appealed to its executive committee for a fair hearing for the editors. In a letter to the committee chairman, the Rev. Sam W. Pace of Lawton, Okla., Ingraham, protested indications that it would arbitrarily act Tuesday on a ``motion to terminate'' Shackleford and Martin ``without discussion.'' Pleading for a chance to defend them, Ingraham asked if the committee was going to deny Southern Baptists ``the opportunity to judge the reasonableness of your actions'' or ``make a display of raw power.'' ``Certainly, Baptists in the pews of the churches of our convention will call you to account for these arbitrary displays of raw power,'' Ingraham wrote. ``They will ferret out those responsible and ... deal with them appropriately.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Tom Cruise stole the thunder of his Hollywood peers by getting People magazine's annual sexiest man alive award Friday. Cruise's role in the movie ``Days of Thunder'' made him an all-American ``hot-rod hero,'' said the magazine, announcing its sixth annual determination of the world's most desirable male. The sexiest thing about Cruise? ``His eyes,'' says Valeria Golino, his ``Rain Man'' co-star. ``Not their color. His regard _ the way he looks with them. They're very alive.'' He's also ``the boy next door as daredevil,'' the magazine said, detailing his delight for race-car driving and skydiving. Cruise has gone skydiving with current flame Nicole Kidman, who co-stars in ``Days of Thunder'' as a brain surgeon, and with his mother, Mary Lee, the magazine said in next week's issue. Previous sexiest men alive winners are: Sean Connery, John F. Kennedy Jr., Harry Hamlin, Mark Harmon and Mel Gibson. Cruise was nominated for an Academy Award for his role in ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' He also starred in ``The Color of Money'' and ``Risky Business.''

British rock star David Bowie stopped his concert to take up the cause of the rap group 2 Live Crew and its right to produce and perform its music. ``I've been listening to the album by 2 Live Crew,'' he said Thursday night after stopping in the middle of the song, ``Young Americans.'' ``It's not the best album that's ever been made, but when I heard they banned it, I went out and bought it,'' Bowie said. ``Freedom of thought, freedom of speech _ it's one of the most important things we have,'' he said to cheers from the capacity crowd at the Spectrum. ``What's happening is the thin end of a very fat wedge,'' he said. In an incredulous voice, he referred to the banning of certain books by some U.S. libraries. ``I mean there are libraries in this country where you can't read (the novelist) Ray Bradbury or (Ernest) Hemingway,'' said the flamboyant 42-year-old singer. ``That's the end of my speech,'' he said, before finishing ``Young Americans,'' during the third of four concerts here. Authorities arrested members of 2 Live Crew in Florida recently after a federal judge in Fort Lauderdale declared the group's lyrics obscene.

Cable chieftain Ted Turner says the United States should make friends with Fidel Castro. When it comes to Turner's own relationship with actress Jane Fonda, it's pleasure, not business. Commenting about a recent interview he conducted with the Cuban leader, Turner said he never intended for the piece to be hard-hitting journalism. ``Maybe Sam Donaldson would have done a better job, but he didn't get him,'' Turner said. Since Castro didn't do any other interviews, Turner said, ``it's better than nothing.'' Turner's typically saucy remarks came Thursday during a question-and-answer session with reporters at an annual television network media tour, sponsored by the networks. The Cable News Network owner responded to media critics' conclusions that his Castro interview televised last month on CNN was a fluff piece. ``I just asked the questions. I didn't grill him. I've been trying to build bridges all over the world,'' Turner said. ``I think we could really be friends with the Cubans and Castro.'' Seated in the front row of was Turner's sometime companion, Miss Fonda. The actress, who donned dark glasses midway through Turner's talk, was mentioned a few times by the cable czar. Asked why Fonda has not participated in a Turner program, he replied: ``We made an agreement to separate business and pleasure.''

Gay rights protesters climbed onto a stage inches from Princess Diana and demanded the right to raise children in alternative environments. Many of the 2,000 delegates to the 16th International Congress for the Family, which the princess opened, jeered and shouted ``shame'' as the four women and one man marched across the stage on Thursday. The princess blushed but sat calmly, looking composed. The protesters carried pink placards spelling out the message: ``Lesbian mothers are not pretending.'' ``The delegates to this congress are trying to make people believe that lesbian mothers and gay men looking after children are not real families but are pretend family groups,'' said protest leader Danielle Ahrens, 21. ``We are not pretending and we have no lesser values than any other family,'' Ahrens said. The princess' decision to open the four-day congress, which strongly opposes abortion, was criticized by family planning groups. Sharing the platform with the princess at the Brighton Center in this south England seaport resort was Cardinal Basil Hume, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Westminster. In her speech, the princess cautioned delegates. ``In all your deliberations you should remember that the very idea of the human family has many different definitions, and perhaps those who depend on it most _ the young, the old, the sick and the lonely _ can really claim to know its meaning,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Military Officers Welcome Visit by NATO Leader
With AM-Soviet-Party Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senior Soviet military officers on Friday welcomed the visit of NATO leader Manfred Woerner as an important step in resolving differences between the Western alliance and the Warsaw Pact. ``Before, we could not even imagine such a visit, but now things are changing so rapidly that even this is possible,'' said army Gen. Valentin Varennikov, chief of Soviet ground forces. ``I expect this visit concretely to bring our points of view closer together,'' he said. Woerner is the first NATO general secretary to visit the Soviet Union. He arrived Friday evening and said the aim of his visit was to convey a message of peace and friendship to the Soviet Union from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Tass news agency reported. Woerner was greeted at Moscow's Vnukovo-2 Airport by Soviet deputy foreign ministers Yuli Kvitsinsky and Viktor Karpov, as well as ambassadors and charges d'affaires of NATO countries. Only high-ranking officers, all delegates to the 28th Communist Party congress, appeared willing to discuss the trip. ``This is a positive step,'' Lt. Gen. Yuri Alexeievich said during a break in the congress only hours before Woerner arrived. ``It will help stimulate relations between the two blocs and we think these relations should be stronger and stronger.'' Varennikov linked Woerner's visit to the invitation extended to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address NATO members at the alliance's headquarters in Brussels. ``These are historical steps that can bring our alliances closer together,'' he said. Less than a year ago, NATO and the Warsaw Pact were defending the Cold War, but events in Eastern Europe have led military leaders to rethink the role of their alliances. ``I never thought this would happen. We were enemies and suddenly there is a friendly visit of a general secretary of NATO coming to Moscow,'' said Lt. Gen. David Dorogonsky. The medal-laden officer said he thought Woerner's visit would help pave the way for the alliances to work as partners. ``Gradually, the role of the Warsaw Pact and NATO must be transformed into political organs,'' Dorogonsky said. ``I would like to see the Warsaw Pact and NATO be partners, not in war, but in peace, and I expect our two sides will be able to take a big step toward better understanding.'' Added Lt. Gen. Alexeievich: ``The more that people from different countries meet and talk, the more they will be able to solve their problems. I am expecting an improvement in the political climate of Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Communists Gave Haven to Terrorist Carlos, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's former Communist regime apparently allowed the international terrorist Carlos to use the country as a base while he carried out attacks in Austria and West Germany, officials said Friday. East German officials recently announced that Carlos also had found safe haven in their country under the Communist government toppled late last year. Carlos, also known as ``the Jackal,'' has already been blamed for an attack on OPEC ministers in Vienna in Dec. 21, 1975 that left three people dead. The chief public prosecutor's office in Budapest disclosed Friday that Carlos also is believed responsible for the 1981 bombing of Radio Free Europe headquarters in Munich in which four people were seriously injured. The U.S.-funded organization broadcasts reports to the countries of Eastern Europe, many of which were ruled by hard-line Communist governments until pro-democracy revolutions swept the region last year. Asked about the prosecutor's office statement, which was carried by the official MTI news agency, a Radio Free Europe spokeswoman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said no group had been linked to the attack before. The Hungarian statement was the latest in a series of revelations that the Moscow-educated terrorist had operated from at least two former Soviet bloc capitals while terrorizing Western Europe. Carlos, a Venezuelan, remains at large. East German officials recently announced that Carlos also had found safe haven in their country under the Communist government toppled late last year. The first indication that he had been welcome in Hungary surfaced June 27. At that time, Interior Minister Balazs Horvath said that former Communist Party officials provided shelter and training facilities for Carlos, whose real name is Ilich Ramirez Sanchez. One of the documents produced by Horvath to back up the allegations was a letter allegedly written by Carlos to late Communist Party leader Janos Kadar in 1980. ``From our base in Hungary, we have developed our international ties, getting in contact with the revolutions of every nation without any hindrance on the part of the Hungarian authorities,'' the letter purportedly said. State television a week ago showed what it termed the first film footage of Carlos in which intelligence agents tried to persuade him to leave Hungary. Besides alleging that Carlos masterminded the Radio Free Europe attack and the OPEC attack while operating from Hungary, the prosecutor's office also said he was suspected of piling up an arsenal of weapons, explosives and ammunition while in Budapest between 1979 and 1985. ``There is well-founded suspicion ... that Hungarian officials and others provided active support for committing these crimes or were accomplices,'' the chief public prosecutor said. ``Therefore investigations have been ordered.'' Carlos, the son of a wealthy Communist lawyer, also has been linked with a bombing Dec. 31, 1984, in Marseille that killed five people and wounded 41. He is also accused of plotting the 1975 hijacking of an Air France jetliner to Uganda that ended with the Israeli commando raid at Entebbe airport.

DOC.HEAD: The Rise of a Mannerly Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Six months after he squeaked into office, Mayor David Dinkins is taking steady steps toward national political prominence. Attacked in the election as indecisive and fiscally incompetent, Dinkins has netted a string of successes that indicate otherwise. He has balanced a painful budget, salved racial wounds, gracefully escorted Nelson Mandela. And this week came his latest coup: winning the 1992 Democratic National Convention for the city, a prize worth $100 million to the economy and uncountable sums in boosting New York's sometimes beleaguered image. ``He has done excellently. ... There's nothing about his performance that I don't like right now,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said in an interview. ``He's a leader now. He's a national voice right now.'' ``He is doing very well, and I applaud him for it,'' said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, whom Dinkins toppled after 12 years in office. ``There were people who worried about his ability to make decisions on the budget. He has demolished that fear.'' Dinkins is the first black to serve as mayor of the nation's most populous city. He often cites his Marines service as a formative experience in his life. Unlike the voluble and sometimes abrasive Koch, he is a quiet conciliator, a negotiator and a champion of tolerance. ``Ed Koch was a confrontational mayor, a verbally provocative mayor,'' said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. ``Dinkins' verbal skills have been to allay racial fears and urge restraint. This is a great change after Koch.'' Political analysts say some of Dinkins' attraction has simply been the change of tone. And he may have been aided by low expectations. ``People voted for him with hope, but not with much confidence,'' said David Garth, Koch's longtime political media adviser. When Dinkins won November's election by only 40,000 votes, said Garth, ``There was great suspicion'' of his strength. ``The expectations of David Dinkins ... weren't as high as they should have been. He's benefited from that,'' said Cuomo. But he has earned his accolades. Confronted with a huge budget gap, Dinkins responded with $850 million in spending cuts and $850 million in tax increases, mainly income and property taxes. Verdict: ``As good as Koch if not better,'' said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group. ``He handled the budget extremely well,'' said Felix Rohatyn, the financier who engineered the city's recovery from its 1970s fiscal crisis. Next came race relations. Faced with tensions surrounding the Bensonhurst racial killing trial and a black boycott of a Korean grocery, Dinkins asked for prime time on local television. He used it for an impassioned speech urging racial harmony. It was well received. ``As a spiritual leader, he put the black middle class in the forefront, rather than the street radicals,'' said Moss. At times the speech seemed a lecture on civility. ``David in a way is a kindly father figure. He has basically said to the city, `You have to be in by 11,'' said political consultant Norman Adler. Mandela's visit last month was another success. ``No way in the world Mandela would have spent one night in Gracie Mansion with Ed Koch,'' said Moss. But Mandela spent three nights as Dinkins' guest at the mayor's residence. ``The Mandela visit gave David Dinkins an opportunity to position himself as a national and international urban leader,'' Moss added. ``What he's starting to build is a certain kind of respect,'' said Garth. ``In the beginning it was begrudging. Now it's serious respect. If he can get through the next year, that kind of respect can grow into a national image.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Heads to Moscow for Talks with Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl travels to Moscow this weekend in another effort to soothe Soviet concerns about German unification and win approval for a united Germany's membership in NATO. Traveling with Kohl are Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Finance Minister Theo Waigel, whose presence has fueled rumors that Kohl will propose some form of financial aid to the Soviets. Sources in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no new financial aid was in the offing. West Germany has already backed a $3 billion West German bank credit to the Soviet Union to help its economy develop toward an open market. Bonn has also agreed to pay $780 million toward the upkeep of Soviet soldiers in East Germany in the second half of this year. At this week's summit of the world's leading democratic financial powers in Houston, leaders rejected a bid by West Germany, France and Italy to put together a $15 billion aid plan to help the moribund Soviet economy. West German government spokesman Hans Klein, briefing reporters Friday on Kohl's visit, said the visit was ``in support of progressing the two-plus-four talks on the way to achieving a united Germany in the Western alliance.'' The ``two-plus-four'' talks bring together the foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the World War II victors _ the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain _ to work out the international ramifications of German unification, expected by the end of this year. During his visit, Kohl will meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and has been invited to stop Sunday in Stavropol, Gorbachev's hometown. Klein said West Germany considered the invitation to Stavropol ``an especially personal gesture and a good omen.'' The Germanys have already merged their economies and social welfare systems and are working on resolving legal and constitutional issues so that all-German elections and full German unification can take place by December. One of the major obstacles to international approval for German unification has been the Soviets' rejection of membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a united Germany. East Germany was the Soviets' first line of defense against the West, and Moscow has about 380,000 of its top troops stationed there. Klein said Kohl would emphasize ``especially clearly, that our politics are embedded in the area of the North Atlantic alliance and the European Community.'' Kohl's Moscow trip also follows the NATO summit in London, where leaders pledged to reduce both nuclear and conventional defenses in Europe and said they had ``no aggressive intentions'' toward the Soviet Union. They also said NATO would not ``in any circumstance be the first to use force.'' During the NATO summit, the Germans also promised to announce by the fall their plans for troop cutbacks in a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Those Who Fought in Vietnam Made Greater Sacrifice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs `The men ...' to ADD that audience gave Quayle a standing ovation after his speech. SUBS 11th graf pvs `Another group ...' to CORRECT word to belief sted believe
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told families of missing servicemen Friday that he'll never apologize for his Vietnam-era service in the National Guard, but that those who fought made a ``far, far greater'' sacrifice than he. Quayle noted his National Guard service, which became an issue in the 1988 presidential campaign, in a speech opening the 21st annual meeting of the 3,650-member National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia. ``As you know, during the Vietnam era, I served in the Indiana National Guard,'' he said. ``And while I have not apologized, and never will, for my National Guard service, I recognize that the members of my generation who served in Vietnam made a sacrifice for their country that was far, far greater than mine. ``The men and women who served in Vietnam were heroes _ not just because of their deeds of valor _ but because they served at a time when words like duty, honor and country had lost their meaning for many,'' Quayle said. ``For the rest of my life, I will live in admiration of their courage.'' Quayle was given a standing ovation at the conclusion of his remarks. As George Bush's running mate, Quayle was dogged by accusations that he avoided combat duty by joining the National Guard. The issue surfaced again May 9 when some members of the American Legion of Paris boycotted a ceremony commemorating the late President Eisenhower's World War II service as Supreme Allied Commander. The vice president spoke at the ceremony in the French capital. Quayle, who was to speak later Friday to the Republican National Committee in Chicago, also told the POW-MIA group that the ``fullest possible accounting'' of missing servicemen ``will continue to be a matter of highest national priority until we achieve success.'' ``We will do everything a government can do to recover your loved ones,'' he aid. ``And, if we discover proof of captivity, action will be taken to bring our men home.'' He added, however, that U.S. efforts ``can be fully productive only if Vietnam makes the political decision truly to cooperate with us.'' ``The Vietnamese government must realize that cooperation now, to clear up this issue of tremendous national concern, can remove the last vestige of the war and lay the groundwork for improved relations in the context of a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia,'' he said. Another group, the newly formed National Alliance of Families for the Return of American Servicemen, was holding a forum later in the day on its belief that as many as 5,000 prisoners of war from the Korean war may have remained in Chinese and Soviet labor camps and some could still be alive. However, Betsy Cox, public relations director of the larger group, said there was ``absolutely no intelligence to back up such assertions.'' State Department and Defense Department officials also have said there is no verifiable evidence to support such claims. Sig Harbak of Seattle, an organizer of the smaller alliance, said the Defense Department declined an invitation to attend that group's meeting. Alliance members want public disclosure of information in government files concerning POW-MIA personnel from World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam. The bill they support would exempt information that would compromise national security by disclosing sources and methods of intelligence. The League of Families opposes that legislation, saying it could jeopardize Americans who might still be held.

DOC.HEAD: Focus on Hocus-Pocus as Magicians Meet
DOC.TEXT: There's something magical about Friday the 13th for Margaret Dailey. She was married 21 years ago on the date and this year she was transformed into the new president of the Society of American Magicians. The Indianapolis woman becomes the society's magical matriach, governing the group that has an 88-year history and once was led by the legendary master of legerdemain, Harry Houdini. Nearly 1,000 amateur and professional performers of the art of magic have gathered in this city to amaze, be amazed, surprise, be surprised and to share the latest secrets of now-you-see it and now-you don't. Dealers in magic paraphernalia offer up modern miracles ranging in price from a few bucks for devices to make silk handkerchiefs disappear to thousands of dollars to make lovely women appear out of small cages. And in nearly every nook and cranny of the convention site one can see 20-foot flames spring from bare hands, cards and coins levitate, or you can ``pick a card, any card'' and it's certain to turn up in the most unexpected places in the most unexpected way. Dailey, a performer in her own right, is married to past national president of the society, Frank W. Dailey. She unabashedly tells wives of performers, ``If you fall in love with a magician, the magic will never go out of your life.'' Her installation as president became official Friday the 13th, a date that holds no fear for Dailey. She and Frank were married on a Friday the 13th in June 1969. The field of magic has gone and is undergoing a subtle metamorphosis. The trusty old rabbit in the hat has given way to high tech wonders where solid safety pins link and unlink, where the watch in your hand changes time at the magician's command. Electronics and computer miniaturization have replaced trap doors, mirrors and wires. The new technology is a high-priced specialty of Rich Bloch of Collectors Workshop in Washington, D.C. Among Bloch's gadgets is a $135 device that will send a stream of playing cards flying out of your pocket. The image of the tuxedoed dandy who plucked coins and cards out of nowhere and sawed a woman in half has also given way to the modern times with the election of Dailey, who declined to give her age, but is a mother of three daughters and grandmother to 11. There are the superstars who are society members, such as David Copperfield and Harry Blackstone Jr., but most members, according to Dailey, are people from all walks of life who have an interest in magic. Typical of the new breed of magician is Sister Carol Ann, a nun from Stamford who is also an honorary assistant coach for the New York Giants. Sister Carol Ann said she has entertained the Giants before big games with magic, including a special effect that involved burning a $100 bill and restoring it _ without divine intervention. ``They enjoyed that so much, they did the wave for me,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes to Sell Off State Industry in Big Reform Step
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers Friday voted to sell off Poland's state industries, a major step in the Solidarity-led government's 7-month-old program of radical economic reforms designed to build a market economy. The author of those reforms, Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, described the legislation as ``the most fundamental bill ever passed by the Polish parliament.'' The government owns 80 percent of industry in Poland, including steel mills, coal mines and factories. None of the 7,600 state enterprises would be off-limits to privatization, officials said. All citizens will be given ``privatization bonds'' that can be redeemed for company stocks, allowing the estimated 65 percent of Polish families with no savings to become shareholders. The Sejm, or the lower house of parliament, passed the legislation 328-2, with 39 abstentions. The vote came one day after the long-delayed bill reached the floor. A separate bill creating a ministry to oversee the changes passed 266-0 with 22 abstentions. The legislation must still be ratified by the Senate on July 19, but with 99 of 100 senators elected from the non-Communist Solidarity movement, it was not expected to encounter any difficulty. ``This is a foundation of the new economic system in Poland,'' Balcerowicz said after the vote. The Finance Ministry official in charge of privatization, Krzysztof Lis, said there would be problems putting the bill into practice, such as assembling the new ministry and creating a stock market. But, ``wide consensus has been created for privatization, and this is the most important thing,'' Lis said. Before introducing the vote on Thursday, Balcerowicz said the ``ownership changes must be completed more quickly than in any country that has attempted it before us.'' Companies in the best financial shape would be sold first. Those judged unsalvageable will be liquidated and their assets sold off. Still, officials estimated that only a dozen major factories would be privatized in the first year, and even after three years fewer than half would be in private hands. Meanwhile, selling or leasing state stores, boutiques, restaurants and services to individuals _ so-called ``small privatization'' _ is already under way and is expected to be completed by late 1991. Hungary and Czechoslovakia are moving toward selling off their state industries. In Hungary, the new centrist government has sold some enterprises but is taking a cautious approach, hoping to minimize the negative consequences such as unemployment and higher prices. In Czechoslovakia, the government intends to issue coupons this fall that would allow workers to buy their own companies. The main privatization laws are expected next year. Poland, whose Communist regime was replaced by the Solidarity government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in August, in January embarked on a radical economic reform program. The first goal was to stabilize runaway inflation. The program whittled inflation down to 3.4 percent in June, compared with 600 percent to 1,000 percent inflation in 1989. But the social cost has been high _ real incomes have dropped by 30 percent. But the privatization measure was stalled for months because of disputes over how to proceed. Many people feared privatization would benefit only foreign investors or the former Communist elite, who alone would have capital to buy state property. But the government promised to issue all citizens ``privatization bonds,'' which can be used toward the purchase of state-owned property. It also promised citizens would be allowed to buy shares on an installment basis and, in some cases, on favorable credit terms. ``In this way, the idea of citizen's stock ownership will be put into practice,'' Balcerowicz said. In a nod to workers, who under Communist rule came to think of factories as their property, employees can buy up to 20 percent of shares in their own companies on preferential terms. Foreign investment will be at the discretion of the minister responsible for privatization, officials said. The first step in the process will be to convert all state-owned enterprises into joint-stock companies owned in full by the state Treasury, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Cut European Troop Strength, Star Wars Budget
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a $289 billion defense bill Friday that would cut U.S. troop strength in Europe and reduce President Bush's 1991 budget request for Star Wars. The panel, responding to the lessening Soviet threat overseas and economic demands at home, unanimously agreed to slash $18 billion from Bush's proposal of $307 billion in military spending for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. ``This is the most sweeping degree of change we've seen in a defense bill that I've had anything to do with since I've been in the Senate,'' committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said in announcing completion of the legislation. Among the decisions reached in an all-night, closed session that ended early Friday was approval of the administration's request for the B-2 stealth bomber, a significant cut in the MX rail-garrison nuclear missile program and a delay in production of the C-17 transport plane. But the surprise was the committee's action on the issue of the nation's 2.1 million men and women in uniform. The panel, by a vote of 15-5, approved reducing the level of 311,855 troops stationed in Europe to 261,855, a cut of 50,000 by Sept. 30, 1991. In negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing conventional forces in Europe, Bush has proposed cutting the number of U.S. troops to 225,000 _ 195,000 in the central front and 30,000 elsewhere in Europe. The reductions would be achieved within the time frame of a conventional forces treaty, but negotiations between the two superpowers have stalled. The committee also included a provision that would allow Bush to refuse to reduce troops in Europe if he believes the cut isn't in the nation's security interests. The panel approved a total personnel cut of 100,000, more than three times the 38,000 the Pentagon proposed for 1991, and set a fiscal 1995 target of 1.6 military personnel, a reduction of nearly 475,000 from current levels. Faced with increasing demands on the money usually earmarked for defense, the committee cut $972 million from the administration's request of $4.7 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as Star Wars. Last year, Congress approved the first reduction in the program since President Reagan introduced the anti-missile shield seven years ago. Amendments to change the SDI figure are certain once the bill reaches the full Senate just before the August recess, lawmakers said. ``Even if it's technically feasible ... no one has a chart showing how you pay for it,'' Nunn said about Star Wars. Responding to recent signals from the Air Force that the B-2 stealth bomber is its top priority, the committee approved the Pentagon's revised proposal for two of the radar-evading aircraft in fiscal 1991. But clashes over the bomber, now estimated at a cost of $860 million apiece, are expected on the Senate floor. While approving the B-2 money, the committee slashed more than $1.6 billion from a plan to move MX land-based, nuclear missiles from fixed silos to railroad cars. The panel earmarked only $548 million in research and development money for the program and $202 million for the single-warhead Midgetman missile. A floor battle also is expected over the committee's decision to kill the Milstar program by eliminating the administration's budget request of $1.3 billion. The Air Force program of a communications satellite was to be the U.S. command and control system for a nuclear war. The committee also: _Deferred procurement of the C-17 transport plane because of development and testing delays, for a savings of $1.8 billion. _Trimmed $150 million from the more than $400 million request for the LH helicopter and directed the Army to postpone full-scale development and fly a prototype first. _Eliminated procurement funds for the A-12 aircraft for a savings of $1.5 billion. _Approved $238 million in research and development money for the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft Bush proposed canceling. _Deleted all new funds for chemical weapons production. _Killed an Energy Department request for $65 million to build a new plutonium facility at Rocky Flats, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Says Hubble Probe May Last Into Next Year
LaserPhoto WX16
DOC.TEXT: The head of NASA's investigation of the Hubble Space Telescope's blurred vision said Friday it may take more than six months to pinpoint the error but that the probe should reveal what went wrong and who was responsible. Dr. Lew Allen, chairman of the NASA review panel, told a House panel the results of the investigation could prove ``very embarrassing'' to those responsible for the flaw. ``We are confident we have the ability to find the error'' and determine responsibility, he said. Allen, making his first congressional appearance since the probe began, testified before the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology. The most likely problem, Allen said, is an error in the curvature of the telescope's primary 94-inch mirror that makes it impossible to properly focus the $1.5 billion observatory. The margin of error is microscopic to the human eye, but enough to make the telescope's vision no better than quality observatories on the ground. The mistake makes it impossible to focus light from all parts of the mirror onto one point. Dr. Lennard A. Fisk, a NASA associate administrator, said the focus problem will be corrected for the main Hubble camera in 1993 when a replacement camera is flown up to the telescope by the space shuttle and spacewalking astronauts switch instruments. But that mission will correct the focus for only one of the five instruments on board Hubble. Other corrections will have to wait until 1996 and later. ``The error is very large,'' said Fisk. ``Therefore some simple, low-cost, no-risk test could have been done that could have detected the flaw.'' Asked why such tests before the telescope was assemble were not performed, Fisk said, ``We're asking those same questions.'' Allen said the instrument used to measure the mirrors when they were constructed nearly a decade ago _ a null corrector _ has been ``untouched since it was used'' and was impounded by the review panel. ``If there was an error in the corrector it would cause the primary (mirror) to be configured wrong,'' he said. Committee Chairman Robert A. Roe, D-N.J., said Allen's probe could be too narrow and not lead to broad changes in the way NASA manages complicated programs and tests complex equipment. But Fisk, the chief scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said, ``If we stop at the findings of Dr. Allen's panel, then we will not have done our job. We won't stop at that.'' Fisk said he would determine if any management changes should be made and would agree to having another panel of outside experts examine the agency's management system, but only after Allen's review panel concluded its work. Allen said the null corrector that measured the primary mirror also was used to measure a 60-inch demonstration mirror for the telescope project. That allows investigators to test the measuring instrument to see whether the corrector caused the problem. But all of these tests will be time-consuming, Allen said, and he told the committee the probe will take ``perhaps six months or more.'' ``We know the most likely outcome from our investigation,'' he said, will be findings that are ``very embarrassing to someone or some group.'' Members peppered Fisk with questions on why the mirrors weren't tested after the entire telescope was built. Although Fisk cited technical reasons for the decision, NASA officials had said in earlier statements that such testing would have required up to $300 million and the construction of a special facility. The testing, Fisk said, would have been ``extremely complicated. It was questionable whether it would yield the information we wanted. And it ran serious risk of contaminating'' the mirrors for measuring ultra violet rays _ a function that was not affected by the focus flaw.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Yeltsin Maneuver `Interesting'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush offered a guarded assessment Friday of Boris Yeltsin's leaving the Communist Party. ``Boris bolting his party _ very interesting development, very interesting,'' Bush said, declining to comment further. Yeltsin, the maverick populist of Soviet politics, stunned thousands of delegates to a Communist Party congress Thursday by announcing he was quitting the party. It was a sharp blow to the unity of the badly fractured party.

DOC.HEAD: County Fined for Missing Federal Court Deadlines
DOC.TEXT: Nassau County must pay a $180,000 fine for failing to meet deadlines for ending ocean dumping of sludge, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Friday. The county, under a court agreement, had been required to award two sets of contracts by May 15 _ one to acquire sludge dewatering equipment and a second to build sludge dewatering facilities. Failure to award the contracts triggered penalties that accumulated at a rate of $2,000 a day from May 15 through June 13, then $10,000 a day from June 14 through June 25, the EPA said. Nassau has paid the $180,000 into an escrow account. Had the county begun building its sludge dewatering plant by June 30, the penalties would have been forgiven. EPA Regional Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff said the penalties will continue building and will reach $420,000 on July 25. Nassau is one of nine areas in New York and New Jersey that dump more than 8 million tons of sewage yearly into an Atlantic Ocean site 115 miles off New Jersey. The eight other authorities are on or close to schedule for ending their ocean dumping, the EPA said.

DOC.HEAD: City Finally Delivers Award Promised in 1926
DOC.TEXT: It was 64 years late and not quite as billed, but New Orleans finally made good on a promise to a 13-year-old boy. Louis May, now 77, tied with a girl named Leola Molbrough in 1926 for first place in an essay contest about why the city needed an air field. A $20 gold piece had been designated for winner. Mayor Arthur O'Keefe said that, out of gallantry, the gold piece would go to the young lady and a duplicate gold piece would be awarded to May. May never got it, and probably never will. But on Thursday, acting Mayor Dorothy Mae Taylor presented May with a certificate of merit from the City Council and a gold-sealed paper proclaiming July 12, 1990, as Louis May Day. Taylor said she was bent on recognizing May after reading a July 6 story about him and his never-awarded prize in The Times-Picayune. She apologized for not giving May the $20 gold piece. ``But with the financial constraints of the city, it just wasn't possible,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Foley Lashes Back at GOP Official for S&L Attack
With AM-S&Ls-Neil Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley responded sharply Friday to Republican official Ed Rollins' attempt to blame Democrats for the savings and loan mess, calling him a panicked, ``out of control person.'' Rollins, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, told the Republican National Committee in Chicago a day earlier, ``Democrats sold out the taxpayers.'' He urged the party to get on the offensive about the S&L disaster, which could cost American taxpayers $300 billion or more by some estimates. Foley, D-Wash., called the remarks ``Mr. Rollins' emotional ravings'' and added, ``It sounded like he was in a panic. ... It was sort of a running doggerel of political invective.'' He said Rollins had made ``a wild statement'' and ``unrestrained and totally raw partisan accusation.'' Foley's strong words were in contrast to his normally reserved demeanor. He noted that Rollins' million-dollar contract with the party to head its congressional campaign committee has been controversial among Republicans. He said Rollins demonstrated he was ``sort of an out of control person'' by earlier statements that he would continue to attack Democratic congressmen on taxes even though President Bush has called for a tax increase to reduce the budget deficit. ``The fact is, he's a political operative, a hired gun,'' Foley said. ``He's there to spread whatever mischief he can.'' ``Certainly he's not the most composed, rational and fair minded man in town in either party,'' he said. Rollins, in his remarks in Chicago, said he was responding to Democratic attacks concerning the S&L situation and frequent mention of Bush's son Neil who is under investigation for his role as a director of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan in Denver. Rollins said Democrats in Congress resisted early Reagan and Bush administration efforts to clean up the troubled industry because of the financial support they were getting from S&L interests. Foley, in his response, said he could think of no attack by Democrats on the issue that compared in partisanship to Rollins's remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Base Celebrates Anniversary By ``Invading Panama'' Again
DOC.TEXT: One successful military invasion deserves another, or so say officials planning a second ``attack'' on Panama to celebrate McChord Air Force Base's 50th anniversary. The highlight of Saturday's day-long show of military might is a re-enactment of the December invasion. The event is billed as a ``joint services air power demonstration,'' complete with explosions and strafing runs, paratroopers dropping from the sky and planes zooming in from overhead. ``We in this office never intended to call it the Panama re-enactment, but a lot of the planes and (some troops) that are jumping did actually participate in the real invasion,'' said Maj. Art Dearing, an anniversary coordinator. ``It's the same general attack scenario we used in World War II, in Vietnam, in Panama and in Grenada,'' Dearing said Friday. Still, an earlier press release promised ``the most spectacular event'' of anniversary celebrations would be a ``re-enactment of the invasion of Panama, with the actual aircraft, aircrews and soldiers who were there participating!'' The action at the base south of Tacoma begins with a simulated bomb run by an A-10 Thunderbolt, followed by a fake strafing run by a Canadian Air Force CT-33. Charges will be planted in the ground for the explosions, Dearing said. After the area is cleared of the ``enemy,'' an Air Force combat controller team will jump from 6,000 feet but not open their parachutes until 1,000 feet above the ground. That will be followed by more simulated bombing and a drop of simulated heavy equipment and ammunition and more control team members. The finale is when C-141 transports drop 150 Army Rangers from nearby Fort Lewis onto the field. The Rangers belong to a unit that went to Panama, where they jumped from only 500 feet in seizing the Rio Hato military airfield, Dearing said. But there will be some major differences between ``Panama II'' and the original. No one will be standing in for Gen. Manuel Noriega, who as a result of the real attack is in custody in Florida on drug-smuggling charges. Nor will the ``attackers'' be shielded by the cloak of night from the enemy. The event begins in mid-afternoon. There won't be an enemy, either, just onlookers on what is expected to be a clear, sunny day. The base expects around 100,000 people to attend the simulated attack, Dearing said. ``I would say the controversy over Panama or Panama II has increased interest,'' he said. ``And it's free.'' About 625 Rangers from Fort Lewis flew out of McChord to participate in the real thing. Two were killed and 36 injured in the Dec. 20 pre-dawn assault and subsequent action.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Indicates Jailed Opposition Leader Won't be Released
DOC.TEXT: A leading dissident under house arrest since last July will not be released next week as scheduled, the military indicated Friday, and warned her party not to try to declare a government despite its landslide election victory. Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, head of military intelligence, said the junta would not yield to international pressure for the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and a transfer of power to her National League for Democracy. Suu Kyi, the charismatic daughter of Burma's foremost independence hero, was placed under house arrest July 20, 1989, for one year. The junta said then that the sentence could be renewed. Khin Nyunt said Suu Kyi would be allowed to hold a religious ceremony at her home on July 19, indicating she would remain in detention the day her intial sentence is to expire. July 19 is Martyrs Day, the 43rd anniversary of the assassination of Suu Kyi's father, Aung San. The junta detained Suu Kyi after she said she would lead an anti-government rally to commemorate her father's death. She has never been formally charged. The pressure to release her and threat of economic sanctions amounted to ``undue interference in the internal affairs of our country,'' Khin Nyunt said. ``We do not care at all about such threats,'' he said. In the election, the National League trounced the main pro-military party, winning 396 of 485 parliamentary seats. But the junta has said the National League must approve a constitution before it can govern. ``The (junta) is a military government ruling the country under martial law. No attempt for a unilateral declaration of government will be tolerated,'' Khin Nyunt said. The junta suspended the constitution when it seized power by brutally crushing a national uprising for democracy in 1988. In the past, it has said the new parliament could choose between two previous constitutions or draw up a new one. The National League has said it wishes to adapt the constitution of 1947. That constitution was adopted when Burma gained independence from Britain a year later. But Khin Nyunt said ``both the 1947 and 1974 constitutions are no longer adaptable to the country's present situation.'' ``Hence an entirely new constitution which would not entail legal problems arising out of its shortcomings must be drawn,'' he said. Western diplomats in Rangoon say the insistence on the constitution is a ploy to cling to power. Khin Nyunt said the junta would hold talks with political leaders only when all election expenses and objections had been cleared by the Elections Commission. He said Suu Kyi was being detained ``according to the law,'' and that she had been treated leniently. ``Though she is restricted to her home, all facilities are being provided for,'' he said. She has been allowed to receive parcels from her British husband through the British Embassy, Khin Nyunt said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Encouraged About Chances of Civil Rights Bill Agreement
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday chances of reaching a compromise with Democrats on legislation to combat job bias look encouraging and his optimism was echoed by sponsors of the bill. ``As I leave here for the weekend, I hope I'm right in saying it looks like we can work something out on that,'' Bush said as he boarded a helicopter for his Camp David, Md., retreat. Sponsors say the measure is needed to redress setbacks handed to the civil rights movement by the increasingly conservative Supreme Court. But the bill has drawn fire from the business community for a provision that would make employers end disparate, or lopsided, hiring practices or prove in court that they were justified by business necessity. Much of the negotiations have focused on the definition of the ``business necessity'' that would be required. Business critics and the Bush administration say the provision would prompt companies to hire on the basis of minority quotas to insulate themselves from lawsuits. Bush's comments came as reports swept Capitol Hill that White House chief of staff John Sununu and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., had reached agreement in weeklong bargaining over terms of a bill to combat job discrimination. Kennedy stopped short of confirming a deal existed but said he expected one next week. Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said unless a compromise materialized by Tuesday he would try to cut short debate and push the bill through over White House objections. Some conservative Republicans remained cool to the latest proposals, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, a leading critic, said again Friday the bill would amount to ``a bonanza for litigators'' and said it would have to be modified considerably. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment on the job to a process for imposing punitive damages in discrimination cases _ a feature business dislikes. Bush stopped to take a few questions on his way to the helicopter en route to Camp David. He said that ``Sununu was back today and had a fairly, I would say, reasonably optimistic proposal.'' ``My position on that one remains clear,'' Bush said. ``I want to sign a civil rights bill. I will not sign a quota bill. And that's about where we are, but I think it's looking encouraging.'' Bush said he ``saw Ted Kennedy down here yesterday and had a chance to share my views with him once again.'' ``And he's been working, I would say, quite cooperatively with us, the Republican side,'' Bush said. Kennedy told a news conference he believed ``we can successfully conclude an agreement next week. ... Because of the involvement of the administration and bipartisan efforts, substantial movement has been achieved. We're dramatically closer.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Disabilities Act, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which President Bush is expected to sign as soon as next week:
DOC.HEAD: DEFINITION:
DOC.TEXT: Any physical or mental impairment that substantially limits a ``major life activity'' _ caring for oneself, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning and working. Anyone perceived as having a disability is covered _ a person with AIDS, for example. But AIDS is also covered because of federal court decisions dealing with the disability provisions in fair housing laws and laws governing recipients of federal money. People with the history of a disability _ a former cancer patient or former illegal drug use, for example _ are also covered.
DOC.HEAD: EXCLUSIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Current users of illegal drugs. Homosexuals, bisexuals, transsexuals, transvestites. Pedophiles, exhibitionists, voyeurs and those with other sexual behavior disorders. Compulsive gamblers, kleptomaniacs, pyromaniacs. Anyone with a mental disorder resulting from current illegal use of drugs.
DOC.HEAD: EMPLOYMENT:
DOC.TEXT: After two years, all businesses with 25 or more workers are covered. Coverage expands after two additional years to all businesses with 15 or more workers. Employers may not reject applicants or fire current employees on the basis of disability. Businesses must modify or buy equipment or devices or provide helpers _ such as readers for blind workers _ to help the worker overcome the particular disability. Businesses are exempt if the accommodations create an undue financial hardship, which is determined case by case. Victims may seek back pay, reinstatement and attorneys' fees.
DOC.HEAD: PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Public accommodations must be made accessible to disabled patrons 18 months after the bill takes effect. Such public accommodations include hotels, restaurants, theaters, auditoriums, convention centers, doctors' offices, pharmacists, retail stores, public transportation terminals, museums, libraries, parks, zoos and recreation centers. Businesses with 25 or fewer employees and gross receipts of $1 million or less have six additional months to comply; those with 10 or fewer employees and gross receipts of $500,000 an additional year. All new facilities must be made accessible.
DOC.HEAD: TRANSPORTATION:
DOC.TEXT: All new buses, rapid rail vehicles or light rail vehicles used in public transit must be wheelchair accessible. Existing vehicles need not be refitted, but key stations and all new stations must be made accessible within three years. All new cars for Amtrak and commuter rail systems must be made accessible. One car per train must be made accessible within five years. Privately owned intercity bus companies would have to acquire accessible buses within six or seven years, depending on the size of the company.
DOC.HEAD: TELECOMMUNICATIONS:
DOC.TEXT: All telephone companies must provide relay services for hearing-and speech-impaired customers with three years.
DOC.HEAD: FOOD HANDLERS:
DOC.TEXT: Employers could reassign employees with certain communicable or contagious diseases from food-handling duties. However, employers could only reassign workers with diseases the Department of Health and Human Services determines can be spread through contact with food. The provision was adopted after an unsuccessful attempt to make it possible for AIDS-infected workers to be reassigned. The government says AIDS is not spread through contact with food.

DOC.HEAD: Dance Group Sues NEA Over Obscenity Certification Requirement
DOC.TEXT: A dance group is suing the National Endowment for the Arts' because of its requirement that grant recipients promise not to create obscene works. The Bella Lewitzky Dance Foundation filed a lawsuit in U.S. District Court on Thursday claiming the restriction is unconstitutional. In May, the New School for Social Research filed a similar lawsuit in New York. ``The NEA has now taken on the role of art censor. And that's precisely the wrong role for goverment,'' choreographer Bella Lewitzky said in a statement. Lewitzky last month rejected a $72,000 NEA grant, which would have accounted for about 8.5 percent of the 12-member modern dance troupe's budget, said spokesman Allen Wallace. In New York, a hearing has been scheduled July 31 for the New School's challenge, which questions the constitutionality of loyalty oaths. The school is a parent of the Otis-Parsons Art Institute. The NEA declined comment on the latest lawsuit. The uproar over funding erupted in Congress last year after conservative groups protested federal support of art shows containing photographs they considered obscene. In the 1990 funding bill for the NEA and the National Endowment of the Humanities, Congress banned support for work judged obscene that did not meet high artistic or scholarly standards. The NEA responded to the bill's provision by requiring grant recipients to sign a statement promising not to create obscene works. Of more than 2,000 grant offers sent out requiring the statement, about 700 have been returned, the NEA said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders Reconsideration in NYNEX Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ordered a district judge on Friday to reconsider his denial of a request by NYNEX Corp. that it be allowed to distribute telecommunications equipment to other companies. The ruling by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia marks another turning point in the battle by the seven regional Bell telephone companies to escape restrictions placed on them in the 1984 breakup of the old Bell System. The appeals court said U.S. District Judge Harold Greene, who continues to oversee the consent decree that effected the Bell breakup, failed to properly address the competitive issues raised by New York-based NYNEX's possible entry into the telecommunications distribution business. The 1982 consent decree under which NYNEX and the other regional Bell companies were created prohibited them from engaging in the long-distance, equipment manufacturing and distribution businesses, among other restrictions. NYNEX in 1985 asked Greene for a waiver to allow its wholly owned purchasing unit, NYNEX Materiel Enterprises Co., to distribute telecommunications products to customers unaffiliated with NYNEX. Greene denied the request. NYNEX appealed to the higher court. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., along with a host of other telecommunications equipment manufacturers, filed briefs with the appeals court arguing against NYNEX. The appeals court Friday left little doubt that it looked favorably on NYNEX's waiver request. ``Under our reading of the decree, which differed in some important particulars from that of the district court, it may well be that NYNEX is entitled to the relief it seeks in this case,'' Circuit Judge Laurence H. Silberman wrote. The basis of the consent decree restrictions is the fear that the Bell companies may use their positions as monopoly local phone service providers to impede competition or that they may make their captive local phone customers foot the bill for new ventures. The appeals court said it saw ``significant merit'' in NYNEX's argument that since thousands of companies are competing in the telecommunications distribution market that its entry therefore would be ``competitively benign.'' NYNEX this year has been hit with a federal indictment for allegedly violating the consent decree's restrictions on providing computerized information services. The Federal Communications Commission also fined NYNEX a record $1.4 million for allegedly overcharging customers through its Materiel Enterprises division. NYNEX has denied any wrongdoing.
