The Wall Street Journal reported this week that NYNEX also is being investigated for allegations that suppliers for NYNEX's New York Telephone helped pay for bawdy parties and prostitutes at annual conventions involving Materiel Enterprises employees. Greene previously has lifted some of the restrictions on the Bells' provision of information services and non-telecommunications products and services, but he has refused to ease other line-of-business restrictions. The Bell companies currently are waging an intense campaign in Congress to get some of the remaining restrictions eliminated. The Senate could vote on lifting the manufacturing restrictions this year.

DOC.HEAD: Owner of Mobile Home Court Bans Pizza Deliveries
DOC.TEXT: Hold the anchovies, and the delivery man. Tenants of a Lawrence trailer park have been told to head for a restaurant, not a telephone, if they want a pizza. Wayne Lacy, manager of Brookwood Mobile Home Community, has banned pizza deliveries because he says pizza truck drivers go too fast through the park. Residents were told this week that they would get a warning for the first delivery and their leases would be terminated after the second. Lacy said residents have been complaining about speeding pizza trucks for two years. ``I'm through with it,'' Lacy said. ``I've had too many cussings from drivers, too many complaints from the tenants. There just won't be any more pizza deliveries.'' Mark Pitner, a counselor with Consumer Affairs Association, said some Brookwood residents have complained about the ban. But the ban appears to be legal because leases at the park carry a 30-day limit. ``Because it's a month-to-month lease, and all he's doing is terminating the lease and not evicting residents. He can do that,'' Pitner said. ``That's something we'd like to see changed in the Kansas Landlord-Tenant Act, but it's legal.'' About 200 of Brookwood 265 units are occupied.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Delay On Promised Proposals To End War
DOC.TEXT: Chances of settling the 12-year war in Afghanistan have slipped because the Soviet Union has not come through on its promise of new proposals on the future of President Najibullah, the Bush administration said Friday. The issue is the main sticking point in peace negotiations. Otherwise, the United States and the Soviets are in basic agreement to hold elections and take other steps to end fighting between Najibullah's forces and Moslem guerrillas. The Soviets, who had troops in Afghanistan from December 1979 until February 1989, are reluctant to undercut Najibullah; the Bush administration supports the guerrillas in trying to get him to yield power promptly while elections are held to form a new government. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze agreed last month in a meeting in Berlin to try to work out a compromise solution. The Soviets were supposed to send experts on Afghanistan to Washington for talks before Baker's meeting next week in Paris with Shevardnadze. But the Kremlin did not send the experts here, and Baker leaves on Monday for the French capital. U.S. officials said the Soviets, their senior policy-makers preoccupied with the 28th Communist Party Congress, apparently had not decided what to do about Najibulah. ``They'll be turning their attention back to those kinds of issues now,'' said a senior U.S. official, who demanded anonymity. He said Baker would try to get an answer from Shevardnadze at their meeting next week. The main purpose of Baker's trip to Paris is to hold talks on German unification with Shevardnadze and the foreign ministers of Britain, France, West Germany, East Germany and Poland. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev failed to resolve major differences over Afghanistan at their summit meeting in Washington in early June. But the two sides made headway since then. Baker told the House Foreign Affairs Committee on June 14 that ``the one thing'' that continues to separate them is whether Najibullah would preside over the government in Kabul during a transition period that would include elections. The Bush administration argues that elections held while Najibullah is still in charge would not be accepted by the Afghan people. During the final years of the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, U.S. officials expressed confidence that Najibullah and the Afghan army would collapse once the Red Army departed. That forecast turned out to be way off the mark. The Soviets left massive arsenals behind and are providing $4 billion in military aid and $1 billion in economic aid. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, senior military adviser to Gorbachev, said during the summit that the United States now fully understood that Najibullah would not be defeated militarily. Last February, Baker persuaded the Soviets to agree that elections should be part of an overall settlement to the war in Afghanistan.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Bill Awaits Governor's Action
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer said Friday he will not sign the nation's strictest state anti-abortion bill, but may allow it to become law without his signature. A state official, meanwhile, said the bill would even outlaw IUD birth control devices. ``I've gone from three options to two. I will either veto the bill or allow it to become law without my signature,'' Roemer said in a statement. He has until July 29 to decide whether to veto it. Roemer said that although the bill provides exceptions for pregnancies resulting from rape and incest, he was not happy with provisions of the legislation and the way the Legislature passed it during the closing days of its session. Roemer, who originally requested a 30-day period in which a woman would be allowed to report a rape and have an abortion later, said he was not happy with the bill's seven-day provision. He also said he believed the bill did not do enough to protect a woman's mental health. ``It's an issue that gives me great concern,'' he said. ``It's part of the discussion of how complex this is. At the very minimum, the mother's physical health has to be taken care of. Mental health of the mother is a legitimate point of discussion and has always been a concern to me.'' The bill calls for up to 10 years in prison and fines of up to $100,000 for doctors who perform abortions. Roemer vetoed a measure that allowed exceptions only to protect the life of a mother. The Legislature hastily assembled and passed the measure that Roemer now says he won't sign. The governor, pro-choice advocates and some lawmakers have expressed doubts whether the bill would pass court muster. The measure sent to Roemer originally was a bill calling for a maximum $25 fine for people who assault flag burners. The Senate stripped of those provisions and amended it into an anti-abortion bill. Louisiana Attorney General William Guste said Thursday he sees nothing wrong with the anti-abortion measure. ``If in fact there were any procedural irregularities, which we do not concede, then these were certainly cured by the adoption of the bill by more than a two-thirds majority in each house,'' he said. An assistant state attorney general, Jennifer Schaye, said the bill would prohibit the use of intrauterine devices, or IUDs. The metal or plastic devices are implanted by a physician in the uterus to prevent a fertilized egg from attaching itself to the uterine wall. Guste agreed, saying: ``Technically, this would be a violation because the premise is that life begins at conception and the law says any instrument or device used on a female constitutes the simple battery of abortion.''

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Freeze Office Expenses of Former Presidents
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Friday to freeze spending on office expenses of former presidents amid complaints they are millionaires who already receive generous pensions. ``With this government tottering on the financial brink of disaster, taxpayers in this country might wonder about the sanity of forcing them to give a half a million dollars each to four wealthy men who are already collecting $107,000 each in pensions,'' said Rep. Andy Jacobs, D-Ind. The action came on amendments to a $20.7 billion appropriations bill for fiscal 1991 spending by the Treasury Department, Postal Service, the office of the president and independent agencies. The bill provides new authority for the U.S. Secret Service to join the FBI in investigating savings-and-loan fraud. It authorizes 300 new Secret Service agents _ a 50 percent increase for the agency _ to join the 600 FBI agents at work in the S&L scandals. The Secret Service, while known for protecting the president, has long been responsible for investigating counterfeiting and securities, credit card and computer fraud. The bill, approved on a 300-72 vote, goes to the Senate. Jacobs, a frequent critic of taxpayer spending on former presidents, tried to amend the bill by slashing all office expenses for former presidents, totaling nearly $1.6 million. But the House voted 300-91 to amend Jacobs' amendment so that it freezes the office expenditure at 1990 levels. That represents a cut of 8 percent, $156,000, in the total spending on former presidents, including their $107,300 a year pensions. Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan receive pensions and benefits. Rep. Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif., floor manager for the appropriations bill, opposed Jacobs' attempt to slash the presidential spending but supported the freeze. It ``sends a message we're looking at this thing very carefully,'' he said. ``They should be prudent in the expenditure of funds.'' The bill contains other provisions that send that message, too. It orders the Treasury Department to report to Congress on how to reduce federal spending on travel by former presidents and their spouses when they are being paid to give speeches, including whether the government should seek reimbursement. It authorizes the Secret Service to accept private contributions to offset the cost of protecting former presidents when they make paid appearances or speeches _ something it can't accept now. The action came among expressions of dismay over payments to former presidents while they use their status to rake in large amounts of money. Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said some former presidents ``look more like retired royalty than retired presidents.'' ``We've got plenty of needs for money that we don't have to pile extra benefits on top of benefits her for people that don't need them,'' he said. The bill's overall spending amounts to an increase of $2.3 billion over 1990 levels and $7.8 million over what President Bush sought in his budget proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Release Japanese Fishing Vessels Held for Two Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Tass report. Picks up 6th pvs, `The foreign...' Minor editing thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Twelve North-Korean flagged, Japanese-owned fishing vessels and their crewmen left a Soviet port Friday where they had been held for two months for poaching Soviet salmon, the Foreign Ministry said Friday. The Soviets released the boats after demanding North Korea take measures to prevent future fishing violations, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said. The boats were heading toward the North Korean port of Hungnam, where they would be examined by Soviet inspectors to determine how much compensation the North Koreans would have to pay for the illegal fishing. Tass said North Korea guaranteed payment of $3 million in bail, pending discussion of the incident. In Moscow, the official Soviet news agency Tass said the ship's captains estimated their ships were carrying 500 tons of fish, worth about $8 million. The ships have North Korean officers, but about three-quarters of their crews are Japanese. The Kyodo News Service reported in late May that 10 North Korean ships were seized May 19-22, with 202 crew members _ 140 of whom were Japanese. The Japanese fishermen had been held since mid-May by the Soviets on Shikotan, a small island in the Kurile chain just off the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is unclear when the vessels will be allowed to sail for Japan. Japan's consul general in the Soviet port of Nakhodka strongly protested that the vessels were headed for North Korea and not Japan. The foreign ministry had said earlier crewmen were afraid of going to North Korea and wanted to return directly to Japan. Japanese coast guard vessels were dispatched to the area to try to monitor the voyage. Acting foreign ministry spokesman Shigeo Takenaka said North Korea promised to return the 169 Japanese fishermen ``without delay'' after they arrived in Hungnam. The seizure of the boats led to an unusual tug-of-war between the Soviet Union, North Korea and Japan over fishing in salmon-rich waters off the Soviet coast. It also accentuated tensions between Moscow and Communist North Korea. Those ties have been strained by a recent thaw in Soviet relations with pro-Western South Korea. Japan has a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union and there is a quota of salmon Japanese vessels can take from Soviet waters. North Korea has no fishing quota agreement with the Soviet Union but its fishing vessels were sometimes permitted to fish for salmon in Soviet waters. Experts said the informal arrangement enticed Japanese operators to put their vessels under the North Korean flag and take more salmon than permitted under the Japan-Soviet agreement. Japan and North Korea have no diplomatic relations and Japanese authorities are examining the ties between Japanese and North Korean fishing operations. Officials at one of the companies that leased boats to the North Koreans said they were optimistic the vessels would soon return to Japan. But a relative of Kazuo Yoshida, chief engineer aboard one of the boats, said: ``I cannot help but remember the case of the Fujisan Maru.'' In 1983, two Japanese fishermen were arrested, tried for espionage and sentenced to 15 years in prison in North Korea after Japan permitted the defection of a North Korean who had stowed away on their boat, the Fujisan Maru.

DOC.HEAD: Census Will Count Military as Residents of Home States
With AM-Census
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau will count overseas military personnel as residents of their homes of record rather than as residents of their last duty station, a lawmaker said Friday. ``Wisconsin's population count will increase by approximately 12,000 under this new policy, and that's good news for my state,'' said Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., who chaired a hearing on the progress of the 1990 census. ``It's also good news for many other states who wouldn't have gotten a fair count under the previous policy,'' he said. The Defense Department has estimated there are between 600,000 and 700,000 active duty soldiers stationed oversees, according to a committee staffer who spoke on condition he not be identified further. That does not include dependents or civilian military employees. The Census Bureau had planned to count overseas military and civilian Defense Department personnel and their dependents as residents of the last state in which they had lived for at least six months.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Considers Barring Recent Immigrants from Donating Blood
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is considering barring all new U.S. immigrants from giving blood for a time after their arrival to further protect the nation's blood supply from AIDS, an official said Friday. The ban is one of several proposals the FDA is considering to replace a policy that prohibits blood donations indefinitely by immigrants from Haiti or sub-Saharan Africa, which have high AIDS-infection rates. Haitian and black African immigrants have criticized the current policy as discriminatory because it singles them out. An FDA advisory committee recently recommended the agency change the policy. ``Our intent was never discrimination,'' said Paul Parkman, director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research. ``The advisory committee said we shouldn't use national origin as a criteria, so one of the ways we can do that is not to single out people from a geographic region, but (impose) a blanket deferral,'' Parkman said. The proposal would be less restrictive than the current policy, since Haitians and sub-Saharan Africans would be able to donate blood after the deferral period. The length of a possible deferral period has not been determined, but he said, ``we have kicked around a couple of years.'' It needs to be long enough to cover that period of time during which a person infected with the AIDS virus still tests negative. That window is believed to be about six months.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of the 28th Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of the 28th Communist Party congress, which closed Friday after meeting for 11 days:

GORBACHEV VICTORIES: Mikhail S. Gorbachev was easily re-elected party leader, succeeded in getting his protege, Vladimir Ivashko of the Ukraine, elected as his deputy, and pushed through a proposal to revamp and decentralize the party's Politburo to include as members the first secretaries of the 15 Soviet republics.

BIGGEST LOSER: Yegor K. Ligachev, the traditionalist standard-bearer and most-vocal Gorbachev critic on the Politburo, was resoundingly defeated in his bid to become the deputy party leader. He also lost his seat on the Politburo and Central Committee. Ligachev, 69, said he plans to go back to his village in Siberia and write a book.

CONSERVATIVE CRITICISM: Conservative delegates, led by Ligachev, launched fierce attacks on Gorbachev throughout the congress and accused his leadership of cowardice and indecision in the economy, politics, the military and foreign policy. Yet, the speakers themselves displayed no new ideas and no alternative to Gorbachev.

REFORMERS WALK: Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and members of Democratic Platform, the party's reform bloc, announced in the waning days of the congress that they were leaving the party. The exodus shattered the unity among reformers that Gorbachev said is necessary for the success of perestroika.

PUBLIC REACTION: Hundreds of thousands of anti-Communist coal miners went on strike July 11, ignoring an appeal from the congress to stay on the job. At two Moscow rallies, demonstrators shouted for the end of communism, with a protester at one of the rallies spitting at a delegate leaving Red Square. Muscovite Igor Smirnov said on Day 3: ``I don't care about this congress. I'm sick of hearing about it. They talk, talk, and there are no changes.''

HIGH DRAMA: There were two dramatic moments: on Day 1, when coal miner Vladimir Bludov stood up nine minutes into the congress and called for the party leadership to resign; and on Day 10, when Boris Yeltsin strode into the Palace of Congresses and stunned a hushed crowd by saying he was quitting the party. The speech drew derisive whistles and shouts of ``Shame!''

LIGHT MOMENT: On Day 9, a relaxed, smiling Gorbachev read out a brief note congratulating delegate Anatoly D. Kravchenko on the birth of his son. The Soviet leader then asked playfully: ``Are we going to discuss what to call the son or not? And then vote on it?''

KEY QUOTES: ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go.'' _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on Day 3 of the congress, answering reporters' questions on what should happen if there are no improvements in the lives of Soviet citizens.

``We are witnessing a congress of living corpses. The people are afraid of many things, but the party is not one of them.'' _ Mikhail Malyutin, member of the Democratic Platform, in an interview with the independent Postfactum news agency on Day 8 of the congress.

DOC.HEAD: After Blaming an Exotic Islander, Dart Suspect Set for Psychiatric Checkup
DOC.TEXT: The man charged with blowing darts at women in skirts claimed innocence and said the real Dartman came from an island where provocatively dressed women are tossed into volcanoes, a prosecutor said Friday. Jerome Wright, 33, was ordered to undergo psychiatric evaluation by Criminal Court Judge Harold B. Beeler after police at a hearing disclosed the rambling, incoherent statement he made after being arrested for the attacks. The evaluation will take place at Bellevue Hospital. Wright, who did not enter a plea at the hearing, is due back in court Aug. 8. At least 55 women reported being attacked in midtown Manhattan by a man who blew darts at their backsides. Not all the darts hit their mark, and none of the women were seriously hurt. Wright was arraigned on two counts of criminal possession of a weapon; two counts of reckless endangerment; and two counts of harassment. He could face up to seven years in prison if convicted on all charges. Wright told police the Dartman could be from an island where they shoot darts at women ``who wear provocative and inappropriate clothing.'' The women on this island, Wright said, without naming the island, sometimes are thrown into volcanoes. Wright also told police that he'd experienced ``a great deal of trouble with women in the past,'' including a girlfriend who dumped him five years ago, said Assistant District Attorney Thomas Shields. Wright, a messenger and mail room clerk, made his comments to police after he voluntarily arrived at a police precinct for a lineup before Dartman victims, Shields said. He was arrested Thursday. Wright, who has a history of psychiatric problems, detailed for police his interest in women's legs, Shields said. All the Dartman's victims were wearing skirts when they were stung with the homemade darts, created with sewing needles or straight pins wrapped in paper. Defense attorney Robert Wolf insisted his client was innocent. ``There's no physical evidence which connects Jerome Wright to these crimes,'' said Wolf. ``He denies vehemently that he did this.'' ``His schedule permitted him to be in the areas where the events took place,'' said Shields. The attacks began on June 26 and continued into this week. He was charged in only two attacks, on July 2 and July 3. Police said Thursday that most of the victims could not identify the assailant because he struck from behind. Wright was on probation for a drug conviction at the time of his arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Plans Trips To Indonesia, Singapore
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will travel to Indonesia on July 27 for talks with delegates attending a meeting of the six-nation Association of Southeast Asian Nations, it was announced Friday. Baker also will travel to Singapore for a July 30 meeting on Pacific economic cooperation. He also is considering a trip to Mongolia after the Singapore meeting but officials said no final decision has been made. In Indonesia, Baker will confer with his ASEAN colleagues as well as foreign ministers from other countries with close ties to Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Still Mum On Support For Specific Tax Plan
DOC.TEXT: President Bush kept mum Friday on where he stands in the congressional negotiations over $25 billion in tax hikes to help shrink the massive budget deficit. ``I see a lot of speculation and a lot of people saying what we will or won't do or what they will or won't do _ Republicans and Democrats, and look, I understand that,'' Bush said. However, the president said he has promised not to discuss details of the budget negotiations while they are underway, and that he would not violate that pledge. ``And at some point,'' Bush said, ``I may have to go out and say, `Look, this is all we can do,' or `Here's where we go.' But I'm not going to do that now.'' Budget negotiators from the White House and Congress expect to begin trading offers by early next week on about $25 billion in tax increases for next year. Republicans could send Democrats the first package of proposed tax hikes by Monday, sources said. One GOP negotiator said the plan probably will contain boosts in excise taxes, perhaps on alcohol and tobacco products, as well as a cut in the capital gains tax rate. It is unlikely to contain a boost in income tax rates, which many Republicans have adamantly opposed, the official said. Negotiators are searching for at least $50 billion in spending cuts and tax boosts for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, to shrink a budget shortfall that will otherwise hit at least $160 billion. Bush spoke with reporters as he headed for his helicopter on the White House South Lawn to go to Camp David for the weekend. He stopped to read a statement urging the House, in a vote on Tuesday, to approve a constitutional amendment eventually requiring a balanced budget. Bush said House passage of the measure would send ``a good signal'' to the budget negotiators. He said the balanced budget amendment ``would halt the steady buildup of the national debt. I think it will bring much-needed discipline to the process _ discipline on the executive branch, discipline on the legislative branch, on the Congress of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Rockport Residents Battle Smithsonian Over Money
DOC.TEXT: This seaside colony whose charms have attracted many artists has found itself fighting a court battle with the Smithsonian Institution over a bequest in a millionaire sculptor's will. Franz Denghausen, the sculptor and poet who lived in Rockport for 36 years, left $1 million town upon his death to replace the town's small, turn-of-the-century Carnegie Library. But the Smithsonian, which also benefitted from Denghausen's will, contends the money can only be used to operate the new library, after the town uses its own money to build it. The existing one-story library building is overcrowded with books, and lacks space for additional collections granted in memory of Denghausen's wife, Luisita. So the town wants to use Denghausen's bequest to convert a former elementary school into a new library. The town library trustees contend the Smithsonian is attempting to block the building of the library so it can obtain the town's $1 million. The Smithsonian already is expected to receive $4 million to $5 million from the Denghausen estate. It also received $3.8 million from Luisita Denghausen's estate after she died on Jan. 19, 1986. The issue is now before an Essex County Probate Court. Denghausen, who was childless, died Oct. 17, 1987. The Smithsonian and town library trustees disagree over the interpretation of a passage from Denghausen's will that said the money is intended ``for the purpose of providing an adequate replacement for the now obsolete Carnegie Library.'' The will said the money would be granted ``provided that the town contribute the land upon which such a library is to be erected or provide the funds for the renovation of some building now owned by the town....'' Residents at the December 1988 Town Meeting voted to give a former elementary school land and building to the trustees for conversion to a library. Residents also voted to spend $15,000 on plans for the new library. Town officials said that without the $1 million from Denghausen, the town cannot afford a new library. ``At this point, the Smithsonian is vigorously trying to prevent the town of Rockport from being able to accept this gift,'' said Ted Reed, chairman of the Rockport Library trustees. But Elaine Johnston, the institution's assistant general counsel, defended the Smithsonian's action. ``The actions proposed by the town seem inconsistent with the terms imposed by Mr. Denghausen, and the Smithsonian feels a responsibility to ensure that his wishes are carried out,'' she said. The state Attorney General's public charities division supports the town. ``The overall purpose of the gift is to provide a replacement for the now obsolete library, not for subsequent operating expenses,'' the office of Attorney General James Shannon wrote. ``Frankly, we do not understand why the Smithsonian has chosen to take such an adversarial position. It does not seem right that such a large, federally supported, national institution is trying to prevent a small town from upgrading its public library,'' said Reed. The Smithsonian's annual budget is $225 million from the federal government and $91 million from trust funds. The Rockport library's annual budget is $147,000.

DOC.HEAD: 19th-Century Farmhouse to be Moved for Newspaper Plant
DOC.TEXT: Preservationists are unhappy over plans by Richmond Newspapers Inc. to dismantle and move a 19th-century farmhouse that is standing in the way of the company's $195 million production plant. ``If that decision is carried out, it will prove to be a very unpopular one,'' said Robert B. Giles, an official with one of 12 Richmond-area historical groups battling the company over the house's fate. RNI announced Thursday that Lockwood, the suburban Hanover County farmhouse that was Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee's field headquarters for four days in 1864, will be dismantled and moved to a new site 12 miles north. The house, built in the early 1800s, stands within 50 feet of where RNI is building its new production plant. RNI and its parent company, Media General Inc., said the house will be given to a Richmond couple who have signed an agreement to reconstruct it. The estimated cost of the project is more than $50,000. RNI will provide a grant up to $50,000 once the reconstruction begins, said J. Stewart Bryan III, publisher of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader. ``This will ensure the continuity of a family owning and living in this house,'' said Bryan, who also is chairman, president and chief executive officer of Media General. ``We think its location is the right location.'' That's not satisfactory to Giles, vice president of the William Byrd Branch of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities. ``As long as the house is still standing, we will carry on what we envision to be our role to enlighten the public as to the importance of the house,'' Giles said. ``It is a concern to a great many people.'' Lee stayed at the house recuperating from dysentery while planning the Battle of Cold Harbor. Bryan said the heritage of the house, ``if in fact it has a heritage, is not so much as a place where General Lee was sick for four days, but its heritage is that of a country farm house. We are much gratified that its future will also be just that _ a house that will be lived in.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Accused of Abandoning His Conservative Base
With AM-Republicans, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five prominent conservatives on Friday accused President Bush of abandoning his conservative electoral base and urged him to return to the fold lest he weaken the Republican party and its candidates. If he doesn't, Bush will face an ``almost certain'' challenge from a conservative candidate in the 1992 primaries, one of them warned. Another, Richard A. Viguerie, said Bush ``took a sharp turn to the left'' shortly after his election. ``It is the conservatives in the Republican Party that have produced the money, the workers and the votes all these years,'' said Viguerie, president of the United Conservatives of America. ``Whenever there's a close presidential race and the Republican nominee abandons his conservative voters, they lose,'' Viguerie said. He cited as examples the races of 1948, when New York Gov. Thomas A. Dewey lost to President Truman; 1960, when Richard Nixon lost to John Kennedy and 1976, when President Ford lost to Jimmy Carter. Viguerie and four other leaders of the conservative movement joined together at a news conference to cite issue after issue as grounds for their concern. Topics ranged from trade concessions for China to support for government-financed art that may be considered obscene, but it was clear their biggest complaint was with the president's abandonment of his ``no new taxes'' pledge. Politicians may change their minds but ``when a politician does that on a core defining issue he used to get elected, he sells out not just his followers but he weakens the system,'' said David A. Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union. Bush has ``dealt a crippling blow to his own credibility,'' Keene said. The conservatives' news conference was timed to coincide with a meeting of the Republican National Committee in Chicago. RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman in Chicago said she was unfamiliar with the conservatives' comments and declined to respond. The five conservatives released a letter to party Chairman Lee Atwater protesting that the administration had showed ``that it does not intend to honor the commitments made to the American people in the 1988 presidential campaign.'' The conservative leaders showed some differences among themselves. Viguerie said he thought Bush had sailed under a ``false flag'' of conservatism in 1988, and now was reverting ``to the big-business, country-club kind of Republican he was in the '60s and the '70s.'' Keene, however, said Bush did not sail under any false flags, but rather had been seduced by high poll ratings. The president appears not to know that ``success in the polls has a history of breeding failure,'' he said. Howard Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus, said ``It is too early to tell what any of us is going to do.'' But Phillips said that if Bush ``stays in his present course he will be challenged in 1992, almost certainly in the Republican primaries and certainly in the general election.'' Also participating in the news conference were L. Brent Bozell III, executive director of the Conservative Victory Committee, and John Cregan, president of the U.S. Business and Industrial Council.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Investigators to Examine Chicago Census Procedures
DOC.TEXT: A team of federal investigators is being sent to Chicago to examine alleged irregularities in local census data-gathering efforts, a Commerce Department official said Friday. Elizabeth Barlowe, deputy counsel to the Commerce Department's inspector general, declined to say what spurred the investigation by her agency, which oversees the Census Bureau. The Chicago Tribune reported Thursday that about 200 valid census questionnaires may have been destroyed in a north side Chicago census office. Workers in that office may have falsified information because of confusion over a nationwide Census Bureau policy of marking a house ``vacant'' when workers can't reach anyone inside, the newspaper said. ``We do have an investigation into some allegations of irregularities,'' Ms. Barlowe said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``That's really all I can say.'' Ms. Barlowe said federal investigators would arrive Monday. She said investigators also were looking into census operations in Atlanta. She did not elaborate on the problems there. The Tribune reported that a manager in the north side Chicago office once asked a colleague for a shredder so he could destroy a stack of census forms. The manager admitted asking for the shredder but denies destroying the documents, the newspaper said. In addition, the Tribune said, other workers in that office said the manager ordered data gatherers not to report a residence as vacant if people were believed to be living there but could not be reached. The newspaper said the manager instead ordered workers to record those residences as having one resident because he believed the city would lose money if occupied homes were recorded as vacant.

DOC.HEAD: Extremists Claim Responsibility for U.S. Chemical Factory Blast
DOC.TEXT: An extremist Islamic group claimed responsibility Friday for the July 5 explosion at a Texas chemical plant that killed 17 people, but U.S. officials and a company spokesman dismissed the claim. A spokesman for the Islamic Liberation Front told The Associated Press that the Arco Chemical Co. Plant in Channelview, Texas, was attacked because the United States supports Israel despite ``its killings and terrorism against our Palestinian families'' in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He refused to give any details of the alleged operation for ``security reasons.'' Arco Chemical Co. of North America said from its headquarters in Newtown Square, Pa., they were surprised by the claim because federal investigators say they've found no signs of sabotage in the explosion. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said there was no reason to believe the explosion at the chemical plant was the result of terrorists. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which is investigating the blast, said in a statement released in Washington that ``there is absolutely no information to substantiate this reputed claim.'' The Arco plant, 15 miles east of Houston, was wrecked by the explosions and fire, which leveled an area the size of a city block. Arco spokeswoman Sallie Anderson said Friday from the company's headquarters that the cause of the explosion had not been determined. She also said she was unaware of any recent threats against the company and that the company had no dealings with Israel. An Islamic Liberation Front spokesman, who identified himself as Bassam Walid said: ``One of our unit commanders, operating in the United States of America, informed our headquarters in the occupied territories last Friday that our comrades had set ablaze a Texas chemical factory and that the mission was successfully accomplished.'' Walid appeared in person at the AP office to make his statement. In a telephone call several hours after he appeared in the AP office, Walid said: ``Many more attacks will be launched against U.S. targets ... inside America and around the world.'' He said attacks would also be made against the U.S. military, but no attacks would be carried out against civilians. The Front is a relatively large group based in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It has followers in Jordan and several other Arab countries. It advocates the elimination of the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: Nostalgia: 25-cent Ferry Fare Going, Going, Gone
DOC.TEXT: Like Steeplechase Park and Ebbets Field, New Yorkers will soon be wistfully recalling the 25-cent Staten Island ferry ride. The round-trip ride past the Statue of Liberty, referred to by many as the best bargain in town, is being doubled to 50 cents Aug. 1 to ease the city's budget crunch. Despite protests from commuters in the city's least populated borough, Mayor David Dinkins made it a done deal Thursday when he signed the fare increase into law. It is only the second official price hike in the history of the ferry, which was taken over by the city from the B&O Railroad in 1905. The ferry cost a nickel each way when Edna St. Vincent Millay wrote: ``We were very tired, we were very merry. We had gone back and forth all night on the ferry.'' But the famous nickel ride was fudged in 1972 when it became a 10-cent round trip, collected in Manhattan; it was altogether obliterated when the fare went to a quarter in 1975 at the height of the city's fiscal troubles. New fiscal woes have caused Dinkins to raise the fare again. The mayor, facing a $1.8 billion deficit, says the increase will add $2 million to city coffers. The Staten Island ferry, which glides past but does not stop at the Statue of Liberty, carries 30,000 commuters daily and is one of the cheapest tourist attractions in New York. The seven-mile trip across New York Harbor is called ``a tourist mecca of great delight,'' by the Architects Guide to New York and ``America's biggest bargain,'' by Geoffrey Moorhouse in his book, ``Imperial New York.'' Those who deal in the sightseer trade doubt that doubling the fare will have any appreciable effect on tourists. ``At a quarter or 50 cents, in our judgment it's still the greatest travel bargain anywhere in the world,'' said Marshall Murdaugh, president of the New York Visitors and Convention Bureau. ``I don't think a half a buck is going to upset anyone,'' said Manny Strumpf, a spokesman for the National Park Service, which operates the Statue of Liberty. By comparison, the Circle Line ferry service which drops passengers off at the statue costs $4. But don't mention the increase to Staten Islanders, already put upon by new laws limiting their voice in city government. To them, the hike is ``another nail in the coffin,'' as one councilman's aide put it, and all the more reason for the island and its population of about 400,000 to secede from the city. The oft-heard secession battle cry was rejuvenated last year after the U.S. Supreme Court abolished the city Board of Estimate and the core of Staten Island's political powerbase. ``This kind of action creates the atmosphere for secession,'' Michael Christiano, an aide to Staten Island Borough President Guy V. Molinari, said before the mayor made the ferry hike history. ``The entire population of Staten Island is utterly incensed,'' said Walter Kramer, chief aide to city Councilman Jerome O'Donovan. He said many feel they are being treated unfairly because Staten Island is the only borough where commuters must pay a fee to get to the rest of the city _ and often as many as three commuting fees to get to work.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Didn't Realize Man Was Dead, Police Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds time element in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of motorists saw a man slumped against a railing under a highway overpass for two days but did not realize he was dead, police said. A woman called police Thursday after she saw the unidentified man in the same position for two days on Interstate 35 near downtown San Antonio, patrolman Richard Smith said Thursday. Officers said the man, a Hispanic between age 35 and 40, was sitting with his head slumped and a full can of beer within easy reach. He carried no identification papers. ``That's a common place for vagrants to go to get out of the sun,'' Smith said. Foul play is not suspected but an autopsy will be performed, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Tries to Ease GOP Tax Fears; Demands Democrats Offer Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 14th graf pvs, Missing from, to UPDATE with conservatives' criticism of Bush.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle on Friday tried to calm GOP fears about the political impact of President Bush's reversal on taxes and demanded that Democrats make the next move by proposing sensitive spending cuts. Quayle told the Republican National Committee that Bush put taxes on the negotiating table to spur deficit reduction talks but would not accept any deal that would hurt the economy _ or the Republican Party. ``He will not accept a bad deal,'' Quayle said in a speech to GOP leaders from across the country. ``His position is simple: a good deal _ or no deal at all.'' Many of the Republicans gathered in Chicago for the party's two-day meeting believe that Bush's decision to abandon his campaign pledge of ``no new taxes'' will hurt GOP candidates this fall. But with Election Day four months away and the GOP already fending off Democratic attacks over the savings and loan crisis, Quayle and other Republican leaders were out to put the party on the offensive on the tax issue. ``The president is willing to go the extra mile in seeking to forge a budget agreement that would be good for America,'' Quayle said. But he said the politically charged budget talks are ``not a one-way street'' and tried to shift the focus from taxes to spending. ``Today I call on the congressional Democrats to come forth with their proposed spending cuts,'' Quayle said. ``Their silence on this issue _ as usual _ is deafening.'' Quayle's speech led a GOP effort to paint Bush's tax switch as a sign of bold leadership. Democrats have tried to paint a different picture, saying Bush is abandoning his no-tax pledge only because of the soaring costs of an S&L debacle they blame on the Reagan and Bush administrations. Friday's focus on taxes and the budget talks came one day after GOP leaders counterpunched the Democratic attacks on the savings and loan crisis. Ed Rollins, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, tried to place blame for the S&L bailout on the Democrats, charging they had ``sold out the taxpayers.'' House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., on Friday called the remarks ``Mr. Rollins' emotional ravings'' and added, ``It sounded like he was in a panic. ... It was sort of a running doggerel of political invective.'' The president's decision on taxes has brought him heat even within his own party, but senior Republicans tried Friday to rally support for Bush. ``It is the obligation of Republicans, I believe, to stand up for the president when the president is willing to take the political heat to stand up for the nation,'' said Republican Illinois Gov. James Thompson. Party co-chairwoman Jeanie Austin sounded a similar theme, saying of Bush: ``It is a measure of his leadership and his courage that he's making the tough decisions today.'' Back in Washington, five leading conservatives held a news conference to accuse Bush of abandoning his conservative electoral base and to urge him to return to the fold. Bush's shift on taxes was one of their chief complaints. The five released a letter to party Chairman Lee Atwater protesting that the Bush administration has indicated it ``does not intend to honor the commitments made to the American people in the 1988 presidential campaign.'' Atwater was hospitalized in Washington as part of his treatment for a brain tumor. But GOP leaders in Chicago were following his recent admonition to adopt a more aggressive stance, particularly in the partisan fights over taxes and S&Ls. Peggy Noonan, a former speechwriter to both presidents Reagan and Bush, told the group Bush showed statesmanlike leadership in putting taxes on the table for the budget talks. But she said Bush should walk away from the talks if Democrats will not agree to substantial spending cuts and reforms in the budget-writing process. Otherwise, she said, Bush will get the blame for raising taxes and Democrats the credit for spending the extra money on social programs. ``We must not lose the tax issue,'' she said. ``There is no more potent issue than this.'' The Republicans continued their S&L offensive on Friday by endorsing a resolution applauding Bush's handling of the crisis and blaming the $300 billion-plus mess on the Democrats. ``While Democrats have been pointing fingers of blame, President Bush has been rolling up his sleeves to make good on his promise to settle the problem,'' the resolution said.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Report: Pro-Government Rally Draws More than 100,000
With AM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 100,000 Albanians rallied Friday in support of their Communist leaders, according to Albania's state ATA news agency. Officials were reported to have condemned those fleeing abroad and to have urged demonstrators to ``be united like a fist around the party.'' The rally was staged in Skanderbeg Square in Tirana, near the row of foreign embassies used as safe haven by about 6,000 Albanians seeking to emigrate, according to the ATA report, monitored in Vienna. About 4,500 of the Albanians in the embassies left Albania by ship early Friday and arrived in Italy hours later. Most of those remaining are slated to make their own way to freedom within days. The rally appeared to be an attempt by Albanian leadership to demonstrate the majority of citizens in that country of 3.1 million residents supported the hard-line Communist government that has recently introduced modest reforms but continues to reject political pluralism. Stung by the threat posed to Communist rule by the asylum-seekers, the leadership has depicted them as social undesirables, and comments to the rally by Xhelil Gjoni, a member of the party's policy-making Politburo, were in the same vein. Gjoni was quoted by ATA as telling the crowd of at least 100,000 that those who are leaving ``do not represent Albania, they do not represent the people.'' ``In difficult moments be united like a fist round the (Communist) party,'' he was quoted as saying. He suggested without elaboration that Yugoslavia _ where harsh Serbian control of ethnic Albanians is increasing _ is to blame for the unrest of the past weeks. Gjoni reiterated modest economic reforms decided on last week, such as sanctioning private enterprise limited to individuals or families; a form of unemployment insurance; wage increases; and the introduction of a form of unemployment insurance. The changes ``represent one of the clearest manifestations of the continuous care of the party and state for the life of our working people and their families,'' he was quoted as saying. The rush on the embassies was partially predicated by dissatisfaction with shortages and low living standards, and hopes of a better existence in the West. The reforms were clearly meant to relieve discontent, along with the replacement of several ministers with economic portfolios. Albania, for decades the hermit of Europe because of its isolationist course, embarked on cautious liberalization several months ago. It has, among other things, signalled its willingness to resume relations with the superpowers. The leadership also decreed that the people, long denied any travel, had the right to passports, abolished the death penalty for those caught fleeing the country and decriminalized religion. Gjoni acknowledged the existence of hardships but said only Albanians could improve their lives. ``We still do not have the economy and the standard of living we would like to,'' he said. ``We know these realities and make all efforts to solve them ourselves. They cannot be solved by foreigners but by us.''

DOC.HEAD: Worker Dies in Fire at Nuclear Plant; No Radiation Released
DOC.TEXT: A flash fire broke out at a nuclear plant Friday, killing one worker and injuring three, but no radiation was released, utility company officials said. The fire broke out in electrical equipment away from the nuclear reactor containment building at the D.C. Cook Nuclear Power Plant, Indiana Michigan Power officials said. ``As such, there is no danger of radioactive release and no danger to the public,'' spokesman Eustace Smarrella said in a statement. Electrical production also was unaffected, Indiana Michigan spokesman Wayne Hasty said from utility headquarters in Fort Wayne, Ind. The dead man was employed by a contractor and was performing maintenance on electrical equipment in one of two generating units at the plant, the statement said. The man was killed when he apparently touched a circuit breaker to which power had not been shut off, it said. The blaze injured a second contract employee and two Indiana Michigan workers. The company did not say where they were being treated or explain the extent of their injuries. Names of the workers were not released. The unit had been shut down since June 29 for refueling and maintenance. The other unit was not affected and remained in service, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Meckel Tells Baker Nuclear Weapons Should Go
DOC.TEXT: East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel called for keeping all nuclear weapons out of Europe in a meeting Friday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. That would include the new surface-to-air missile known as TASM, which the Bush administration wants to deploy. ``We feel we do not need them at all, on European soil or on German soil,'' Meckel said of nuclear weapons. He also said Poland should not be worried about the merger of East and West Germany. ``The future Germany will have good relations with countries in the East,'' Meckel told reporters after seeing Baker. The two will meet again next week in Paris when Baker, Meckel and the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain, France, West Germany and Poland discuss Germany's future. The main issue is the border of Poland, which was divided between Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II. Both West and East Germany have told the Poles that a reunified Germany would not expand. Meckel said both the merger of Germany and the border treaty should be completed about the same time, probably in January. ``I could not envisage a problem on what Poland requires,'' the East German minister said. The United States agreed with its 15 allies at a North Atlantic Treaty Organization summit last week in London to remove 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells once all Soviet troops are withdrawn from Eastern and Central Europe. President Bush in May, at the behest of West Germany, decided not to deploy new, short-range Lance missiles, although 700 older U.S. nuclear-tipped Lances are in Western Europe. Also, 1,560 U.S. battlefield nuclear weapons are based in West Germany and six other NATO countries, and the Bush administration plans to deploy the more potent TASM missiles now being developed. Meckel said that in his meeting with Baker ``we discussed nuclear weapons in general,'' but not the new missile specifically. He said Germans favor the ``zero option,'' meaning the elimination of all short-range nuclear weapons. A U.S.-Soviet treaty in 1987 banned all medium-range nuclear missiles. ``It is our strong interest to have all nuclear weapons go,'' Meckel said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Child to Remain With White Family Pending Possible Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A white suburban family can continue its foster care for a black baby while the child's mother and social workers try to settle a dispute over her children's placement, a judge ruled Friday. Social workers have tried to move the woman's two children, ages 5 months and 14 months, to black foster homes in the inner city to keep them in the same socioeconomic environment as their mother. While the younger child is staying with the white suburban family, the 14-month-old is at a black foster mother's home. The children were taken from their mother earlier this year after social workers determined the woman was unable to maintain a proper home for them, said Jeff Aikin, a spokesman for the Milwaukee County Department of Health and Social Services. The 30-year-old woman, who has not been named in court to protect her children's identities, has not contested that her children should be taken from her. But she has petitioned the court to overrule the social workers and allow both children be placed with the white couple, Beverly and David Cox. Milwaukee County Children's Court Judge Ronald S. Goldberger was to rule on the mother's request Friday but adjourned the hearing until Aug. 16 after lawyers met for 3{ hours and indicated the case may be settled out of court. Until Aug. 16, the younger child will remain with the Coxes while the older one will remain in the inner city foster home, the judge ruled. The Coxes had originally joined the children's mother in protesting the social workers' decision, arguing race should have no affect on foster placement decisions. But Goldberger ruled last month the couple had no legal standing in the case and only the children's mother could appeal the placement.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Lingers In The East
DOC.TEXT: More locally heavy rain fell over parts of the eastern half of the nation Friday, and temperatures dipped to record lows from the Plains to New England. In the East, showers and thunderstorms continued to develop along and ahead of a slow moving cold front curving through the central Gulf Coast states, the southern Ohio Valley and the middle Atlantic coast region during the morning and early afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms were developing along the same cold front over the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas, and storms were clustered over a few parts of the lower and middle Mississippi Valley. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 2.65 inches at Apalachicola, Fla., 2.48 inches at Panama City, Fla., 1.48 inches at Knoxville, Tenn., and 1.44 inches at Montgomery, Ala. It was unseasonably cool east of the Rockies, with afternoon temperatures generally in the upper 60s and 70s. Temperatures in the 80s and lower 90s were primarily confined to southern Texas, the central Gulf Coast states, and the southern Atlantic Coast region. Temperatures were not quite as unseasonably hot as they have been in the Pacific Northwest, where afternoon readings were mostly in the 80s and 90s. However, temperatures again soared above 100 in the valleys of northern and central California and the desert Southwest. Overnight lows dipped below 60 across most of the area from the Rocky Mountain region to New England, with lows in the 40s reported in the northern and central Plains, the Great Lakes, and the northern Atlantic Coast. Record lows for the date were set at Bridgeport, Conn., 57; Dallas-Fort Worth, 64; Dodge City, Kan., 46; Duluth, Minn., 39; St. Cloud, Minn., 44; and Goodland, Kan., 43. The previous record at St. Cloud had stood since 1897. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 38 at Custer, S.D.

DOC.HEAD: Appropriations Committee Virtually Eliminates Crop Insurance
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, Madigan is, with Senate to take up farm bill; picks up 6th graf pvs, The overall
DOC.TEXT: The House Appropriations Committee on Friday approved $50.4 billion for agriculture spending in fiscal 1991, but angered House Agriculture Committee leaders by virtually eliminating crop insurance. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., whose Agriculture subcommittee has been working on improvements to the crop insurance program, said an amendment to restore funding would be offered during full House debate if the program is not reinstated sooner. ``Abolishing the program while major improvements are under consideration creates a situation whereby those improvements cannot be put into effect in an orderly manner,'' Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza said in a letter to Appropriations Chairman Jamie Whitten. The letter also was signed by English, Rep. Edward Madigan, R-Ill., and Rep. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo. Madigan is ranking Republican on the full Agriculture Committee and Coleman the ranking GOP member on English's subcommittee. Meanwhile, congressional leaders said the Senate expects to start debate next week on the 1990 farm bill, with budget constraints as the guiding force in determining the agriculture policy for the next five years. ``Aside from the factor of time, the bottom line for acceptance and passage of this legislation must be the budget,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole in a news release. The House version of the farm bill will be taken up next week by the House Rules Committee, which will decide on the rules for debating the measure on the House floor. The appropriations measure the House panel approved Friday provides funding for all Agriculture Department agencies except the Forest Service. It includes funds for the Food and Drug Administration and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and puts limits on funds for the Farm Credit Administration and the Farm Credit System Assistance Board. The overall appropriation for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 is $5 billion greater than fiscal 1990. The boost is reflected in higher allocations for administrative salaries, payments to land-grant colleges, research grants, food safety and inspection, marketing services and rural development. The popular food program for poor pregnant and nursing mothers and their infants, known as WIC, was allocated $2.35 billion, an increase of $195 million from this year and $109 million more than the Bush administration requested. Whitten, D-Miss., a longtime opponent of crop insurance, favors a system through which the government appropriates money to pay farmers each time there is a substantial crop loss. The measure passed by Whitten's committee allows for $262 million to be spent next year on crop insurance administrative phase-out costs and to make payments on any policies sold before Oct. 1. The Bush administration, which also wants the program abolished, has said $601 million would be needed in 1991 to operate crop insurance at its current level. Spending for 1990 has been $400 million. ``A straight-out disaster program would be as expensive,'' English said. Only about 40 percent of eligible farmers buy crop insurance. Farmers say they avoid the program because the premiums are too high, yields are inadequate or because the price forecasting for certain crops by the insurance companies is inaccurate. Farmers may buy insurance from either the government or private companies. Thirty percent of all costs are paid by the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Friday's Session of the 28th Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of Friday's session of the 28th Communist Party Congress, its 11th and final day:

SESSION CLOSE: Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet, closed the session with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev standing beside him, and the nearly 4,700 delegates gave themselves a standing ovation and sang the socialist anthem, ``The Internationale.''

GORBACHEV SPEECH: Gorbachev, in a final address, welcomed Western aid without ``any political conditions,'' warned of a gap between the party and ``workers, peasants and intellectuals,'' and he denounced those, like former party member Boris Yeltsin, who ``demand repentence from the party, settling scores, those who declare it even a criminal organization ... to remove (the party) from the political life of the country.''
CENTRAL COMMITTEE: The delegates, by secret ballot, elected a 412-member Central Committee that appeared to be packed with moderate reformers of the Gorbachev mold.

LIGACHEV ON YELTSIN: Party traditionalist Yegor K. Ligachev, commenting to reporters on Yeltsin's quitting the party, reprised a statement he made in insulting tones to Yeltsin at the party conference in summer 1988: ``I'll say what I said two years ago: `Boris, you're not right.'''
KEY QUOTE: ``We are ready to cooperate and will be thankful for assistance. We act not as beggars but as partners and we are not going to take anything free of charge.'' _ Gorbachev on Western aid.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Aide Confirms His Security Clearance Revoked
DOC.TEXT: An aide to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh confirmed Friday that his security clearance was revoked for failing to provide full background information for 18 months. Associate Deputy Attorney General Barry H. Stern, who turned in his resignation this week, said he ignored repeated requests for what he termed minor information. Stern also confirmed that until last week he hadn't signed an oath that he had given truthful answers on the background questionnaire he filed last year. ``If I didn't sign it, it was a pure oversight,'' said Stern, adding that signed the oath after belatedly providing the information sought by security officials. He also said he signed a statement last year authorizing the FBI to conduct a background investigation. Stern, a 43-year-old lawyer, said his security clearance was revoked last month because he had failed to provide information that involved addresses of some references and some job history information. Stern, who oversaw the Justice Department's program for seizing the assets of drug dealers, organized crime figures and other convicted criminals, said his duties did not require him to have access to classified information. The revocation of Stern's security clearance is the latest personnel problem for Thornburgh, who reassigned two of his closest aides after it was disclosed they ``showed deception'' on lie detector tests during an FBI investigation of an unauthorized news leak. The May reassignments of chief of staff Robert S. Ross Jr. and press spokesman David Runkel were portrayed by officials as part of an effort to dispel the perception that Thornburgh was surrounded by political cronies. Stern is one of a group of aides to the attorney general who served under Thornburgh when he was governor of Pennsylvania. He will join a Philadelphia-area publishing company, LRP Press. Stern received a temporary security clearance when he joined the Justice Department in September 1988 while the FBI completed a background check. Such temporary clearances, usually lasting 14 months, allow top officials to function in sensitive positions pending final approval of permanent access to classified information, officials said. A Justice Department official familiar with the case said Stern's delay in filing the information was unprecedented and angered department security officials. Aides in Stern's position normally file the requested information within several weeks of taking office so the FBI can begin its work. The Justice Department's security office asked Stern in November to provide several answers to questions that he had not completed, including the addresses of references. Stern said he put off returning the form with the completed answers over the Christmas holidays and continued to procrastinate for six months despite intermittent requests.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly $41,000 Spent on Travel by Prosecutors to Fraud Conference
DOC.TEXT: It cost $40,985 to bring 87 U.S. attorneys to Washington last month for a conference on thrift fraud that featured a stump-style speech by President Bush, the Justice Departent said Friday. The money was spent on travel and accommodations for the federal prosecutors who attended the Financial Institution Fraud Conference at the department. The major event of the conference was a speech by Bush to unveil plans to seek additional resources for prosecuting savings and loans fraud. The president's speech was made in direct response to growing criticism by Democrats in Congress that the Bush administration was not aggressively tracking down S&L criminals. The conference was attended by 88 U.S. attorneys from around the country and the District of Columbia. Jay B. Stephens, the U.S. attorney in the nation's capital, didn't have to travel far. His office is six blocks from the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze at Plant That Produces Rocket Fuel Oxidizer
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 tons of a chemical that is vital for the solid fuel in space shuttle boosters went up in flames at a Kerr-McGee Corp. plant, near a similar plant that blew up two years ago. No injuries were reported in Thursday night's fire, which was extinguished in about 45 minutes. Damage was originally estimated at $200,000, but was revised downward Friday to $135,000, said Kerr-McGee spokesman Myron Cunningham. The cause of the accident was under investigation, Cunningham said. The fire destroyed 106.5 tons of ammonium perchlorate, an oxidizer which provides oxygen for the burning of solid rocket fuel. Kerr-McGee produces about 1,500 tons of the material per month, according to Rick Stater, plant operations manager. Stater and fire officials credited new fire safety regulations with averting a disaster similar to one on May 4, 1988, when ammonium perchlorate exploded and destroyed the Pacific Engineering Co. or PEPCON plant a mile from the Kerr-McGee plant. Kerr-McGee and Pacific Engineering were the only companies in the United States producing the critical oxidizer, which is also used for some military rockets, and the loss of the plant left U.S. officials facing a possible shortage. Pacific Engineering since has built a new plant in Cedar City, Utah. The earlier blast killed two people and injured more than 300. The blast rocked the Las Vegas Valley and caused more than $74 million in property damage, primarily in this community of 55,000, some 25 miles southeast of Las Vegas. Following that blast, Clark County fire officials imposed strict new fire safety codes at the Kerr-McGee plant. Included was a provision that the ammonium perchlorate not be stored in one pile but be divided up for storage on individual pads separated by concrete walls. Stater and fire department spokesman Bob Leinbach said the safety walls prevented the spread of the fire and possible explosion. Leinbach said he did not know why the Kerr-McGee fire did not produce an explosion similar to the Pacific Engineering blast. ``That may be one of the mysteries of life,'' Leinbach said. ``PEPCON was not supposed to explode.'' Kerr-McGee is building a new plant in a remote area northwest of Las Vegas for production of ammonium perchlorate.

DOC.HEAD: Political Groups Slow to Support Chamorro's Plea for Dialogue
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro received only limited support Friday following her appeal for a national dialogue to avoid a repeat of the Sandinista-inspired labor unrest that crippled the country. Five splinter centrist parties and a non-Sandinista labor federation declared they would take part in such a national dialogue after meeting with Mrs. Chamorro. But both the leftist Sandinistas, now the country's largest opposition group, and the 14-party coalition that backed Mrs. Chamorro when she mounted her presidential campaign did not immediately indicate whether they would support her call for negotiations. In announcing the strike settlement Thursday, Mrs. Chamorro called for wide-ranging negotiations aimed at reaching a social accord involving the new U.S.-backed government, the private sector and the Sandinistas that ruled from 1979 until they left office on April 25. The 10-day Sandinista-led strike was settled with an accord that grants hefty wage hikes to government workers, pledges no mass firings of public sector workers, and puts some key elements of the new administration's plan to return Nicaragua to a free-market economy on hold. The accord also calls for suspension of a decree to return land confiscated in the 1979 Sandinista revolution to the original owners. Mrs. Chamorro and her aides have said the settlement prevented more bloodshed and unrest, and made it possible for Nicaragua to get back down to business. But the business community and some leaders of the governing coalition have complained the settlement resulted in concessions that were a victory for the Sandinistas and a defeat for the administration's plan to restore a free-market economy. In a joint statement Friday, the leaders of the five small centrist parties declared their readiness to participate in the dialogue. The five parties _ the Popular Social Christian, Social Christian, Revolutionary Unity Movement, Liberal for National Unification and Conservative Democratic _ support Mrs. Chamorro but are not members of the governing coalition. ``The dialogue must serve to force the Sandinistas to commit themselves not to use violence again to obtain political and labor conquests,'' the party leaders said they told Mrs. Chamorro. ``Equilibrium and social peace can only be achieved through unity and national identity,'' the statement said. The Permanent Labor Congress, a federation of unions linked to Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, also announced it would support her call for dialogue. ``Dona Violeta's idea is a good one, because the country needs to know the opinion of all Nicaraguans in order to strive for peace,'' Nilo Salazar, a Labor Congress leader, told reporters. The Sandinistas have not yet formally reacted to Mrs. Chamorro's proposal. Former President Daniel Ortega, unseated by Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition coalition in the Feb. 25 elections, told reporters Wednesday night that ``an understanding must be reached with the Sandinistas and their revolution to contribute to the country's stability.'' The governing coalition, whose fractious members range from communists to hard-line conservatives, appeared to be divided over its response to the settlement and Mrs. Chamorro's appeal for dialogue. After the announcement of the settlement, the 14 parties established a Committee for National Solidarity headed by Vice President Virgilio Godoy. But it was unclear what action the committee would take. Godoy, a conservative who has frequently criticized Mrs. Chamorro, has termed the settlement a success for the Sandinistas, claiming it has nullified the government's efforts to assert control. The nation's leading business group, the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, criticized the government for giving in to what it called Sandinista ``blackmail.'' Gilberto Cuadra, the business group's president, said the settlement had left the government's economic recovery program ``bleeding'' and dampened hopes of attracting foreign investment. He said the business group estimates the strike caused $35 million to $50 million in lost business, property damage and diminished crops. The strike posed the most serious threat yet to Mrs. Chamorro's new government. During the last six days of the strike, street fighting broke out between strike supporters and opponents, claiming at least four lives.

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Negotiations Begin, Could Take Weeks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to CORRECT Thursday to Friday and 2nd graf to delete extraneous word `for'
DOC.TEXT: Congressional talks on a final clean air bill began Friday as a White House aide said the president remains strongly opposed to giving financial aid to workers who lose jobs because of tougher pollution requirements. The House-Senate negotiations over the first strengthening of federal air pollution laws in 13 years are expected to take weeks as numerous differences in the complex House and Senate bills are worked out. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., head of the House delegation to the talks, made clear that he will not be rushed. ``We have an enormous amount of work ahead of us,'' he said. Dingell rejected pleas by senators at the hour-long session for a quick response to two initial Senate proposals on two relatively obscure parts of the legislation. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., conference chairman, said ``we have to work quickly'' if a compromise bill is to be completed before Congress adjourns in early October. No date was set for the next session of the House and Senate conferees. Bills passed last spring by wide margins in both the House and Senate call for tougher pollution controls on factories, automobiles and electric power plants to reduce urban smog, toxic industrial releases and acid rain by the end of the decade. But scores of differences remain between the two bills. A major issue is job protection for workers who lose jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The House bill contains a three-year, $250 million assistance program for such workers, but the Senate version does not. Roger Porter, President Bush's chief domestic policy adviser, who will sit in on the talks, said the administration remains ``fundamentally opposed'' to a job-loss assistance provision. He said he would recommend the president veto the bill if it contains such aid. Supporters of the assistance contend Bush would be hard pressed to scuttle the massive package solely because it provides money for the unemployed. They argue that the $250 million cost of the program is relatively small over three years. But administration officials have argued there is no way to control the costs of mandated assistance. ``It sets a precedent that we're uncomfortable with,'' said Porter. Although no substantive agreements were reached in the first negotiating session, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he remained ``hopeful and certain'' a compromise clean air bill can be worked out before Congress is scheduled to adjourn in October. But some senators and environmentalists expressed concern this week that the tight congressional schedule may jeopardize strong legislation, especially if it is held over for final action in a possible lame-duck session after the November election. Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., said after the meeting that he was ``plenty worried because we don't have much time.'' Chafee and other senators offered two recommendations to resolve differences on permit requirements and on dealing with ozone-destroying chemicals. But Dingell said only that the House would refer the matters to staff members for analysis. Other areas likely to raise controversy are a House requirement for automakers to build alternative fuel cars as a pilot program in California; a requirement strongly opposed by oil companies that ethanol-blend fuels be used in some smog-plagued cities; whether to require small industrial polluters to comply with new smog controls; and whether to retain a House provision that calls for pollution controls over national parks.

DOC.HEAD: First Clinical Trial Begins for Juvenile Diabetes Treatment
DOC.TEXT: University of Florida researchers announced Friday the first clinical trials of a drug they hope will prevent juvenile diabetes, the most deadly strain of the disease. The study is being led by diabetes specialists at the university's Health Science Center. It involves giving daily doses of an immunosuppressant drug called Imuran to people likely to be afflicted. Also known as Type 1 or insulin-dependent diabetes, juvenile diabetes affects 1 million people and kills 300,000 Americans each year, said Dr. Noel Maclaren, a UF pathologist. The medical centers involved in the study will offer free screening to close relatives of people who have Type 1 diabetes. The National Institutes of Health granted $3.5 million to pay for the screening of about 10,000 people, while about 80 who have indications of diabetes would receive the new drug. Besides the University of Florida, participating centers include the Joslin Diabetes Center at Harvard Medical School, the Barbara Davis Foundation and Denver Children's Hospital in Denver and the University of Washington in Seattle. The study is the result of research by Maclaren and Mark Atkinson, who discovered antibodies that precede the onset of juvenile diabetes. In the June issue of the British medical journal Lancet, Atkinson reported that an antibody he isolated can be detected up to seven years before symptoms of diabetes appear. Peggy Polopolus of Gainesville, who has been taking the drug since 1984, has not developed diabetes despite having Type 1 antibodies. ``We're convinced the medication has prevented the disease,'' said Dr. William Riley, who is directing the nationwide clinical trials. The drug keeps the body's immune system from destroying cells in the pancreas while it produces insulin, a hormone essential to the body's storage and use of sugars for energy, Riley said. Several patients who received Imuran after being diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes were able to stay off insulin for up to two years.

DOC.HEAD: Leaks in Atlantis, Columbia Different, NASA Says
DOC.TEXT: The hydrogen leaks crippling space shuttles Atlantis and Columbia appear to be in different places, ruling out the possibility that the problems are related, NASA said Friday. ``The things that we know leak on one we know aren't leaking on the other,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. A common problem with the shuttles' fuel system would have been much more difficult to deal with, said shuttle director Robert Crippen. Early indications following an elaborate test of Atlantis' fuel system Friday are that hydrogen escaped from a flange on the external tank side of a 17-inch-diameter valve, Lenoir said. The valve is in a pipe that carries fuel from the tank to the main engines. No leaks were found in that area on the plumbing from Columbia that was sent for laboratory testing to shuttle builder Rockwell International Corp. in Downey, Calif., Lenoir said. Rockwell engineers believe Columbia's problem lies in a small, Teflon shaft seal on the orbiter side of the valve, Lenoir said. But further tests are needed before concluding there are no leaks on the two shaft seals on the side of the external tank, he said. Earlier this week, NASA officials said the main suspect appeared to be a U-shaped Teflon seal in the 17-inch pipe on the orbiter side. Later, that proved to be fine. Lenoir said the problem with Columbia has been corrected since new plumbing was installed in the faulty area.
