The new components were taken from the shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. It's too soon to say how NASA will deal with Atlantis' leak, Lenoir said. The solution may be as simple as tightening the seal, which could be done at the launch pad. Putting in a new seal would require a return to the hangar, he said. ``About all we can do at the pad is tighten up the bolts,'' Lenoir said. NASA wants to launch at least one shuttle before Discovery's scheduled flight with the sun-exploring Ulysses satellite in October, Crippen said. The most likely candidate is Atlantis, on a classified Defense Department mission. Discovery has until Oct. 23 to lift off with Ulysses because of the alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter. Otherwise, the flight must be delayed for 13 months. Lenoir said there is no reason to believe Discovery has a leak. It's uncertain whether that shuttle will undergo a tanking test prior to launch, he said. The space agency wants to avoid making such tests routine, he said. Columbia's leak was discovered during fueling for a May 30 launch attempt. A test a week later duplicated the leak, and the shuttle was returned to the hangar for repairs. As a precaution, NASA conducted a similar test on Atlantis on June 29 as the shuttle awaited a mid-July liftoff. A leak was detected, and the agency grounded the three-shuttle fleet. It was the first time all of the shuttles had been grounded since the 1986 Challenger explosion. The next shuttle did not fly until 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Metro Commuter Rail Services
With AM-Blue Line,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Getting them off the streets and out of the smoggy freeway system is one of Los Angeles' goals for the 21st century. The advent of the Blue Line commuter rail is the beginning of a 150-mile transportation system for the metropolitan area. Here at a glance are some of the recent services introduced in other metro areas:
DOC.HEAD: Miami _ The Tri-County Commuter Rail Organization (Tri-Rail)
DOC.TEXT: began operating a 67-mile, 15-station commuter service in January 1989. The service operates in Palm Beach, Broward and Dade counties.
DOC.HEAD: Chicago _ Metropolitan Rail (Metra) for many years has operated
DOC.TEXT: a 495-mile commuter rail system serving 224 stations on 13 lines radiating north, west and south from downtown Chicago. The most recent addition, Northern Indiana Commuter Transportation District (NICTD), operates a single 88-mile route serving 7 stations in Illinois and 20 in Indiana .
DOC.HEAD: San Francisco _ CalTrain Peninsula Commute Service (CalTrain)
DOC.TEXT: offers service to 26 stations along a single 47-mile route extending south from San Francisco to San Jose.
DOC.HEAD: Baltimore _ Maryland Rail Commuter Service (MARC) operates
DOC.TEXT: service to 32 stops over three routes linking Washington's Union Station with Baltimore and with Martinsburg, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Winery Worker Accused of Killing Family Gets Trial Delay
DOC.TEXT: The murder trial of winery worker Ramon Salcido, accused of killing his wife, two daughters and four others, was delayed for a week Friday. San Mateo Superior Court Judge Phrasel Shelton granted the request of defense attorney Marteen Miller, who said his wife has malaria and needs his care. Assistant District Attorney Peter Bumerts, who fought earlier delay attempts, did not object at the emergency afternoon court session held in Redwood City, where Salcido's trial is now scheduled to begin July 23. Jury selection had been scheduled to begin Monday. On Thursday, the 1st District Court of Appeal refused to grant a two-month delay, which Miller had sought saying he needed time to convince Mexican authorities to hand over extradition papers that could prevent the prosecution from seeking the death penalty. However, prosecutors say Miller is stalling and that a U.S.-Mexico treaty does not bar the death penalty. Salcido, 29, is accused of killing his wife, two daughters, his mother-in-law, her two daughters and a co-worker 15 months ago. A third daughter, 2 years old at the time of the attack, had her throat slit but survived and lives with a foster family. After the attacks, Salcido fled to Mexico, where he was arrested and gave a full confession. Miller said he would not dispute the facts of the case, but would argue against the death penalty by showing that Salcido was drunk and high on cocaine and suffered other mental impairments during the attacks. San Mateo Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell, a visiting Sierra County judge who will preside over the trial, said jury selection should take about six weeks, with the trial to last at least another month. The trial was moved from Sonoma County, the area north of San Francisco where the murders occurred, to San Mateo, south of the city, because of pre-trial publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Letter Reaches Destination from Vietnam 23 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: When a young sailor wrote a letter to his parents during the Vietnam War, he forgot to include the ZIP code. That might have made it a little late, but doesn't account for all 23 years, the U.S. Postal Service says. Bert Budai wrote his parents a 2{-page letter filled with typical adventures of a young sailor during the war. He returned home in 1969 and his parents later died. But the post office delivered the letter Tuesday to Budai's former home in Ravenna, just across the road from where he now lives. ``I was quite shocked,'' said Budai, now 44, married and stepfather of two children. ``My sister lives in my father's house now and it came to that address and she brought it over to me.'' The letter is postmarked Oct. 17, 1966 _ the same day Budai penned it aboard the USS Valley Forge, a helicopter carrier stationed off the Philippines. Stamped with an 8-cent air mail stamp, the envelope included Budai's shipboard return address, in care of the San Francisco post office. The mailing address lacked the Ravenna ZIP code, but Joseph L. Johnson, communications manager for the Grand Rapids division of the postal service, doesn't think that made much difference. ``It you don't include a ZIP code it might delay it a couple of days, but certainly not 23 years,'' Johnson said. ``Of course, we apologize for the late delivery.''

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 Romanians Demonstrate Against President Iliescu
DOC.TEXT: About 20,000 demonstrators marched Friday to demand the release of a jailed activist who had been savagely beaten by vigilante miners loyal to President Ion Iliescu. Shortly after the orderly demonstration, Iliescu went on state television to appeal for national trust and criticized those who seek to teach Romania ``lessons of democracy.'' The march was among the largest street gatherings in Bucharest since the December revolution overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu and his wife Elena were executed Dec. 25. Iliescu implored Romanians to ``do away with the atmosphere of suspicion'' and called on the police to crack down on corrupt bureaucrats and black marketeers, who he blamed for the shortages now plaguing the country. Demonstrators marched on the government building in Victory Square and demanded the release of jailed student leader Marian Munteanu. They shouted anti-Iliescu slogans and carried signs equating Iliescu's National Salvation Front with the defunct Romanian Communist Party. Munteanu was a leader of the 53-day opposition rally that blocked central Bucharest until June 13, when police tried to put it down. The resulting violence killed at least six people. Munteanu was badly beaten by pro-government miners whom Iliescu urged to come to the capital to impose order. The miners subsequently terrorized the capital, and Munteanu was arrested in connection with the anti-government violence several days later while he was still hospitalized. Iliescu, a former Communist official, won free elections in May but opponents demanded he step down because of his hard-line past. He was harshly criticized by the world community for the miners' rampage, a and the United States and other nations cut off millions of dollars in non-humanitarian aid to Romania. In an indirect slap at the United States, Iliescu criticized ``those among our friends who now treat us with lack of faith... who coquetted with Ceausescu's regime and now want to give us lessons on democracy.'' For years, Washington maintained fairly close ties with Ceausescu, who it viewed as relatively independent of Moscow. Asking Romanians to ``settle into a more constructive climate,'' Iliescu said: ``Let's overcome our climate of suspicion... Let's overcome partisan interests and create a climate of cooperation and quiet work.'' Turning to the huge economic problems, Iliescu attacked ``the phenomenon of corruption'' in Romania's still-powerful bureaucracy. On Thursday, Prime Minister Petre Roman also attacked the managerial ``incompetence'' brought on by decades of communism. He called for more police action against black marketeers who deplete stores by bribing officials and vendors and then sell products at higher prices. ``For some the idea of free initiative ... means accumulating personal wealth without work... a parasitic way of life,'' he declared. ``Honest free initiative means amplification of production and services, not recycling of the insufficient supply.'' Iliescu avoided the issue of Munteanu or the other anti-government activists who have been charged with various offenses and imprisoned. The demonstrators were blocked from approaching the government building in Victory Square by several hundred police. After converging on the government building shouting ``Down with communism,'' the 20,000 marchers _ accompanied by police _ circled back and retraced their route to the starting point at Opera Square. The crowd shouted: ``Try the miners!'' and ``Try the one who called them!'' in reference to Iliescu. Halfway down their route the marchers stopped at the Justice Ministry and a delegation left a petition calling for the release of all jailed activists. ``The arrests are an outrage,'' said 37-year-old photographer Cristian Duma. The National Liberal Youth League on Friday also appealed for Munteanu's release, but assailed the attacks on government buildings by anti-government demonstrators on June 13. It was during these attacks that most of the fatalities reportedly occured. The Ecological Movement, meanwhile, accused the government of ``totalitarian inclinations.'' The charge was made at a Friday news conference called to protest this week's refusal by the Education Ministry's to recognize new private universities. Among them is the Ecologists' university in the former Communist Party building.

DOC.HEAD: More Cubans Seek Refuge in Spanish Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Two more Cubans have taken refuge at the Spanish Embassy in Havana, bringing to 17 the number of asylum-seekers at foreign embassies in Cuba's capital, according to official reports Friday. In a related development, five other Cubans seeking asylum briefly held a Czechoslovak diplomat hostage in his Havana apartment, the official Czchoslovak news agency CTK reported Friday. The report came as Czechoslovakia urged Cuba to provide free passage to the Cubans who had sought shelter earlier this week at Prague's embassy in Havana, and said it would not hand them over to Cuban authorities. The Cubans apparently followed the example of thousands of Albanians who recently flooded foreign embassies in their capital, Tirana, to seek asylum and received permission to leave their Communist homeland. Cuba and Albania remain among the last hard-line Communist countries in the world and have resisted the democratic reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. In Madrid, Spain, a Spanish foreign ministry spokesman said two more Cubans entered the Spanish Embassy in Havana on Friday afternoon, joining another asylum-seeker there. The Mexican government news agency Notimex also reported that three Cubans were seeking refuge in the Spanish Embassy, in a report from Havana monitored in Mexico City. Notimex said two young men went to the consular section at the Spanish Embassy on Friday and declared that nobody could make them leave. ``We have given them protection while we study the situation,'' said Spanish foreign ministry spokesman Juan Lena. He said the Spanish government was seeking permission from Cuban authorities to send the asylum-seekers to a third country. The Spanish ambassador to Cuba, Antonio Serrano de Haro, cut short a vacation in Madrid to return to Havana on Friday. Lena said he did not know the identities of the two new refugees. The first Cuban, identified as 27-year-old Luis Monteagudo Rodriguez, sought refuge in the Spanish Embassy on Wednesday in an effort to escape the hard-line Communist government. Monteagudo was jailed from 1985 to 1988 after he tried to seek asylum at the U.S. Interests Section, which operates out of the Swiss Embassy in Havana, the Spanish news agency EFE said, citing diplomatic sources in Havana. In Prague, CTK quoted the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry as saying five Cubans forced their way into the downtown Havana apartment of Czechoslovak charge d'affaires Jan Doemoek on Thursday. Doemoek was held hostage for several hours, the statement said. The five demanded to join the Cubans in Prague's Havana embassy, the Foreign Ministry said. Doemoek eventually escaped ``using a trick'' and immediately informed Cuban authorities of the incident, emphasizing that Prague would not provide refuge to these five ``violent instigators,'' the statement added. The ministry's statement did not specify what had happened to the five, but it denied what it said were Cuban reports that there were now 19 asylum-seekers inside the Czechoslovak Embassy. Czechoslovakia's Deputy Foreign Minister Lubos Dobrovsky was quoted by CTK as saying it was ``in the interest of both countries'' for Cuba to allow safe passage as soon as possible. He later met senior Soviet, West German and Italian diplomats to ask their help in resolving the situation, CTK said. It did not elaborate. Czechoslovak officials say at least nine of the Cubans in the embassy have requested political asylum. Tension has grown between Cuba and Czechoslovakia, two former allies, since Czechoslovakia's democratic revolution last year. Cuba's Foreign Ministry, in a tough statement reported by EFE from Havana, accused Czechoslovakia late Thursday of provoking the asylum-seeking by Cubans it described as ``habitual bums.'' Dobrovsky told the Cuban ambassador the refugees sought shelter in the embassy ``without any Czechoslovak participation,'' CTK said. In April 1980, thousands of disaffected Cubans jammed the Peruvian Embassy in Havana. Shortly thereafter, many joined what became the Mariel boatlift, which eventually took 125,000 Cubans to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow, Leningrad Mayors Quit Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with resignation impact unclear, Gorbachev comment and closing speech. Picks up 8th graf `The Tass' with minor editing to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS4, MOSB3,7,11
DOC.TEXT: The mayors of Moscow and Leningrad joined Boris N. Yeltsin in quitting the Communist Party on Friday, putting the country's two largest cities as well as its heartland republic in the hands of non-Communists. It was not immediately clear how the resignations of the three leading reformers would affect their party organizations. Yeltsin began the exodus Thursday and it gathered steam as the party's 28th congress drew to a close. Leaders of the Democratic Platform reform group said they would cap their departures by founding their own, non-Communist party this fall. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the president and party leader, said in an interview with CBS News that he had ``contempt'' for those who left the party. He told the congress in a closing address that ``those who demand party repentance and the settling of accounts and brand the party as almost a criminal organization are simply out to remove it from the political scene and thereby deal a blow to the entire cause of revolutionary renewal.'' Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak said in a statement that the two-week congress ``showed the complete inability of the party to offer the country a real program of transition to a new society.'' Popov, an economist, and Sobchak, a lawyer, were elected this spring as reform-minded candidates swept to power in local councils. Under their leadership, the two city councils have been trying to break the control of local Communist Party organizations. They have been active in the same reform circles of Soviet politics as Yeltsin. Moscow has about 9 million people and Leningrad has 5 million. They are by far the largest cities in the Soviet Union. In his closing speech, Gorbachev said the party intended ``to drastically change its attitude to elected governing councils, renounce attempts at substituting for them, make every effort to assist them to stand up firmly on their feet, and help deputies deal with problems involved in meeting vital popular needs.'' Yeltsin, elected in May as president of the huge Russian federation, told the congress Thursday he was quitting the party. As president of the Russian republic, which has three-quarters of the Soviet Union's territory and 52 percent of its people, he must listen to all political parties and cannot obey only the Communist Party, he said. Moscow and Leningrad both lie within the Russian republic. The Tass news agency quoted Yeltsin as telling the Russian parliament on Friday that he made the decision ``with a heavy heart.'' At the party congress, delegates voted to strip him of his congress credentials. An aide to Popov, who is traveling outside the Soviet Union, read the statement from the Moscow and Leningrad mayors to reporters in Moscow's City Hall. ``Aware of our responsibility before the people and history, we have decided to withdraw from the Communist Party to help create a multiparty system and to have the possibility to more effectively lead the councils we head,'' the statement said. Leaders of Democratic Platform made a declaration after Yeltsin's speech Thursday that they also were quitting the party. They said they would struggle to gain a fraction of the party's vast wealth in proportion to the percentage of the 18 million Communist Party members who join their new party. At a news conference, they said they would hold a founding congress for a new, non-Communist party in October, and that they believed many party members would follow them. ``People see that the vicious circle has been broken,'' said Democratic Platform leader Vladimir Lysenko of Moscow. Gorbachev ``doesn't understand the size of the movement that started yesterday,'' added Stepan Sulakhin of the Siberian city of Tomsk. While Democratic Platform does not expect Yeltsin to join, ``Boris Yeltsin remains the leader of the entire democratic movement,'' he said. But Sulakhin and other Democratic Platform leaders said it was too early to say exactly how many members of their own organization, and of the party itself, would join. The new party also will have to work out its programs in the coming months, they said. ``Our party will not be a Communist Party, but it will not be a party of confrontation,'' said Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, who has been the rector of Higher Party School in Moscow. ``It will be a party of social progress.'' Shostakovsky said the new party would accept both market economics and private property in a new economic system, but that the approach must be ``well-thought out.'' Shostakovsky estimated months ago that Democratic Platform had 500,000 to 600,000 supporters among Communist Party members. Surveys by the group indicate that about 40 percent of the 18 million members of the Communist Party are sympathizers.

DOC.HEAD: 39 Officers Injured in Jail Brawl Over Religious Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd and last grafs with 19 inmates injured, two hospitalized; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A group of jail inmates bent on avenging the knifing of their Muslim religious leader stormed a cellblock at a city jail Friday, and 39 officers were injured trying to stop the fighting. At least 19 of the 60 inmates involved in the brawl at Riker's Island also were injured, said Correction Department spokeswoman Ruby Ryles. Seventeen weapons were recovered in the cellblock hallway after the fight, she said. Rikers Island is the maximum security city jail, located on an island in the East River off the borough of Queens. According to Ryles, the fight stemmed from Thursday night's stabbing by inmate Rolando Gonzalez of Andrew Jackson, the elected imam, or spiritual leader, of the jail's Muslim population. Authorities said they didn't know what prompted the stabbing. Forty-eight Muslim inmates were returning from church services around 3 p.m. Friday when they passed Gonzalez's cellblock, Ryles said. ``They tried to crash the block and get their revenge on Gonzalez,'' she said. A dozen inmates in the hallway clashed with the Muslim prisoners, and 50 correction officers were called in to subdue the brawlers. Four of the injured officers and two injured inmates were hospitalized, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rules Out Political Strings to Western Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, SUBBING 15th graf `Politburo members' to UPDATE with Central Committee not reaching decision on new Politburo members and INSERTING three grafs after 18th graf `He denounced' to ADD Gorbachev quotes. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev closed the Communist Party's 28th congress Friday by saying he would welcome Western aid without political strings, and warning of a ``gap'' between the party and the people. The congress elected a new 412-member Central Committee that appeared to be packed with moderate reformers of the Gorbachev mold. And Gorbachev ousted hard-liner Yegor K. Ligachev from the Central Committee and the Politburo. The nearly 4,700 delegates to the congress closed their tumultuous two-week session by giving themselves a standing ovation and singing ``The Internationale,'' the socialist anthem. The congress was the stormiest in the Kremlin since 1921, when Bolshevik revolutionaries faced violent uprisings among workers and sailors. It also marked a major political victory for Gorbachev, and cemented his hold over the party. It will be a different party, however, with the exodus of maverick Boris N. Yeltsin and other reformers. The congress opened July 2 with a demand from a miner that Gorbachev and the entire leadership resign. The meeting hit its emotional peak on Thursday when Yeltsin announced his resignation from the 18-million member organization. At the close of the congress, delegates applauded Gorbachev's statement that ``this is the end of the Cold War'' and that doors were opening to the West. The decision of leaders of seven industrialized nations to consider offering the Soviet Union economic aid, he said, showed the success of his government's effort ``to overcome self-isolation and become an integral part of the world economy.'' Western leaders, meeting this week in Houston, Texas, resolved to study giving economic aid to Moscow, as advocated by West Germany and France. President Bush said Wednesday he would look more favorably on helping the Soviet government if it would cut defense spending. Gorbachev told delegates: ``We are ready to cooperate and will be grateful for assistance being not just seekers but partners who are not going to take anything free.'' ``I want to emphasize that I exclude all attempts to stipulate any political conditions for such cooperation,'' Gorbachev said. ``It can and it must develop on an equal and mutually beneficial grounds.'' His comments were the highest-level Soviet response to the Houston summit. In a surprise development, the largely traditionalist party congress approved Gorbachev's plan to nearly double the size of the Politburo to 23 members and give seats to the party leaders of the 15 Soviet republics. The Central Committee met late Friday night to choose Politburo members, but no decision was made by early Saturday. The Politburo, the party's highest body, was redesigned to ensure a moderate cast and help reduce the ethnic tension that is ripping the country apart. Restructuring the Politburo also marked a triumph in Gorbachev's drive to shift power from the party to the government, which he also heads. The Politburo appeared unlikely to meet frequently or to seek control matters not dealing directly with the party. Gorbachev, smiling, relaxed and very much in control, warned the delegates in his six-minute closing remarks of a ``gap between the party committees and workers, peasants, and intellectuals.'' He denounced those, who like, Yeltsin, ``demand repentence from the party, settling scores, those who declare it even a criminal organization, those who attempt by doing this to remove (the party) from the political life of the country.'' Gorbachev, in an interview with CBS News, said he didn't ``see anything frightening'' in the prospect of a multiparty system emerging in the Soviet Union. Summing up the results of the congress, Gorbachev said it did not mark as some thought the death of the party, but rather ``the rebirth and renewal of the Communist Party.'' ``In spite of all the criticism ... all the delegates feel certain that we're on the right course, and that reforms should advance in all directions,'' he told CBS News. Yeltsin's theatrical announcement that he was quitting the party, and statements by other reformers that they two were leaving, signaled the first split in the party since factions were formally banned in 1921. Besides Yeltsin, the reformist mayors of Moscow and Leningrad, Gavriil Popov and Anatoly Sobchak, also announced they were quitting the party, along with leaders of the radical Democratic Platform. Equally worrisome from Gorbachev's perspective was a nationwide warning strike Wednesday by miners who demanded that nationalization of all party assets and a mass exodus of workers from the party. Yeltsin, Sobchak and Popov have also indicated they would use their government positions to divest the party of its billions of rubles worth of publishing houses, office buildings, cars and vacation resorts. Thousands of people have quit the party in recent months, and the departure of the reform leaders and the rising anger of miners and other workers appeared likely to accelerate that process. The precise impact could not immediately be determined although it cracked the unity among reformers that Gorbachev has been urging.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Blames Israel for Slump in Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's foreign minister on Friday blamed Israel for the slump in the U.S. drive to open Mideast neogtiations. Marwan al-Qasim also said after talking to Secretary of State James A. Baker III that he hoped the United States would be dealing with the Palestine Liberation Organization again. ``I hope that the suspension of the dialogue will not last too long,'' the Arab official said. The Bush administration last month suspended its talks with the PLO after Chairman Yasser Arafat took no action against Abul Abbas, a member of the PLO executive council who was accused of plotting a terrorist attack against Israel. Meanwhile, diplomatic sources said Baker hopes doctors will permit Israeli foreign minister David Levy, who is recovering from surgery, to come here for talks early next month. The U.S. drive came to a halt in March when Israel's cabinet collapsed over Baker's formula for Israeli-Palestinian talks. Al-Qasim, blaming Israel, said, ``the efforts by the American administration were derailed by Israel.'' ``We hope there will be reconsideration, and have everyone indulge in a meaningful dialgoue that would lead to the comprehensive peace we need,'' he added. Jordan, after failing to persuade Israel to relinquish the West Bank, decided two years ago to leave the area's future to the Palestinians. But the foreign minister said Jordan always has been interested in achieving a durable and just peace. ``We never went out of the circle and we continue to be in that,'' he said. Jordan, like all Arab states, considers the PLO the sole representative of Palestinians. ``We are trying to inject every possible idea that would keep the peace process going and re-engage the Palestinians,'' Al-Qasim said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Secretary Says Learnfare Bugs Must Be Worked Out
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top welfare official on Friday commended a Wisconsin experiment tying welfare benefits to school attendance but cautioned officials to resolve the program's administrative problems. U.S. Health and Social Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said his office would continue to monitor the Learnfare program for improvement but had already found the program's goals ``quite laudable.'' ``We feel that the data thus far merit continued investment in the program,'' Sullivan said at a news conference. Learnfare, started in 1987, trims Aid to Families with Dependent Children benefits to families whose teen-agers skip school. It has been touted as an incentive for teen-agers to continue their education and chances of employment, but harshly criticized by welfare advocates. The program was ordered suspended in Milwaukee schools this week by U.S. District Judge Terence Evans, who cited poor attendance records that have resulted in some families being wrongly penalized. A lawsuit filed against the program said one family was evicted from its home and others had to turn to food pantries for food. Evans' injunction applies only to the 3,200 teen-agers attending Milwaukee Public Schools who have lost or are in danger of losing AFDC benefits under Learnfare. The program continues in other parts of the state. Penalties under Learnfare average about $100 a month for an average family receiving $517 a month in benefits. Sullivan, who was in Marshfield to dedicate a new $6.1 million research center at Marshfield Clinic, said he was not concerned by the judge's action. ``Obviously, with any program that is new, there are always a number of glitches or problems that might need to be addressed,'' he said. ``Clearly, the administrative issues must be addressed.'' Despite criticism that Learnfare is a cruel and unsuccessful anti-truancy tool, the federal government in June approved Wisconsin's request to expand the program to include elementary children. ``We have a number of problems that will be addressed by our society if we can improve our education approach,'' Sullivan said. Dropout rates are as high as 50 percent in some inner-city schools, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former President to Observe Haitian Election
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter, who has traveled the world monitoring elections and advising governments, will lead a team of international political experts to help Haiti prepare for free elections. Carter, as chairman of the council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, will lead the team to the island nation on July 25-26 at the invitation of the Haitian government, according to a statement issued Friday. The mission will help determine the need for election observers in Haiti's general elections in November. Carter said the delegates will meet with government officials, the electoral council, the Council of State, political candidates and military leaders to develop methods ``to assure Haitians that they can vote in confidence and without fear of their safety.'' Delegates also include Rosalynn Carter and officials from Barbados and Canada, including former Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Negotiate in Quebec; British Columbia Indians Block Roads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with minister's comments, shortages reported, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Mohawk Indians said Friday that Quebec has offered concessions to end their armed confrontation with police. The dispute spread across Canada to British Columbia, where Indians blocked roads to show support. Quebec's native affairs minister, John Ciaccia, arrived at the barricades in a chauffeur-driven limousine Friday for the second day of talks behind Mohawk lines. He told reporters Thursday's talks ended on a positive note. On Wednesday, an officer was killed in a gun battle between Mohawks and provincial police Wednesday arising from planned construction of a golf course addition on what Mohawks say is ancestral land. An investigation was to determine which side fired the fatal bullet. The standoff and tight police security created problems on both sides. After three days of living in a town under siege, residents grumbled that this community of 3,000 people was running out of supplies. Mohawks complained that police restricted access to Indian territory and food, medicine and water were in short supply. Access to Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, was so restricted that even a truck delivering morning papers was turned back. Ciaccia said Friday, ``I think we have some basis for negotiations and discussions and we will pursue them. We are taking these negotiations one day at a time and it's too early to give details on progress.'' Other Mohawks, on the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal, blocked the Mercier Bridge in solidarity with their Oka brethren. The span links the populous south shore of the St. Lawrence River with the island of Montreal. Ellen Gabriel, Mohawk spokeswoman in Oka, said she warned Ciaccia by phone that natives would blow up the bridge if police attack. The dispute started four months ago when Mohawks built a roadblock to prevent Oka from building an extension to a nine-hole golf course on land the Mohawks say belongs to them. Early Wednesday, a provincial police raiding squad stormed the barricade, setting off the gun battle that killed Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31. Members of the militant Warrior societies from Kahnawake and from the Akwesasne reserve, south of Cornwall, Ontario, then filtered into Oka to reinforce the Mohawk position. Police sent reinforcements, and now total about 1,000 here. About 200 Mohawks stared down at police from the top of a hill. ``The police have to retreat completely from the area before we can ever work out a deal with Ciaccia,'' Ms. Gabriel said. She said that on Thursday, ``Mr. Ciaccia gave us a message and some details about some of the bargains that the governments want to make with us.'' She said Ciaccia discussed a possible guarantee that natives involved in the occupation would not be prosecuted, another Mohawk peacemaking condition. Just outside the town, young Indians drove cars and trucks at high speed along a native-controlled stretch of Highway 344, conveying news of police movements to other Mohawks and to journalists. The Union of British Columbia Indian Chiefs asked all native bands in Canada's westernmost province to block roads and bridges in their territories. Three roads were blocked for a time. An Indian chief, Marvin Bob of the Pavilion band, was arrested, charged with public mischief and released. Le Journal de Montreal said Friday that ballistics tests show the bullet that killed Lemay was not the same type as those from his service weapon or from the weapons of his colleagues. Montreal police declined to comment. Ms. Gabriel said Ciaccia asked the natives to cooperate in the police investigation of Lemay's death. ``We said yes,'' she said. `` We know we're innocent. We did not cause the death.'' A spokesman for Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said the federal government is monitoring the standoff at Oka but considers it a provincial dispute for now.

DOC.HEAD: Music Group Threatens Boycott if Louisiana Labeling Bill Signed
DOC.TEXT: The North American Concert Promoters Association announced Friday it would cancel its New Orleans convention this fall if the governor signs into law a bill requiring labels on explicit records. Under the bill, which if signed by Gov. Buddy Roemer would be the first state law of its type, records with lyrics some consider offensive or obscene would be labelled and kept from minors. Carl Freed, director of the concert promotion group, said in a statement from New York: ``If this bill becomes law, concert promoters, recording artists and community retailers will be driven out of business. They are being made scapegoats by soap box politicians.'' The bill now awaiting action from Roemer would require the labeling of any recording that promotes or has as its central theme illegal use of drugs and alcohol, violence, ritualistic acts or certain kinds of sexual behavior. On Thursday, members of the music industry in Louisiana suggested a voluntary labeling program to head off Roemer's signature of the bill. ``Our plan is to have every record dealer in the state voluntarily sign a pledge that they will not sell records with explicit lyrics to minors,'' said Shea Dixon, backer of a proposed Grammy Hall Of Fame for New Orleans. ``That's pretty much what's being done now. This just formalizes it.'' Record dealers said they have a standing policy of not selling records that deal with sex, drugs or violence to minors. State Sen. William Jefferson, a Democrat, said the bill awaiting Roemer's action is unconstitutional. Dealers said it's simply too confusing to live with. The Record Industry Association Of America labeling system, which took effect July 1, effectively singles out records with explicit lyrics, said Freddie Szilagi, manager of Tower Records in New Orleans.

DOC.HEAD: Stones Cancel Two London Concerts Because of Richards Injury
DOC.TEXT: The Rolling Stones canceled sellout concerts in London on Friday and Saturday nights because lead guitarist Keith Richards has an infected finger. Richards told reporters Friday he would ``absolutely'' be back on stage for Saturday's concert at Wembley Stadium, but within hours doctors decided his finger needed more time to heal. The finger, pricked on the end of a guitar string, was injured during a show last weekend at Wembley. ``Two physicians and a hand specialist have conferred and agreed it would not be advisable for him to play for the next couple of days,'' said tour publicist Jane Sen. Doctors warned Richards that playing for two hours at Friday night's Wembley concert with his infected finger would cause it serious damage. A concert Wednesday night in Cardiff, Wales, was also canceled because of the injury. The Wembley concerts, where sellout crowds of 72,000 had been expected, have been rescheduled for Aug. 24-25, Ms. Sen said. Dr. Michael Paul, who saw the star Friday afternoon, said: ``Mr. Richards is suffering from an abcess on the left third finger, which has spread to the rest of his finger and the lower part of his hand. ``The condition is rapidly improving under antibiotics.'' Speaking from a house in Wimbledon where he is staying during the British leg of the Stones' Urban Jungle tour, Richards said: ``I stabbed it on the end of a guitar string at last weekend's show at Wembley.'' By Tuesday, he said, ``it had swollen up like a football'' and Wednesday night's concert in Cardiff was canceled. It has been rescheduled for Monday. ``It's the first show I've ever missed in 27 years. It's like I've blotted my copy book,'' the guitarist said. After a week on antibiotics and off alcohol, he said, the swelling was going down. The tour is scheduled to end in August with concerts in Prague, Czechoslovakia, and East Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Audubon Prints Stolen From Louisiana State Museum
DOC.TEXT: Sixty rare Audubon prints and two by Goya were stolen from the state museum, and police issued an arrest warrant Friday for a volunteer who allegedly carried them out past the guards, officials said. The stolen prints were brokered through dealers and ended up in France, Canada, Chicago, Philadelphia and New York, state police Capt. Ronnie Jones said. Officials said they did not know how much the prints brought, but it was estimated maybe as much as $2 million. All but one of the Audubons have been located, Jones said. The dealers apparently were unaware the prints were stolen, and have cooperated with police efforts to get them back. Museum director James Sefcik said other prints are also missing, but the list is still being compiled because there is no accurate record of total museum holdings. Two of the missing prints were by Goya. Michael Moskaluk, a 43-year-old volunteer at the museum, is sought in the thefts, which took place at the Presbytere branch of the museum, in the French Quarter. Moskaluk had five previous felony convictions, including art theft, and served time in federal and state prison in Massachusetts, Jones said. Sefcik said the thefts were discovered by the museum's curator nearly a month ago when other prints were returned to storage after an exhibition of Audubon's Louisiana birds. The theft was kept secret until Friday while state police investigated. The stolen prints were apparently taken past guards during the transfer of other museum material, Sefcik said. The Audobon prints were part of a complete set of 425 acquired by the museum 150 years ago, shortly after John James Audubon finished the so-called elephant folio of 2 feet-by-3 feet prints.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General's Office Takes Umbrage at Accused Officer
DOC.TEXT: The attorney general's office on Friday expressed amazement that a high-ranking officer accused of covering up the massacre of six Jesuit priests has not been arraigned. An arrest warrant was issued June 26 for the officer, who remained in command of an elite infantry battalion until at least July 5, when the military said he was placed under arrest. Court sources said military authorities were obliged by law to take Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez before 4th Criminal Court Judge Ricardo Zamora as soon as he was arrested. ``We're amazed that several days after Hernandez' detention, he still has not been brought before the judge,'' said Edward Blanco, an assistant attorney general. Army troops have admitted killing six Jesuit priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter last Nov. 16. A colonel, three lieutenants and five soldiers have been charged with murder. Zamora ordered Hernandez' arrest because of testimony alleging the officer ordered the burning of military log books that could have shed light on the crime. The delays in arresting Hernandez and in taking him before the judge for arraignment come despite repeated avowals from Defense Minister Gen. Humberto Larios of the military's complete collaboration with the investigation into the Jesuit massacre. Asked why Hernandez, who the armed forces say is under arrest at the National Guard headquarters, has not been taken before the judge, military spokesman Maj. Mauricio Chavez Caceres responded: ``I don't know.'' Local Jesuit and church authorities contend high-ranking military authorities are engaged in a cover-up designed to protect the ``intellectual authors'' of the killings. U.S. legislators intend to condition part of next year's military aid to El Salvador on successful investigation and prosecution of the priests' murderers.

DOC.HEAD: Giant, Flesh-Eating Lizards Prepare for Public Debut
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Naga and Wanita, a pair of giant, flesh-eating Komodo dragons from Indonesia, inspired a burst of affection from their keeper Friday as he prepared for their weekend debut at the Cincinnati Zoo. ``Naga!'' Cincinnati Zoo reptile supervisor Johnny Arnett shouted at the seven-foot-long, 120-pound male lizard staring back at him through the glass wall of his custom-built cage. ``I love them. That's the sexiest lizard in the world right there,'' Arnett said, whistling at Naga. The gray-green Komodo dragons, a gift from Indonesian President Suharto to President Bush, are the second set in the United States. The first pair live at the National Zoo in Washington, D.C. Arnett said the Singapore Zoo has the only other set of Komodo dragons outside Indonesia. The Indonesian ambassador to the United States, Adbul Rachman Ramly, arrived Friday for a reception to celebrate the opening of the permanent display here. The 10-by-40-foot cage includes a bathtub-size pool of water, as well as plants and a painted backdrop based on photographs Arnett took on tropical Komodo Island, the home of the reptiles, when he visited Indonesia to bring back Naga and Wanita. The lizards also have an outdoor display. ``They're 7 years old, so they have some growing to do. When they're full size, they should be nine feet long and about 175 pounds,'' Arnett said. Naga, whose slender tail makes up half his length, crawled around his cage Friday on his stocky legs, lifting his head and flicking his six-inch forked tongue. Wanita remained in a den to one side. ``She's not hiding from us as much as she's hiding from him,'' Arnett said, explaining that the behavior indicates the female is carrying eggs she wants to protect. ``If she lays those eggs, and if we get them, we will be the first zoo in the Western Hemisphere to breed them in captivity,'' Arnett said. David and Tracy Barker, who raise rare pythons in Baltimore for sale to zoos, said they traveled to Cincinnati for the opening of the lizard display. ``He is beautiful. He is absolutely perfect,'' David Barker said, gazing at Naga with a smile on his face. ``We fantasize about seeing the babies born, that's what it is,'' Tracy Barker said. ``That would be amazing.'' In the wild, Komodo dragons usually eat rotting flesh scavenged from the carcasses of dead animals, but are fast runners if they choose to hunt live game, Arnett said. ``They've been known to walk down the street in a village going after dogs and such,'' he said. The zoo plans to limit their menu to goat, chicken, and the occasional rodent left over from feeding snakes. ``It's very hard to give them a rotted carcass. It's disgusting to the public and it's disgusting to me,'' Arnett said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules No Charges Warranted in Fire that Killed Five
DOC.TEXT: A jury conducting an inquest into the deaths of five children in a housing complex fire ruled Friday that no criminal charges should be filed against police, firefighters, or the child's mother. The Dane County Circuit Court jury determined there was no criminal negligence in the children's deaths March 13 at the Somerset Apartments. It noted that testimony in the case was contradictory. The fire, which started on a kitchen stove burner, killed Derrick Robinson, 9; Kenneth Jones, 5; Eboni Jones, 2; Cynthia Jones, 1, and Mark Jones, 5 months. Some residents of the complex testified police and fire officials were callous about the lives of poor black children and did not attempt an immediate rescue although the childrens' screams could be heard outside the building. Some also claimed police prevented citizens from entering the burning building to try to rescue the children and one officer used a flashlight to beat back a man attempting a rescue. Police and firefighters testified they refused to allow rescue attempts because they feared further loss of life. Authorities testified they had difficulty locating Cheryl Robinson, the mother of the five, and were uncertain if she was home when the fire broke out. Residents, however, testified they saw Ms. Robinson flee the burning building and plead for someone to rescue her children. ``I'm surprised the descrepancies seem even greater now after four days of testimony,'' District Attorney William Foust said.

DOC.HEAD: Spiritual Leader of Orthodox Christians Visits New York
DOC.TEXT: Patriarch Dimitrios, the spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox Christians, stepped off a train at Penn Station on Friday and was welcomed by several hundred flag-waving faithful. ``As a spiritual leader and as a free man, I am deeply moved that God has enabled me to visit beautiful New York City for the first time,'' said Dimitrios, the first Orthodox patriarch to visit the United States. Mayor David Dinkins greeted Dimitrios by noting the growing role of the Orthodox Church in Eastern Europe. Orthodox leaders here, he said, ``are now in a position to assist in the grand task of regenerating the church in their homelands.'' Most of the church's 250 million members live in Eastern Europe, but 6 million Orthodox Christians live in the United States, including 1 million in the New York area, according to the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese. Dimitrios, who arrived on a special train from Washington, was greeted by a brass band and several hundred men, women and children waving flags with the patriarch's white seal. ``It was a very proud moment,'' said Katina Mihaltses, who immigrated from Cyprus in 1956. ``The moment I saw him I felt like crying. My eyes were full of tears.'' Dimitrios, speaking through an interpreter, praised New York City as representing ``the model of a multi-racial society made up of a host of different races, nationalities, traditions and religions all joined in a coherent whole, united by common ideas of humanity and international solidarity.'' The 75-year-old religious leader was in Washington for a week to attend the 30th Greek Orthodox Biennial Clergy-Laity Congress. He will spend five days in the New York metropolitan area. Other stops on his tour will be in Pennsylvania, San Francisco, Chicago, Buffalo and Boston. Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I, installed in 1972, holds the title Archbishop of Constantinople. His domain includes the Albanian, Bulgarian, Czechoslovakian, Georgian, Greek, Polish, Romanian, Russian and Ukrainian Orthodox churches. Dimitrios lives and works in Istanbul, Turkey, known as Constantinople when it was capital of the Byzantine Empire.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Breaks Arm While Vacationing
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa broke his arm while taking a few days off for a fishing vacation at his cabin in northern Poland, state television said Friday. The accident occurred during Walesa's annual summer vacation in the Kaszubian Lakes region, where he has a cabin. There were contradictory versions of how it happened. The state television report said Walesa fell from a ladder Thursday, breaking his right arm. It gave no further details. A source close to the Solidarity leaders's office in Gdansk said he was told Walesa was injured in a traffic mishap Tuesday, while driving his van which was loaded with lumber for cabin repairs. The van reportedly slid into a ditch on an uneven dirt road, the source said. Walesa himself could not be reached for comment. His cabin has no telephone.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to restore writethru designation
Report: Eastern Airlines to Face Charges for Maintenance Practices
SUBS: CORRECTS spelling to Shugrue sted Shagrue in 7th, 8th and last grafs
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has notified Eastern Airlines that it will be charged with criminal violations for allegedly altering maintenance and safety records before last year's strike, NBC News reported Friday. Quoting unidentified sources close to Eastern, NBC reported that the airline is considering whether to plead guilty or no contest. A federal grand jury conducted a 10-month investigation into charges that Eastern altered the records at New York's Kennedy and La Guardia airports and at the Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta, Eastern's major hub. Eastern managers at Kennedy and LaGuardia allegedly ordered mechanics to disregard safety guidelines and then falsified logbooks to show that proper checks had been made, the report said. If criminal charges are filed, it will be the first time an airline has faced such charges over maintenance practices. In the past, airlines have been fined by the Federal Aviation Administration for bad maintenance. Eastern's bankruptcy trustee, Martin R. Shugrue, told NBC he had discussed the investigation with the prosecutor, U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney. ``He sought my cooperation as trustee,'' Shugrue said. ``I pledged it to him, and the investigation is ongoing.'' The network said Eastern's lawyers plan to meet with the prosecutor Monday to say whether they'll fight the charges. Maloney would not comment on the case, and there was no answer at Eastern's offices in Miami Friday evening. Shugrue was appointed trustee to run Eastern as Frank Lorenzo's replacement as the airline tries to pull itself out of bankruptcy proceedings. Machinists at Eastern have been on strike since March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Rape Convict Charged With Deaths of Young Women Found in Texas Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `But Erika ...' to CORRECT name to Vasquez, sted Vaxquez; Subs 12th graf `Under Texas ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with causes of death listed in indictment. Picks up penultimate graf pvs: `Some of ...'
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury Friday indicted a jailed rapist on murder charges in the slayings of at least six young women and teen-agers whose bodies were found in the desert three years ago. But while some relatives of the victims were pleased, others thought authorities might be just finding a scapegoat. David Leonard Wood of El Paso was charged after new evidence was presented to a grand jury, although prosecutors would not elaborate. He is serving a 50-year prison term for a 1987 rape. The decayed remains of the victims, 14 to 23 years old, were found in the desert about 18 miles northeast of El Paso between Sept. 4, 1987 and March 14, 1988. Each of the victims had been missing at least two months before the body was discovered. All were buried in shallow graves within a half-mile of each other. Three people are still missing. The discovery led to an intensive investigation and the formation of a special task force that has dwindled to two members. ``This investigation has gone on practically three years and a lot of my staff's been involved and a great number of officers and other agencies have been involved,'' said District Attorney Steve Simmons. ``We're certainly relieved that in a crime like this the subject can be brought to justice.'' ``Oh, I'm real happy right now,'' said Marcia Wheatley, the mother of Desiree Wheatley, whose remains were found Oct. 20, 1987. But Erika Dismukes, mother of Cheryl Lynn Vasquez Dismukes, who has been missing since she was 19, said she was angry that Wood was indicted. ``David had nothing to do with it. Maybe he knows something but he had nothing to do with it,'' Mrs. Dismukes said. Mona Dismukes, the missing woman's sister-in-law, also was angry. ``They don't know who else to blame,'' she said. Wood knew Cheryl Lynn and at least one of the confirmed victims. The Dismukes family has conducted its own investigations into the murders and disappearances and believes Wood is innocent, Erika Dismukes said. The indictment says one victim was stabbed several times with a sharp instrument and the others were killed ``by some means, instrument or weapon, unknown to the grand jury.'' Under Texas' serial murder law, Wood faces life in prison or execution by injection if he's convicted. Some of the victims were runaways or prostitutes, and police were criticized for not responding more quickly to reports of their disappearances. Wood, who was convicted in March 1988 of the rape, had been mentioned before as a suspect. Last year, he filed a $20.5 million lawsuit against Police Chief John Scagno, claiming police schemed to implicate him because they could not solve the case.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Throws Out Warrant for Arrest of Reputed Duvalierist
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A judge dismissed a warrant for the arrest of Roger Lafontant, a former high official of the Duvalier dictatorship whose return from exile prompted a nationwide protest strike, radio stations said Friday. Magistrate Justin Fougere acted after government prosecutor Bayard Vincent showed up in court Thursday to defend the warrant, but left before the judge arrived, after waiting for him for more than an hour, independent Radio Haiti Inter reported. Fougere declared the arrest warrant null and void because of Vincednt's absence, the report said. In an interview Friday with Radio Antilles, another independent station, Vincent protested Fougere's decision and accused the Justice Department and police of complicity in obstructing justice. Vincent issued an arrest warrant for Lafontant last Saturday, the day Lafontant returned after more than four years in exile in the neighboring Dominican Republic. The return from exile of Lafontant and retired Maj. Gen. Williams Regala was widely regarded as an attempt by Duvalier loyalists to disrupt general elections scheduled for Nov. 4. Foreign Minister Kesler Clermont told a news conference at the United Nations that the Haitian government was seeking about 345 U.N. observers to ensure free and fair elections in November. But he admitted a consensus by the 15-member Security Council was unlikely and the issue was expected to be taken up by the General Assembly on July 23. Past elections in Haiti have been marred by bloodshed and violence, but the strife has been entirely domestic. Opponents of Security Council involvement say U.N. intervention could set an unfortunate precedent for handling other domestic disputes. Political and union leaders organized a nationwide one-day protest strike here Wednesday after President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot failed to meet its demand to arrest Lafontant and Regala, who returned separately from exile last week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Murder Charge in Infanticide Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday dismissed a murder charge against a veterinarian who slammed his newborn son against a delivery room floor seven years ago after realizing the boy had birth defects. Daniel McKay had been tried twice on the murder charges. Both trials ended in hung juries. Cook County Circuit Judge Will Gierach on Friday ruled there wasn't enough evidence against McKay to sustain the charge of murder in the 1983 slaying in this south Chicago suburb. ``There will be no more trial, it's over, it's done,'' said McKay's attorney Jo-Anne Wolfson. She said the state cannot bring her client to trial on a lesser charge. McKay and his wife, Carol, broke into tears when the judge made his ruling, Ms. Wolfson said. McKay slammed his infant son to the delivery room floor moments after the boy was born with a cleft palate, a harelip and webbed fingers. His attorneys claimed that the child's terrible condition had driven McKay into a state of temporary insanity. The state argued the deformities did not excuse the killing. ``Baby McKay did not deserve the fate he met,'' Raymond Garza, an assistant state's attorney, argued at one point in the proceedings. ``He was not such a horrible creature that his life deserved to be snuffed out.'' After the two hung juries, the defense moved in November 1987 that the charge be dismissed. Judge Gierach granted the motion in January 1988, but the state appealed. The appeals court returned the case to Gierach on a technicality. The judge's final dismissal on Friday left McKay, who practices veterinary medicine in Beecher, ``absolutely ecstatic,'' said his attorney. The McKays have one child, Amy, 14.

DOC.HEAD: Shakeup at Soviet Defense Ministry
DOC.TEXT: Army Gen. Alexei D. Lizichev, the political commissar of the Soviet armed forces, has been relieved of his duties at his request for health reasons, the state news agency Tass reported Friday. He was replaced by his senior deputy, Col. Gen. Nikolai Shlyaga, Tass quoted a Defense Ministry statement as saying. Lizichev, 62, was appointed to his post shortly after Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. He has been assigned to the group of inspectors-general at the ministry, Tass said. The job's formal title is chief of the main political directorate of the Soviet army and navy, the head of the system of commissars that oversee the loyalty of the armed forces to the Communist Party. Radical reformers want to obliterate the system of communist control in the armed forces and the KGB security police. Lizichev was dropped Thursday from the list of nominees to the Communist Party's Central Committee, and his place on the policy-making body was taken by Shlyaga. Col. Gen. Viktor F. Yermakov was put in charge of the main personnel department of the Defense Ministry, replacing Gen. Dmitry S. Sukhorukov, 67, who also was relieved for health reasons, Tass said. Sukhorukov also was assigned to the inspectors-general's office.

DOC.HEAD: High-Rise Fire Kills One, Injures Two in England
DOC.TEXT: A fire swept the top four floors of a 16-story apartment block in this central England city Friday night, killing a woman resident and injuring two firefighters, police said. Firefighters on hydraulic ladders rescued eight people and 80 others escaped down a fire-protected staircase. They spent the night at a nearby community center. West Midlands Police said the cause of the fire was not immediately known. Divisional Officer Charlie Gunter of West Midlands Fire Brigade said the building was owned by the Smethwick city council and had recently been renovated. He said many residents had not yet moved back into their apartments.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Institute to Set Noses to the Task in Determining Odor
DOC.TEXT: A scent squad has been unleashed in Bartlesville to trace and identify an elusive odor that has plagued residents in the western part of town for months. The 19-member Bartlesville Odor Mitigation Task Force will distribute about a half-dozen devices to trap the smell, which then will be sniffed and characterized by select noses at a Chicago research company, officials say. The IIT Research Institute will try to match the descriptions with a smell that could be produced in the Bartlesville area, said Demetrio Moschandreas of the Chicago-based institute. The city has received 60 calls since Jan. 1 about the smells, but has been unable to determine the cause, said Barbara Hachmuth, superintendent of the city waste water management department. After dozens of reports of a smell likened to rotten eggs or butane, an energy-research institute operated by IIT in Bartlesville went to work. Linda McGrew, spokeswoman for the National Institute for Petroleum and Energy Research, said the task force will gather reports of the odor and plot them on a city map. She said odor-collection devices will be scattered in neighborhoods in this city of 35,000 about 40 miles north of Tulsa in northeastern Oklahoma, and volunteers will snag samples to be shipped to Chicago. ``You press a button and it will suck in the air and put it in a hermetically sealed bag,'' Ms. McGrew said of the devices. In Chicago, panel members will take a whiff of the contents and describe what they smell. Moschandreas said the panel has a list of 144 words or phrases to describe the smell, such as fried chicken, leather, alcohol, chemicals, soap and sour milk. Scientists at the institute will review the descriptions to see if they match any odors that could be produced in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Governor, New Education Chairman, Razzed by 5,000 Angry Teachers
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 teachers jeered Gov. Booth Gardner outside a hotel Friday where he was elected chairman of a national education reform group. Gardner, who bills himself as ``the education governor,'' said he was neither embarrassed nor moved by protest, which wasn't audible inside the Westin Hotel, where the Education Commission of the States held its annual meeting. ``It's their show and this is my show; we're both doing what we have to do,'' he said. Gardner has been at loggerheads with the teachers since February, when they staged a one-day walkout to protest his refusal to use part of a $750 million state revenue windfall to boost teachers' pay hikes. Gardner was speaking Friday before about 800 people from the commission, a reform group that includes governors, lawmakers and education leaders from every state but Montana. ``We need to rethink public education from the ground up,'' he said. ``What's missing is a clear vision of how our nation's entire educational system _ from Head Start to Harvard _ can be redirected to serve the needs of the future rather than the needs of the past.'' Gardner has promoted innovative teaching programs in the state and free pre-school for disadvantaged 4-year-olds. He has promised to sponsor across-the-board pay boosts for teachers next winter but wants some of the pay package to be linked to performance, which the teachers' union opposes. The protest march Friday was one the larger ones in recent memory in Seattle. The throng was estimated by police at between 5,000 and 6,000, at 12,000 by National Education Association President Keith Geiger. The teachers complained that Congress and state legislators weren't committing their checkbooks to education. The protest theme _ ``No More Hot Air'' _ was emblazoned across the front of a huge hot air balloon. Washington Education Association president Carla Nuxoll, a teacher from the Spokane area, said Gardner is heralded as an educational leader everywhere but in his home state. ``A true `education governor' must do more than just puff about his commitment to education,'' Nuxoll said. ``I can assure you that there is far more hot air inside this hotel than we have outside right now.''' ``He'd get an `A' in speechmaking, but an `F' when the assignment comes due,'' said Katrina Dohn, a fifth grade teacher in Tukwila, south of Seattle. Washington's class sizes are the fifth largest in the nation. Textbook and per-pupil spending are below the national average, and teacher salaries have dropped from fourth in the nation to 23rd in the past decade, Nuxoll said. The education commission's outgoing chairman is New Mexico Gov. Garrey Carruthers. Maine Gov. John McKernan was tapped as chairman-elect.

DOC.HEAD: Bahamas Lawyer, Haitian Exile Leader Want Probe into Haitian Drownings
DOC.TEXT: Haitian exile leaders on Friday called for investigations into the drownings of 39 Haitians whose overloaded sailboat capsized while being towed by Bahamian authorities. Exiles also questioned the Bahamian government's decision to bury the dead in a mass grave on an uninhabited key. The circumstances surrounding the drownings ``seem quite questionable and demands an official explanation'' into whether officers of the Bahamian Defense Force were negligent in the accident, said Eliezer Regnier, a lawyer and human rights activist in the Bahamas. ``The fact that the deaths occurred while these people were in official custody of the defense force all the more warrants more explanation than what was given by the official press release of the government,'' Regnier said. Another 67 Haitians pitched into the sea when the sailboat rolled over Wednesday were rescued by those aboard the Bahamas Defense Force patrol boat. ``No one should treat his or his own brothers and sisters this way,'' said the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, a Haitian exile leader in Miami, who also urged an investigation. ``This is shameful.'' The bodies of 30 men and nine women were buried in a mass grave Wednesday at uninhabited Bitter Guana Cay in the Exumas, about 80 miles from Nassau, according to the government. ``Although the people are poor and may have been trespassing in another jurisdiction, there ought to have been some dignity given them. There need not have been a mass burial'' said Regnier, a Haitian-born Bahamian. The statement said the boat was chased by the Bahamian Defense Force vessel Yellow Elder after it was spotted off Staniel Cay, about 200 miles southeast of the southern tip of Florida near Great Exuma island. The sloop tried to enter shallow waters before it was overtaken and put under tow by the Yellow Elder, the government said. During the tow back to Staniel Cay, the sloop capsized. The survivors were brought Wednesday to Nassau. In almost all cases, Haitians intercepted while fleeing their homeland for the United States are returned home. U.S. Coast Guard Lt. Jeff Karonis said Friday that 537 Haitians have been picked up so far this year in the waters off Florida as they attempt to leave their Caribbean island. Earlier this week, 193 Haitians were picked up from a 40-foot boot. ``There's always the potential for a tragedy,'' he said about the dangerous crossing in vessels that may be overloaded or unseaworthy.

DOC.HEAD: Weary, Dirty Albanians Joyous On Arrival In Italy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs. UPDATING with Tirana rally where asylum-seekers called ``degenerate.'' Picks up 3rd graf, The four . .. with minor editing to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BRI1,1A,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of weary Albanians trudged from ferry boats onto Italian shores Friday, realizing a dream that had led them to besiege foreign embassies in Europe's last citadel of hard-line Communism. ``We shall win!'' refugees on one ferry chanted in Italian as they approached the port of Brindisi. Albania's state ATA news agency meanwhile reported that about 100,000 Albanians rallied on Friday in Skanderbeg Square, near Tirana's diplomatic quarter, in support of the country's Communist leadership. Xhelil Gjoni, a member of the party's policy-making Politburo, told the rally that ``Albania and its people's power are unshaken by degenerate people who abandon their homeland or by anyone else,'' said a Tirana Radio broadcast, monitored in London. The four ships, chartered by the West German and Italian governments, picked up about 4,500 Albanians in Durres early Friday under an agreement worked out with United Nations mediation. After journeys of about seven hours, the ferries disgorged crowds of ragged, sweaty Albanians onto the Brindisi docks, where they were met by Red Cross workers and soldiers serving warm milk and cold soda. ``I am very, very happy to come here,'' said Artano Harizai, 25, as he and three friends examined plastic relief bags filled with new socks and shirts. ``Here and in Europe there's freedom. In Albania there's not.'' His friends, one without shoes and another shirtless, nodded vigorously and gave thumbs-down signs for the Albanian police. Fifteen Albanians were admitted to Brindisi's hospital, including two women expected to give birth soon, said Red Cross spokesman Ricardo Moro. Several other people were suffering from wounds suffered when Albanian police fired at people trying to scamble into Western embassies. A baby was born on one ship, the Espresso Grecia, after it left Albania, a Red Cross spokesman said. About 3,200 refugees were from West Germany's Embassy, and they boarded trains at the dock to continue to that country. ``Everyone off to freedom!'' a refugee cried to other Albanians waving from a departing train. A fifth ferry, chartered by the French government, took on 545 Albanians for a voyage from Durres directly to Marseille. About 800 Albanians from Italy's embassy were taken by bus to a temporary camp outside Brindisi, and 29 refugees from Greece's embassy took a plane from Brindisi to Athens, said Clara Minerva, assistant director of the local Interior Ministry office. The evacuation eased a crisis that prompted dismissals from the Albanian government and damaged its efforts to soften its isolationist foreign policy. Albanian leader Ramiz Alia introduced limited reforms this year, including some religious freedom and travel abroad. But that was not enough for the thousands of Albanians who sought refuge in foreign embassies in Tirana. Many predicted Albania's Communist government would fall, just as the East German government did last year after thousands of its citizens crowded foreign embassies to flee to the West. ``Many people are unhappy in Albania. They are with us,'' said a mining engineer who identified himself as Muharrem. Several people put on chains with crosses given to them by Italians at the dock. Until recently religious observances were forbidden in Albania. Several Albanians admitted to having had trouble with the government either because of criticizing it or having relatives who tried to escape from the country. Others said they had always dreamed of freedom or wanted a better life. ``We haven't a need for food,'' Muharrem said in broken English. ``We have the need for freedom of ideas.'' Many people said they hoped to eventually make it to the United States, where, as 21-year-old Voltan Rexhepi said: ``Life is good.'' Rexhepi said he spent the last five days squeezed into the West German Embassy. Albanian authorities frequently cut off the water and toilets became unusable, but the diplomats struggled to provide food for all 3,200, he and others said. The Albanians were transported by bus late Thursday from Tirana to Durres, where they boarded the ferries, they said. Police ringed the dock to prevent anyone else from jumping aboard, ferry crew members said. Durres is about 85 miles from Brindisi. Until Friday, only 51 of the asylum-seekers crammed into embassies had left Albania. The small group flew to Prague, Czechoslovakia, on Tuesday. Arrangements were made to fly 40 Albanians who had taken refuge in the Hungarian embassy to Budapest. As some Albanians left the ferries at Brindisi, they gaily waved their new red passports, their ticket to a new life. The Albanian government agreed to let the refugees leave after supplies of food and medicine in the embassies ran low and hygienic conditions deteriorated. The Foreign Ministry in Bonn said its embassy had been closed for renovations. ``The embassy is in an inconceivable state,'' said spokesman Juergen Chrobog.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Minister Back in London, Expected To Resign
DOC.TEXT: Britain's beleaguered trade secretary, Nicholas Ridley, came home Friday night from a trade visit to Hungary and expectations were he will resign after his charge that West Germany wanted to take over a united Europe. His comments in a magazine interview, which he later retracted, provoked cross-party calls for his resignation and were denounced in Germany, France and other European countries. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher refused Friday to answer questions about Ridley's political future, reportedly leaving the first move up to him. But even rank-and-file members of her Conservative Party, who applaud his warning of German supremacy over a united Europe, said he will have to go. Sir Marcus Fox, vice chairman of the 1922 Committee of Tory lawmakers, told BBC Radio 4 that Ridley's position was now ``very bad.'' Mrs. Thatcher told the House of Commons on Thursday that Ridley was not reflecting government policy, nor her own views, but she rejected demands for his dismissal. Ridley, 61, the outspoken and controversial son of Viscount Ridley, is considered Mrs. Thatcher's closest ideological ally in the Cabinet. Political commentators said his departure would be a blow to her. In the interview with the conservative weekly, the Spectator, Ridley said the West German government's support for European monetary union ``is all a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe. It has to be thwarted. ``This rushed take-over by the Germans on the worst possible basis, with the French behaving like poodles to the Germans, is absolutely intolerable.'' Ridley said he opposed yielding sovereignty to the 12-nation European Community, which he said was run by ``17 unelected reject politicians.'' He said: ``You might just as well give it to Adolf Hitler, frankly.'' Earlier Friday night, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd made the government's first move to repair the damage to Anglo-European relations. Speaking at the Anglo-American conference center near Oxford, Hurd said: ``Our alliance, our partnership and our friendship with France and Germany lie at the heart of modern British foreign policy. ``Lingering memories from the past do not prevent us from strengthening, month by month, the practical proofs of that friendship. ``Irreversible also is the steadily increasing cooperation with the fellow members and institutions of the European Community of which the prime minister spoke after the Dublin (EEC) summit (last month). ``Nothing will now put these processes in doubt.'' Paddy Ashdown, leader of the centrist Liberal Democratic Party, said: ``The issue has now become not Mr. Ridley's folly but Mrs. Thatcher's judgment. By refusing to sack him, she is multiplying the insult of his outrageous views.'' Gordon Brown, the opposition Labor Party's trade spokesman, said she was guilty of a ``dismal failure of leadership'' for leaving the decision about Ridley's future in his hands. ``With this indecision following on top of the Ridley insults, her inaction today signifies an astonishing abdication of responsibility that will make Britain the subject of, at best, ridicule, and at worst, hostility throughout Europe,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Orders Moody Detained; Sets Trial Date
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday ordered a man who has been the focus of a probe into fatal mail bombings held without bail until his trial on unrelated charges of witness tampering. Judge Wilbur D. Owens Jr. set a tentative trial date of Sept. 17 for Walter Leroy Moody Jr., 56. He also ruled that Moody's wife, Susan McBride Moody, 28, could be released on a $250,000 property bond. The Moodys were arrested Tuesday and charged in a 13-count federal indictment with conspiracy, obstruction of justice, subornation of perjury, bribery of a witness and tampering with a witness. The charges arose from Moody's attempts to erase a 1972 conviction for possession of a pipe bomb in Macon. The bomb injured his then-wife Hazel. Thursday's session of the bail hearing featured secretly videotaped meetings in March and April between the Moodys and Julie Linn West of Atlanta. The government contends she was one of two women the Moodys bribed and intimidated into providing Moody with a concocted alibi for the bombing. The materials used in the pipe bomb explosion reportedly were similar to those found in four December mail bombs, two of which killed a federal judge and a lawyer in December. At one point Friday, Owens closed the hearing after a prosecutors mentioned the mail bombings that killed 11th Circuit Court Judge Robert S. Vance and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson. The other bombs went to the 11th Circuit courthouse and to the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Letters that claimed responsibility for the mail bombs attributed them to a racist hate group. Bruce Harvey, Moody's attorney, has claimed that the indictment was a consolation prize for prosecutors who have been unable to indict Moody in the mail bombings despite six months of investigation. After an hourlong close hearing with Harvey and prosecutors, Owen returned to open court and ruled that attorneys in the Moodys' current trial could not discuss potential evidence in the mail bombings case. ``The charges in this court do not involve the bombings the government has mentioned,'' Owens said, noting neither Moody nor his wife has been indicted in the bombings. ``When and if they are indicted, that is a matter that will be taken up.''

Members of a reformist bloc in the Communist Party say they will follow the lead of maverick Boris N. Yeltsin and quit the party in what would be the first such split since the time of Lenin. The dramatic events came Thursday as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was wrapping up a personally victorious 28th party congress with the last major task: electing a new policy-making Central Committee. Delegates began voting by secret ballot this morning, the official Tass news agency said. About 420 candidates were running for the committee, which in its last form had 250 members but may be modified. After the vote, delegates will conclude debates on the new party rules and adjourn after hearing a report by Gorbachev summing up the congress, the news agency said.
