DOC.HEAD: Brady Offers Olive Branch in SEC-CFTC Battle; Chicago Cool
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady says he will oppose further reductions of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's powers if Congress passes legislation stripping the agency's authority over stock-index futures. Brady offered the olive branch at a Senate committee hearing Thursday on the Bush administration's plan to transfer control over stock-index futures to the rival Securities and Exchange Commission. One futures industry official said he saw Brady's remarks as an indication that the secretary thinks ``he's losing'' in the race to win Senate approval. ``I will oppose more sweeping changes to the CFTC authority if the administration's bill passes in its present form,'' Brady told the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. But outside the hearing, when asked what he would do if Congress doesn't pass the bill, Brady said: ``I think it will pass.'' A spokesman for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Andrew Yemma, declined comment but noted that in the past the Merc has favored merging the SEC and CFTC over stripping the futures regulator of some of its authority. At the Chicago Board of Trade, spokesman Michael O'Connell also declined comment on the specifics of Brady's proposal but restated the BOT's position that ``we are against the proposed legislation and stand by the CFTC as the regulatory body that should oversee all futures markets.'' ``We are opposed to anything that weakens the CFTC,'' said John Damgard, president of the Washington-based Futures Industry Association. Although he hadn't seen Brady's statement, Damgard who was in Chicago to give a speech, noted: ``I think there's a sense on Brady's part that he's losing. If this went to a vote right now, we're pretty confident we would take the day on an up or down vote.'' Stock-index futures, often used in program trading strategies by large institutional investors such as pension funds, allow investors to trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. The CFTC and the futures industry oppose the administration bill, saying it would cripple the agency's ability to regulate other futures products while drying up market liquidity and driving business out of the country. But the SEC and the Treasury Department argue the move is necessary to curb wild price swings in the stock markets arising out of price differences between the futures and securities markets. ``Stocks and stock-index futures are one market linked together by electronics,'' said Brady, who first advanced that opinion while heading a presidential task force that investigated the 1987 stock market crash. He noted that in the 42 years between 1940 and 1982 when stock index futures first began trading, there were only three instances when the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined by more than 6 percent, while there have been four instances since the 1987 crash. In an apparent attempt to allay concerns that the bill is the first step toward a complete dismantling of the CFTC which oversees the futures industry, Brady said ``the administration's proposal is not the proverbial `camel's nose under the tent.' ``The way the markets are now functioning makes no further shifts in regulatory jurisdiction necessary _ not Treasury bond futures to the SEC, not a full merger of the SEC and CFTC,'' he said. He urged passage of the bill to prevent further market disruptions. Noting that debate on the bill would lead to a political ``bloodletting,'' Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., complained that the administration should have settled the dispute. Instead ``we find ourselves acting as a referee between the SEC and the CFTC'' which he described as ``two agencies acting like children.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC To Present Plans for Restrictions on Net Capital Moves
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators are exploring plans for a financial warning system to head off potential troubles at big brokerage firms like those that sank Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The Securities and Exchange Commission voted Thursday to seek public comment on proposed changes in the net capital rule. That rule requires broker-dealers to maintain minimum amounts of cash and assets easily converted into cash to offset the risk of the securities they trade. ``This is not part of a process in which the commission is seeking to micro-manage or second-guess the management of a either broker-dealer or its parent,'' SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said. ``This is more in the nature of what I would characterize as a smoke alarm, a smoke detector,'' he said. ``This is more or less a corporate equivalent of that.'' Last February's sudden collapse of the parent company of junk bond giant Drexel has raised concerns that regulators aren't getting enough advance notice when the parents of Wall Street firms withdraw large amounts from capital reserves. While financially sound itself, Drexel's brokerage business was a victim of money woes at its parent Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. DBL Group filed for bankruptcy court protection after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt. The SEC and the New York Stock Exchange refused to allow it to draw down cash from the brokerage to repay its debt. Breeden said the intent of the rule change ``to give us a chance to make a quick review of whether a sudden and really enormous _ in proportion to total capital _ movement of capital is due to something that's a planned event or due to striking an iceberg.'' Richard G. Ketchum, director of the SEC's Market Regulation Division, said there are legitimate reasons like a restructuring for a parent company to withdraw large amounts of capital. The rule change, he said ``is in reaction to situations like Drexel,'' where the parent company was having major financing problems. He and other SEC officials said their task would be easier by pending legislation that would give them access to the financial health of the parent holding companies of broker dealers. The proposed rules changes must be reviewed _ and possibly re-worked _ before the commission can vote on fial passage. The proposal would require broker-dealers to give the SEC two days notice before withdrawing net capital beyond a prescribed amount, in excess of 20 percent over a 30-day period or 30 percent within a 90-day period. Current rules do not set a time limit for firms to report capital problems to the SEC, although they must file periodic disclosure statements. Firms are required to maintain net capital equalling at least 5 percent of customer-related receivables, and below 2 percent they must cease operations. The proposed rule change also would give the SEC authority to stop further capital transfers if it determines ``the result would put the firm in financial jeopardy,'' said Ketchum. In addition, the change would upgrade the standard for limiting capital withdrawals. The standard now is tied to the value of customer obligations.

DOC.HEAD: French Lodging Company Agrees To Pay $1.3 Billion for Motel 6
DOC.TEXT: Judging from its folksy radio ads and cut-rate conveniences, Motel 6 might be the last place to expect to find the French. Paris-based Accor SA said Thursday it had agreed to pay $1.3 billion in cash for Motel 6 LP in a deal that would make Accor the world's budget motel leader. Analysts said the timing of the proposal was somewhat surprising, given the generally weak environment for both real estate and financing. But Accor said it already has arranged financing for the buyout. Securities analyst William S. Fellows of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco noted that budget chains often benefit during economic downturns as travelers try to cut costs by choosing less expensive lodging. ``Motel 6 might lose some customers but you have other people trading down from mid-priced levels,'' he said. Accor already owns more than 850 hotels and 3,000 restaurants in 60 countries, including the growing 120-hotel Formula 1 budget chain in Europe. Its target has been to own 2,000 budget hotels, and buying Motel 6 with 554 motels would be a big step toward that goal. Motel 6 has carved out a profitable market niche for itself by emphasizing its low cost _ rooms average about $27 a night _ and no-frills ambience. Its radio ads end with the signature, ``We'll leave the light on for you.'' The company estimated it would have operating income of $220 million on revenue of $475 million this year. The deal appears to signal another hefty return for the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which led a group that bought the Motel 6 chain for about $880 million in 1985 and kept a controlling interest after the company went public a year later. Under the terms of the proposal, Accor said it had agreed to begin a tender offer of $22.50 per share in cash for the more than 55 million outstanding Motel 6 partnership units. Payments for preferred stock make up the balance. An affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis owns more than 50 percent of Motel 6 and the companies said it has agreed to tender its holdings under the offer. The deal was announced after the stock market closed. Motel 6 units rose $2.62{ a share to $19.25 on volume of 1.5 million shares in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Paul Dubrule and Gerard Pelisson, co-chairmen of Accor, said the deal will help their company become the world's pre-eminent budget hotel company. They said Motel 6 Chief Executive Joseph W. McCarthy and his management team would stay on, and Motel 6 headquarters would remain in Dallas. The founding partners of Kohlberg Kravis, Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, said the deal made sense for both sides. ``It is appropriate at this time, five years after we began the process of transforming Motel 6 into a dynamic, modernized and aggressive economy lodging company, that it become part of a global lodging company with even greater resources and potential,'' they said in a statement. Kohlberg Kravis and its partners acquired Motel 6 from City Investing Co. in 1985. The company was converted into a publicly traded limited master partnership in 1986 with units offered at $13.50 a share. A source close to the firm said investors who bought shares at that time will have received over $27 per unit for their investment by the time the Accor deal closes, a 21.5 percernt compounded annual rate of return counting both the amount of the tender and the $4.63 a share in cash dividends already paid. The source said those who invested in the original buyout did even better _ a 38 percent compounded annual rate of return on a $125 million equity investment. When Kohlberg bought it in 1985, Motel 6 had 378 motels with 42,279 rooms and 7,000 employees. The chain has since grown to 554 motels, 63,765 rooms and more than 11,500 employees. Accor said the deal will makke it the world's largest owner and operator of hotel rooms, with more than 160,000 rooms worldwide. Its properties include Sofitel, a luxury chain; Novotel and Mercure, aimed at business travelers; and Ibis-Urbis, moderately priced chains. Accor estimated it will earn nearly $150 million this year on sales of more than $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Union Sues U.S. Company for Unpaid Wages
DOC.TEXT: In an unusual case testing whether federal labor laws apply to U.S. subsidiaries overseas, a South Korean union is suing an American manufacturer of cable television components for more than $1 million in back wages. A South Korean union sued Pico Products Inc. in U.S. District Court on Thursday, alleging breach of contract for shutting down its South Korean factory and withholding more than $1 million in wages from workers. An attorney for the union, said the lawsuit was the first in federal court by foreign workers seeking to settle a labor disagreement. The lawsuit accuses Pico, based in Liverpool, N.Y., of suddenly closing its Pico Korea Ltd. factory in Buchun City in February 1989 to avoid compliance with a collective bargaining agreement. The union is seeking back wages and severance it claims are owed to 294 workers employed by Pico Korea, a wholly owned subsidiary of Pico. Frank E. Deale, legal director of the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York City, which is representing the South Korean union, said the lawsuit was filed on the basis of two federal laws. They are the Labor Management Relations Act, which gives federal courts jurisdiction to enforce collective bargaining agreements and the 1988 Worker Adjustment, Retraining and Notification Act, which entitles all workers employed by American corporations to 60-day notice of plant closings. Deale said the lawsuit would test whether that law can apply to employees of a U.S. corporation who work abroad. Pico Chairman Bernard Hitchcock repeated claims that union representatives are ``terrorists'' who kidnapped a company management team, ransacked the factory and seized its contents, and extorted unreasonable contract concessions. ``They ripped us off for $2 million and stole the company. I'm through with these people. We're now in court and I'm happy with that,'' Hitchcock said. During their three-month stay in the United States, the union leaders and a growing number of supporters have picketed Pico's headquarters regularly. Last weekend, they protested outside Hitchcock's home in Syracuse. Hitchcock responded by standing on his roof and dousing the demonstrators with water from a garden hose. Jum Soon Yoo, president of the South Korean union, and a dozen other supporters ended a week-long hunger strike with the filing of the lawsuit. Yoo and two other union leaders came to the United States in April to get Hitchcock to negotiate a settlement after failing to resolve the dispute in their homeland. Hitchcock has refused to negotiate with the union. Yoo said the union brought the lawsuit because the South Korean and American governments were ``ignoring the crimes of multinational firms against Third World workers.'' The union charged that Pico Korea took advantage of its status as a foreign firm and enjoyed tax breaks and other benefits offered by the South Korean government. The company grew rapidly after it opened in March 1983. The workers mobilized in June 1988 to form a union in response to what they called unsafe working conditions and subminimum wages. The union and company reached a labor accord in November 1988 that excluded the issue of wages, which was to be settled through future talks, according to the lawsuit. But before those talks could begin, Hitchcock fired Pico Korea's top officers and ordered the plant shut down, the lawsuit alleged. Union members admitted seizing the plant on Feb. 28, 1989, and refusing to allow shipment of finished products, but said they did so to force negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: $700 Million Lawsuit Says Mogul Tricked Wife on Finances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to correct cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: Industrialist Armand Hammer methodically defrauded his wife Frances by deceiving her about her rights to property amassed during 33 years of marriage, her sole heir contends in a $700 million damages lawsuit. Frances Hammer died in December, leaving her estate to her niece, Joan Weiss. Mrs. Weiss' husband, Robert Weiss, was named executor and brought the lawsuit, which also seeks unspecified punitive damages. Among other things, the lawsuit says Mrs. Hammer was tricked into signing away her interest of at least 50 percent in Hammer's art collection. Hammer is building a new museum to house the collection, estimated to be worth up to $450 million. But the lawsuit seeks to have Mrs. Hammer's portion of the art returned and a freeze put on other contested property until its ownership can be sorted out in court. Hammer, 92, the Occidental Petroleum Corp. chairman known for private world peace crusades and contributions to cancer research, declined to comment on the lawsuit through a spokesman. But interviewed by reporters in April after the company's annual meeting, Hammer said his third wife, the former Frances Tolman, ``always wanted to keep her estate separate from me.'' But he seemed to foresee that a lawsuit would be filed. It is ``a matter that will be litigated, I suppose,'' Hammer said. By challenging his sole ownership of the art, the complaint further clouds the future of Hammer's museum, being built beside Occidental's Los Angeles headquarters. Lawsuits filed by shareholders already contend Hammer is squandering $100 million in Occidental funds on a project designed for his own glory. The lawsuit, filed in state court in Los Angeles, says Frances Hammer was a multimillionaire widow when the couple married in 1956. By contrast, Hammer's art gallery and distilling businesses were struggling, and his income from them was less than his alimony to two former wives, it says. The lawsuit claims that using his wife's fortune as a bankroll, Hammer invested in Occidental, building it from a company with less than $80,000 in assets to one of the biggest oil concerns in the country. It says much of Hammer's vast fortune also was built from money his wife brought to the marriage. Hammer borrowed funds at 2 percent for speculative ventures and often failed to make interest payments to her, it says. When he did repay her, it was with money that was their joint property, the lawsuit contends. Hammer allowed his wife no control over their property, most of which should have been jointly held under California law, according to the lawsuit. ``For example, almost all of the Occidental stock acquired by the Hammers was held in Armand Hammer's name,'' the document says. ``Similarly, Armand Hammer exercised complete control over the many millions of dollars in salary and dividends paid to him by Occidental, using that money for his own selfish interests and purposes, including acquiring a vast art collection and making numerous gifts of community property that were intended primarily for his self-aggrandizement,'' it says. Hammer tricked his wife into signing over her interests in the art collection, Occidental stock and other property, according to the lawsuit. It seeks to nullify those agreements. It also claims Mrs. Hammer was due at least a half interest in much of the property. Hammer has contended his wife understood clearly what she was doing, willingly signing the agreements to demonstrate there was no community property. The 18-count suit, filed Wednesday, alleges fraud, legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty. It accuses the Chicago law firm of Lewis, Overbeck and Furman of failing to provide adequate financial advice to Mrs. Hammer, a longtime client. David J. Creagan Jr., a partner in the law firm, which also is named as a defendant, said he hadn't seen the complaint and couldn't comment on its specifics. But he denied wrongdoing in dealing with Mrs. Hammer. ``All I can say is that we fairly represented her interests during the time we had the privilege of doing so,'' Creagan said. Also named as defendants are Occidental; the Armand Hammer Foundation; and the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center, where Hammer's art collection is to be housed. Occidental spokesman Roger Gillott said neither Hammer nor officials of the trust and museum would have any comment on the lawsuit. Of the $700 million in damages, a total of $400 million is sought from Hammer and the law firm and another $300 million from the foundation, museum and oil company combined.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Believed Boesky _ At Least in Part
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury believed the testimony of Ivan Boesky _ at least in part _ against former stock speculator John A. Mulheren Jr. despite courtoom attacks on the admitted inside trader, securities experts said. Jurors in federal court in Manhattan convicted Mulheren of four counts of conspiracy and stock manipulation stemming from dealings with Boesky in 1985 but failed to reached a verdict on 26 other counts. U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum dismissed the panel and declared a mistrial on the undecided charges Thursday after nine days of deliberations failed to yield a verdict. The conviction of the flamboyant Mulheren on the four counts, returned Tuesday, marked another victory for the government. Juries have returned guilty verdicts against the principal defendants in all but one of about a dozen cases in prosecutors' four-year crackdown on Wall Street fraud. Many defendants have pleaded guilty rather than face trial. Mulheren's conviction also followed another pattern, securities experts said, in that the jury convicted on charges that contained a clear victim of fraud, in this case involving the manipulation of Gulf & Western Inc. stock. They appeared stymied, however, on more technical allegations of ``stock parking,'' a violation that before the recent wave of cases typically was prosecuted as a civil rather than criminal violation. Prosecutors had charged Mulheren bought 75,000 Gulf & Western shares at Boesky's behest, driving the stock to $45 a share, the price at which Boesky wanted to sell about 3.5 million shares back to the company. The jury was hung up on charges that Mulheren secretly held large blocks of stock to help Boesky evade taxes and federal securities disclosure laws. ``The jury obviously believed Boesky on the most central transaction,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University. ``They convicted on on the story that had the clearest motive and clearest sense of injury,'' Coffee said. ``Gulf and Western you can understand _ there is a victim there who has been defrauded. The company paid too much.'' ``Stock parking is more of a regulatory crime,'' he said. Parking refers to the illegal practice of disguising ownership of securities to avoid federal reporting requirements. Mulheren, 41, was an aggressive and successful trader of stocks of companies targeted for takeover before he was implicated in 1988 in the government's fraud investigation by Boesky, a former friend and associate. His trial in federal court in Manhattan was marked by Boesky's first public testimony under his settlement with investigators. Boesky spent two years in prison and paid $100 million in penalties to settle insider trading charges. Defense attorney Thomas Puccio's main tactic was to try to discredit Boesky as a repeat liar who was motivated to say anything to fulfill his promise to assist federal authorities in exchange for leniency. In his summation, Puccio called Boesky ``a pile of human garbage.'' After the mistrial, Mulheren joked with supporters, reflecting a casual demeanor that was his trademark on Wall Street and in court. Mulheren has said he went to trial, unlike others implicated by Boesky in wrongdoing, as a matter of principle. ``Lots of money spent and no answer given,'' he said. Prosecutors said they could not immediately comment on whether they planned to retry Mulheren on the oustanding counts of securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations. ``We're very satisfied with the verdict,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Scott Gilbert said. Cedarbaum scheduled an Oct. 5 sentencing for the four counts on which Mulheren was convicted. He faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count. Puccio said he planned to appeal the verdict. Co-defendant Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's defunct firm Jamie Securities, was acquitted of all conspiracy and record-keeping violations charges brought against him.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges, Stocks Up Slightly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell to a 4{-month low against the Japanese yen while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange ended the week slightly higher. The dollar closed the week at 147.42 yen, down 1.48 yen from Thursday's close, the lowest close since Feb. 22. The dollar has fallen 3.58 yen in the last six trading days. Currency dealers said the dollar's plunge followed its slide in New York trading Thursday. The downward trend was triggered by a statement by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan that the Fed might consider easing interest rates, they said. Lower U.S. interest rates tend to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors. ``The Fed chairman's statement has an impact on the exchange market,`` said Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Separately, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 69.05 points, or 0.21 percent, to 32,644.37. The index rose 281.14 points on Thursday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 500 million shares, up from Thursday's 430 million shares. Share prices sagged after opening firmly. ``The market lacked buying interest to support gains,`` said Daiwa Securities dealer Kazuyuki Suzuki. He said many dealers felt the yen's strength was only temporary because the bond market reacted mildly to Greenspan's remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chairman Signals Reduction in Interest Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's suggestion that interest rates will head lower couldn't come at a better time for President Bush. In a rare public disclosure of the central bank's intentions, Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday the Fed may have to nudge rates down in response to mounting evidence that banks are being stingier with loans. That was a sharp reversal from his assessment only three weeks ago, when he said the lending squeeze hadn't yet developed into a broad-based credit crunch affecting the national economy. Whatever the reason, the shift in central bank policy is sure to please the president, who has been pushing for lower interest rates for months. The administration needs lower rates to counteract the dampening effect on the economy if Congress and the White House lower spending and raise taxes as part of a budget deficit reduction pact. A few days before the central bank's midyear policy review on July 2 and 3, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged it not to wait for a budget agreement before cutting rates. Bush mentioned the subject as recently as Wednesday in a news conference in Houston. Greenspan met earlier this week with worried Senate Republicans. Business owners have been saying since last winter that banks have tightened lending standards in response to the savings and loan crisis, a softer economy and weakening real estate markets. Greenspan said the first statistical evidence backing their contention may be emerging. He pointed to slow growth in the money supply and an increase in average interest rates on commercial loans. ``If that is in fact the case, it could have undesirable effects on the economy that the Federal Reserve would have to consider offsetting using monetary policy,'' he said. Such a shift would produce ``a very modest change in the level of the federal funds rate,'' the key rate banks charge among themselves for overnight loans, he said. Stock and bond markets rallied after Greenspan's comments. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks jumped 37.13 to 2,969.80, a record high. It is rare for the central bank chairman to so strongly signal the future direction of interest rates. Usually he declines comment on the subject or uses deliberately ambiguous language. ``I can't remember any Fed chairman ever doing something like this,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based consultant. ``In my recollection this is an absolute first.'' Evans pointed out that Greenspan's four-year term as chairman expires in 13 months. ``I guess he's scared for his life. ... The implied threat (from the administration) is `Hey kid, if you want your job, play ball.' Nobody's as crude as that but that's what it amounts to,'' he said. In response to a question about political pressure from Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., Greenspan said the Federal Reserve welcomed comments from the administration or anyone else who can supply new insight. But, he said, members of the Fed make their decisions independently. Economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Inc., a government securities dealer in New York, said Greenspan may indeed be feeling political heat, but he said he believes the chairman's concern about the credit crunch is genuine. ``What Greenspan is saying is `If I don't do something now, it could make what is already a very soft economy worse,''' Jones said. Many analysts believe it may already be too late to give the economy the kind of boost the White House wants to bolster Republican chances in the November congressional elections. A change in monetary policy can take as long as six months to ripple through the economy. Jones said he expects the Fed to cut rates by late July. Virtually announcing the move in advance allows Greenspan to focus attention on the reasons he prefers to highlight and shift attention from other reasons, he said. ``The Fed wants to link this easing to the credit crunch and not to any political factors,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Target Tax-Dodging Foreign Corporations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Not since Congress declared war on drugs have lawmakers found such a tempting target. Democrats and Republicans now are raining fire on a common target: tax-dodging foreign corporations. ``What we have here is the granddaddy of tax avoidance,'' Rep. Byron L. Dorgan, D-N.D., said. Lawmakers see big bucks at stake _ money that could be used to cut the budget deficit without imposing on individuals. Some members of Congress insist the government is being cheated of as much as $50 billion a year, although Bush administration officials are skeptical. Whatever the figure, the prospect of reining in big-time cheats was enough to unite such diverse politicians as House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Duncan Hunter of California, chairman of the House Republican Research Committee. ``Before we raise taxes,'' Gephardt told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee Thursday, ``we should look at the profitable operations of foreign-controlled corporations that don't pay any at all.'' Hunter released a list of Japanese companies, compiled from newspaper reports, that he said are being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service on suspicion their U.S. subsidiaries have underpaid. The list included such well-known giants as Sony, Hitachi, Toshiba, Nissan, Toyota, Yamaha and Matsushita (Panasonic). ``American citizens who conspire to defraud the government of large amounts of tax money stand a good chance of going to jail,'' Hunter said. ``The same should be true of any foreigner who takes advantage of our open market but defrauds the American government of tax money.'' The IRS told the subcommittee earlier in the week that in 1987, the nearly 45,000 foreign-controlled U.S. corporations had receipts totaling $686 billion and paid income tax of only 0.66 percent of that total. U.S.-owned companies paid a 1.04 percent rate. For nine months the subcommittee has been investigating 36 foreign-controlled subsidiaries and found that over a 10-year period, most of them paid little or no U.S. income tax. The chief means of avoiding tax was through ``transfer pricing.'' By manipulating prices at which it sells goods to its U.S. subsidiaries, a foreign company could significantly reduce the amount of taxable income subject to U.S. tax. ``I propose we're talking about billions _ in the range of $30 billion'' a year in tax avoidance, Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, the subcommittee chairman, said Thursday. Other members put the figure at $50 billion. ``We really do not have a way of estimating'' the tax loss, Kenneth Gideon, assistant Treasury secretary for tax policy, said. ``I would find $50 billion very hard to accept,'' since the U.S. take from all corporations is only about twice that figure. Are foreign-controlled corporations paying their share, Rep. Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala., demanded. ``That's a question I can't answer,'' Gideon replied. Nevertheless, he added, the situation is unclear enough to justify careful examination. ``In many case what we have is criminal conduct,'' Rep. Clay Shaw, R-Fla., said. ``The outrage this committee feels ... I don't think I could overstate,'' Rep. Ray McGrath, R-N.Y., said. ``These companies are paying less than the average citizen, the average taxpayers of the United States,'' Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa., said. ``That's abominable.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Says Around-the-Clock Ban on `Indecent' Programs Needed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission says it needs to extend the current daytime ban on ``indecent'' radio and television programs to 24 hours to fully protect young eyes and ears. The agency on Thursday said children under 18 are in the viewing-listening audience 24 hours a day and that lock boxes or parental supervision are not enough to ensure that they don't watch indecent programs. It said a round-the-clock indecency ban would not violate broadcasters' First Amendment rights. The commission voted 5-0 to report its conclusions to a federal appeals court here that is considering a 24-hour ban the FCC adopted under orders from Congress in 1988. The report will not change current FCC indecency regulations, but it could play a major role in how the appeals court _ and, ultimately, the Supreme Court _ decides the issue. Commissioner Ervin S. Duggan said the FCC had received 88,000 letters complaining about indecent programming. He read from a letter from a mother who said it would take a ``superhuman'' effort for parents to monitor what their children hear on see on radio and TV at all times. ``The people who write letters like that are not enemies of the Constitution,'' Duggan said. ``They are people like you and me. ... They are parents.'' Opponents attacked the commission's action immediately. ``What adults should be able to hear or see should not be determined by what children's needs are,'' said Andrew J. Schwartzman, an attorney for People for the American Way, one of the activist groups challenging the 24-hour ban. ``I think it's preposterous,'' said Peggy Charren of Boston-based Action for Children's Television, the main plaintiff in the court challenge. ``Protecting children from indecency should not be the role of the FCC. That should be the role of parents.'' Currently, obscene material is banned from the airwaves at all times and indecent material from about 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. The FCC defines indecent as language or material ``that depicts or describes, in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards for the broadcast medium, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' The FCC under its new chairman, Alfred Sikes, has in the past year put the nation's radio stations on notice it will not tolerate the broadcast of indecent programs before 8 p.m. It has fined several stations already for broadcasting sexually explicit material. Sikes said Thursday that in seeking a 24-hour ban, the FCC simply was reflecting the will of Congress and the American public. ``We've received a huge amount of mail ... and it seems the public strongly supports the action we're taking today,'' he said. FCC officials repeatedly refused to speculate on what types of TV programs could be considered indecent. The commission in June 1988 fined a Kansas City, Mo., TV station $2,000 for showing an allegedly indecent film, ``Private Lessons,'' at 8 p.m. At that time, the FCC had established an after-midnight ``safe harbor'' for indecent programs. However, the FCC vacated the fine when the appeals court in July 1988 ordered the commission to study the time-of-day issue further. In its report, the FCC said a 24-hour indecency ban promotes a ``compelling'' government interest and was ``narrowly tailored'' to serve that interest without infringing broadcasters' First Amendment rights. The commission said it was guided by a 1989 Supreme Court ruling that used the ``compelling interest-narrowly tailored'' argument in deciding that the government had the right to regulate indecent telephone transmissions. Congress in 1988 ordered the FCC to adopt a round-the-clock ban on indecency, and it did. But broadcasters and free-speech groups challenged the rules, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in January 1989 stayed implementation of the 24-hour ban pending further review. The court said the FCC could develop evidence supporting a 24-hour ban.

DOC.HEAD: Consumerists, Industry Agree on Benefits of New Labeling Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Consumer advocates and industry officials agree shoppers would find it easier to learn the nutrition content of nearly all foods in the grocery store under a new government proposal to overhaul food labeling. Shoppers would be able to tell at a glance the amount of saturted fat, calories from fat, cholesterol and fiber. Serving sizes would be standardized, so nutrient comparisons would be more meaningful. But this doesn't assure the proposal's smooth sailing, among the public or within the Bush administration. ``It's a step in the right direction, but it's a long road, and the question isn't what they're proposing but whether they'll ever finalize it,'' said Ellen Haas, executive director of the consumer group, Public Voice for Food & Health Policy. Past efforts by the Food and Drug Administration to change the food-labeling system stalled, which prompted action in Congress. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., and Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, are sponsoring bills that would accomplish many of the same things the regulation would. On Thursday, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan outlined the latest effort to make sweeping changes in the system, to be published in 400 pages of the Federal Register next week. The proposals would: _Require nutrition labeling for most packaged foods as well as fresh produce and seafood. _Require labels to include saturated fat, calories from fat, cholesterol and fiber. _Establish standardized serving sizes for 159 food categories. _Restrict use of the terms ``no cholesterol,'' ``low cholesterol'' and ``reduced cholesterol.'' Food industry representatives applauded the effort, and said they will continue pressing to have the regulations applied uniformly nationwide. The issue held up announcement of the regulations late last month because of a disagreement within the administration, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Health and Human Services Department wanted uniform rules, but White House reportedly officials objected, saying states should be allowed to build their own regulations onto the federal ones. To get the proposed regulations published and begin the administrative rule-making process, the uniformity language was stripped from the proposal and the issue instead was posed as a question for comment. ``Without uniform labeling there will be consumer confusion and distribution chaos,'' said C. Manly Molpus, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America. Under the proposed regulation, nutrition labels would have to appear on product packages. For fresh produce and seafood, nutrition information could be available at the point of purchase, such as in brochures or on posters. Listing of the thiamin, riboflavin and niacin _ now required _ would become optional, and listing of protein would be required only for food intended for infants and very young children. To be called ``cholesterol free,'' a product would have to have less than two grams of saturated fat, less than five grams of total fat and less than two milligrams of cholesterol. A food meeting the targets on fat but with two to 20 milligrams of cholesterol could be called ``low cholesterol.'' A manufacturer could claim a food had ``reduced cholesterol'' if its cholesterol was cut by at least 75 percent. It could also make that claim if the reduction was compared with other foods on the market, but the comparison would have to be explained on the label. ``The axiom here is truth in labeling,'' said acting FDA Commissioner James Benson. HHS set a 30-day comment period on the cholesterol rule and said it could become final by the fall. Manufacturers would then have one year to comply. A 120-day comment period was set for the regulations on nutritional labeling, intake references and serving size. Benson said he hoped a final regulation could be issued by next spring. The industry would have a year to comply. Exemptions to the labeling rule would include restaurants, bakeries, cafeterias, bite-size foods and foods that have less than 40 calories per serving, do not make a health claim and have no meaningful supply of nutrients.

DOC.HEAD: Debt-for-Nature Swap To Help Save Lemurs And Forests of Madagascar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A novel deal called a debt-for-nature swap will pay for a $5 million conservation program in Madagascar, where destruction of exotic forests threatens wildlife found nowhere else. Among the forests' inhabitants are 43 varieties of lemurs, tree-dwelling human relatives that live only on Madagascar, an island off the southeast coast of Africa. Eighty percent of their habitat has been wiped out. Washington, D.C.-based Conservation International, which negotiated the debt swap, has pledged to pay off $5 million of Madagascar's debt to commercial banks, said spokesman Roderic Mast. ``We consider Madagascar to be one of the highest conservation priorities in the world,'' Mast said Thursday. A first-ever combination of debt reduction and trade credits will enable the environmental group to get better than double value for the cash it pays. Madagascar's end of the bargain is to begin a five-year conservation and protection program staffed by its own people under the direction of Conservation International. Madagascar is an island about 40 percent larger than California. It contains some of the world's most threatened wild habitat. Eighty percent of Madagascar's forests have been lost to encroachment by poor farmers struggling to eke out a living. The remaining forest contains 150,000 to 200,000 species of plants and animals. About three-quarters are found only in Madagascar. Last year, the World Wildlife Fund negotiated a $3 million debt-for-nature swap with Madagascar, Africa's first such agreement. The first debt-for-nature swap was negotiated by Conservation International in Bolivia in July 1987. ``The government of Madagascar has shown its commitment to saving its own wildlife,'' Mast said. ``They're taking a real leadership role, in terms of African countries, in showing this strong commitment to preserving their natural heritage.'' The new agreement is unusual for two reasons. The United Nations Development Program is considering providing much of the money, the first time the U.N. has joined in a debt-for-nature swap. And the agreement may let Madagascar reduce its debts to foreign companies as well as its commercial bank debt. Under the accord, foreign companies that have sold goods to Madagascar and haven't been paid could be paid off in exchange for further government commitments to conservation. Conservation International officials are hoping that some companies will agree simply to forgive the debts, in effect donating the money to the conservation effort in Madagascar. ``This is the first ever debt-for-nature swap that I'm aware of involving trade credits as well as bank debt,'' said Steven Rubin, Conservation International's director of business and legal affairs. ``We're effectively bringing private companies into the cause of ecosystem preservation in Madagascar.'' Debt-for-nature swaps have appeared only in the last few years. The legal and financial underpinnings of the swaps are complex, but their intent is to get conservation groups more bang for the buck. In this swap, for example, Conservation International will use money it raises from the U.N. or elsewhere to pay off portions of Madagascar's foreign debt and trade deficit at less than face value. At current rates, $1 million in debt can be paid off for about $400,000. Banks are willing to accept less than what they are owed so they can close the books on their loans. For each $1 million paid off, the government agrees to use $1 million worth of its own currency _ which banks generally won't accept as payment _ to finance conservation. The result is that $400,000 raised by an environmental group results in $1 million worth of Madagascar's currency spent on conservation.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Says Requiring Child Safety Seats on Airlines Would Cost Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Requiring child safety seats on airliners for infants instead of continuing to let parents hold them on their laps would cost more lives than it would save, the Federal Aviation Administration maintains. The FAA on Thursday cited past experience to estimate that such a requirement would save only one child's life over the next decade _ but at an additional cost of $3 billion to families who fly. ``While the chance of survival aboard an airplane may be slightly improved, the costs associated with mandating the carriage of a child in a separate seat will divert a significant number of families from ... air travel to far less safe travel by automobile,'' said Associate FAA Administrator Anthony J. Broderick. However, sponsors of House and Senate bills that would require the FAA to mandate child safety restraints on airliners attacked the study as ``specious'' and vowed to press ahead with their legislation. ``It's in the airlines' economic interest to keep families flying,'' Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., told the House Transportation Committee's aviation subcommittee. ``And in order to do so, I believe they will establish fares for infants that are reasonable.'' Infants under age 2 now may fly free by traveling on the laps of a parent or guardian. All of the major airlines also allow infants to travel in safety seats attached to a regular seat at the reduced 80 percent fare customarily charged for children between ages 2 and 12. Testifying before a House subcommittee, Broderick said the study commissioned by the FAA concluded that requiring safety seats for infants would increase their families' average air fare by 31 percent or $185. Those higher costs, the study said, would cause about 20 percent of the families now using airlines for long-distance trips to instead drive or stay at home, which also would expose them to higher risks associated with increased local travel. The increased auto traffic would produce at least nine additional highway deaths, 52 serious injuries and more than 2,300 minor injuries, the study said. Companion bills by Bond in the Senate and Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, in the House to mandate the use of child safety seats on airliners are supported by the industry's chief trade organization, the Air Transport Association, as well as airline unions and consumer safety groups. ATA Vice President Walter Coleman said it would be ``foolish'' to think that the airlines would not discount ticket prices for the infant seats in an effort to keep their parents' business. The FAA study estimated that measure would raise annual airline revenue by $80 million to $119 million _ depending on whether the carriers charge an 80 percent reduced fare for the toddlers' seats or a 50 percent reduced fare. The legislation was prompted by the crash-landing a year ago of a United Airliners jet at Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112 aboard, including a 23-month-old child. Three other children under age 2 were injured. As the result of its investigation into that crash, the National Transportation Safety Board recommended to the FAA in May that child safety seats be required for all children less than 40 pounds in weight and 3 feet, 4 inches in height. Susan Coughlin, the board's vice chairman, aid the FAA's policy of allowing infants to be held in an adult's arms, while everyone else must wear seat belts, was a ``contradiction of basic safety principles.'' The FAA study said the death of the child in the Sioux City crash was the only one of 10 infant deaths in aviation accidents over the past 12 years that could have been prevented by the use of a child safety seat. Of the 16 infant injuries in those accidents since 1978, only three to six of them would have been prevented by the use of child restraints, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Surges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: penultimate graf NEW to ADD Hong Kong gold price; uppicks last graf: Silver bullion...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar slumped in European trading this morning, undermined by a hint that U.S. interest rates may be going down. Gold rose strongly. Currency dealers said the dollar's fall continued a drop that began in New York trading Thursday, following a statement by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan that the Fed might consider easing interest rates. Lower rates would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to its lowest level since Feb. 22, closing at 147.42 yen, down 1.48 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar firmed to 147.80 yen. The British pound traded at $1.8020, from $1.7995 late Thursday. Other midday dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.6470 West German marks, down from 1.6525; 1.3970 Swiss francs, down from 1.4020; 5.5285 French francs, down from 5.5460; 1,206.00 Italian lire, down from 1,211.00; 1.1564 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1580. The Dutch guilder rate was unavailable. DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Friday after the government announced that the rate of inflation remained below 10 percent. The government said inflation rose to 9.8 percent in June from 9.7 percent in May, the government said. Dealers said the market was relieved that the rate had not moved to 10 percent or higher. Stock prices opened higher on Wall Street's performance Thursday following hints from U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan that interest rates should come down to counter tight credit. At midday local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index was up 1.1 points, or 0.046 percent, at 2,371.6. The narrower 30-share index was up 3.3 points or 0.2 percent at 1,873.4. DOC.HEAD: Retail Price Index Inflation Up to 9.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's inflation rate rose to 9.8 percent in June from 9.7 percent in May, the government said Friday. It was the highest rate since inflation hit 10.4 percent in March 1982, the government said. However, the government said the underlying rate _ excluding mortgage payments and local taxes _ stood at 6.9 percent in June, down from 7 percent in May. Inflation was spurred by increases in charges for electricity and for maintaining automobiles, the Central Statistics Office said. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, the Treasury secretary, said: ``The figure is a good deal higher than I would wish to see it, and I shall be content only when it begins to come down.'' He told BBC radio that ``it's wholly wrong to say we are off course. Certainly it is taking a little longer to come down than we imagined.''

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Brings $500 Million Countersuit Against Time Warner
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. has countersued Time Warner Inc., escalating the bitter dispute over Pathe's collapsed attempts to negotiate a loan for its buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co. Time Warner now is unlikely to participate in the planned purchase of MGM-UA and Pathe is seeking new financial partners, spokesman Craig Parsons said Thursday. The lawsuit, seeking damages in excess of $500 million, alleges breach of contract, fraud, libel, interference with contractual relationship and unfair competition. It was filed in state court in Los Angeles in response to Time Warner's $100 million breach-of-contract lawsuit against Pathe filed June 29. In April, Time Warner had agreed to lend Pathe $650 million, half the $1.3 billion purchase price for MGM-UA. Time Warner insisted that none of the rest of the money for the deal should be borrowed and that Pathe, a motion picture production company, should come up with $450 million equity on its own. Time Warner's lawsuit also claimed Pathe Chairman Giancarlo Parretti misled Time Warner regarding the video and theatrical rights to certain films. Pathe's attempted purchase of MGM-UA has been troubled since it was first announced in March. Time Warner's financial involvement was one of the few solid components in a hodgepodge financial arrangement Pathe was assembling for the purchase of the historic studio. Time Warner and its subsidiaries also were to get a lien on the valuable United Artists library as part of the deal, as well as distribution rights to films from the Pathe and MGM-UA studios. Ed Adler, a spokesman for Time Warner, said the suit was Pathe's ``latest attempt to divert attention from the facts, which are that Pathe breached its April 1990 agreement with Time Warner, its theatrical distribution agreement with Warner Bros. and a video rights distribution agreement with Warner Home Video.''

DOC.HEAD: Contel Agrees To $6 Billion Takeover By GTE
DOC.TEXT: The planned $6 billion takeover of Atlanta-based Contel, the nation's third-largest independent telephone company, by No. 1 GTE Corp. will give GTE a big boost in the cellular phone business at a good price, an industry analyst says. ``They are making a very wise move for the company's long-term future,'' telecommunications analyst Frederick Moran, of Moran and Associates in Greenwich, Conn, said of GTE. ``They are buying Contel for less than half of what it's worth. ``We value Contel at $81 to $87 a share. ... If I were running Contel, I wouldn't have agreed to it.'' In the deal, announced Thursday, GTE would exchange 1.27 shares of its common stock for each of Contel's 159 million shares. That values Contel stock at about $37.78 a share at the Thursday closing price of GTE stock of $29.75, down $1.25. Contel shares rose $7.25 on the news Thursday to close at $35.25 in New York Stock Exchange trading. Moran said the deal raises the question of whether another company ``will step in and offer a higher price than GTE has offered.'' The merger, which the companies described as tax free, is subject to the approval of both companies' stockholders, and by regulatory agencies. The merger would result in the country's second-largest cellular phone system operator after McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., and the nation's largest local-exchange telephone company. In a joint announcement with Contel, GTE Chairman James L. ``Rocky'' Johnson characterized the merger as ``a perfect combination of two great companies.'' Contel provides a broad range of telecommunications products and services. For 1989, Contel reported record earnings of $287 million or $1.80 a share, up 4 percent from a year earlier, on revenue of $3.1 billion. ``This merger will provide the critical mass and financial strength Contel has sought in order to accelerate the many initiatives we have recently taken across a wide spectrum of ventures,'' Contel Chairman Charles Wohlstetter said in the statement. GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., is the nation's largest independent operator of phone systems, providing service to more than 14 million customers in 31 states. It also provides cellular phone service in 34 metropolitan areas, and operates a satellite communications network. Since deregulation, much consolidation has occurred among smaller phone companies, but this is the first deal of this size, said Theodore J. Moreau, an analyst with Robert W. Baird in Milwaukee. ``This may be the test to see how the regulators view this kind of deal,'' he said. In other telephone industry consolidations this year, McCaw bought control of cellular phone operator Lin Broadcasting Corp. for $3.4 billion, MCI Communications Corp. bought the long distance company Telecom USA Inc. for $1.25 billion, and GTE said it would buy the cellular phone operations of Providence Journal Co. for $710 million. Last month, Contel announced it wanted to sell Contel Office Communications, a division that provides shared telecommunications services for tenants of high-rise office buildings. This spring, the company announced it was restructuring its telephone operations, which provide 74 percent of revenues, to eliminate about 600 jobs nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Up 0.5 Percent in June
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup; also moving general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales, bolstered by a big jump in department store sales, shot up 0.5 percent in June, posting the first increase in five months, the government said today. The Commerce Department said sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $147.82 billion last month, up $784 million from the May sales level. The June increase came after a string of three consecutive declines, something that had not happened since 1981, during the last recession. Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, prolonged weakness in this area raises fears that the economy could be headed for a downturn. The June rebound should lessen recession anxieties, but analysts cautioned against reading too much into one-month's change, especially given the fact that retail sales had been sluggish for most of this year. This was the first increase since a big 2.8 percent increase in January. After that gain, retail sales showed no change in February and then fell 0.4 percent in March, 1 percent in April and 0.6 percent in May. With job growth very weak this year, consumer confidence about the future has slipped and resulted in spending cutbacks, especially for big-ticket items such as cars and appliances. The June increase was led by a 2.8 percent rise in spending at department stores, reflecting a rebound after a big 2.2 percent drop in May. The 2.8 percent jump in department store sales was dramatic, given the fact that sales in this sector had fallen for three months, but analysts attributed part of the gain to price markdowns to encourage purchases of slow-moving summer clothes. Auto sales edged up a tiny 0.1 percent in June after being down 0.2 percent in May. Weakness in auto sales has been a major factor contributing to the overall sluggishness of consumer spending this year. Sales at building material and hardware stores rose 1.3 percent after falling 0.2 percent in April. Bucking the upward trend in June, sales at furniture and home furnishings stores plunged 1.9 percent. They had been up a slight 0.4 percent in May. Sales at grocery stores were up 0.3 percent while sales at gasoline stations climbed by 0.5 percent. Sales at drug stores were up 1.2 percent but spending at bars and restaurants fell 0.6 percent in June.

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes-Benz Negotiating to Add Shifts to Meet Demand
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for Mercedes-Benz AG confirmed Friday that the company is negotiating with unions to add special shifts at a number of its factories to help meet rising demand from East Germany and elsewhere. The auto making arm of Daimler-Benz AG, West Germany's largest industrial concern, is negotiating with the Workers' Council and unions for permission to add weekend shifts. The official said that an announcement could be made later Friday, or perhaps by Monday. But he cautioned that so far no agreement has been reached. He added that attempts to add weekend shifts in January were thwarted by the unions. Mercedes-Benz had planned to build about 556,000 passenger cars this year, up from 542,000 produced in 1989. But the spokesman said that rising demand from East Germany, Western European markets and from Japan has prompted the company to boost production goals for the year to 570,000. ``We would very much like to introduce special shifts,'' the spokesman said in a telephone interview. ``But this must be agreed upon with the Workers' Councils.'' The official said that demand from East Germany, in particular, has been greater than expected. He noted that Mercedes-Benz recently received an order for 500 new taxis for East Germany, to be delivered by the end of September. ``But it's not just East Germany, it's the domestic market in general as well that's quite strong,'' he said. He added that sales in Japan during the first half of the year were up by about 40 percent from a year earlier. The company's goal for the U.S. market is to maintain last year's sales level, when it sold about 75,000 passenger cars, the spokesman said. Mercedes-Benz currently operates two shifts: one between 6 a.m. and 2 p.m. local time and the second shift between 2 p.m. and 10 p.m. local time. He said that it was unlikely night shifts would be introduced.

DOC.HEAD: Emirates, Kuwait Cut Back Production, Prices To Climb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after the 7th graf with oil prices above $18 on some markets.
DOC.TEXT: Production cutbacks by two OPEC members should restore oil prices to the $18-a-barrel benchmark within days, Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said Friday. Speaking to reporters at the end of a two-day visit to the United Arab Emirates, he said production cuts by the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait will drive the prices up before the next OPEC meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, on July 25. At the meeting, Iran will request that the benchmark price be increased by $2 a barrel to $20, the minister said. Aqazadeh's remarks reflect confidence that OPEC members would refrain from pumping too much oil, which depresses prices. Oil produced by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was selling recently for $14 a barrel. During his visit, Aqazadeh held talks with Oil Minister Mana Saeed Otaiba. ``We're expecting prices to reach $18 a barrel by the time we meet in Geneva, and then we will propose an increase of $2 in the reference price,'' said Aqazadeh at Abu Dhabi airport. ``U.A.E. is dropping its output by 400,000 barrels per day and Kuwait by 500,000 barrels per day, and this will lead to a (price) hike,'' Aqazadeh said. Oil prices have already traded above $18 this week on New York and other markets, but OPEC determines its reference price by averaging the prices of seven separate crudes. Otaiba, who also spoke at the airport while seeing his guest off, said the U.A.E. output reduction will be effective as of the day. There was no official comment on the cutback reports from Kuwait, another OPEC member that has been producing well beyond its quota of 1.5 million barrels a day. OPEC offered the U.A.E. a quota of 1.5 million barrels a day at its last meeting in Vienna in November, but the U.A.E. rejected the figure as too low. At that meeting, the collective production ceiling at 22.086 million barrels a day, within which the U.A.E.'s output was calculated at only 1.095 million barrels a day. But OPEC production in June was estimated at 23.2 million barrels per day. Saudi Arabia, the world's chief oil exporter and a leading OPEC member, was expected to reciprocate for the efforts by the U.A.E. and Kuwait to stabilize the oil market, according to senior gulf oil executives in Manama, Bahrain. They said they expected the kingdom to demand that its production quota make up 24.45 percent of OPEC's ceiling. News of the planned production cutbacks surfaced in Saudi Arabia Thursday night. Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer described the moves as a ``historic crossroads'' for the 13-member cartel. He said the decisions followed high-level contacts between King Fahd and U.A.E. President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan. Iran and Iraq, their economies battered by the gulf war, have been lobbying for higher prices of crude oil. Both countries have been critical of Kuwait and the U.A.E. for overproducing and causing a glut on the oil market.

DOC.HEAD: Declining Food and Energy Prices Hold Inflation to 0.2 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 6th graf pvs, Another report... to UPDATE with White House reaction; picks up 7th graf pvs, The Commerce...; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Declining food and energy prices helped hold wholesale price inflation to a modest 0.2 percent in June, despite a worrisome jump in the cost of other items, the government said today. The rise in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods one stop short of the retail level followed a rise in May of 0.3 percent. It brought wholesale inflation for the first half of 1990 to an annual rate of 3.7 percent, compared with 4.8 percent for all of 1989. The number was about what economists anticipated. However, prices for items outside the volatile food and energy sectors jumped 0.6 percent in June, the steepest incrase in a year and about double the expected rise. Analysts consider this so-called ``core'' rate a better indicator of underlying inflation pressures in the economy. However the jump follows a string of five moderate rises of 0.3 percent or 0.2 percent.

Another report today showed retail sales, bolstered by a big jump in department store sales, shot up 0.5 percent in June, posting the first increase in five months. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration was pleased with the figures on both producer prices and retail sales. ``Inflation has been steadily declining since the first of the year, confirming our conclusion that the January price increase was indeed temporary. This is excellent news for the economy,'' he said. He said the rise in retail sales in June showed that ``the economy continues to grow but at a very moderate rate.'' ``We're hopeful that today's news on inflation and retail sales indicates a steadily growing economy in the month ahead,'' he said. The Commerce Department said sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $147.82 billion last month, up $784 million from the May sales level. The June increase came after a string of three consecutive declines, something that had not happened since 1981, during the last recession. Wholesale prices rose for tobacco, 3.2 percent; passenger cars, 2.3 percent; women's clothing, 0.5 percent; furniture, 0.5 percent; jewelry, 0.9 percent; newspapers, 0.5 percent; over-the-counter drugs, 0.8 percent, and household flatware, 2.3 percent. Tobacco prices are now 13.9 percent higher than a year ago. Automobile costs rose after months of generally flat or falling prices. Energy prices, which skyrocketed 13.7 percent in January because of a severe cold snap, have declined every month since. They were down 0.9 percent in June after dropping 1 percent in May. Fuel oil fell 10.5 percent and gasoline was down 1.3 percent. Natural gas costs rose 0.4 percent. Food prices headed lower for the third time in four months. They dropped 0.4 percent last month after a 0.6 percent increase in May. Prices for both fresh fruit and eggs jumped 6.7 percent and vegetable prices rose 2.5 percent. But, prices fell sharply for pasta, 7.4 percent; pork, 3.4 percent; chicken, 5.8 percent, and fish, 14.7 percent. The fairly stiff increase in prices excluding food and energy could put a crimp in Federal Reserve plans to lower interest rates. The Fed attempts to quell inflation by slowing demand with high interest rates. On Thursday, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan strongly suggested that the central bank would cut rates to counter the dampening effects of an apparent pullback in bank lending. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 117.9 in June. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117.90 last month, up from $114.30 a year earlier. The inflation news was better at earlier stages of the production process with prices falling 0.2 percent for intermediate goods and 2.4 percent for crude goods. Excluding food and energy, intermediate prices edged 0.1 percent lower and crude costs fell 0.6 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

Consumer prices have been rising faster than producer prices. That is because half of the prices contributing to the consumer index are for services, which are not measured directly by the wholesale index. Economist Davd Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer, said economic weakness has been most pronounced in the goods-producing sector. It has only recently spread to services, where a stable unemployment rate near 5.3 percent has kept wages and, thus the price of services, high, he said. For the first five months of the year, consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of 5.8 percent, up from 4.6 percent for all 12 months of last year. Economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University, who conducts his own inflation surveys, predicted that by the end of this year, wholesale prices will have risen only 3.6 percent for the best performance in three years. He forecast they would increase 3.9 percent in 1991, largely because depressed energy prices will start rising again. ``Underlying inflation appears to be drifting downward, although the speed of downward drift remains slight,'' Ratajczak wrote in a recent newsletter.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Expects Big Drop in Earnings Per Share
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. today said it expects about a 32 percent drop in quarterly income per share from continuing operations due to losses in its insurance group and lagging earnings in the retail division. Sears estimated earnings of 65 cents a share from continuing operations in this year's second quarter. That would be down from 95 cents a share, or $391.2 million, of comparable earnings a year earlier. An estimate of total income in the quarter ended June 30 was not given. The expected earnings deterioration would be an even greater 41 percent if comparing this year's figure against last year's total net income. The company's total profit in 1989's second quarter came to $1.11 a share, including operations that have since been discontinued. Sears had a second-quarter gain last year of $54.9 million from the sale of the commercial division of the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group. Edward A. Brennan, company chairman and chief executive officer, noted that unexpectedly high catastrophe-related losses in its Allstate Insurance Group will contribute to the shortfall. Claims resulting from the recent fires in California contributed to Allstate's losses. Profits in the Sears Merchandise Group for the second quarter are expected to be lower than last year, Brennan said. ``We continue to expect a solid performance for the second half of the year based on our outlook for continued moderate growth in the economy,'' he said in a statement. The company said its second-quarter results will be released in the week of July 23.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Big Three Sales Rise in Early July
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Strong truck sales by the nation's Big Three automakers pushed the sales rate for North American-made vehicles up 1 percent in early July compared with the same period last year, the companies said Friday. The increase comes on the heels of a 7.1-percent rise in late-June sales by the Big Three. The two increases, both based on strong truck sales, support speculation earlier this year that the auto industry will begin to pull out of its early 1990 slump sometime in the middle of the year. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their combined car and truck sales averaged 33,850 a day July 1-10 this year, compared with a daily average of 33,504 last year. A 6.3 percent rise in truck sales offset a 2.3 percent decline in car sales. Light truck sales by GM and Ford during the period rose 18.2 percent and 6.1 percent, respectively. Truck sales by Chrysler dropped 13.9 percent. Chrysler, which has been struggling financially, gets a large percentage of its vehicle profits from its minivans and Jeeps, both classified as light trucks. Drawing an accurate conclusion about a trend in the industry from two 10-day sales periods is difficult. Industry observers prefer to see at least a month's worth of sales figures before speculating about where the industry is heading. Despite the recent back-to-back increases, car and truck sales for the Big Three are lagging behind last year. The companies said they sold an average 33,061 vehicles a day so far this year, compared with 35,308 in the same period last year, a 6.4 percent decrease. Car sales were down 9.5 percent and truck sales were off 1.3 percent. Chrysler was the only one of the Big Three whose combined car and truck sales fell during early July. The nation's third-largest automaker reported a 16.3 percent drop in vehicle sales as the decline in truck sales combined with an 18.8 percent decrease in car sales. So far this year, sales of Chrysler's domestic cars and trucks were down 13.2 percent. Sales of GM vehicles in early July were running 6.7 percent ahead of last year's pace. Car sales by the nation's largest automaker were up 0.9 percent. GM's vehicle sales this year were down 3.1 percent from last year. Ford said a 0.4 percent decline in car sales combined with its higher light truck sales for a 2.2 percent increase in early-July vehicle sales. So far this year, sales of Ford's North American-made cars and trucks were down 7.3 percent from last year.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Dow Industrial Average Average Breaks 3000 Barrier for First Time
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones industrial average shattered the 3,000 level for the first time in history today as the stock market surged on a fresh wave of investor enthusiasm. The nation's best-known barometer of Wall Street, an index measuring the performance of 30 big American industrial companies, moved up 31 points from Thursday's close into 3,000-plus territory shortly after 1:30 p.m. EST, then receded back into the 2,990-range. The average had risen nearly 79 points in the previous two sessions. The catalyst for the latest advance came from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who surprised the market Thursday by saying the nation's central bank was prepared to ease credit if necessary. The remark signaled an increased likelihood of lower interest rates, which would help boost corporate profits and dim the prospects of a recession. Bullish investors snapped up stocks on the news. The Dow average was created more than a century ago when the stock market was a fledgling operation on Wall Street and is considered the granddaddy of all stock averages, although it no longer necessarily reflects the behavior of stocks in general. It closed above 100 for the first time in January 1906. The average broke the 1,000 barrier in November 1972 and the 2,000 barrier in January 1987. It has been flirting with the 3,000 barrier for several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: adv16
DOC.NOTE: For Release AMs Monday, July 16
DOC.HEAD: Bond Default Rate Soars As Junk Issues Come Back To Haunt Market
DOC.TEXT: For the bond market, this year's second quarter turned out to be an unwelcome rerun of the first. The Bond Investors Association, a non-profit group that tracks bond defaults, says 26 U.S. corporations stopped making interest payments on bonds with a face value of $5.7 billion in the April-June period. That compares with 14 issuers who defaulted on an identical amount of bonds in the first quarter. ``The default rate is almost twice the historic rate,'' said Richard Lehmann, president of the group.``We think that's basically because the quality of the debt that was put out from '85 to '89 was vastly inferior to what was done before.'' Lehmann places the blame on junk bonds, those high-risk, high-yield debt securities that were the rage during the takeover binge of the mid to late 1980s. The junk bond market has all but dried up due to the demise earlier this year of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the Wall Street house that built its short-lived fortune by selling and tirelessly promoting junk issues. But the junk bonds it pumped out in the '80s are coming home to roost _ or die, as seems to be more the case. All of the defaulted bonds in the second quarter were junk issues, Lehmann says. Among them were $1.9 billion in bonds sold by Southland Corp., troubled owner of the 7-Eleven chain; $652 million in bonds issued by equally troubled fellow convenience store operator Circle K Corp.; $705 million in bonds sold by Farley Inc. for its underfunded takeover of textile giant West Point-Pepperell; and $637 million in Western Union Corp. bonds. All were Drexel clients. Also among major bond defaulters in the second quarter were troubled savings and loans, which had issued junk as a last-ditch attempt to stave off collapse. Among them were Imperial Corp. of America, a San Diego thrift holding company with $342 million in bad bonds, and CenTrust Bank of Miami, at $315 million, the Bond Investors Association says. Lehmann said he doesn't expect bond defaults to ease anytime soon. Over the next three years he projects a total of $40 billion in corporate bond issues will stop making payments. ``It should peak early next year and then start to decline. But if the economy turns bad it could go on through next year,'' he said last week in a telephone interview from his group's suburban Miami headquarters. Had Drexel survived and the junk market not collapsed, many of these troubled junk-financed deals from the past few years might have been able to restructure their debt and avoid default, said David Blitzer, chief economist for Standard & Poor's Corp., a major credit rating agency. Drexel's destruction left many junk-dependent clients in the cold. ``They found themselves without a link to the market,'' Blitzer said. These companies also found closed doors elsewhere, he said, as banks became wary of highly leveraged deals when the real estate market soured and credit tightened. Lehmann's group said only 12 new junk bond issues totaling $1.7 billion were sold in the second quarter, compared with 93 issues totaling $15.6 billion in 1989's second quarter. Recently, however, some experts have said the junk bond market may not be all gloom and doom. Junk bonds have staged a rally of sorts in recent months, and by some measures, some of the bonds have provided better returns to investors than some investment-grade issues. The market received a boost last month when Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the big New York investment group, said it would inject $1.7 billion into RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco company it took private last year. The news ended speculation that RJR could become another troubled junk bond giant.
