DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mostly Higher After Bullish Report
DOC.TEXT: Crop futures prices closed mostly higher Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department lowered its projections for winter wheat production and corn and soybean stockpiles. But gains were limited by expectations that beneficial weather will continue as the corn crop enters its critical pollination phase. ``The market's focusing mostly on supply considerations right now and things are looking very, very good,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service in Chicago. In a supply-and-demand report released after Thursday's close, the USDA estimated soybean stocks for Aug. 31, the end of the 1989-90 soybean marketing year, at 275 million bushels, down 20 million from its previous estimate. Looking ahead to next year, the government also reduced its forecast for the 1990-91 soybean carryout by 80 million bushels to 265 million. In addition, the USDA trimmed its 1990-91 corn carryout estimate by 90 million bushels to 1.13 billion and slightly reduced its 1990 winter wheat harvest projection. At the close, wheat futures were 3{ cents lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.08 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 2{ cents higher with July at $2.79 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to 1} cents higher with July at $1.26{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 7 cents higher with July at $6.11 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Still Tackling Rumors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s stock moved higher Friday as rumors and speculation about the struggling defense contractor's future continued to swirl. The company denied rumors _ circulated in the financial markets and phoned into news organizations _ that it planned to sell its Long Beach, Calif., subsidiary, Douglas Aircraft Co., to Japanese industrial giant Mitsubishi Group and that Chairman John F. McDonnell would resign. ``McDonnell Douglas has no plans to sell Douglas Aircraft to Mitsubishi or to anyone else,'' spokeswoman Ellen LeMond-Holman said Friday. ``The resignation of John McDonnell, there's no truth to that either.'' On Thursday, the company denied rumors that it planned to file for bankruptcy court protection. McDonnell Douglas stock was up $1.50 to $45.12{ a share in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The rumors have been multiplying as McDonnell Douglas prepares for what it calls substantial layoffs in an effort to cut expenses by $700 million and help bolster its sagging financial performance. The uncertainty surrounding those layoffs and other cutbacks have kindled the rumors, LeMond-Holman said. ``People are concerned for their jobs and what happens is that anything they hear, they tell that to someone else, and it's that feeding process, one rumor feeding off another,'' she said. ``It's an unfortunate situation, but if we knew how to control rumors, then I guess a lot of people would want to talk to us to find out how to do that.'' Howard Rubel who follows the company for the brokerage C.J. Lawrence in New York, said the rumors were helped partly by speculators who were betting on price movements in McDonnell Douglas' stock. ``Basically, speculators are playing games with each other,'' Rubel said. ``It's sort of amusing but it's distracting, too.'' Rubel said the rumors were ``in the realm of fantasy'' and guessed that the company was most likely to engage in layoffs among white collar workers in areas of the business that haven't shown good returns. LeMond-Holman also denied a rumor heard by some analysts that McDonnell Douglas had scheduled a news conference for Monday to announce specifics concerning the layoffs and cutbacks. Paul Nisbet, of Prudential-Bache Securities, said employees likely were the biggest source of rumors. ``It starts at the water cooler and goes all over,'' he said. McDonnell Douglas officials blame the layoffs and other cutbacks on the company's weak financial performance at a time that it needs cash to invest in new programs. McDonnell Douglas earned $2 million during its first quarter, down 98 percent decline from a year earlier. The drop stemmed mainly from huge losses at the Douglas Aircraft unit, which primarily builds commercial jets. The company, the nation's biggest defense contractor, also faces an uncertain future in the defense business as the Pentagon slashes spending. While the company has not announced how many workers it plans to lay off, analysts are predicting 10,000 to 15,000 layoffs on top of earlier job cuts of 4,000 workers and 3,000 contracted workers at Douglas Aircraft. McDonnell Douglas now employs about 127,000. The company faces serious cost problems on three military programs, the C-17 cargo plane, the A-12 advanced tactical aircraft and the T-45 Goshawk trainer. It also faces large investment costs in its not-yet-certified MD-11 commercial jumbo jet and has experienced production problems with its MD-80 commercial airliners.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules on Award in Patent Infringement Case
DOC.TEXT: The Ford Motor Co. today was ordered to pay nearly $5.2 million to the inventor of intermittent windshield wipers because the automaker unintentionally infringed on his patents. Ford attorneys said they were pleased with the amount of the award to Robert W. Kearns. But Kearns' attorney and son said they were disappointed and considering an appeal. ``It follows the standard of the auto industry, but I don't think that's fair. They have no interest in paying for innovations,'' said Dennis Kearns, the inventor's oldest son. Robert Kearns, a former Wayne State University professor who now lives in Gaithersburg, Md., was absent when the jury anounced its verdict shortly after noon. The verdict could have wide implications because Kearns has similar suits pending against General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Daimler-Benz, Honda, Toyota, Nissan and more than 20 other companies. The Ford case was the first to go to trial. Dennis Kearns said other automakers also being sued by his father probably would offer ``minuscule'' settlements in light of the Ford verdict. Kearns, 63, originally sought $141 million, an amount that could have been tripled had the previous damages trial determined that Ford willfully infringed on Kearns' patents. Ford attorneys said a reasonable licensing agreement would have paid the inventor $1.5 million or less. The jury's award, for $6.3 million, was based on what Kearns had called Ford's profit of $6.85 on each of 20.6 million intermittent-wiper options it sold from 1972-1988, when his main patents were in effect. During a Friday afternoon hearing, U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn ordered the award reduced to $5.16 million, which represents what is owed to Kearns only after April 1978, when he originally filed suit. The jury that decided Kearns' patents had been infringed deadlocked on how much money he should get. The second jury heard evidence pertaining only to the damages Kearns suffered through the infringement.

DOC.HEAD: Castle & Cooke Looking for Buyer for Dole
DOC.TEXT: Castle & Cooke, Inc., has hired consultants to evaluate the possibility of selling its Dole Food Co. subsidiary, the company said. Castle & Cooke had announced earlier that it would split Dole and its real estate holdings into two businesses. However, those plans were held up by a softening of the real-estate financing market and the time needed to obtain an Internal Revenue Service ruling on a possible spinoff. Castle & Cooke Chairman David Murdock said Thursday that a sale of Dole could be ``an attractive alternative to the planned separation of our two businesses.'' He said Castle & Cooke has been contacted by several major companies interested in acquiring Dole. The evaluation of a possible sale will be done by the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs and Co., he said. Dole, founded in 1901 as a Hawaii pineapple company, has annual sales of $2.5 billion. It is incorporated in Hawaii and based in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Early-July Domestic Vehicle Sales Up
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks rose 2.5 percent in early July over a year earlier, prolonging a rebound that began in late June, the automakers said Friday. It was the second consecutive increase for the automakers, which report their sales in 10-day periods. While the back-to-back advances don't provide enough evidence to signal a trend, they support expectations earlier this year that a sluggish early-1990 sales rate would pick up this summer. Despite the successive increases, the sales rate so far this year continues to lag behind last year's pace. Car and truck sales since Jan. 1 this year averaged 36,921 a day compared with a 38,100-a-day average last year, a 3.1 percent decline. Car sales for the year were down 4.3 percent and truck sales were off 1 percent. Early July car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. fell 2.3 percent, while sales of U.S.-made Japanese cars and trucks rose 35.2 percent. The Big Three held 90.3 percent of the market and the Japanese cars made up the rest. Together, the 10 major U.S. vehicle makers said they sold an average of 36,499 cars and light trucks a day during the July 1-10 period this year compared with a daily rate of 35,614 vehicles last year. Truck sales fueled the early July increase, rising 5.6 percent over last year. Car sales during the period were 0.6 percent higher. ``We're certainly a little mystified,'' said auto analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York. ``We're surprised because incentive costs have come down, which would have suggested that sales would have weakened a little bit.'' He speculated that sales may have been boosted by people who last bought cars during the 1984-86 boom years, during which 45 million cars and trucks were sold in the United States. ``Those vehicles are now in excess of four years of age, and most of them have been paid off,'' he said. ``There's no question that there is a lot of replacement pressure.'' Chrysler was the only one of the Big Three whose combined car and truck sales fell during early July. The nation's third-largest automaker reported a 16.3 percent drop in vehicle sales, as a 13.9 percent decline in truck sales combined with an 18.8 percent decrease in car sales. So far this year, sales of Chrysler's domestic cars and trucks were down 13.2 percent. Sales of GM vehicles in early July were 6.7 percent ahead of last year's pace. Car sales by the nation's largest automaker were up 0.9 percent and truck sales improved by 18.2 percent. GM's vehicle sales this year were down 3.1 percent from last year. Ford said a 0.4 percent decline in car sales combined with a 6.1 percent increase in truck sales for a 2.2 percent increase in early July vehicle sales. So far this year, sales of Ford's North American-made cars and trucks were down 7.3 percent from last year.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Kubota Sued for $25 Million
DOC.TEXT: The founders of a California computer company have filed a $25 million lawsuit claiming Kubota Ltd. of Japan forced their firm into a merger with a financially unstable competitor. The suit was filed in Santa Clara County Superior Court on Thursday by Allen Michels and Matthew Sanders, founders of Ardent Computer of Sunnyvale, Calif. They contend Kubota, Ardent's largest shareholder and creditor, planned the merger in order to weaken Ardent and gain its technology. ``I'm outraged,'' said Sanders. ``We want Kubota to stop trying to drain the assets of this company.'' According to the suit, Kubota forced Ardent into a merger with Stellar Computer of Massachusetts last year by threatening to withhold $50 million in promised financing. The merged company was called Stardent Inc. According to the suit, Kubota's actions were intended to weaken Stardent to where the troubled company's technology could be acquired. In the worst case, Stardent would have gone bankrupt, leaving Kubota as the largest creditor and shareholder. When the merger was completed, Kubota controlled 22 percent of the company. Michels and Sanders serve as co-chairmen and Stellar President John Poduska is president and chief executive officer. Stardent, based in Newton, Mass., issued a statement Friday saying Michels and Sanders acted on their own, without authority from Stardent or its board of directors. The statement said because Stardent is not named in the suit, the company would have no comment on the legal action. But the statement said Stardent and Kubota remained fully committed to their partnership. ``Our relationship has been and continues to be excellent and has worked to the advantage of both of our companies,'' Poduska said.

DOC.HEAD: Losses at Insurance Group Will Reduce Profit
LaserPhoto CX5
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. said Friday that heavy insurance claims after California's recent fires contributed to losses at its Allstate Insurance Group, leading Sears to expect a steep drop in second-quarter income. A weak earnings performance by the Sears Merchandise Group also held back companywide profitability. Sears estimated that its profit from continuing operations will slump 41 percent to 65 cents a share in the three months ended June 30 from $1.11 a share of net income in 1989's second quarter. Stock of the Chicago-based parent of the nation's largest retailer sagged 37{ cents to $34.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Sears is scheduled to release its second-quarter results in the week of July 23. Last year's second quarter included a gain of $54.9 million from the sale of the commercial division of the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group. Excluding earnings from those discontinued operations, Sears earned 95 cents a share, or $391.2 million, in the second quarter of 1989. Edward A. Brennan, Sears' chairman and chief executive officer, noted that unexpectedly high catastrophe-related losses in its Allstate Insurance Group will contribute to the quarterly profit deterioration. Payments on claims resulting from the fires that ravaged parts of California took a heavy toll on Allstate. Profits in the Sears Merchandise Group for the second quarter are expected to be lower than last year, Brennan said. ``We continue to expect a solid performance for the second half of the year based on our outlook for continued moderate growth in the economy,'' he said in a news release. The projection of losses in Sears' insurance operation came as somewhat of a surprise because it had been expected that Allstate would show increased earnings from last year, said Monroe H. Greenstein, a Bear Stearns & Co. analyst. Earnings at Allstate suffered in 1989 on account of Hurricane Hugo, the California earthquake, floods in the South and freezes in the Southeast and the Southwest. ``This year they are getting the fire around Santa Barbara, Calif.,'' Greenstein said. ``It (catastrophe-related losses) almost sounds Biblical in nature.'' Greenstein said Sears' failure to implement substantial rate increases also has hurt Allstate. He attributes the company's reluctance to raise rates to the political climate. A number of states, including California, have had movements to roll back insurance rates, which critics contend are inordinately high. The reduced earnings at Sears' retailing division are due largely to the depressed durable goods sector. Prolonged economic weakness has made consumers conservative in buying expensive, long-lasting merchandise, such as home appliances. Particularly hard hit has been Sears' home improvement business, analysts say. For instance, sales of air conditioners, accounting for an estimated 25 percent of the retailer's home improvement business at this time of year, were sluggish in the spring due to unseasonably cool weather. One bright spot for Sears is Brand Central, the retailer's first attempt at selling national brands other than its own. Greenstein said sales of appliances and consumer electronics at Brand Central are up 7 percent to 8 percent, against a 4 percent industry-wide decline in sales. Sears has been struggling to maintain its market share. Last year it restructured and switched to an ``everyday low prices'' policy to attract customers.

DOC.HEAD: Good News on Inflation, Retail Sales
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in June as declines in food and energy costs helped offset large increases for autos and tobacco, the government said Friday. Meanwhile, retail sales rebounded a strong 0.5 percent, the first gain in five months. The overall increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for goods one stop short of the retail level was about what economists expected. However, prices for items outside the volatile food and energy sectors jumped 0.6 percent in June, the steepest increase in a year and about double the anticipated rise. Analysts consider this so-called ``core'' rate a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. Normally, a combination of stronger consumer spending and an upturn in core inflation would spook financial markets by discouraging any hope that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates. This time, the market shrugged off the statistical reports. Both stock and bond prices rose in the hours after the reports' release. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks touched 3,000 briefly before falling back to 2,980.20, still a record high. Traders' optimism was buoyed by Thursday's comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who suggested the central bank was on the verge of cutting interest rates slightly to offset the economic effects of an apparent pullback in bank lending to businesses. According to traders, the central bank followed through on Friday by pushing down the federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans, from 8\ percent to 8 percent. The rate cut comes at an opportune time for the Bush administration, which needs continued economic growth to bolster Republican chances in the November congressional elections. Most analysts agree a rate cut would be needed to counter the economic effects of any White House-Congress budget agreement including higher taxes and reduced spending. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater welcomed Greenspan's comments and said the administration was pleased with the reports on retail sales and wholesale prices. ``This is excellent news for the economy,'' he said. ``Declining inflation should continue to relieve pressure on interest rates.'' The 0.2 percent increase in wholesale prices followed a moderate gain of 0.3 percent in May and declines in April and March. Last month's increase brought wholesale inflation for the first half of 1990 to an annual rate of 3.7 percent, compared with 4.8 percent for all of 1989. Prices rose 3.2 percent for tobacco and 2.3 percent for cars. They were also up for women's clothing, furniture, jewelry, newspapers and over-the-counter drugs. Tobacco prices are now 13.9 percent higher than a year ago. Automobile costs are rebounding as dealers scale back buyer-incentive programs. Economist David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm, attributed the higher tobacco prices to chances in federal price supports and taxes and to a crop shortfall. Wyss said about half of the 0.6 percent rise in core inflation can be attributed to autos and tobacco. ``In general, it's neutral data,'' he said. ``Most of what we're seeing is just a swing in food and energy prices. ... We think the inflation rate is going to remain essentially stable.'' Energy prices, which skyrocketed 13.7 percent in January because of a severe cold snap, have declined every month since. They were down 0.9 percent in June after dropping 1 percent in May. Fuel oil prices fell 10.5 percent. Gasoline costs were down 1.3 percent. Natural gas prices rose 0.4 percent. Food prices headed lower for the third time in four months. They dropped 0.4 percent last month after a 0.6 percent increase in May. Prices rose for fresh fruit and vegetables, eggs and dairy products, but fell sharply for pasta, pork, chicken and fish. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 117.9 in June. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 would have cost $117.90 last month, up from $114.30 a year earlier. At earlier stages of the production process, prices fell 0.2 percent for intermediate goods and 2.4 percent for crude goods. Excluding food and energy, intermediate-goods prices edged 0.1 percent lower and crude-goods costs fell 0.6 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. In Friday's other report, the Commerce Department said retail sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $147.82 billion last month, up $784 million from the May sales level. The June increase came after a string of three consecutive declines, something that had not happened since 1981, during the last recession. Sales had been flat in February.

DOC.HEAD: Trustee: Eastern Losses To Shrink; Airline May Show 1991 Operating Profit
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines expects to cut its losses considerably during 1990, but will still show a shortfall of more than $330 million, trustee Martin Shugrue said Friday. Shugrue told a news conference the airline's performance continues to improve and Eastern is seeing an increase in ridership that should help the carrier show an operating profit in 1991. Eastern lost $852.3 million last year. Shugrue said the company would suffer a substantial loss tis year, but it would be much lower than in 1989. Asked if the deficit would be more than $330 million, Shugrue replied that it would. He said he hoped the airline could emerge from bankruptcy court protection by the end of this year, but no target date has been set for Eastern to file a plan of reorganization with the court. Shugrue was appointed in April by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland to take control of the airline from Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., the former Texas Air Corp. The trustee said the airline would announce during the summer a marketing plan aimed at grabbing a greater share of the crucial business travel market and ultimately improving Eastern's profitability. ``We expect to be in a good position to be capitalizing on the business frequent flyer'' during the fall, Shugrue said. Shugrue spoke with reporters after meeting with Eastern's unsecured creditors committee and presenting to them the company's latest business plan. The trustee spoke in broad generalities about the plan and offered few numbers. He said it presented a bleaker picture of the airline's finances for the next few months, but a healthier outlook for 1991. He said the creditors reacted positively to the plan, were expected to continue funding the airline's short-term losses and were not planning to call for a liquidation of the company. The trustee said Eastern was still holding ``substantial talks'' with Northwest Airlines about a possible purchase of the carrier. Shugrue said he had met with Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi, and ``we are setting up follow-on meetings to see if there is an opportunity for Northwest and Eastern to do something together.'' Other parties have expressed interest in Eastern, but the carrier is not currently holding substantive negotiations with anyone other than Northwest, Shugrue said. At times Shugrue boomed the airline's accomplishments as he does in Eastern television commercials. The carrier's current ad campaign shows Shugrue giving Eastern employees a pep talk and confidently predicting a turnaround. Shugrue boasted several times of the airline's on-time performance, said service was improving and that passengers increasingly are satisfied. But at other times, his frustration was apparent, especially as he discussed Eastern's labor problems. Shugrue said the airline continues to negotiate with its pilots union, which is threatening a strike if their contract dispute is not resolved. Eastern and the pilots are in a 30-day cooling off period after having declared their contract dispute at an impasse. ``It's hard for me to understand how pilots who are not working can go on strike,'' Shugrue said. Most of Eastern's pilots, who struck in March 1989 in sympathy with the airline's Machinists union but later called off their walkout, have not been recalled to work. Eastern hired replacements for the pilots and machinists and flight attendants who also walked out. Eastern filed for bankruptcy reorganization after the walkouts began. Since then, the company has sold some of its routes, including its Northeastern shuttle, and has pared away other assets in order to reposition itself as a smaller carrier.

DOC.HEAD: American Pilots Replace Negotiators in 10-Month-Long Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: The union representing American Airlines' 8,500 pilots has replaced its contract negotiators, signalling a possible hardening of positions as the two sides work for a new agreement. The Allied Pilots Association suspended talks with the airline last month while its board of directors convened to discuss dissatisfaction with the pace of the 10-month-old negotiations. A large faction of pilots reportedly was unhappy with the failure of the negotiating team to win an agreement to abandon, or reduce the impact of, the so-called ``B-scale'' pay rate for less senior pilots. At a board meeting in Chicago Wednesday and Thursday, the five-member negotiating team was replaced and expanded to six members, according to a message on the union's information line. Union officials remained in Chicago Friday and did not return telephone calls to The Associated Press seeking comment. The replacement is expected to lengthen the negotiations, which have been conducted with a federal mediator since February. ``We will negotiate with whomever the union authorizes us to negotiate with,'' said Al Becker, spokesman for Fort Worth-based American. ``The real issue is to get back to the negotiating table as quickly as possible so that we can work in the spirit of compromise toward reaching a new agreement.'' The contract became eligible for amendments on Dec. 31, although negotiations on a new pact began in October. After a stalemate in January, federal mediator Harry Bickford was brought in and meetings were held almost daily beginning in February until last month's recess. Under the National Railway Act, the contract does not expire, and a strike cannot be called unless the mediator declares talks to be at an impasse and a 30-day ``cooling off'' period has elapsed. The old contract provides for a ``B-scale'' wage rate for pilots hired after 1983, amounting to about half the starting pay for pilots already on the payroll. With about half of the pilots now covered by the lower wage rates, there is growing pressure to bring them closer to their colleagues at American and elsewhere. American Chairman Bob Crandall has warned that a huge increase for pilots would threaten the airline's aggressive expansion program. He argues that the airline's growth provides opportunities for a more rapid rise to a captain's rank and pay. Also at issue is American's insistence the pilots contribute more to their health care program.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market forged ahead again Friday in buying that carried the Dow Jones industrial average briefly to the 3,000 level for the first time. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed at 2,980.20, for a net gain of 10.40 points on the day and a 75.25-point rise for the week. The average, the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices, crossed 3,000 just after 1:30 p.m., then turned back a few moments later. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 954 up, 619 down and 460 unchanged. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, surprised traders in the stock and bond markets Thursday by signaling a shift in the emphasis of the Fed's credit policy. He said the central bank, which has been concentrating on fighting inflation, is now ready to ease credit conditions if necessary. Interest rates fell sharply on the news. Analysts said Greenspan's comments also went a long way toward relieving recession worries on Wall Street. Enthusiasm over that prospect persisted Friday, apparently not much affected by statistical reports from the government for June showing a 0.5 percent rise in retail sales and a 0.2 percent increase in the producer price index of finished goods. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines rose 1 to 121; General Electric 1{ to 74~; Merck | to 88~, and Eli Lilly 1 to 88{. Motel 6 L.P. was one of the volume leaders among NYSE issues, up 2} at 22. Accor S.A. of France announced an agreement late Thursday to acquire Motel 6 for $22.50 per partnership unit. Castle & Cooke jumped 6 to 36{. The company said it has received inquiries from several parties interested in buying its Dole operations. Computer Associates International dropped ] to 9~ on top of a 6\-point slide Thursday, when the company said it would probably show declines in both revenues and earnings for the second quarter. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 215.60 million shares, against 211.51 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 259.30 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $17.45 billion, or 0.50 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.01 to 200.33. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 2.01 to 435.38, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.87 at 367.31. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.27 to 468.44. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 363.99, up 1.76.

DOC.HEAD: Execs Say Motel 6 Buyers Plan to Double Expansion Rate
DOC.TEXT: The French company paying $1.3 billion for Motel 6 plans to accelerate the budget lodging chain's expansion rate and open the brand's first outlets in Canada and Mexico, executives said Friday. Lodging industry analysts, meanwhile, said the price that Accor SA of Paris agreed to pay for the chain reflects both the appealing growth prospects for economy lodging and Accor's view of the best path into the U.S. market. Burland East, an analyst for the investment firm Bateman Eichler Hill Richards & Co., said the economy segment of the lodging market has been growing three to four times as fast as the industry overall. He said Accor, which already owns 850 hotels in 60 countries, is getting an experienced management team and a popular brand name along with the 554 Motel 6 properties in the United States. ``They are getting a lot more than they could build on their own,'' he said. Accor announced Thursday that it had agreed to pay $22.50 per unit for the more than 55 million Motel 6 LP partnership units. It said its tender offer would begin no later than Wednesday and that it had the financing for the deal. The investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which owns more than 50 percent of the partnerhip's equity, said it would tender its stake under terms of the deal. The firm expects its partners will realize a healthy 38 percent annualized profit on their initial investment in Motel 6 in 1985. The Kohlberg Kravis group bought Motel 6 for $880 million, including $125 million in equity and $756 million in debt, and sold a minority interest to the public in 1986. Accor said it intended to keep the current management team that had overseen the $700 million invested in the motel chain over the past five years. Motel 6 used the money to add 180 motels to the chain, install telephones and color televisions in all 63,765 rooms, start a national reservation system and launch a folksy advertising campaign that extolled its low prices and clean rooms and poked fun at the amenities more expensive motels provide. ``You can't get a hot facial mudpack at Motel 6 like you can at those fancy joints,'' humorist Tom Bodett said in one Motel 6 radio ad. The strategy enabled Motel 6 to attract more business travelers and boost its occupancy rate to about 77 percent this year compared with an industry average of about 63 percent. But guests still pay less than at many other hotels _ currently an average of about $27 a night. Georges LeMener, director of the office of chairman for Accor, said in an interview Friday that his company has no plans to change Motel 6's approach. He said Accor plans to invest about $225 million a year in each of the next five years to expand the chain. Motel 6 Chief Executive Joseph McCarthy said the chain has been adding about 35 to 40 motels a year, but said that with Accor's backing the expansion program will be twice as rapid. ``We will try to get 75 a year, and we will begin expanding into Mexico and Canada as well,'' he said. Motel 6 has no motels in either country now. McCarthy said the chain would also stick with its approach of owning and operating all of its properties, unlike some other chains that award franchises to independent operators. ``When you are in the economy business, all you have to sell is price and consistency of product,'' McCarthy said. ``You can't do that unless you own and operate the product.''

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Insurance Department Investigating Fail
DOC.TEXT: The Arizona Department of Insurance is investigating James Fail for failing to disclose that he had been barred from working in the insurance business in Alabama for alleged securities fraud. Fail, who also has been accused of misleading regulators in Texas and Florida, already is the subject of a U.S. Senate panel probe related to his purchase of 15 failed Texas savings and loans. He was indicted in Alabama in 1976 for securities fraud, but those charges were dropped after he signed an order barring him from conducting future business in that state. Arizona insurance investigators said Thursday that they are attempting to determine why Fail denied having been subjected to any court order regarding violation of securities in his annual disclosure certificate filed in 1988. However, Arizona insurance officials apparently were aware of his background when Fail acquired Farm & Home Insurance Co. in 1979. Records show that the indictment and order were revealed during a hearing on the acquisition. False information provided to the department can result in the revocation of an operating license, officials said. Fail reportedly was in Europe this week and could not be reached for comment. His Washington attorney, Stanley Brand, issued a statement earlier this week saying Fail has complied with federal regulations. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, the head of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, has launched an investigation to determine whether federal regulators adequately probed Fail's background before they allowed him to take over the failed Texas savings and loans. Metzenbaum contends Fail should be disqualified from a 1988 agreement with the government because of his background. Fail was allowed to buy the thrifts with only $1,000 of his own money and $70 million in loans. In return, he was promised $1.85 billion in federal aid. Arizona insurance officials suspended Farm & Home's license last week, and the company was placed under the department's supervision. The company has more than 125,000 life insurance policies nationwide, 6,700 of them in Arizona, according to insurance officials.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Surge But Some Advise Caution
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rallied strongly Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange but some analysts wondered whether the market will sustain the gains, which were prompted in part by a decline in interest rates. On other commodity markets, silver also rose; petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans advanced; and livestock and meat futures rose. Gold futures settled $6.20 to $6.70 higher in New York with the contract for delivery in August at $365.70 a troy ounce, its highest settlement price since May 31. Silver futures ended 1.7 cents to 1.8 cents higher with July at $4.908 a troy ounce. The rally in gold extended a $3.90 gain posted Thursday after Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan indicated the Fed, which has been concentrating on fighting inflation, is now ready to ease credit conditions if necessary. Interest rates fell sharply on the news and gold, which is considered an investment hedge against inflation, rose. Analysts agreed that lower rates could create a friendlier atmosphere for gold. Craig Sloane, a metals analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said gold's upward reversal on Thursday following the Greenspan comments could be construed as a sign that the market has ended its recent decline. But Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said other conditions did not appear right for gold to sustain the rally. Sharp gains in the stock market, such as occurred on Thursday and Friday, are typically bearish for gold, he said. Silver's relatively weak gains on Friday also contradicted notions of a major bull move beginning in the precious metals, he said. Savaiko said the two-day runup in gold prices might simply have represented book-squaring ahead of Friday's expiration of the August gold options contract on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and bottom-picking by investors when gold fell to near $350 an ounce on Thursday. ``We had a lot of bargain hunting at those lower levels,'' he said. ``The question is, are they willing to hold it here at these levels?'' Crude oil futures ended mixed in a volatile session dominated by bullish news of OPEC unity on measures to contain crude production and boost prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 10 cents lower to 17 cents higher with August at $18.36 a barrel; heating oil was .78 cent to 1.85 cents higher with August at 54.21 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .43 cent to 1.38 cents higher with August at 61.95 cents a pound. Crop futures prices ended higher on the Chicago Board of Trade following an Agriculture Department report in which the agency lowered its projections for winter wheat production and corn and soybean stockpiles. But gains were limited by expectations that beneficial weather will continue as the corn crop enters its critical pollination phase. The National Weather Service predicts more good growing weather on the way. In reports released after the close, the agency predicted normal to above-normal temperatures and precipitation in the Midwest for the period July 19-23, and normal temperatures and rainfall for the next 30 days. Wheat futures settled 4 cents lower to 2 cents higher with July at $3.07 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 2{ cents higher with July at $2.79 a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent higher with July at $1.25{ a bushel; soybeans were 6 cents lower to 3 cents higher with July at $6.10\ a bushel. Cattle futures rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash markets. Pre-weekend position-squaring lifted hog futures. Live cattle were .35 cent to .67 cent higher with August at 75.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to 1.15 cents higher with August at 87.42 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to 1 cent higher with July at 61.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.12 cents lower to .90 cent higher with July at 49.35 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds Rise on Signs of Fed Easing
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices posted another broad advance Friday as the Federal Reserve took steps that traders viewed as evidence the central bank was adopting a more generous credit policy. A day after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan hinted that the Fed was poised to relax credit conditions because loans were becoming harder to get, the central bank injected reserves into the banking system at midday. The move led to a quarter-point decline in a key lending rate. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond climbed 17-32 point, or about $5.25 per $1,000 face amount, after rising $7.50 on Thursday. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, dropped to 8.45 percent from 8.49 percent late Thursday. Bond prices moved higher from the start of trading on expectations that interest rates would be moving lower in the wake of Greenspan's comments Thursday to the Senate Banking Committee. Prices moved even higher in late morning trading when the Fed added reserves to the banking system by arranging short-term purchases of securities. With more funds available to banks, the federal funds rate, which is the interest that banks charge each other for short-term loans, slipped to 8 percent from 8\ percent late Thursday. The funds rate had fluctuated near 8\ percent for months. ``The Fed eased,'' said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, who heads a consulting firm that bears her name. ``They are putting Greenspan's `may' and `might' into action.'' The federal funds rate is often seen as an indicator of which way other lending rates are headed. But Mrs. Ramirez said she does not expect a quick decline in consumer lending rates to follow the move in the federal funds rate because many banks are facing profit pressures due to shaky real estate and Third World loans. Meanwhile, government reports on wholesale inflation and retail sales went virtually ignored by bond traders. The Commerce Department said declining food and energy prices helped hold the Producer Price Index to a modest 0.2 percent in June. However, costs of other items were up more sharply than in recent months. A separate report showed retail sales rose 0.5 percent in June, snapping a string of five straight monthly declines. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose 7-32 point, intermediate maturities gained between \ point and 13-32 point and long-term issues advanced as much as 17-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.10 to 1,161.96. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 7-32 point to 92]. The average yield to maturity slipped to 7.42 percent from 7.44 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.83 percent as the discount dropped 8 basis points to 7.59 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.89 percent as the discount declined 7 basis points to 7.50 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.89 percent as the discount fell 7 basis points to 7.36 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up in Roller Coaster Session, Gold Continues Climb
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose domestically Friday in volatile, heavy trading after falling in Europe. Meanwhile, gold prices surged, continuing a climb that began Thursday after the value of the dollar fell. Gold typically rises when the dollar falls because it becomes a more attractive investment alternative and becomse relatively cheaper to investors using foreign currencies. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $364.40, up $6.30 an ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $364.00 an ounce for gold, up $6.30 from Thursday. Warren Myers, a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Co. who follows the gold market, said trading was influenced Friday by ``a carryover effect from yesterday.'' On Thursday, gold rose sharply after the dollar fell on comments by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan that the Fed might consider easing interest rates. Lower rates reduce the returns on dollar-denominated investments, thus sending investors to other currencies. Other traders said gold prices were boosted Friday by the expiration of the August contract on gold options on the New York Comex. Gold rose even more sharply overseas, partly due to Greenspan's comments and in part because of at least two waves of Middle East buying, traders said. Gold jumped to a late bid of $364.55 a troy ounce in London from $351.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold traded at $364.20 per ounce, up from $351.60 late Thursday. Earlier, gold rose $5.56 an ounce to close at $359.94 in Hong Kong. The dollar, meanwhile, changed direction from Thursday, rising in domestic trading in a seesaw session. Traders said the dollar rose after the government reported that wholesale prices climbed a modest 0.2 percent in June, indicating low inflation. But the dollar fell after the Federal Reserve arranged weekend repurchase agreements, the agency's method for adding funds to the banking system. That has the effect of lowering interest rates, and some traders interpreted it as a a follow-through to Greenspan's remarks. The federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, moved lower, a negative for the dollar. But the dollar soon climbed, partly because European traders were buying dollars to shore up their positions as the markets there closed, said Francoise Soares-Kemp, a vice president in the foreign exchange department of Credit Suisse in New York. The dollar also was boosted by traders who believed the currency had reached its floor and were buying dollars to cover short trading positions, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to its lowest level since Feb. 22, closing at 147.42 yen, down 1.48 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar firmed to 147.50 yen. In New York, one dollar bought 148.15 yen, up from 147.40 yen late Thursday. In London, the British pound traded at $1.8020, up from $1.7995 late Thursday. But in New York, a pound cost $1.8005, cheaper than $1.8130 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.6510 German marks, up from 1.6355; 1.4025 Swiss francs, up from 1.3895; 5.5390 French francs, up from 5.4910; 1,208.75 Italian lire, up from 1,198.75; and 1.1579 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15675. Other dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Thursday included: 1.6430 West German marks, down from 1.6525; 1.3925 Swiss francs, down from 1.4020; 5.5115 French francs, down from 5.5460; 1.8520 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8625; 1,203.25 Italian lire, down from 1,211.00, and 1.1576 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1580. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $4.93 a troy ounce, up from $4.86 late Thursday. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery finished at $4.908 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $4.890.

DOC.HEAD: American, Iberia Settle Differences Over Reservation System
DOC.TEXT: Iberia Airlines will return to the Sabre computer reservations systems Monday under an agreement announced Friday between the Spanish carrier and American Airlines Inc. Iberia, the national airline of Spain, had withdrawn from American's Sabre system June 11 in a dispute over the way its flights were listed in the computer. The agreement, reached after a meeting between the two carriers last week, will modify the way U.S. travel agents view schedules to improve international carriers' chances of showing up on Sabre's computer screens. The two carriers also agreed to abide by the code of conduct of Common Market countries, which requires that prices charged be reasonably related to cost. The agreement is subject to approval by the U.S. Department of Transportation. Sabre, which enables travel agents and others to make reservations on and sell tickets on all airlines, is the nation's largest computer reservation system.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Probing Insider Trading in Contel-GTE Takeover
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs, bgng The SEC...with 4 new grafs of details, SEC comment; Picks up 6th graf, Tony Hamilton... SUBs 10th graf pvs, According to... to CLARIFY. Picks up 11th graf, The buyout...
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged Friday that unknown parties engaged in insider trading in Contel Corp. securities in the days before the telephone company agreed to a $6 billion takeover by GTE Corp. The SEC, in a federal lawsuit filed in New York, claimed that ``individuals or entities whose identities are as yet unknown to the commission'' bought Contel common stock or call options contracts while in possession of confidential corporate information. According to the SEC, the unidentified defendants stood to make more than $1 million in alleged illegal profits on investments of $205,125. The SEC obtained court orders freezing U.S. brokerage accounts used to conduct the alleged illegal trading and preventing the destruction or alteration of documents. Joseph Goldstein, associate director of the SEC's Enforcement Division, said it was not unusual for the agency to act against alleged wrongdoers without knowing their identity. ``We know what the accounts are but we don't know who the persons are. What we don't know is who the ultimate customer is,'' he said. Goldstein declined to say how the SEC became aware of the alleged illegal activity. Court papers said the defendants bought Contel call options on the American Stock Exchange and Contel common stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Tony Hamilton, a GTE spokesman in Stamford, Conn., said the company was aware of the investigation and intended to cooperate fully. On Thursday, Atlanta-based Contel, the nation's third-largest independent telephone company, said it would accept the takeover offer by No. 1 GTE Corp. GTE is to exchange 1.27 shares of its common stock for each of Contel's 159 million shares. That values Contel stock at about $37.47 a share based on Friday's closing GTE price of $29.50 a share. Contel shares jumped $7.25 to close at $35.25 a share Thursday following news of the buyout agreement. According to the SEC complaint, on Tuesday and Wednesday the unidentified defendants bought or caused the purchase of Contel securities through New York accounts maintained by financial institutions in Switzerland and Germany. The buyout negotiations were intended to be confidential, although numerous people from both companies, their investment bankers and attorneys firms were privy to the discussions. ``Contel and GTE closely monitored the volume of trading in Contel and GTE securities to determine whether possible leaks were occurring,'' the SEC said, although it did not indicate whether the companies tipped it off to the suspicious trading. The suit said such trading took place in both Contel common stock and call options. Call options _ which are the right to buy 100 shares of a stock at a set price before a certain date _ are used by investors speculating that a stock's price is about to rise sharply. The lawsuit said trading in Contel call options on the American Stock Exchange for for July 5, 6, and 9 was 329 contracts. On July 10 and 11 _ the two days before the deal was announced _ 6,546 contracts were traded. The lawsuit said the defendants accounted for about 3,292 of the contracts purchased on July 10 and 11. The trading of Contel common stock involved 10,000 shares bought on July 11 by a German bank. The lawsuit said the buying price was not known. The merger is subject to the approval of both companies' stockholders, and by regulatory agencies. It would result in the country's second-largest cellular phone system operator after McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., and the nation's largest local-exchange telephone company.

DOC.HEAD: P&G Closing 83-Year-Old Plant in Neighborhood Named for Ivory Soap
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. said Thursday it was closing an 83-year-old plant on Staten Island in a neighborhood that takes its name from the company's famed Ivory soap. P&G said operations from the plant, which employs about 425 people in the island's Port Ivory section, would be relocated to other factories around the country. The plant is to be shut down over the next 19 months. In addition to Ivory soap, the Port Ivory factory makes Coast soap bars, Bold and Solo liquid laundry detergent, Mr. Clean and Top Job surface cleaners, and Citrus Hill orange juice. P&G spokeswoman Louise Hughes said employment at the factory, which was built in 1907, peaked around 1980 with 1,400 workers. Mrs. Hughes said the decision to close the factory was made late last week after the company decided it would be more economical to consolidate production at other plants. `We wanted to consolidate that manufacturing to fewer locations,'' she said. ``It made more economic sense to phase out manufacturing at Port Ivory than it did at other locations.'' The company so far has decided to move the Citrus Hill production to its Chicopee, Mass., plant and the Mr. Clean and Top Job production to its St. Louis plant, she said. Some employees will be transferred to other plants starting this fall. A Procter & Gamble plant in Avenel, N.J., that now employs 75 people making perfume for company products will be expanded and some of the Staten Island workers may wind up there, officials said. ``This is just another example of how the high cost of doing business in this city and state is driving industry away,'' Staten Island Borough President Guy Molinari said in a statement. Staten Island is part of New York City. The Port Ivory plant was one of the first opened by Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble.

The Dow Jones industrial average shattered the 3,000 level for the first time but settled below that lofty mark. Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange whooped when the nation's best-known stock barometer, which has flirted with 3,000 for nearly two months, finally crossed that level on Friday and stayed there for about six minutes before sellers pushed it lower. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed at 2,980.20, for a net gain of 10.40 points on the day and a 75.25-point rise for the week.

Wholesale prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in June as declines in food and energy costs helped offset large increases for autos and tobacco, the government said. The overall increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for goods one stop short of the retail level was about what economists expected. In a separate report on Friday, the government also said retail sales rebounded a strong 0.5 percent, the first gain in five months.

Sales of North American-made cars and trucks rose 2.5 percent in early July over a year earlier, prolonging a rebound that began in late June, the automakers said. Friday's reports marked the second consecutive increase for the automakers, which report their sales in 10-day periods. The back-to-back advances support expectations earlier this year that a sluggish early-1990 sales rate would pick up this summer.

The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged that unknown parties engaged in insider trading in Contel Corp. securities in the days before the telephone company agreed to a $6 billion takeover by GTE Corp. The SEC, in a federal lawsuit filed Friday in New York, alleged that ``individuals or entities whose identities are as yet unknown to the commission'' bought Contel common stock or call options contracts while in possession of confidential corporate information. According to the SEC, the unidentified defendants stood to make more than $1 million in alleged illegal profits on investments of $205,125.

A federal jury ordered Ford Motor Co. to pay nearly $5.2 million to an inventor for infringing his patents for intermittent windshield wipers. Ford said Friday it was pleased with the amount it must pay Robert W. Kearns, 63, of Gaithersburg, Md., who had sought $141 million. Kearns was not present for the verdict but his attorney and son said they were disappointed and expected him to appeal.

Sears, Roebuck and Co. said heavy insurance claims after California's recent fires contributed to losses at its Allstate Insurance Group, leading Sears to expect a steep drop in second-quarter income. A weak earnings performance by the Sears Merchandise Group also held back companywide profitability. Sears estimated Friday that its profit from continuing operations will slump 41 percent to 65 cents a share in the three months ended June 30 from $1.11 a share of net income in 1989's second quarter.

Eastern Airlines expects to cut losses considerably during 1990, but will still show a shortfall of more than $330 million, trustee Martin Shugrue said. Shugrue told a news conference Friday the airline's performance continues to improve and Eastern is seeing an increase in ridership that should help the carrier show an operating profit in 1991. Eastern lost $852.3 million last year. Shugrue said the company would suffer a substantial loss tis year, but it would be much lower than in 1989.

Widely available computers, printers and copiers have become so sophisticated that U.S. currency and other securities can be counterfeited with remarkable accuracy, the Treasury Department said. ``The introduction of such equipment makes counterfeiting a crime of opportunity for anyone with access to such equipment,'' Carl V. D'Alessandro, assistant director of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, told the Senate Banking Committee on Friday.

Scores of East German factories agreed to raise wages and preserve jobs for 350,000 metalworkers but said the labor contract may actually speed the collapse of some plants. The one-year pact was reached Friday after a series of strikes by hundreds of thousands of metalworkers around Berlin. It is the biggest labor agreement since East Germany became a free market on July 1.

Bond prices posted another broad advance Friday on signs the Federal Reserve had adopted a more generous credit policy. The dollar rose in volatile, heavy domesrtic trading after falling in Europe. Gold futures prices rallied strongly; silver also rose; petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans advanced; and livestock and meat futures rose.
